fields.headline: Hooligan ringleader jailed
fields.standfirst: Football violence: special report
fields.trailText: An English fan described as one of the ringleaders behind the trouble in Brussels last Friday was yesterday given a one-year jail sentence, half of it suspended, for assaulting a policeman.
fields.body:
An English fan described as one of the ringleaders behind the trouble in Brussels last Friday was yesterday given a one-year jail sentence, half of it suspended, for assaulting a policeman.

Mark Forrester, 33, a married man from Birmingham with a two-year-old child, was convicted of inciting violence and attacking police.

Brussels police described him as a ringleader who had egged others on. He maintained he had been drawn into the throng of rioting fans by accident.

Forrester, who has a record of similar offences in Britain, has lodged an appeal which, court officials said, would be heard in two weeks.

In the first case brought under Belgium's fast-track system to deal with hooligans, the judge Regine Claeys said there was "very clear and very detailed" evidence that Forrester instigated clashes on the eve of last Saturday's group match between England and Germany in Charleroi.

"You were very provocative and very aggressive," the judge told him. "Hooliganism will not be tolerated in whatever form."

Brussels police detained 450 fans after the riots, which left a trail of destruction in the centre of Brussels. Most were deported but 34 are still in jail.

Uefa's chief executive Gerhard Aigner justified the threat to kick England out of Euro 2000, saying: "We have specific problems with English fans, who come ticketless and drink a lot. To see 5,000 or 10,000 of them come without tickets is unacceptable. There are more cases like this among English fans than among others and that's a fact."

Asked about violence by other fans, particularly Turks, he said : "They are often residents in the host countries. That's different. If they are not provoked, they are not necessarily violent."

Yugoslavia have been fined £49,000 for the behaviour of their fans during and after the defeat by Spain on Wednesday. Two fans tried to assault the referee Gilles Veissière after he sent off Yugoslavia's Slavisa Jokanovic, who has been banned for tomorrow's quarter-final against Holland. Later Veissière was struck above an eye by a coin thrown from the crowd.

 England and Turkey have been excluded from the Euro 2000 fair play ranking because of the bad behaviour of their supporters.

fields.headline: From the top
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: In his speech to Birmingham businessmen, Digby Jones stated the popular prejudice in favour of old-economy businesses. This is the belief that companies manufacturing or selling products are fundamentally different from new economy information and services businesses and thus worthy of special treatment.
fields.body:
Recently there was a curious public spat between Digby Jones, the new director-general of the CBI, and Sir Stanley Kalms, chairman of Dixons.

Kalms was offended by a speech from Digby Jones which criticised the statement that Freeserve, "employing only 100 people and making a loss of £1m-£1.5m a year" was valued by the stock market at more than Midlands based Wolseley, the plumbers' merchants with annual profits of £300m.

In his speech to Birmingham businessmen Digby Jones was stating the popular prejudice in favour of old-economy businesses. This is the belief that companies manufacturing or selling products are fundamentally different from new economy information and services businesses and thus worthy of special treatment. He also appeared to be getting very confused as to the difference between profit and value. Many people fail to realise that there is very little correlation between the profits a company makes and what a company is worth.

The current profits of a company are the difference between its revenues and expenses. Expenses include production costs but also investments in marketing, brands, research and development. When a company stops growing, profits are boosted by its reduced need to invest. As the great Russian economist Kondratieff explained more than 70 years ago, what look like high profits are actually repayments of capital that are no longer needed by industries that have ceased to grow.

What investors are interested in is value. Value is determined by future profits, not current profits. Companies with high growth poten tial are, by definition, likely to be less profitable because of their need to invest heavily in marketing and development. Entrepreneurial companies with outstanding growth opportunities can easily accept losses in the early years. If they do not invest heavily and quickly they will be rapidly pre-empted by rivals also alert to the emerging opportunities for profits.

If investors believe in the prospects of these entrepreneurial businesses it is easy for them to calculate that their value far exceeds today's profitable old economy businesses. Investors know they are unlikely to get rich investing in Wolseley, but they have seen what happens when you get in early for Nokia, Dell and Cisco.

For west midland businessmen like Digby Jones it is galling to see a company like Rover, with thousands of employees and huge plants, being valued at only £10. But Rover is not alone; many old economy companies - Ford, Daimler-Chrysler, Unilever and P&G, have seen their values slide dramatically.

What these devaluations reflect is real economic change. Old-economy manufacturing is a mature business. There is tremendous excess capacity. It is often done cheaper in Bangladesh than Birmingham. Employment in these industries will not grow. Better options for growth and future profits lie first in new economy manufacturing: electronics, computers, communications equipment, pharmaceuticals and biotechnology. Next it is in services: information technology, finance, education, healthcare and entertainment.

It is better for Birmingham to recognise the future than to seek to preserve the past. We do not want old-economy manufacturing to become the new agriculture, uselessly subsidised to the tune of billions of pounds a year. Like agriculture, traditional manufacturing employs fewer and fewer people and it is not where the country's future prosperity and competitiveness lies.

 Peter Doyle is professor of marketing & strategic management at the University of Warwick Business School.

fields.headline: What you can do
fields.trailText: If you are worried that your endowment policy may not pay off the mortgage, there are a number of things you can do.
fields.body:
If you are worried that your endowment policy may not pay off the mortgage, there are a number of things you can do.

The number one piece of advice from the Financial Services Authority, the chief investment watchdog, is: "Don't make any hasty decisions." It says you should never cash in your policy, or stop making payments, without taking advice. This is because endowments often involve high charges in the early years, and if the policy is only a few years old you will probably end up getting back less than you've spent.

After taking advice, you may consider one or more of the following options:

Do nothing. While the predictions are for lower investment returns in the future, nobody can really be sure what will happen. You may be happy to cross your fingers in the hope that the policy makes the grade,
particularly if your policy only just fails to hit the target using a projection rate of 6%, or if the potential shortfall is fairly small.

Increase your monthly payments into the policy. While this will probably delight your insurer, you may feel this amounts to throwing good money after bad. Also, with some companies it may involve you having to pay extra charges.

Contact your lender and arrange to change part of your mortgage to a repayment loan. This could be a much better option. For example, if your mortgage is £60,000 and the potential endowment shortfall is £10,000, you could rejig the mortgage so that £50,000 continues on an interest-only basis and £10,000 is converted to a repayment loan.

Set up a separate investment that can be used if necessary to meet a shortfall.
One good way of building up a lump sum might be to go for an individual savings account. However, check carefully to see what the charges are. With many stocks and shares Isa providers, the minimum monthly investment is £50 but in a few cases is as low as £25.

If you have a spare lump sum, and your lender allows it, you could make extra capital repayments to your lender to reduce the amount you owe on the mortgage loan. Check for early redemption penalties.

Arrange for the policy term to be extended. "This is not likely to be a good idea if the policy will continue after you have retired, unless you are sure you will still be able to afford the payments," says the FSA.

fields.headline: No headline
fields.trailText: I make no claims of computer wizardry but, despite my technical limitations, I was able to make a £74 saving on motor insurance after about an hour and a half seeking quotes on the internet.
fields.body:
I make no claims of computer wizardry but, despite my technical limitations, I was able to make a £74 saving on motor insurance after about an hour and a half seeking quotes on the internet.

Not only was this a result that should offer encouragement to others hoping to save money in this way, but also I was left with the feeling that had I been prepared to spend longer, there was probably an even greater saving to be made.

The renewal premium offered by the Liverpool Victoria on my ageing and little-used Renault 19 Cabriolet was £487 with a £250 excess. As I had changed insurers last year after shopping around on the phone for the cheapest cover, I expected this still to be reasonably competitive.

Getting telephone quotes is a time-consuming and frustrating business. Each company takes - more or less uniformly - about 10 minutes from answering the phone to providing the quote. With the AA and the Norwich Union this time was increased substantially because the phone is answered by a machine rather than a person.

(If everyone just hung up on hearing recorded messages, businesses would soon be forced to get rid of these ghastly, time-wasting machines).

The three telephone quotes I obtained were all more than my renewal figure, so despite my scepticism, I gave the internet a try. Feeding "motor" "insurance" and "quote" into a search engine threw up a list of sites offering online quotes. In addition I keyed in what I would have expected to be the addresses of a few well-known insurers.

Most of these did send me to the right destination. Surprisingly, www.AA.co.uk did not seem to be recognised at all, though www.theaa.co.uk or www.automobileassocia tion.co.uk. did work.

I restricted my researches to sites that actually offered online quotes, rather than those which just gather up information and then call or email back with a figure.

By and large this was a lot quicker than phoning, the fastest sites providing a figure in less than three minutes. The best were able to work out the make and model of my car from the registration number.

Some were slowed down by refusing to accept a date unless it was entered in exactly the required format, a simply rectified flaw which is overlooked by all too many website designers.

The AA's site took strikingly longer than any of the others, though this was partly a consequence of its useful policy of offering comparative quotes on the basis of different excesses or driver restrictions.

One anomaly I discovered from this - which was confirmed by other companies - is that the quote is actually reduced if the owner's spouse is added to the policy.

Generally speaking, online quotes seemed to be about 15% less than the same companies charged on the phone, though the Norwich Union wanted £34 more on its site.

After getting quotes from nine sites I found Eagle Star's £459 with a £200 excess was the cheapest. Coversure, despite its claim to compare several different policies, was the worst with £766 and a £500 excess. Screentrade, which made a similar claim, was also very disappointing, offering me a Norwich Union policy for more than £200 more than it would have cost me to buy it direct.

However, insurance is a very buoyant market and the fact that a particular company is best for one motorist does not mean that it will be best for everybody. Just how buoyant it is, I discovered before I went to buy the Eagle Star policy the next day. On a hunch I asked for a new quote and fed in identical information. The figure it offered came down from £459 to £413.

After buying insurance at that figure, I repeated the exercise to find it had gone up to £446. If I had had time to go through all the sites every day for a week, I am sure that one of the quotes would have eventually gone down to an even lower figure.

In our article on Euro 2000 bets on page 17 in last week's issue, the websites which bypass conventional bookmakers should have read www.betfair.com and www.flutter.com, not <A HREF="http://www.playfair.com."

fields.headline: Oz accounts can be wizard
fields.standfirst:
Putting your mortgage, salary, savings and credit card into one place can save thousands of pounds, says Patrick Collinson
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Putting your mortgage, salary, savings and credit card into one place can save thousands of pounds, says Patrick Collinson.
fields.body:
Australian-style bank accounts which mix your salary, mortgage, savings and credit card into an all-in-one account to minimise interest payments are set to take off in the UK with banks lining up to launch new products over the next few weeks.

The idea behind all-in-one accounts is that a mortgage effectively becomes a current account. For example, someone with a £60,000 mortgage pays their £1,500 salary cheque into the account, which immediately reduces the mortgage balance to £58,500 and therefore cuts the interest owed. But the bank continues to allow the homeowner to pay their usual bills and expenses out of the account as if it were their current account, as long as the customer does not exceed certain limits.

Savings accounts are also put against the mortgage, so instead of earning at best 3%-4% interest after tax, the person saves 7.75% on loan interest payments. But the savings are not "lost" to the mortgage; customers are still free to withdraw the money at any time.

Yorkshire Bank, which today launches an all-in-one account called Rapid Repay, believes that the typical UK homeowner will save £16,449 by switching to the new-style accounts, and will pay off their mortgage seven years early.

In the land of Skippy the kangaroo (where Yorkshire Bank's parent National Australia Bank is based) all-in-one bank accounts are used by around one in four people, but in the UK they have been slow to take off. Virgin and First Active have offered the accounts for several years but are coy about revealing the number of customers.

But more recently Woolwich's Open Plan account has brought the concept to a wider audience, and in July the new phone and internet bank Intelligent Finance will take the concept further. It hopes to by-pass people's concerns about putting all their eggs in one basket by running a new system which will keep savings and mortgage accounts separate, but "sweep" the accounts every night to minimise the total interest paid.

One drawback to the accounts is that the mortgage rate charged is rarely competitive, even if the total amount of interest paid is reduced. For example, Yorkshire Bank will be charging a 7.74% rate on its Rapid Repay loan - the same as the Halifax standard rate but much higher than many of the sub-5.5% discount mortgage deals currently available on the market. If you are a mortgage holder who switches regularly to gain the best deal, the all-in-one accounts will hold few attractions.

However, some of the all-in-one accounts do offer discounts; First Active cuts its standard 7.74% rate to 4.49% for the first six months. It also has a base rate tracker which will keep the rate at no more than 1.25% above base rate (currently 6%) for the lifetime of the loan. Another drawback to the accounts is that because they require your entire monthly salary cheque to be paid in, it means closing your previous bank account and switching to the new one. That also spells the inevitable hassle and delays of switching direct debits and standing orders to the new bank.

To counter the hassle factor and force banks not to drag their heels on transferring accounts, Intelligent Finance this week promised that it will name and shame those which take the longest to enact a transfer. IF chief executive Jim Spowart says: "We promise to expose any bank that appears to be obstructing the process of customers switching their current account by publishing the time it takes for customers to move from each bank."

It is employing 400 people dedicated to helping people transfer their accounts, and will pay a £10 bonus to cover the cost of interest and inconvenience during the changeover. It says the process should be speeded up by CATS, the new current account transfer scheme being piloted by a number of banks.

But what if the worst heel-dragger turns out to be Halifax, the parent company of IF? Mr Spowart promises to name and shame them too. Watch this space.

webTitle: Buy to let looks a hot property again

fields.headline: Buy to let looks a hot property again
fields.standfirst:
Some experts believe that demand for homes to rent is growing and the time is right to become a landlord. Rupert Jones reports
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Some experts believe that demand for homes to rent is growing and the time is right to become a landlord. Rupert Jones reports.
fields.body:
Growing numbers of people have been turning to property in order to accumulate a decent retirement nest-egg, and are spurning the traditional route of saving in a pension plan.

With a personal pension or money purchase scheme, your cash is out of your reach until you retire, and then you are forced to buy an annuity, which at current dismal rates could leave you with far less than you expected.

Owning property means you are in control of your destiny: you can sell it to access the cash whenever you wish, and in addition to having a long-term investment that is likely to supply you with a regular monthly income, you've got an asset you can pass on to your children.

However, four interest rate rises since last September combined with an over-supply of properties available for rent in some areas have led some commentators to declare that the buy-to-let bubble has burst. Rents dipped while owners' costs increased, leaving some amateur landlords more than a little disillusioned.

But now the tide could be turning back in favour of buying properties to rent out, according to two recent surveys. They point to a number of factors that suggest a growth in demand for rented property.

First, all the evidence from mortgage lenders indicates that house price inflation is now slowing following the impressive rises notched up in many parts of London and the south-east - the region that accounts for 50% of all investment properties. Growing numbers of would-be first-time buyers have been priced out of the market, and so are having to continue renting.

At the same time, the strong property price growth has prompted some landlords to abandon the rental market and put their properties up for sale. Added to this, interest rates now appear to have stabilised, and some economists reckon the next move could be down, which of course means lower mortgage costs for property owners.

"The increasing costs of becoming a homeowner are stoking demand for rental property. At the same time rental property is being removed from the market as some buy-to-let investors sell up in order to take their profits following the dramatic rises in the values of London residential property," says Stephen Ludlow at www.ludlowthompson.com, an online sales and lettings agent.

He points out that the average starting salary for new graduates in London is still just £16,200 and has lagged behind the growth in the capital's house prices; the average student is graduating in debt to the tune of close to £6,000; and private rented accommodation still only makes up 5% of the capital's housing stock. fields.headline: Baroque breakdance
fields.standfirst: Montalvo-Hervieu's new work is eye-boggling
fields.trailText: Le Jardin Io Io Ito Ito is at the Barbican, London EC2 (020-7638 8891), tonight.
fields.body:
Stumbling in on a performance by French dance company Montalvo-Hervieu, you could be forgiven for thinking you are under the influence of some very strong psychedelic drug. Humans turn into flamingos, a flamenco trio segues into Queen's We Will Rock You. The effect is like channel surfing through 100 TV stations, each showing a different style of dance.

Breakdance collides with ballet in a scratch-edit of movement that makes the unlikeliest of connections seem plausible: maybe Vivaldi was a hip hop renegade master after all. That may sound gimmicky, and Montalvo-Hervieu's style is unashamedly crowd-pleasing; indeed, the accessible, engaging troupe has become one of France's most successful exports. But there is a method in the madness of the company's latest work, Le Jardin Io Io Ito Ito. It is a "happy eulogy to cosmopolitanism," according to choreographer José Montalvo, a man much given to lyrical flights of fancy about his work and inspired by the dance festivals of his childhood. "An amazing multi-colour tribe participated. At night, in the heart of drunkenness and the hide-and-seek of desire, the dancing and singing transformed everyone. Each individual became virtuosos for one moment."

Taking that as his starting point, Montalvo has assembled a line-up of 18 performers who are all expert in their varied fields. His trick is to throw acrobats and baroque stylists on stage together and exploit the flying sparks. It could turn out an unholy mess. But such is the company's exuberance that Montalvo succeeds in rolling back the years using dance as a metaphor for the innocence of youth. Most remarkable are the connections between apparently disparate forms. Using the kind of call-and-response interplay more readily associated with old soul records, dancers from contrasting styles bounce moves off each other as proof that dance is an international language.

Le Jardin Io Io Ito Ito's title is drawn from the curious collages of surrealist master Max Ernst, and his sense of deranged imagery is at play in the film sequences that are intercut with the dancers. Animals on screen compete in a curious posing contest with their human partners; balancing acts combine live and filmed performers. The result is a skewed take on the world that can throw in Wiseguys dance anthem Ooh La La La, US wrestling star Scotty Too Kool Taylor's trademark "worm" move (or maybe I was just seeing things) and a breakdancing Christmas tree, without pausing for breath. As Montalvo puts it: "It's a poetry of juxtaposition at the service of movement, desire, fantasy, dreams and childhood."

 Le Jardin Io Io Ito Ito is at the Barbican, London EC2 (020-7638 8891), tonight.

webTitle: There's an old mill in their dream of home

fields.headline: There's an old mill in their dream of home
fields.standfirst:
Living in a former barn, chapel or bank may be very appealing, but getting the mortgage has its hurdles, says Elizabeth Langton
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Living in a former barn, chapel or bank may be very appealing, but getting the mortgage has its hurdles, says Elizabeth Langton.
fields.body:
Buyers who dream of owning a converted chapel, barn, water tower or other unusual home have always struggled to convince banks and building societies to share their vision.

But given the current movement to renovate existing buildings before building new homes a handful of lenders will lend to those willing to give old buildings a new lease of life.

This week the Norwich and Peterborough building society launched what it calls a "brown" mortgage, designed to encourage the renovation and restoration of buildings. The society's general manager Stephen Penlington says demand for mortgages to finance conversions has grown dramatically in the past five years. The National Housebuilding Council says conversions are taking place at a rate of 16,000 per year.

He attributes the rise in demand partly to geography - the society is based in East Anglia, an area stuffed with windmills, chapels and barns. But the rise in house prices in many parts of the UK means many people can no longer afford to buy an interesting home unless they convert if themselves.

Around the country thousands of former churches, commercial and agricultural buildings have come on to the market. There is considerable romantic allure in an echoing schoolhouse or Victorian water tower. In the battle of TV detectives, BBC's Jonathan Creek lives in a windmill.

Many are sold at auctions or through estate agents, others privately. The Church Commissioners keep a list of redundant churches, some of which are made into homes while others go on to have a new life as commercial premises. The commissioners test local opinion before a church is made redundant and have the final say about future use.

While the announcement that Barclays Bank wants to close 171 branches was greeted with dismay by some, others saw it as an opportunity to obtain a prime property in a rural area. A spokeswoman from Donaldsons, one agent charged with disposing of the branches, says some of the buildings are situated in very pretty villages in Lincolnshire, Suffolk and Norfolk. Most are disposed of through auctions, so interested buyers need to keep their eyes peeled to spot "for sale" signs.

But these conversions can be deeply unpopular locally and councils are unlikely to grant planning permission for change of use where locals have opposed the closure.

Lenders can be equally hard to persuade. Most are wary of mortgages for self-build or conversions because applicants are usually asking for the money before the building is habitable, says Ray Boulger of mortgage brokers John Charcol.

Applicants are more likely to get a loan from one of the older building societies than new-style mortgage banks, he says. However, they would need a chunky deposit. For a limited period homebuyers can borrow up to 85% of the value or purchase price of the land and property to be renovated and, when work is completed, up to 95% of the value of the completed property.

After the offer period the loan to value will revert to 80%, says the Norwich and Peterborough building society. The mortgage comes with a free energy rating survey.

The Ecology Building Society also has a flexible approach. It will lend up to 80% of the valuation to buy land or to buy a solid but derelict property and release further funds as the value of the property is increased through renovation work subject to a maximum of 80% loan to value at any one time.

Whether or not lenders are happy to fund a purchase will depend largely on the valuation, says Mr Boulger. "If the valuer likes converted buildings he or she will tell the lender that there is a reasonable demand for the property if it needed to be re-sold." Mr Penlington is enthusiastic about self-build and conversion projects. "I'd like to follow in the footsteps of our treasurer and build my own house," he says.

If he did, he'd learn from the experiences of his customers, he adds. "While most borrowers are realistic about how much money they need, many say they underestimated the amount of time it would take and how much the role of project manager takes over their life."

Buyers without the time to undertake such a mammoth task have plenty of ready-made conversions to choose from. Boltby Chapel, a four-bedroom home in Thirsk, Yorkshire, is on the market through Strutt and Parker for £275,000.

 Norwich and Peterborough 01733-372372; Ecology Building Society 01535-635933; Details of redundant churches are available from the Redundant Churches Division, Church Commissioners, 1 Millbank, London SW1P 3JZ.

fields.headline: When accidents happen
fields.standfirst:
Around 10,000 children are permanently disabled each year so it may be worth considering insurance, writes Jill Papworth
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Around 10,000 children are permanently disabled each year so it may be worth considering insurance, writes Jill Papworth.
fields.body:
The thought of one's child being involved in an accident is probably the worst thing any parent can contemplate. But ignoring the possibility means that many parents leave themselves open to financial hardship should the untoward happen.

Accidents in the home, on the road, at school and while playing sports affect 2.5m children a year. Of these, more than 100,000 are admitted to hospital accident and emergency departments requiring long-term care. Some 10,000 are permanently disabled, according to Carol Sherriff, director of the Child Accident Prevention Trust, whose campaign to reduce the risks of such accidents has been highlighted during the current Child Safety Week.

On top of the emotional trauma should a child suffer a serious accident, parents may have to cope with high costs, including loss of income through taking time off work to visit them in hospital or nurse them, plus the expense of special care or adapting the home to cater for their needs. This is where insurance comes in.

Providers of such policies are surprisingly few, with Ace Insurance in West Sussex underwriting the majority of those available. While the core benefit of each policy is 24-hour, worldwide cover paying a tax-free lump sum if a child is permanently disabled as a result of an accident, the policies on offer vary considerably in the extra benefits they offer and the premiums they charge.

The most straightforward policy is Class Cover from Holmwood, the schools division of HSBC Insurance Brokers. Underwritten by Ace, this offers two levels of cover. Plan A pays up to £100,000 permanent disability benefit for £20.74 a year per child, while Plan B pays up to £200,000 for a premium of £30.56. Premiums are doubled for two or more children.

If a child is hospitalised for three or more days after an accident, it also pays hospital benefit of £30 per day plus a further £30 per day if a child has to convalesce.

Parents or guardians can get a slightly cheaper premium on Class Cover if they buy a policy over the internet through the www.eduvia.com website. Marketed as ChildCover, though providing ex actly the same benefits as Class Cover's Plan A, it costs £19.90 per child and Save the Children receives £1 for every policy sold.

Ace's own marketed policy First Cover Plus pays out supplementary benefits for certain non-permanent, but more frequent child injuries. At £54 a year for one child and £90 for two or more children, it provides up to £150,000 permanent disability cover plus £60 a night if your child is hospitalised for three or more days and up to four weeks' home nursing help during convalescence.

Extras include up to £300 paid for broken bones, £500 for the loss of an adult tooth and £500 a month for individual tuition if your child is hospitalised or convalescing at home for at least 30 days. For new policies taken out before the end of July, Ace is offering a reduction in premiums to £45 and £75 respectively. Higher or lower levels of cover are available.

Also underwritten by Ace is the Child Accident Plan from American Express. Its top level, Extra Cover, has an annual premium of £57.12 per child, for permanent disability cover of up to £100,000, but policies are only available to cardholders.

The only main competitor to these Ace-underwritten policies is Boots Accident Insurance for children, underwritten by Royal SunAlliance. At annual premiums of £30 for one child and £60 for two or more, this provides a maximum of £150,000.

Like First Cover Plus, the Boots policy also offers supplementary benefits for more common injuries, such as £50 for a broken bone requiring hospital treatment, up to £2,000 for damage to adult teeth and up to £2,000 for facial scarring. But, unlike its competitors, it offers no hospital cash benefits.

One way of reducing premium costs for school-age children is for a significant number of parents to get together, typically via the parent teacher association of a school, and organise a block policy for their children.

Holmwood offers a group scheme version of Class Cover, minus the hospital cash benefit, paying a maximum of £125,000 permanent disability benefit at just £6.30 per pupil per year.

 Class Cover, 0800-318-312; ChildCover, www.eduvia.com; First Cover Plus, 0800-444-233; American Express Children's Accident Plan, 0800-700707; Boots Accident Insurance for Children 0845-840-1111.

webTitle: Spotlight on way ahead for UK's new economy

fields.headline: Spotlight on way ahead for UK's new economy
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Birkbeck College, University of London, is hosting a one-day workshop headed UK.Com, Prospects and Policies for the New Economy, on July 4. Sessions include Building the Knowledge-Driven Economy, e-commerce @ work and what's new about the new economy.
fields.body:
Birkbeck College, University of London, is hosting a one-day workshop headed UK.Com, Prospects and Policies for the New Economy, on July 4. Sessions include Building the Knowledge-Driven Economy, e-commerce @ work and what's new about the new economy.

The opportunities that the internet, digital TV and third-generation mobile phones can offer have been researched by the Retail e-commerce Task Force. Its report, published by the Department of Trade and Industry, will be presented by Task Force chairman Chris Townsend. And the Co-Operative Party is launching its study of "e-mutualism or the tragedy of the dot.commons". Booking details from conference organiser Steve Warby, tel: 020-7631-6743.

There are serious profits to be made through building a successful transnational pan-European business modelled on US or Japanese multinationals. The prizes include economies of scale, the ability to exploit brands, technology and market share. But what is a truly pan-european company? Manchester Business School and management consultant Collinson Grant are collaborating in a review of how companies in Europe are structured and managed. The programme will seek views from more than 900 of the largest businesses using a postal survey and face-to-face interviews. The results will help determine the defining features of an integrated European business. Collinson Grant has published a preliminary overview of how the current developments in the markets, preferences of consumers, advances in technology and the impact of the euro are driving change in European businesses. For a free copy of the initial report Building Pan-European Businesses call Jennifer Whittle at Collinson Grant, tel: 0161-793-9028.

Ever wondered what it would be like to take a simulated helicopter flight to a North Sea oil rig, build a website, programme a robot, or design stained glass? You can do all this and more at The Skills Show between July 5-9, at the NEC Birmingham. The show encourages young people to see a variety of trades in action from fish frying, plumbing, and hairdressing to robotics. Tickets £6 from the NEC box office, tel: 0121-780-4133.

fields.headline: Should you be a boomerang?
fields.standfirst:
The busy jobs market is encouraging employers to tempt former staff back, while some workers ask to return. But is this ever a good idea? Sandra Deeble reports
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: The busy jobs market is encouraging employers to tempt former staff back, while some workers ask to return. But is this ever a good idea? Sandra Deeble reports
fields.body:
We've all had the old cliches scrawled on leaving cards: "Keep in touch". Or maybe "Come back and see us". Then it's presentation time: a few words, the jokes, and the leaving party. You're on your way: pastures new; onwards and upwards. You'll never look back.

But your old boss might. The booming jobs market is encouraging employers into offering lucrative deals to lure back workers who may have left only months before.

"It's becoming increasingly common, particularly in a tight labour market. Employers are welcoming people back with open arms," says Imogen Daniels, an adviser for the Institute of Personnel and Development. There's even a new term for them: "boomerang" employees. They are the people who leave an organisation, maybe to go to a competitor, then realise that it's not quite what they'd hoped for.

Six months or a year later, either they ask if there's anything going at their old place or their original employer asks them to come back, sometimes offering a hard-to-turn-down incentive: a giddy combination of more responsibility, more respect, more excitement and more money.

"In the past, employers were concerned with loyalty. There was a long marriage between employers and employees. Today, things are more fluid," says Ms Daniels. "But when interviewing boomerang employees, it's important to find out why they left. Yet when they do come back, they may be more loyal. Their networks may still be active. They can slot back in."

But not all employers or recruitment agents agree. Jo Ousten of Jo Ousten & Co, who has spent 18 years helping people to find career paths that feel right for them, says: "As an employer, I would never take somebody back. People can come back with baggage.

"There are subtle negatives to the idea. You might want to come back to something you know - but it's not what you know, it's moved on." Some companies have a policy of not re-employing, explains Ms Ousten, for the reason that there are too many imponderables.

She makes the distinction between a job and a career: if someone goes back to a former employer to do a specific task, there may be huge advantages. If it's a management position, she believes the person may be stuck in the past.

Yet people do it. "We see it happening more now than before," says Georgina Stewart, marketing director at Freshfields, a London law firm. One such "boomerang" is Geoff Peters, associate at Freshfields. After qualifying at Freshfields and spending three years there, he went to work "in-house" at Shell. He lasted only six months. He then went to a smaller law firm for another six months. How did people react when he walked back in?

"People were curious to find out what it's like out there," he says. "It brings home to people the fact that perhaps the grass isn't always greener."

And if you do come back, won't your former colleagues want to know what went wrong? According to Dr Rob Briner, senior lecturer in organisational psychology in Birkbeck College, it depends on the way you tell it. "Careers are just stories that people tell each other, linked together in a way that makes sense to them."

And it depends very much on the industry, and the level of gossip. "In academia, if you screw up, everybody would know," he says.

Yet whatever your story, believes Dr Briner, it won't ever top the one your employer will tell. "Look, people love it here - they can't stay away!"

But why go back? If it doesn't work out in the new place, so what? You've already made one move, why not two? Or is going back a way of getting what you wanted in the first place?

"The 80s trend for de-layering has increased the incentive to leave a company, go to another and come back in a higher position," explains Richard Reeves, director of futures at the Industrial Society. "In organisations today, the traditional ladder has been taken away. You can feel stuck. The only way to go up is to get out and come back."

For when it comes to money, leaving an organisation is a sure-fire way of being offered more. "It's ironic, but your stock with a company goes up the day you leave," says Mr Reeves.

Not surprisingly, given that many people spend more time at work than with their partners, the relationship parallels are obvious. If you're head-hunted, or if you accept another job, your current employer might suddenly shower you with riches and wild promises to encourage you to stay.

Just as, if someone suddenly starts showing an interest in your partner, you're less inclined to slump in front of the television and more likely to reach for the cookery books and rustle up a light aphrodisiac.

Knowledge, particularly if gained in a competitor's lair, is also something that can make "boomerangs" extremely attractive to former employers. An insight into how an arch-rival approaches a new business pitch can be worth wooing.

Yet it's not always the case. "The knowledge you've taken away in the first place might have been so valuable that the company might feel betrayed," says Dr Briner. "What is more, people can think: 'Hold on, if you're telling us about someone else, what did you tell them about us?' " he adds.

And if you pursue the analogy of lovers reunited after a taste of what else is out there, new skills learned in another camp are definitely best kept to yourself. For Rachel, a lawyer, it's clear cut: "Jobs are like relationships: never go back."

They call me the prodigal son

John Parkin worked at advertising agency HHCL & Partners for two years, then left to go to Partners BDDH. After six months, he returned to HHCL and has been there for two years - he is now a creative director.

"I've been called the prodigal son for two years. I think that when you're working somewhere good, you can start taking some of the good things for granted. You need a break sometimes. When you start at a new place, there's a buzz. You're meeting new people and your learning curve is steep.

"When I first went to Partners BDDH I enjoyed it a lot but then I started missing certain things. At HHCL we work in teams differently; it's very collaborative. Going somewhere else made me see this place very clearly.

"If it doesn't work out in a new place and you suddenly look at the old place through rose-tinted glasses, that's not the way to do it. I think that if the things that make you leave are things that are fundamentally wrong with a company, forgetting about them and then going back is something you do at your peril. I suppose the danger is that you fall back into the same responses and attitudes. I've been very conscious of not doing that.

"When anyone leaves HHCL, you have what's known as an 'exit chat'. I had mine quite late; I'd already started working at the other agency. They asked me: 'What could we have done and what could we do in the future?' One of the things I asked for was to come back on a four-day week.

"You get all that stuff about 'you can't do that; you can't go backwards'. I was very aware of it. But if you do it with integrity and you think you can grow, you shouldn't worry too much about what other people think. On balance, you've got to do what's best for you. For me, it was right to come back."

It was like a school reunion

Kate Valentine went back to her former employer - a communications consultancy - after having left five years before to work in another consultancy. "I was flattered to be asked back. It was to do a job that promised much greater scope than the one I had been doing before.

"But when I went back, they still saw me as the same person. It felt like regressing. Going back to a company is the wrong thing to do, even if it is in a very senior position. All the things you loved about a company aren't there any more and the things you didn't like are still there: they seem worse. When you start a new job you need enthusiasm and freshness. If you go back, you don't have that.

"As soon as you step through the door, it all comes flooding back: the politics, even the smell of the office. People come up to you and say 'do you remember that conference we went to?' It's a bit like a school reunion. It sends shivers down your spine.

"But I don't regret going back. It made me realise what I really want to do." Ms Valentine left after six weeks and is now happy working in a new company.

fields.headline: Now we are old
fields.standfirst: The Kirov's bright, technically brilliant young dancers make  Judith Mackrell feel her age
fields.trailText: The Kirov is at the Royal Opera House, London WC2 (020-7304 4000), till June 27 and returns from July 31 to August 19.
fields.body:
As an artform, dance exists only at the moment of performance, but it is lovingly embalmed in the memories of its public. In the life of all fans there comes a point when they start to believe that dancers don't (and can't) perform the way they used to. This is a position of infuriating smugness to others. Young dancers rage at being judged by the ghosts of the past, while novice dance-goers are made to feel they are seeing only a dim echo of what was granted their elders.

The Kirov, as the world's greatest living ballet museum, inspires this generational oneupmanship all the time. When the company visited Britain in 1988 after 18 years' absence, older fans were quick to compare it with remembered glory days. Now those of us who became besotted with the company 12 years ago are showing our age by fretting over certain changes, especially among the company's youngest ballerinas.

The 24-year-old Diana Vishneva, for instance, is a dancer of exhilarating speed and attack who has developed a style that looks far more international than previous generations. Her power and personality illuminate comedy ballets such as Don Quixote and the 20th-century repertory (she has been outstanding this season in Balanchine's Rubies), but in the more classical context of Sleeping Beauty her qualities can jar, especially when compared with the very traditional Aurora danced by Zhanna Ayupova. At 33, Ayupova is one of the few remaining principals trained in what has become old-school Kirov.

This is a style more sculptural than linear, in which movements are embellished by a contrapuntal activity of head, eyes, shoulders and hands. Its beauties can be breathtakingly flukey, because they combine so many nuances of style and expression. It is also highly sociable, because each move connects spatially and dramatically to everything else on stage. When Ayupova dances, the focus of her gestures and her glance is always directed outside her: she isn't isolated within her own technical prowess.

By contrast, Uliana Lopatkina, 26, is a one-woman phenomenon whose boneless fluency and eerily extended line have become the ideal of her generation. Lopatkina moves as if her body were tuned by a far more sophisticated technology than the rest of us. But her exquisitely long lines are achieved at a cost. She is a dancer who is all limbs and feet, and her torso, which should be a radiant and responsive focus of energy, is a blank. There are dramatic and musical dead points in her style as a consequence. So while her Nikiya in Monday's Bayadère was a marvel of supple control, it felt monochrome compared with performances I remember from Altynai Asylmuratova (who dances the role tonight). At 39, Asylmuratova may be in decline as far as technique goes, but she can still work the musical and dramatic alchemy by which familiar, even hokey, classical roles are made profound.

A new ballerina coming through the ranks is 21-year-old Veronika Part, who closely resembles Lopatkina in the near-frictionless action of her legs and arms (although she lacks the absolute control that produces Lopatkina's peculiar grace). In Sleeping Beauty, Part has been a Lilac Fairy of some charm, but as Odette/Odile she moves in an introverted trance. This new breed of superballerinas have honed and glossed their techniques to awesome extremes, but at the expense of personality and imagination.

This season has given fewer opportunities to the Kirov's men - most of them have gone to Igor Zelensky, a freelance who returns to the Kirov, his home company, whenever his schedule allows. Zelensky started the season looking jetlagged and distracted, and when he danced Swan Lake with Part their pas de deux looked under-rehearsed. On Monday though, as Solor to Lopatkina's Nikiya, he was dancing as well as I've seen him. The humming power of his pirouettes and the arrowy length of his jumps were imposing in themselves, but they also sang with the music.

Among the soloists, standards have looked uneven. The best are still beautiful enough to make other companies weep but there's a tendency among the less gifted to force their effects so that their dancing looks choppy. The corps de ballet, though, remain the Kirov's treasure. Physically they look as if they've all come off the same assembly line (barely a deviant calf muscle in sight), yet the unison with which they move is not blindly drilled but a harmony of style and tradition. The other enduring treat is the Kirov's mime artist, Vladimir Ponomarev, performing a sublimely testy King Florestan, a madly infatuated priest and a rampant Shah. With his Rasputin glare and his baroque gift for melodrama, it is impossible to imagine the Kirov's 19th-century repertory without him.

 The Kirov is at the Royal Opera House, London WC2 (020-7304 4000), till June 27 and returns from July 31 to August 19.

fields.headline: Smells like teen spirit
fields.standfirst:
Kelis
Shepherd's Bush Theatre, London
****
fields.trailText: Shepherd's Bush Theatre, London and Glastonbury Festival tomorrow.
fields.body:
Best known for her hit Caught Out There, in which she bawls out an unfaithful boyfriend with the refrain, "I hate you right now," 20-year-old Harlem singer Kelis is putting female rage back on the agenda. Recorded with Virginia Beach production team the Neptunes, her debut album Kaleidoscope is a skilful mix dubbed "cyberpunk R&B". At her first UK show, Kelis does not disappoint. She strides on through dry ice in 70s-style thrift-store gear and lurid sunglasses, with her errant Afro dyed vanilla and blue. Though ably supported by a predominantly female band, including three backing singers with attitude, and a very cool bassist, Kelis gets off to a creaky start.

She is a graduate of New York's High School for the Performing Arts, and there is a touch of Kids from Fame about her stage show, with the glitter, space-age glam, rapping, and very shouty vocals. Subtler songs from the album, like the soothing teen talk ballad Get Along With You and the "conscious" Ghetto Children are partly swallowed up in the noisy mix. Things get better, though, particularly when Kelis leaves the stage and reappears in black leather pants and silver halterneck. Now she means business. All the girls join her for a startlingly rich rendition of Born to Be Wild, performed with minimal percussion and bass. There's also the sinuous, bass-heavy Good Stuff, and Caught Out There, which inevitably turns into a shout-fest with the eager audience.

Despite the funky R&B, she seems most comfortable as a rock chick, a hybrid of Courtney Love and Tina Turner. "Here we are now! Entertain us!" she belts out with conviction, as if she has been rocking out all her life. Kelis exudes a raw power: it may need finessing, but she has plenty of time for that.

fields.headline: Surf your way to savings
fields.standfirst:
It is possible to lower the cost of your motor insurance if you brave the internet for an hour or two, finds web beginner Richard Colbey
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: It is possible to lower the cost of your motor insurance if you brave the internet for an hour or two, finds web beginner Richard Colbey.
fields.body:
I make no claims of computer wizardry but, despite my technical limitations, I was able to make a £74 saving on motor insurance after about an hour and a half seeking quotes on the internet.

Not only was this a result that should offer encouragement to others hoping to save money in this way, but also I was left with the feeling that had I been prepared to spend longer, there was probably an even greater saving to be made.

The renewal premium offered by the Liverpool Victoria on my ageing and little-used Renault 19 Cabriolet was £487 with a £250 excess. As I had changed insurers last year after shopping around on the phone for the cheapest cover, I expected this still to be reasonably competitive.

Getting telephone quotes is a time-consuming and frustrating business. Each company takes - more or less uniformly - about 10 minutes from answering the phone to providing the quote. With the AA and the Norwich Union this time was increased substantially because the phone is answered by a machine rather than a person.

(If everyone just hung up on hearing recorded messages, businesses would soon be forced to get rid of these ghastly, time-wasting machines).

The three telephone quotes I obtained were all more than my renewal figure, so despite my scepticism, I gave the internet a try. Feeding "motor" "insurance" and "quote" into a search engine threw up a list of sites offering online quotes. In addition I keyed in what I would have expected to be the addresses of a few well-known insurers. Most of these did send me to the right destination.

I restricted my researches to sites that actually offered online quotes, rather than those which just gather up information and then call or email back with a figure.

By and large this was a lot quicker than phoning, the fastest sites providing a figure in less than three minutes. The best were able to work out the make and model of my car from the registration number.

Some were slowed down by refusing to accept a date unless it was entered in exactly the required format, a simply rectified flaw which is overlooked by all too many website designers.

The AA's site took strikingly longer than any of the others, though this was partly a consequence of its useful policy of offering comparative quotes on the basis of different excesses or driver restrictions.

One anomaly I discovered from this - which was confirmed by other companies - is that the quote is actually reduced if the owner's spouse is added to the policy.

Generally speaking, online quotes seemed to be about 15% less than the same companies charged on the phone, though the Norwich Union wanted £34 more on its site.

After getting quotes from nine sites I found Eagle Star's £459 with a £200 excess was the cheapest. Coversure, despite its claim to compare several different policies, was the worst with £766 and a £500 excess. Screentrade, which made a similar claim, was also very disappointing, offering me a Norwich Union policy for more than £200 more than it would have cost me to buy it direct.

However, insurance is a very buoyant market and the fact that a particular company is best for one motorist does not mean that it will be best for everybody. Just how buoyant it is, I discovered before I went to buy the Eagle Star policy the next day. On a hunch I asked for a new quote and fed in identical information. The figure it offered came down from £459 to £413.

After buying insurance at that figure, I repeated the exercise to find it had gone up to £446. If I had had time to go through all the sites every day for a week, I am sure that one of the quotes would have eventually gone down to an even lower figure.

www.theinsurancecentre.co.uk, £549

fields.headline: Invest and deal online
fields.standfirst:
A personal finance website launched by Virgin yesterday is offering cut-price Isas, unit trusts and share services. Jessica McCallin reports
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: A personal finance website launched by Virgin yesterday is offering cut-price Isas, unit trusts and share services. Jessica McCallin reports.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson is hoping to gain a chunk of the online investment and sharedealing market and further his ambition to make Virgin the ultimate internet retailer with the launch of personal finance website www.virginmoney.com.

By offering cheap investments and sharedealing through the site, the company hopes to gain an edge over its competitors in what is fast becoming an over-crowded market.

Customers are guaranteed that all Isas and unit trusts available through the site can be bought with a zero initial charge. The downside of this deal is that only funds offered by Fidelity, Gartmore, Invesco, M&G, Norwich Union and Family Assurance have agreed to drop the initial charge and only their funds can be bought through the site. So if you had your heart set on a fund from a different provider, this one's not for you.

Virgin says the average initial charge levied by the providers on its site is 3.92% for Isas and 4.04% for unit trusts, so a customer investing £7,000 in an Isa which grows by 7% a year would save more than £500 over 10 years.

Customers are also being promised cheap online sharedealing through the website's association with Sharepeople.

With no annual account charges and a flat fee of £14.95 per deal regardless of the size of the transaction, Virgin claims the deal is one of the best on the market.

It certainly seems better than this week's online sharedealing launch from Abbey National. With a commission structure of £16 for deals up to £1,000, £25 for deals up to £2,500 and £39.50 for those of more than £2,500, Abbey National's offer is significantly more expensive than many others.

But frequent traders might be better off going to www.idealing.com. This charges an annual fee of £20 but thereafter individual trades only cost £10. Similarly, www.h-l.co.uk charges an annual fee of £50 but just £9.95 per trade.

Live newsfeeds from Reuters and www.thestreet.co.uk have been included in the Virgin package to help you decide what to buy.

And if you want to compare and contrast different products, a link to Money£acts should prove useful. In addition, the site's background information on how to sort out your finances is pitched at three different levels of financial understanding, promising, amongst other things, an easy to understand beginner's guide to investing.

Also ripe for the picking are mortgages from Alliance & Leicester, Bank of Scotland, Bristol & West, the Woolwich, Virgin One and the Lambeth, Skipton and West Bromwich building societies.

The mortgages are not subject to any special discounts, but Virgin promises that they have been vetted to fit in with its standards of customer service and transparency.

Virgin says it will add other types of financial products as well as schemes from a wider range of providers as and when it finds them suitable. In the immediate future, however, customers can look forward to the launch of a chatroom on the site.

The Virgin launch is hot on the heals of Financial Services Authority chairman Howard Davies saying online companies are seriously underestimating demand. Egg and Cahoot are cited as two of the culprits. Only time will tell if Virgin falls into the same trap.

Free info service for UK savers

 Investors wanting professional information free can now click on to www.comdirect.co.uk. And it is cross-referenced, making it easy to move from prices to news to historical data and dealing. Comdirect is the UK arm of successful German stockbroking operation of the same name. It charges £12.50 for trades under £5,000, £14.50 above. There is a £25 a year fee so the more you deal, the lower the cost. Buying and selling the new index-tracking iShares is free within a self-select Isa.

 Interactive Investor International has opened a funds supermarket at www.iii.co.uk/fundsnow with access to 20 fund managers and over 300 funds. Currently, customers will have to download application forms but iii is promising "straight through processing to providers" later this year.

 Newcastle Building Society has come up with NewcastleNet Savings, which claims to beat all rivals on £10,000-plus accounts with a 7.1% rate. But at the minimum £5,000, the account is out-gunned by rivals such as Bristol & West, first-e and Nationwide e-savings.

 Legal & General is going into business with website totallyjewish.com. The initial deal will provide brochureware information on the insurer's protection and investment products. Later this year, customers will be able to access policies and unit trusts online.

 Hire vehicle group Holiday Cars Direct has revamped its website to give online quotes and a £5 discount on online bookings. The site, holidaycarsdirect.com, offers motors at a range of locations worldwide from a range of operators and promises all-inclusive prices. It quotes a Peugeot 106 in Alicante at £76 a week.

 The Nursing Home Fees Agency, which funds its free advice service from commission it earns selling financial products, has re-engineered its site on www.nhfa.co.uk to give better information on longer-term care. It covers state assistance, advice on how to meet care costs and preserve capital, legal matters plus the latest on the long-term care front.

webTitle: A good time to shop around

fields.headline: A good time to shop around
fields.standfirst:
As Halifax absorbs Bank One's customers to add to its 1.2m cardholders Patrick Collinson seeks out the best deals now available on plastic
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: As Halifax absorbs Bank One's customers to add to its 1.2m cardholders Patrick Collinson seeks out the best deals now available on plastic.
fields.body:
Halifax snapped up Bank One's 200,000 credit card customers this week to add to its own 1.2m cardholders in a bid to become a bigger player in the market.

But with rates at both companies poor in comparison with rivals, now may be a good time for their customers to shop around for a better deal.

Halifax's Visa card charges users 18.9% on purchases and 20.6% on cash advances, while Bank One's standard card charges 18% and 18.6% respectively. But neither bank's customers enjoy a particularly competitive rate.

A large number of card issuers offer better rates than either Halifax or Bank One. Apart from internet-only Cahoot's 0.0% rate, which is only available to the first 25,000 customers to log on, there are a growing number of cards which have a standard charge rate of 10-13%, led by Northern Rock and Egg. Even Halifax's own internet and phone bank subsidiary, Intelligent Finance, which launches next month, will easily beat its parent with a rate which will be 10.8%.

A similar picture emerges with gold cards, which usually require the holder to have a minimum income of £20,000. Halifax's rate is better, at 16.9%, but still significantly worse than the best gold card, offered by Smile at 12.9%.

One City analyst, commenting on the £50m takeover of Bank One, said that Halifax has until now relied on "inertia" selling. More suprising is that Bank One has managed to build up 200,000 customers since its launch 18 months ago despite being far from the cheapest in the market.

One reason is that Bank One has focused on "affinity" marketing, producing specialist cards for different communities of people, where a club or group receives benefits from the card issuer every time the card is used. Bank One has deals with Cardiff City, Bristol City and Manchester City football clubs and the Wimbledon Lawn Tennis Championship. These cards all offer identical rates to the core Bank One card, suggesting that although the cardholders are not being ripped off, their loyalty to club or association nonetheless comes at a price.

This autumn the Bank One name will disappear and cardholders will see a new identity. But the two card brands will remain distinct and Halifax insists there will be no merger.

Halifax says its strategy is to aggressively increase market share in the credit card market, so customers of the enlarged group may benefit if the company makes its rates more competitive to attract new customers. When asked if Halifax/Bank One will aim to beat the best rates now on offer, a spokesman would only say: "Watch this space."

Meanwhile, Egg this week moved to consolidate its market-leading position with a new offer to anyone wanting to transfer a card balance to the internet-only issuer. From this week Egg is offering the UK's lowest rate of 2.5 APR for six months to customers who transfer their card balances to the Egg card. After six months the rate reverts to Egg's standard 10.9 rate.

Egg chief executive Mike Harris says: "We revolutionised the market with the launch of our card in September and by March had issued 390,000 cards. It offers enduring good value because we give clear indications of what our pricing intentions are, often giving guarantees on our products."

One drawback, however, is that the Egg card is only available to applicants over the internet at www.egg.com and the company charges £2 every time you telephone them for information already available on the website, £2 for paper statements and £2 if you make payments by anything other than direct debit.

One cloud looming over the flood of cut-rate credit card offers is that there are signs that consumers are again bingeing on debt to an extent not seen since the 80s. Borrowing on credit cards rose by £490m in May, almost three times the rise seen in April and the biggest since the British Bankers' Association's records began in 1986.

There have been four interest rate rises since September 1 last year, but many credit card rates have actually fallen over the same period. Tesco Visa card had cut its interest rate three times since May 1999, and in one month alone received 250,000 applications.

webTitle: Shopping around can boost  size of your final pot

fields.headline: Shopping around can boost  size of your final pot
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Despite annuity rates at record lows, there are lots of ways to improve your pension income by shopping around. When your pension plan matures, usually at age 65, the pension company will offer you an annuity based on how much you have saved.
fields.body:
Despite annuity rates at record lows, there are lots of ways to improve your pension income by shopping around. When your pension plan matures, usually at age 65, the pension company will offer you an annuity based on how much you have saved.

Astonishingly, 75% of people take this first offer, ignoring the fact that they can shop around from one company to the next. For example, just because you saved in a Norwich Union pension plan, you don't have to take their annuity offer - you can go to Prudential, Standard Life or any of the many other companies in the market to see what is on offer.

The shopping around route is called the "open market option". The simplest way to exercise this is by contacting one of the handful of specialist brokers who will search the market for the best deal. The two biggest are Annuity Direct and Annuity Bureau.

The difference between the best and worst company at any one time can be 25-30%, so a couple of phone calls could see your pension income go up by a third. Even between the top companies, rates vary as much as 10%, as life offices move in and out of the market and cherry-pick customers.

For instance, a man aged 65 with a £100,000 fund buying a single-life level annuity guaranteed for five years would today receive an annual income from Friends Provident of £9,175, nearly a tenth better than the £8,428 currently on offer from Norwich Union. But don't assume that the best company for a single life male annuity will be best for other classes of annuity. For example, with a joint life annuity, where a portion of the pension income (usually half) is paid to the spouse on death of the annuitant, Canada Life currently tops the table with a figure of £7,578, significantly ahead of Standard Life's £7,008. Anyone wanting to see a rising income, which escalates each year in line with inflation, will be quoted lower figures.

If rule one on annuities is to take the open market option, rule two is to check if you are eligible for an "enhanced annuity". These are available to people with unhealthy lifestyle or medical problems, because insurers reckon they will die sooner. A rule of thumb is that you have to have smoked at least 10 cigarettes a day or be at least 30% overweight to qualify.

Enhanced annuities (also called impaired life annuities) are also available to people with conditions such as high blood pressure, diabetes, heart conditions, kidney failure, cancer, multiple sclerosis and chronic asthma, or any condition which the insurer believes will significantly reduce your life expectancy.

These types of annuities were pioneered by Stalwart Insurance (now GE Life), and this week the former managing director of Stalwart, Mike Fuller, launched a new company called Evergreen which will aim to distinguish between the health and life expectancy of each individual seeking an annuity.

"We estimate that 36% of those retiring could today receive pension annuity income up to 30% more than they currently receive. Only 4% currently do so. Evergreen intends to end the 'one size fits all' approach to annuities and to ensure each person can recieve the best pension for their circumstance," says Mr Fuller.

fields.bodyText: Despite annuity rates at record lows, there are lots of ways to improve your pension income by shopping around. When your pension plan matures, usually at age 65, the pension company will offer you an annuity based on how much you have saved. Astonishingly, 75% of people take this first offer, ignoring the fact that they can shop around from one company to the next. For example, just because you saved in a Norwich Union pension plan, you don't have to take their annuity offer - you can go to Prudential, Standard Life or any of the many other companies in the market to see what is on offer. The shopping around route is called the "open market option". The simplest way to exercise this is by contacting one of the handful of specialist brokers who will search the market for the best deal. The two biggest are Annuity Direct and Annuity Bureau. The difference between the best and worst company at any one time can be 25-30%, so a couple of phone calls could see your pension income go up by a third. Even between the top companies, rates vary as much as 10%, as life offices move in and out of the market and cherry-pick customers. For instance, a man aged 65 with a £100,000 fund buying a single-life level annuity guaranteed for five years would today receive an annual income from Friends Provident of £9,175, nearly a tenth better than the £8,428 currently on offer from Norwich Union. But don't assume that the best company for a single life male annuity will be best for other classes of annuity. For example, with a joint life annuity, where a portion of the pension income (usually half) is paid to the spouse on death of the annuitant, Canada Life currently tops the table with a figure of £7,578, significantly ahead of Standard Life's £7,008. webTitle: Villages link up again with cash machines

fields.headline: Villages link up again with cash machines
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
Securicor
fields.trailText: Villages abandoned by banks are to see the return of cash machines after the Link network opened its doors to the first five new independent ATM operators.
fields.body:
Villages abandoned by banks are to see the return of cash machines after the Link network opened its doors to the first five new independent ATM operators.

Led by Securicor, they promise 11,000 new machines in villages, convenience stores, hospitals, petrol stations, bars and nightclubs. The new machines will take the total Link network to nearly 40,000 ATMs over the next two years.

Charges for withdrawing cash are expected to be £1, although Link guarantees that there will be no double charging of customers by both their bank and the independent ATM operator.

Securicor aims to open 1,000 machines by the end of this year and a further 2,000 over the next three years. The four other companies joining the network are Moneybox, a subsidiary of media company Ambient, Infocash, a newly created private group and two US cash machine operators, Hanco and TRM.

The independent operators claim they can run the machines profitably with as little as 600 transactions per month, compared to the 3,000 required by banks, allowing them to put ATMs in remote areas. Securicor says it is buying US-made ATMs which cost only £5,000 each and says rental and servicing costs will add no more than £5,000 annually per machine. This compares with the £25,000 to £30,000 that the banks say machines cost them to operate.

Securicor sales and marketing director Graham Levinsohn said: "We are going to put machines in villages that have lost their banks. Our low-cost machines can be profitable even with a quarter of the transactions that the banks expect. We already service 7,000 remote ATMs for banks, so operating our own machines is a natural extension."

Securicor's initial investment will be around £10m, and it is also examining linking its cash machines to the web to create joint ATM/internet kiosks.

fields.headline: Creativity accounting
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Steve Dunn has been creative director at Ogilvy & Mather since the start of the year. So what does a creative director do? Simply, they direct creativity.
fields.body:
Steve Dunn has been creative director at Ogilvy & Mather since the start of the year. So what does a creative director do? Simply, they direct creativity.

He elaborates: "I'm like a coach. People come out with random ideas and I shape and edit those ideas, weeding out the bad ones.

"I tend to be very focused on the problem. I'll read about the product history and background and then ideas emerge. I replenish my ideas and form my mental scrapbook by looking at fine art. But people get their ideas from lots of different sources."

Mr Dunn, 39, arrived at this formula by hard work. He left school in Newcastle at 16 with little idea of what he wanted to do.

"My eyesight went at the age of 14 and I couldn't see the blackboard, so I went from class to class finding which subject I could do without having to see the front of the class. That's how I got interested in art. But I failed art 'O' level.

"Had I not taken a creative path I would have done what the guy before and the guy after me did, become an electrician or draftsman or worked in the shipyard," he says. Instead, he mooched around, living at home, not knowing quite where to put himself. It was a fleeting acquaintance with a guy called Tommy Hannah which pushed him in the direction of art school.

"He saw my doodles one day and suggested I study art. I had never really thought about it as a valid subject. At school art was the legal equivalent of slagging class." ("bunking off".)

He realised that what he actually wanted to study was advertising. He sat on his bed at home teaching himself the trade. He read, trawled the library, trudged to London and knocked on doors. "This lasted between nine months and a year, and I was having about five interviews a month. That's a lot of rejections. But every time I was kicked out of a door I learned from it."

Eventually, in 1979, he knocked on the door of Dave Trott, one of advertising's great gurus who was then working at BMP DDB Needham. Trott, who took on hardly anyone, took him on for two weeks. "He re-trained me from scratch and I learned how to structure ideas. It was hell. He was such a tough bugger he had me in tears. After two weeks he said I could come back for another two, and that was hell too. I was living on Sugar Puffs; the agency was working on the account and there were loads of packets around and I couldn't afford any thing else. I was sleeping on friends' floors."

After that infernal experience there was another six months of nothing, lying on his bed back at his parents' house. Until Dave Trott called him and offered him a job, starting on April 1. "I was elated and my parents were amazed. They thought I would never get a job. And I thought it was a joke because of the date," he says.

At the age of 21- very young in agency terms - he was made head of art at the fledgling Leagas Delaney, rising to become deputy creative director and co-partner.

"We were pretty smug at that time, thought we were pretty good. Then a show reel came over from an agency in the States called Wieden & Kennedy. It was their Nike work, and we were just blown away. I decided I really wanted to be part of that."

He's not sure whether he actually took the Nike campaign to new heights, but says he did good work overthere. He returned to the UK for personal reasons to the Lowe Howard Spink agency.

He considered setting up his own agency but never did. What he would have enjoyed is encouraging new talent and keeping the passion in and the pretension out of advertising.

So where does he intend to go with Ogilvy & Mather? "Paul Simons (head of O&M) told me to keep doing what I have done in the past, which is work at the highest level for the biggest clients in the world. I'm still guiding and editing work and helping the agency get better," he says.

But the executive creative director who has been featured in the recent publication Twenty Five of the World's Greatest Art Directors, adds: "I'm here by default, thanks to Tommy, and I don't forget that. People are not born creative. I've just learned how to be. I've worked very hard and I think that if I had gone on to be an electrician or draftsman I would have worked hard and done very well at that too."
