webTitle: Retirement income has halved in 10 years

fields.headline: Retirement income has halved in 10 years
fields.standfirst:
Pensioners have to buy an annuity, but many are shocked to find returns are tiny and even if they die early, the insurer pockets the money. Patrick Collinson reports
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Pensioners have to buy an annuity, but many are shocked to find returns are tiny and even if they die early, the insurer pockets the money. Patrick Collinson reports.
fields.body:
Fed up with pension companies and the government badgering you into shovelling ever greater amounts into a pension? You will be even more fed up when you discover that even if you build up a large lump sum, the income they pay you on retirement is puny.

Ten years ago, a married couple who saved £100,000 into a pension would have been able to pick up an inflation proofed annuity (an annual income) of £11,000 a year at age 65 until they died. Today the same £100,000 will only give you just £5,800 a year. What's more, if you die soon after retirement, the full £100,000 goes into the pockets of the life insurance company.

Understandably, many pensioners are shocked that their life savings produce such a low income.

One caller to Jobs & Money last week was furious about the annuity she has been offered. "If I'd known it was going to be so little, I would never have taken a pension out in the first place. I would have put the money into property instead," she said. Others find it inconceivable that if they die early, their pension money (unlike a property investment) will not go into their estate. This is because annuities are effectively a gamble on your life expectancy. If you live to 100, you win, because you continue receiving the income all those years. But if you die at 66, you lose.

On Monday the Social Market Foundation, the leading political think tank, will issue a damning condemnation of the current annuity rules. It says that the rules forcing pensioners to buy a compulsory purchase annuity by age 75 should be abolished.

SMF director Phil Collins says: "Our work shows that under the current system, flexibility and choice for those who choose to invest in their future is sadly lacking. Pensioners are boxed into a corner and forced to purchase an annuity. For many, this is a poor investment. The case against compulsory annuitisation is overwhelming."

The report was sponsored by pensions company Winterthur Life. "Gordon Brown needs to take the bull by the horns and end this unfair requirement. The current regulations are more than 40 years old, and with changes to life expectancy, the government must at least consider shifting the age limit from 75 to 80," says John Moret of Winterthur.

The report concedes that under current rules, investing in property, even without the tax breaks enjoyed by pensions, is more attractive than saving within a pension.

Many people are unclear exactly what annuities are. A basic annuity promises to pay a fixed income every year until the death of the holder.

But that's only the start. A joint life annuity will pay a proportion of the income to a spouse if the holder dies. And an escalating annuity will give the pensioner a pay rise each year, increasing the annuity income by the level of annual inflation. Both these options will involve taking a lower income at first.

An impaired life annuity will give you a higher income - but only if the life insurance company thinks you will die soon because, for example, you are a heavy smoker or have a life-threatening medical condition.

But why have annuities become such poor value? Behind the plunging levels of income is a double whammy of falling interest rates and rising life expectancy.

Interest rates

The level of interest rates is the single biggest influence on annuity income. The key rate is not base rate but the price of gilts, the long-term government stock that life insurance companies use to finance annuities.

In 1990, with inflation surging, the rate of interest paid on medium-term gilts was nearly 11%. Today it is around 5%. A technical situation, related to tough rules introduced after the death of Robert Maxwell and the Mirror pension scandal that emerged afterwards, has pushed gilt levels to new lows. The rules may shortly be eased, but with almost all economists in agreement that we are in a low inflation, low interest rate period, there is little hope that gilts (and therefore annuity rates) will bounce back up.

Mortality

Because pensioners are enjoying longer lives, the amount of money built up in a retirement pot has to be spread over more years and, therefore, the annuity income paid out is lower. A recent report from the Continuous Mortality Investigation Bureau, covering 30m people, found dramatic improvements in life expectancy for people aged 65 over the last 20 years. Men and non-smokers, in particular, are living far longer. Colin Kirkwood of the CMIB said: "The numbers of people who now survive into their 80s has grown remarkably. But the longer people live, the worse annuity rates will become."

The annuity industry has not been deaf to the complaints about falling incomes. In the mid-90s new legislation permitted the introduction of deferred annuities, which allowed people retiring at age 65 to leave their pension money invested in shares until age 75, and buy an annuity then. But the extra investment growth achieved on the shares was cancelled out by the continued fall in annuity rates, leaving holders little or no better off. Deferred annuities are also only appropriate for savers with pension pots of at least £100,000.

The rise of specialist annuity products, which segment the £7.5bn-a-year market into good lives (ie: the ones that die early) and bad lives (ie: the ones who live long) will mean that the healthier will receive even lower incomes, because they can no longer rely on the early deaths of others to cross-subsidise their annuity.

The fortunate are those employees who are members of final salary pension schemes, where retirement incomes are not influenced by the vagaries of annuity rate fluctuations. Sadly, many of these are now closing and being replaced by money purchase schemes, where the saver will be forced to rely upon buying an annuity with the cash they build up.

Until then, there are four choices for today's savers. Firstly, you can pile ever more money into your pension plan. Secondly, you can continue working long beyond age 60 or 65. Thirdly, you can take out a share-based individual savings account, which will not involve having to buy an annuity. Or finally you can forget pension plans altogether and opt for buying a rental property instead.

fields.headline: Flesh and blood feet
fields.standfirst:
The Royal Ballet New Works
Linbury Studio Theatre, London
***
fields.trailText: Until July 2. Box office: 020-7304 4000.
fields.body:
The Linbury Theatre is like a border pass between the Royal Opera House and the rest of the world: a place in which outside artists can collaborate with the residents and through which new audiences can be reached.

So it's apt that in the Royal Ballet's New Works season the most exciting commission so far has come from the modern dance choreographer Wayne McGregor.

McGregor's reputation has been made through his visionary use of computer technology, his poetic, sometimes disorienting weave of live and virtual bodies, real and electronic imagery. His new duet Symbiont is purely flesh and blood - and shows that McGregor's brain is expertly wired to the nuances of human movement. It makes its dancers, Edward Watson and Deborah Bull, glitter.

Watson, who is almost as tall as McGregor, easily accommodates the hyperactive dazzle which is McGregor's trademark style, but as the dance slams and coils and shimmers through his own elegantly classical body he also looks superb himself.

Bull appears intoxicated, and in this concentration of fast articulate dance, we're moved not only by the abstract excitement of the movement, but by the bold - erotic even - and tender emotions it awakes in the dancers.

By contrast, Matthew Hart's Acheron's Dream looks quaint and trifling. It's based on a vague scenario about a man reinventing his past, sporting with three women in a manner that's solemn, coy or predatory according to the score, Copland's Clarinet Concerto. Hart isn't short of steps, nor of neat (if derivative) ways of joining them. It's just that his story and his motive for telling it seem depressingly muddled.

Two pieces originally planned for the season failed to materialise (one was to have been by the late Jeremy James), which may explain the two revivals in Thursday's show, including Ashley Page's Sleeping With Audrey (1996). This, though, is a piece worth repeating, for its power is created, remarkably, as much by what it omits as by what it shows.

It presents a group of men and women whose tightly structured moves are progressively splintered by destructive social and sexual forces. The violence is shockingly in the timing, in the nervy impulses which travel like a virus from one dancer to another, in the charged pauses and sudden convulsions of activity.

Its subtleties could be lost on a larger stage. At the Linbury its effect is fierce.

 Until July 2. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

webTitle: At least we can still put on a good show

fields.headline: At least we can still put on a good show
fields.trailText: Forget the failures, what about the Centre Court, Lord's and Ascot for sheer fun.
fields.body:
Britain is a nation of invention, from the science laboratory to its artists to every sport that is worth a damn. You name it, we thought of it first. The only snag is that we confuse the idea of being the first with a divine right to being the best.

During a week of debate and bickering on my Radio 5 Live programme I am battered and bruised. "What do you think of our country?" I asked a caller from Switzerland. "You are arrogant, you all believe the world thinks you are a great people and you have beer bellies with tattoos on them" was the straight reply.

It was tempting to hit back with a "what the hell have the Swiss ever done?" retort but I bit my lip, held in my stomach and took the blows.

We are feeling a bit punch drunk at the moment. Our poor reputation across the globe, which has rested in the fists of a few psychopaths who travel under the flag of St George, has been confirmed at Euro 2000 and the bid for the 2006 World Cup is surely lost, probably to South Africa.

We are light years behind France and Holland at football, our Test cricketers, despite the odd flourish, are not up to much and our rugby union team is the best in Europe but still petrified by the southern hemisphere. Some of our golfers - and, indeed, our courses - are outstanding and we have a fine pedigree in men who drive quickly and engineers who enable them to do so.

Tennis? Well, as we enter Wimbledon fortnight, there are fears that we have seen the best of Tim Henman and Greg Rusedski, though Arvind Parmar might give us a few days of excitement. And reliable information says we should not expect more than one track-and-field gold medal at the Sydney Olympics.

But, after a week of being bashed, let us dust ourselves down and celebrate what we are good at: putting on a show. Forget the grumbles of Mary Pierce and Andrei Medvedev. The championships in SW19 are a tribute to great planning and attention to detail, and the new facility for the players on the site of the old No1 Court will stop the moans.

Nobody can put on a racing spectacle like Royal Ascot, whether we like the class barriers or not. The Swiss would ensure the races started on time but where would we find the colour, the daftness and the style?

Where better to watch a test match against West Indies than Lord's? Even the staunchest cynic will admit the revamped grounds in St John's Wood are a source of great pride. Then there is Henley, though I am barely qualified to discuss the intricacies of its pleasures. An event of mind-blowing boredom to most of us, it is an example of mad dogs and Englishmen at play.

Commercially these events are huge successes, attracting corporate consumers from around the world in vast numbers. In stark contrast to the beer bellies of Brussels, we illustrate remarkable willingness to show off our eccentricities and our confidence in the bedrock of tradition.

All these events are way beyond the average pocket and do not fit Tony Blair's dream of "a sporting future for all" but at least they project a positive image. And, if that is all we have to cheer at the moment, then let us be thankful for small mercies.

Maybe something constructive will come out of this lousy week. Perhaps we will be less arrogant and more realistic about how good we are and how good we should be. We need to accept that other nations have adopted sports we created and made them their own by learning from our mistakes and laziness.

While we have been sleeping in a cosy bed of our own making, the rest of the industrialised western world has woken up to the importance of continual improvement of health, education and sport programmes.

For too long we have rested on the virtues of tradition without having the vision to look ahead. Poor administration, ineffective use of money and reliance upon old ways are the well-known causes of our sporting sloth.

We have known our failings for decades and done little about it. Now we must get real and set sensible targets for a second-rate nation of under-achievers.

webTitle: France's shadow puts rest in the shade

fields.headline: France's shadow puts rest in the shade
fields.standfirst: Euro 2000 special report
fields.trailText: I tipped France, and I'll stick by that... but watch out for the others.
fields.body:
It's a good job I wasn't doing live commentary on England's game on Tuesday night because I think the broadcasting authorities might have had something to say. We were so awful, I was going mad. But now I've calmed down I'm really looking forward to the quarter-finals.

France were my pre-tournament tip and their performance with a shadow team against Holland on Wednesday did nothing to change my mind. They played well against a very strong side and their coach, Roger Lemerre, will not be unduly worried about any injuries or suspensions because he clearly has excellent players to step in.

Johan Micoud and Sylvain Wiltord impressed me, but I think they have ready-made replacements in every position except for right-back: I'm not sure about Christian Karembeu. So I take them to see off Spain and meet Italy in the semis, with Holland and Portugal also progressing.

Not that Spain will be walkovers. They'll be on a high after coming back from the dead and, if they find a bit of inspiration, they can be very dangerous. Against Yugoslavia, they showed a cutting edge I didn't think they possessed.

Alfonso could offer a threat but the only thing which can really stop France is over-confidence. Their stars will be fresh, their all-round quality is outstanding, and Thierry Henry and Nicolas Anelka will have too much pace for the Spanish defence.

Similarly, I think the Dutch will be too strong for the Yugoslavs. Winning their group with maximum points will have given them confidence and, now they are staying in Holland, their home crowd will be an enormous help. That could sweep them all the way to the final.

In any case, they have been improving with every match and they looked far more of a team against France than in their previous two games. Dennis Bergkamp showed some good touches, although I'm not sure Marc Overmars is 100%. Holland's only real weakness was their defence, particularly on set-plays, and they will have to be wary of Yugoslavia, who can counter-attack at pace.

I thought Savo Milosevic would be one of the leading scorers and he's in the pot all right. But the Yugoslavs ship too many. I thought they'd be better defensively but they lack discipline.

The hardest to call is Italy v Romania. Dino Zoff's side have been effective rather than spectacular and some of their defending has been very un-Italian, real last-ditch stuff. They have the tournament's best keeper in Francesco Toldo but the fitness of Paolo Maldini is vital.

Up front Zoff doesn't have an outstanding out-and-out centre-forward. Christian Vieri has been missed and Alessandro del Piero is not that sharp at the moment. The Italians will need all their know-how against Romania, whose battering of England was no fluke.

Romania have a brilliant midfield of which Adrian Mutu could be the find of the tournament. He's only 21, but he's energetic, sprints forward looking for goals and can put his forwards in with good short passes. In fact I'm not sure whether I'd bring back Gheorghe Hagi, I'd hold him back as a super-sub.

In the other quarter-final, I'm sure most neutrals will be hoping Portugal beat Turkey. They've been the most spectacular team in the competition and if you picked a side of the best players here Luis Figo and Rui Costa would walk into it.

Over the years the Portuguese have consistently had great youth teams but they've never gone on from there. I think it's helped that fewer Brazilians are playing for their club sides now, giving the home lads a chance to bloom.

Turkey are quick and bright and it's been a great year for them with Galatasaray's Uefa Cup victory, but to stop Portugal don't be surprised if they resort to a bit of the rough stuff.

fields.headline: Azharuddin given Indian grilling
fields.trailText: A scrum of 100 reporters and photographers mobbed Mohammed Azharuddin as he emerged from three hours of questioning by the national government's Central Bureau of Investigation yesterday.
fields.body:
A scrum of 100 reporters and photographers mobbed Mohammed Azharuddin as he emerged from three hours of questioning by the national government's Central Bureau of Investigation yesterday.

The former India captain, who Hansie Cronje says introduced him to the Indian bookmaker who gave him his first bribe, had been escorted into the offices in New Delhi by more than a dozen officials and refused to talk when he left.

"This is a preliminary inquiry. We are yet to register a case," said S M Khan, a spokesman for the CBI, which has questioned more than half a dozen players and officials in the past month. "We recorded Azharuddin's statement. We had called him to investigate the entire allegations of match-fixing. He was questioned for about three hours."

The bureau stepped up its investigation last month when the former test all-rounder Manoj Prabhakar accused Kapil Dev, India's current team coach, of offering him 2.5m rupees (£36,000) to play below form in a match against Pakistan in 1994. Dev has angrily denied the claims.

Cronje told the King Commission last week that the first bribe he ever accepted, in 1996, was some $30,000 (£20,000) from a bookmaker called Mukesh Gupta whom Azharuddin had introduced him to during the third test in Kanpur in 1996.

Azharuddin denies any impropriety.

Meanwhile West Indies are hoping that an injury to Franklyn Rose will not rule him out of the second test at Lord's next week. The fast bowler made only a brief appearance on the second day of the match against New Zealand A at Chelmsford yesterday. Rose was on the field for one delivery and then retired to the pavilion for treatment on a pulled hamstring.

West Indies, defending a first-innings total of 232, bowled out their opponents for 193 to establish a lead of 39. By the close, the openers Chris Gayle and Adrian Griffith had extended that by 50 runs.

 Centuries by Saeed Anwar (123) and Inzamam-ul-Haq (112) put Pakistan in command as they reached 341 for five, a lead of 160, on the second day of the second test against Sri Lanka in Galle yesterday.

fields.headline: Cronje counts cost of 'addiction'
fields.standfirst: South African who loved money hits out at trial by media
fields.trailText: Hansie Cronje attacked the Indian police phone-tap tapes that sparked the match-fixing case against him but admitted that his acceptance of money from bookmakers became an addiction, as he faced a second day of cross-examination at the King Commission here yesterday.
fields.body:
Hansie Cronje attacked the Indian police phone-tap tapes that sparked the match-fixing case against him but admitted that his acceptance of money from bookmakers became an addiction, as he faced a second day of cross-examination at the King Commission here yesterday.

While the former South African captain complained of being subjected to "trial by media" over the tapes of his phone conversations with Indian bookmakers during a tour earlier this year, he likened his temptations in accepting money from them to that of an alcoholic.

Having admitted to an "unfortunate love of money" on Wednesday, Cronje was asked why he accepted some offers but not others, even when the circumstances were similar. "I am not an alcoholic and I have never been addicted to nicotine, but I understand there are times when you give in to the temptation," he said.

"At various times guilt made me realise what I was doing wrong," he said when asked why there was a gap of three years before he accepted money again in January of this year. "I didn't realise at that stage I was hooked. That only became apparent later.

"My resistance to accepting any more money at that stage overcame my love for money."

When questioned on the details of transcripts of the conversations between himself and "Sanjay", believed to be the London-based bookmaker Sanjiv Chawla, that were released by New Delhi police earlier this year, Cronje complained that the tapping of his phone had been an invasion of his privacy.

And, while he admitted having "a lot of conversations" with Chawla, he said that "95% of the time I was stringing him along".

Cronje, when questioned about several points in transcripts that have been in public circulation for more than a month, said: "Whose phones were tapped or bugged? Was it Sanjay's or mine? Was it a cellphone or a hotel phone? Isn't this an invasion of privacy? Am I being tried by the media?"

Cronje has admitted to receiving $80,000 (£50,000) from the bookmaker Mukesh Gupta in 1996, after alleging that he was introduced to him by the former India captain Mohammed Azharuddin, and said another $20,000 (£13,000) paid into his account could have come from Gupta.

But he said yesterday he had stayed clean for more than three years before accepting 50,000 rand (£4,500) from the bookmaker Marlon Aronstam in January during the Centurion Park test against England.

Judge Edwin King, who must decide whether Cronje has made a full disclosure of the facts and therefore be granted immunity from prosecution and a possible prison sentence, pressed Cronje on Aronstam's offer to donate 500,000 rand to a charity of his choice to set up the game.

"Did you really believe that Mr Aronstam's offer ... was genuine?" asked King. "Yes, I did," Cronje replied.

"Of your choice?" King said.

Of the "gift" that Aronstam promised for Cronje's connivance, Cronje said: "I would have been happy with a drink in the bar of the hotel. I thought it might be money but I didn't know."

"If you would have been happy with a drink in the bar then you must have been surprised, even shocked to be given 50,000 rand," asked Shamila Batohi, who is effectively the commission's chief prosecutor.

"Yes, I thought he was a very generous man," Cronje said.

Having implicated Azharuddin for introducing him to Gupta in his initial statement last Thursday, Cronje said yesterday: "He may not have known what Mr Gupta wanted to do. He left the room before we talked about it."

Azharuddin, who was taken in for questioning by Indian federal investigators in New Delhi yesterday, has said he did not know Gupta and denies involvement in match-fixing.

webTitle: No shifting France and Holland as favourites

fields.headline: No shifting France and Holland as favourites
fields.trailText: Chandler have reacted to Wednesday night's cracking game between France and Holland by quoting the Big Two as their new 9-4 joint favourites to win the championship. Italy are 7-2 third favourites - from 11-2 earlier in the week - with Spain on 7-1 and Portugal 8-1. Romania are given an 18-1 quote with Yugoslavia on 25-1 and Turkey the 40-1 outsiders.
fields.body:
Chandler have reacted to Wednesday night's cracking game between France and Holland by quoting the Big Two as their new 9-4 joint favourites to win the championship. Italy are 7-2 third favourites - from 11-2 earlier in the week - with Spain on 7-1 and Portugal 8-1. Romania are given an 18-1 quote with Yugoslavia on 25-1 and Turkey the 40-1 outsiders.

A France v Holland final can be backed at 2-1 with Chandler, who believe an Italy v France showdown is the next most likely finale at 4-1.

Chandler have also updated their prices on the Golden Boot and the Yugoslav Savo Milosevic - available at 100-1 before the tournament began but now with four goals to his name - is their 11-8 favourite to hold on to his lead. Thierry Henry and our pre-tournament choice Patrick Kluivert are next best at 7-2 apiece, with Portugal's hat trick scorer Sergio Conceicao offering a bit of value at 9-1. Spain's Alfonso and Raul are on 12-1 and 20-1 respectively.

Chandler make France 5-6 favourites to win Sunday's quarter-final against Spain in Bruges. A Spanish win is on offer at 11-4 and you can get 11-5 about a draw after 90 minutes. The market leaders will be strongly fancied to win the other three games for which Italy are 3-4 to triumph against Romania and Portugal 8-13 to eclipse Turkey. Chandler will give you 4-6 about Holland beating Yugoslavia in Rotterdam.

fields.headline: Euro 2000 shorts
fields.trailText: • Uefa is to investigate the incident in which two Yugoslavia fans seperately tried to assault the referee Gilles Veisseire after he had sent off Slavisa Jokanovic during the 4-3 defeat by Spain in Bruges on Wednesday.
fields.body:
 Uefa is to investigate the incident in which two Yugoslavia fans seperately tried to assault the referee Gilles Veisseire after he had sent off Slavisa Jokanovic during the 4-3 defeat by Spain in Bruges on Wednesday.

One of the fans was led away by Yugoslavia's Savo Milosovic and the other was prevented from reaching the official by the Spanish player Alfonso. Both fans were arrested and appeared in court yesterday.

There was further trouble after the game, which Spain won 4-3 with two injury-time goals, with the referee being hit by a coin thrown from a section of the Yugoslav fans.

 Christoph Daum has ruled himself out as a potential successor to Germany's outgoing coach Erich Ribbeck, who resigned after his side failed to reach the quarter-finals. Daum is to stay with Bayer Leverkusen saying: "I have a contract in Leverkusen until 2001, and I fully intend to honour it."

Meanwhile the team's main sponsor, DaimlerChrysler, has demanded changes at the German Football Federation. "We can in no way tolerate the performance of the German delegation at the European Championship," DaimlerChrysler's head of sponsoring Mathias Kleinert said. "We will make it absolutely clear how the future should look."

 The Dutch striker Pierre van Hooijdonk, who was interesting PSV Eindhoven, said yesterday that he was moving to Benfica on a three-year contract in a £4.5m deal. year. The 30-year-old former Nottingham Forest striker will leave Vitesse Arnhem after only one season at the first division club where the former Dutch international Ronald Koeman is the coach.

"I'm happy to be getting a chance at a big club. I did not expect to leave after a year, but because of their financial situation, I had to. I got on fine with the players there," he said.

 There is a doubt over Emmanuel Petit's fitness for France's quarter-final against Spain in Bruges on Sunday. The Arsenal midfielder missed training yesterday because of a recurrence of the left-knee injury that forced him to be substituted during the victory over the Czech Republic on Friday.

 The Yugoslav defender Goran Djorovic will miss the quarter-final against Holland in Rotterdam on Sunday after suffering a leg muscle injury during the defeat by Spain. The midfielder Vladimir Jugovic is doubtful because of back spasms. Meanwhile the Dutch midfield player Ronald de Boer is hopeful of recovering from a hip injury in time to play.

 France and Spain will have to be on their best behaviour in their quarter-final in on Sunday in Bruges because the match will be refereed by the imposing Italian Pierluigi Collina.

Dick Jol of the Netherlands will take the match between Portugal and Turkey in Amsterdam tomorrow, while Vitor Melo Pereira of Portugal will be in charge when Italy play Romania in Brussels on the same evening.

fields.headline: United start with home comforts
fields.trailText: Stephen Bradfield previews the opening days fixtures.
fields.body:
The fixture computer has handed Manchester United a relatively easy start to their defence of the Premiership title on August 19 when they play Newcastle United at Old Trafford.

Last season United defeated a struggling Newcastle 5-1 two days after Ruud Gullit had left the club, although by the time of the return match their opponents were sufficiently revived under Bobby Robson to beat the champions 3-0.

Arsenal, the runners-up, have a potentially difficult trip to the Stadium of Light where they were held to a 0-0 draw by Sunderland in the corresponding fixture last August.

Leeds, whose title challenge faded badly in the spring although they still managed to finish third, start at home against an Everton side hoping to continue their improvement under Walter Smith.

The FA Cup holders Chelsea, whose inconsistency is likely to be rectified by the presence of a natural goalscorer in Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink, have a London derby against West Ham at Stamford Bridge.

Manchester City are denied the chance of a glamorous return to the big time. Joe Royle's side will be on familiar ground at the Valley against the First Division champions Charlton Athletic.

Ipswich Town, who gained promotion through the back door of the play-offs, will get an early indication of their chances of Premiership survival against Tottenham at White Hart Lane.

The Premiership's newest managers, Leicester City's Peter Taylor and Chris Hutchings of Bradford City, will have to be on their mettle. Leicester take on Aston Villa at Filbert Street while Bradford face a rather tougher assignment at home to Liverpool, whom they beat 1-0 at Valley Parade on the last day of the season to preserve their status.

Bradford's former manager Paul Jewell faces a tricky first outing in charge of relegated Sheffield Wednesday. They travel to Wolverhampton Wanderers in the First Division when the Nationwide League gets underway on August 12.

The long road back to the Premiership begins for Wimbledon at Selhurst Park against Tranmere, the beaten Worthington Cup finalists. Graham Taylor's Watford, the other relegated side, are at Huddersfield Town.

Preston North End, impressive winner of the Second Division title under the skilful management of Dave Moyes, play at Grimsby. Burnley, who finished runners-up to Preston, have a Lancashire derby against Bolton Wanderers at the Reebok stadium.

Jan Molby's Conference champions Kidderminster begin life in the Football League with a home game against Torquay United at Aggborough.

In Scotland, the traditional New Year Old Firm derby has been scrapped. The Scottish Premier League have moved the holiday fixture between Celtic and Rangers to February in a bid to accommodate its revamped league which now consists of 12 teams which will be split into two sections for the last five games of the season.

First-day Premiership fixtures: Bradford City v Liverpool; Charlton Athletic v Manchester City; Chelsea v West Ham United; Coventry City v Middlesbrough; Derby County v Southampton; Leeds United v Everton; Leicester City v Aston Villa; Manchester United v Newcastle United; Sunderland v Arsenal; Tottenham v Ipswich Town.

fields.headline: England 2006: mission impossible
fields.trailText: This morning, England's 2006 World Cup campaign team should have been putting the finishing touches to the final two presentations of their highly regarded £10m bid - in Luxembourg a week today and Zurich five days later.
fields.body:
This morning, England's 2006 World Cup campaign team should have been putting the finishing touches to the final two presentations of their highly regarded £10m bid - in Luxembourg a week today and Zurich five days later.

Instead Alec McGivan, Sir Bobby Charlton and the rest of the team who have lobbied hard in the backyards of every Fifa member with a vote over the past four years have gone back to square one.

With only two weeks left before the decision by the world governing body's 24-strong executive committee, McGivan's team must quickly assess how much damage has really been done to the bid by English hooligans at Euro 2000 and Uefa's threat - not carried out due to England's elimination - to expel Kevin Keegan's side from the tournament.

Campaign officials will today set out on a damage limitation exercise with their prospective supporters - and those who may be sympathetic in subsequent rounds of voting - to ascertain whether there is any point in continuing with the bid at all.

McGivan admits, as he prepares to hold urgent talks with individual Fifa members, that he has his work cut out. Presentations are due to be held at the Uefa congress in Luxembourg, where most of the delegates will support the German bid anyway, and a few hours before the vote itself in Zurich on July 6.

"A week ago, I would have said we had enough votes to get us into the final round," said McGivan. "The question is: do those votes still exist. We need to speak to the people who can answer that question."

With five candidates in the running and 24 votes at stake, the widely held view is that England could negotiate a path through the first round with possibly as few as six votes.

But with only two cast-iron certainties in the bag, Scotland's David Will and New Zealand's Charles Dempsey, McGivan now seems certain to focus on the votes of the three members of Concacaf, the confederation covering north and central America and the Caribbean.

The biggest beneficiaries of all this, of course, are the South Africans who are still hoping to strike a deal with Brazil whereby the South Americans will pull out of the running this time round and vote for them in exchange for South African backing in 2010.

Significantly, talks about a South African-Brazil alliance are planned for today in Johannesburg. The timing for McGivan and his team could not be worse.

fields.headline: Cardiff reject Hammam bid
fields.trailText: The former Wimbledon owner Sam Hammam wants to take over Cardiff City. Informal talks took place last week but Hammam's verbal offer of £1.5m for 80% of the Welsh club has been rejected by the board.
fields.body:
The former Wimbledon owner Sam Hammam wants to take over Cardiff City. Informal talks took place last week but Hammam's verbal offer of £1.5m for 80% of the Welsh club has been rejected by the board.

Hammam severed his links with Wimbledon in March after 22 years and the club were relegated to the first division.

"We've had no firm offers, just expressions of interest from various parties including Sam Hammam," said Cardiff's chief executive David Temme. "His proposal was considered unacceptable - as was another one we considered - but we must continue with our open-door policy towards investors."

Chelsea are set to take their summer spending towards the £25m mark after agreeing a £5.6m fee with Parma for the Croatia international Mario Stanic. The 28-year-old midfielder is close to signing a five-year deal.

West Ham have signed the 36-year-old veteran defender Nigel Winterburn from Arsenal on a two-year contract. The left-back, for so long a member of the famous Highbury back four, cost an undisclosed fee. In 13 years with Arsenal, he made more than 550 appearances and won the league title three times.

Chris Waddle resigned as Sheffield Wednesday's reserve coach yesterday, hitting out at the relegated club as he left. The former England winger insisted it had nothing to do with Paul Jewell becoming manager but that "they could have informed me two or three weeks ago" that he was not in the frame for the top or No2 post, which has gone to the caretaker manager Peter Shreeves.

Stig Inge Bjornebye will complete his £300,000 move from Liverpool to Blackburn in the next few days. The 30-year-old Norway defender will link up again with Graeme Souness who, as Anfield manager, signed him in 1992.

fields.headline: Bradford go for Hutchings
fields.standfirst: Paul Jewell's unsung assistant steps up to the hot seat as City's chairman ignores the fans' favourite McCall
fields.trailText: Paul Jewell's unsung assistant steps up to the hot seat as City's chairman ignores the fans' favourite McCall.
fields.body:
Bradford City yesterday resisted intense pressure from their supporters to install the club captain, Stuart McCall, as manager in the wake of Paul Jewell's sudden departure to Sheffield Wednesday, and instead named Jewell's unsung assistant, Chris Hutchings, as his successor.

Jewell's enthusiastic switch to Hillsborough, where, for all Wednesday's posturing, his first task will be to halve their £18m debt, suggests that Bradford have not exactly tempted Hutchings, a former player at Chelsea and Brighton, with unlimited transfer funds.

Nevertheless Bradford need to reshape a side who avoided relegation only on the final day of the season. Hutchings, on a two-year contract, talked of "higher targets".

"The pressure was on us to make a quick decision, so we can get on with team strengthening," said City's chairman Geoffrey Richmond. He still has to outline the money available to Hutchings, who is left to assume that yesterday's mention of "around £100,000" is merely a Yorkshire sense of humour. Richmond did at least scotch one rumour: if Bolton are really interested in Dean Windass, they can forget it at any price, he said.

Terry Yorath remains as City's first-team coach with McCall, who is on holiday in the United States and who is thought to be oblivious to the shenanigans, to be offered the role of assistant manager on his return.

"Stuart has another year on his playing contract and he may well go forward after that," said Richmond. "It is a very big ask for any individual in the Premier League to have the responsibility of player-manager. That ruled him out at this stage."

The overriding impression is that McCall is City's manager- in-waiting and cynics will suggest that, if things go badly, he might not have to wait too long. Hutchings was offered the job minutes after next season's Premiership fixture list pitted Bradford against Liverpool, Chelsea, Arsenal and Manchester United in their first five games.

The only slight relief in that period comes with a home match against Leicester City and even they are presented as the side Bradford most wish to emulate. "We want to establish ourselves in the Premiership; we are not the victims that the national media think we are," said Richmond.

 Everton fans have accused local councillors of "double standards" in response to news that Liverpool are considering a £150m move to a new 70,000-seat stadium in Stanley Park. The Everton shareholders' association spokesman Kevin Nolan said: "We have asked the question of the council about Stanley Park and been told no way. Then, when Liverpool come up with the suggestion, it looks like people are falling over backwards to help them get what they want."

webTitle: Five to light up the last eight

fields.headline: Five to light up the last eight
fields.standfirst: Some unsung players (and some written off)  have made a big impact so far - and plan to so the same in the quarter-finals
fields.trailText: Some unsung players (and some written off) have made a big impact so far - and plan to so the same in the quarter-finals. Guardian writers give you the lowdown on five of the best.
fields.body:
Savo Milosevic (Yugoslavia)

How things have changed. Formerly of Aston Villa and Row X, there was a time when Savo Milosevic was of more danger to the executive boxes than opposing defences.

From blunderer to plunderer, the Yugoslavia striker has been a rejuvenated figure at Euro 2000. He headed his fourth goal against Spain on Wednesday and is now the competition's leading scorer.

In certain parts of the west Midlands that may be more surprising than, say, Phil Neville being named defender of the tournament.

But, as regular Savo-watchers will testify, his scoring exploits should not really be any surprise. This, after all, is a player who, with Real Zaragoza, has established himself among La Liga's 20-goals-a-season brethren.

The man once known as Savo Miss-a-lot-evic has racked up 24 goals in 47 games for his country and now has set his sights on Stjepan Bobek's all-time national record of 37.

"Everything has worked out as I hoped," he says. "I'm doing very well here but why should I be surprised? Just look at my scoring record and what I have done in Spain. I can always score goals, no matter what some people in England may think.

"It is all about motivation. When I look around and see my team-mates giving everything it makes me play with all my heart. I will play until I fall down for my country.

"I am the record scorer in the current team, so none of this is new to me. In fact, my object now is to become the record Yugoslavia scorer of all time. If I don't succeed I will feel like killing myself."

All of which is a far cry from his slump-shouldered Villa days. Brian Little paid £3.5m to sign him from Partizan Belgrade in 1995 but in three turbulent seasons he managed only 31 goals.

Matters came to a head when Milosevic's umpteenth six-yard miss in a match against Blackburn was the catalyst for him to be abused by his own fans. When he spat at them he was transfer-listed by Little's successor John Gregory and, within a couple of months, Villa had recouped their money from Zaragoza.

Even so Milosevic still has an admirer in Little. "There was never any doubt in my mind that he would become a great goalscorer," Little says.

"When he came to England he was only 21 and it was hard for him to settle. He was worried about the events back home where his family were in the middle of a war zone. He didn't score a lot of goals here but he still had everything to be a first-class player."

Daniel Taylor

Stefano Fiore (Italy)

Stefano Fiore must pinch himself as he settles down to his waffles at breakfast in Belgium. A year ago, after another season without regular football at Parma, Euro 2000 must have felt as likely a destination this summer as the moon.

Then the midfielder was restricted to occasional club appearances in place of Juan Veron. Tomorrow he will be the pivotal figure in his country's attempt to reach the semi-finals. The 25-year-old would be entitled to ask: Where did it all go right?

The answer lies in a transfer to Udinese last summer as part of the deal which took Amoroso to Parma. A makeweight then, Fiore is a heavyweight now. He ended with nine goals in 32 games for his new club, making his Italy debut in February. The game against Romania will provide only his seventh cap but already he is indispensable. As Paolo Condo of Gazzetta dello Sport puts it: "We have champions in Maldini, Nesta, and so on. But Fiore is the key man."

Technically outstanding, Fiore dictates the pace and makes Italy tick. Often it is simple, occasionally spectacular, as his goal against Belgium showed. If Kevin Keegan wants to teach England's players how to keep possession, he could do worse than make them watch this man.

His late but rapid rise has come about purely because his talent has finally been allowed to shine. Some doubted whether he had the the strength of personality to lead a major club, never mind an international side. But the courage of Italy's coach Dino Zoff has been vindicated.

"Fiore is a very modern midfielder," Condo says of the former under-21 international. "He scores goals, he's a good offensive player and when the other team has the ball he can defend. And he is particularly important because Christian Vieri is not around.

"When Italy have Vieri in attack they play all the balls to him and can go slowly because he is able to hold the ball and wait for the team to arrive in attack. [Filippo] Inzaghi has other qualities. Now we must arrive in the box very quickly, so Fiore is extremely important."

That strike against Belgium was a classic example, Fiore feeding the ball to Inzaghi, taking an instant return and shooting past Filip de Wilde from the edge of the area. As if to announce his arrival, Fiore turned his back to the crowd and pointed to the name on his shirt.

Few in Italy needed reminding. Internazionale, Lazio and others are keen to buy him but Udinese are determined to hold on to the player for another season to maximise the profit. They have an impressive record of buying cheap and selling big.

Fiore has retained a professional approach despite his sudden rise to fame. Once the boyfriend of Miss Parma, he is becoming Mr Italy now.

Jon Brodkin

Cristian Chivu (Romania)

When he chipped that ball in to England's far post it is difficult to know whether Cristian Chivu (left) really meant to find the back of the net or the head of Viorel Moldovan. It doesn't matter. For with that goal the 19-year-old Ajax defender found instant fame.

It has been a heady rise for the boy from Resita, who only three years ago was playing for that small-town team and whose inclusion in the Romania squad came as such a surprise that the official Uefa media guide could not manage a photo of him.

But the young defender's confidence has remained unaffected by the altitude of his surroundings and the manner in which Chivu has filled the left-back position has impressed his veteran team-mates. His tenacity and bravery in defence allied to a poise on the ball and willingness to get forward mark him out as one of the best of Romania's new generation.

The game against England was only Chivu's fifth cap. But despite being booked and blamed by some for giving away a penalty - actually Paul Ince was not fouled but trod on the ball - Chivu emerged with his already growing reputation enhanced. "I thought Chivu was man of the match and did an excellent job marking Beckham," said his team-mate Dan Petrescu. "In two or three years I am sure he will be the best left-back in the world."

The son of a former Romania international, Chivu says he started playing in the streets when he was eight. He developed his game at school and joined CSM Resita at 14, making his first-team debut at 16. A year later, he moved up a notch to Universitatea Craiova and, in August 1999, he was at Ajax, moving for £3m on a six-year deal.

A scout for the Dutch club had spotted him playing for the Romania Under-21s in a tournament in France. Then at the start of last season Ajax's player-coach, Danny Blind, went to watch him against Dinamo Bucharest. And in no time he was wearing the red and white, thrust into the first team a month after his arrival because of injuries to other defenders.

He has been a fixture since, his burgeoning talent impressive enough to earn a place in Romania's Euro 2000 starting line-up for their three games so far. The only black mark against Chivu has been the four red cards he picked up for Ajax last season.

However, he is not an aggressive player. In fact the former Internazionale coach, Mircea Lucescu, says that Chivu "could be a strong leader for his generation". With his ability to play in central defence, he could be a versatile leader too.

But for the moment he is a boy among men, his stylish contribution to Romania's continued presence in Euro 2000 an apprenticeship and an adventure rolled into one.

Martin Thorpe

Alfonso (Spain)

The headline in Spain's Marca newspaper said it all: "Long live the mother who gave birth to you." With one swipe of his left foot Alfonso Perez has become a national hero.

While Spanish eyes looked to Raul for deliverance against Yugoslavia on Wednesday, it came seven minutes into stoppage time from a player who wears white boots, an Alice band and, until now, has never been totally accepted by the Spanish media.

Alfonso - he plays under the single name - clearly has an impeccable sense of timing. Spain had just equalised to make it 3-3 but were on the first flight home unless they could find another goal. Only a win would be enough for European football's great under-achievers.

A high cross was pumped into the penalty area and the Slavs backed off. Alfonso was loitering with intent 12 yards out. The ball came his way. He steadied himself, drew back his foot and lashed out. The next few moments are a blur.

"It was like a daze. When I saw the ball hit the net, I just lost my head," he says. "I don't know what happened. I was running away and then there were 20 bodies on top of me.

"I just concentrated on keeping the ball down. After that it was a case of praying for good luck. But it was a miracle, the whole thing was a miracle."

So Spain lived to fight another day after one of the most dramatic matches in national memory. And if this really is going to be their year, then Alfonso will surely be offered the Freedom of Iberia when they return.

An intricate player, with a penchant for creating goals as well as scoring them, Alfonso scored Spain's first and last goal on Wednesday to rescue them from yet another early exit.

The Real Betis striker now has 11 goals in 35 games for his country, an impressive tally for a player who has suffered from injury problems and was only a substitute in the first match against Norway.

Presumably the 27-year-old has cemented a place in the starting line-up for Sunday's quarter-final against France in Bruges.

Boudewijn Zenden (Holland)

It was Ronaldo who gave Boudewijn Zenden the nickname Bolo at PSV Eindhoven, deciding his team-mate's real name was too much of a mouthful. And a little of the Brazilian's scoring touch seems to have rubbed off on Zenden at the right time.

Yet there is more to Zenden's game than finding the net. His pace, balance and ability to beat men and cross make him a menace on both flanks. A shimmy, dart and centre to set up Ronald de Boer's tap-in against Denmark epitomised the flashes of inspiration he can offer. At PSV he was a pin-up but the 23-year-old is not just a pretty face.

"He's a sparkling player," says a Dutch journalist who was close to Zenden during his time at PSV. "The people here like his style. He's fast, he never hides and he knows how to dribble and go past opponents. He's the personification of Dutch attacking football."

Zenden's proficiency in martial arts may not sound much use on the pitch unless Norman Hunter makes a comeback. But the skills he picked up at his father's judo school in the south of the Netherlands have added something to those honed in the youth system at PSV.

"You should look at the way he reacts when he is tackled and goes down," the journalist says. "He uses the judo technique of breaking his fall and in an instant he's on his feet again. It's amazingly fast."

Zenden speaks at least four languages and plays in as many positions. A left wing-back of late for Barcelona, he played the first game here behind Patrick Kluivert and most the second on the right flank. Now he seems settled at left midfield.

Left-footed, he looks most dangerous in that role. After moving there in place of Marc Overmars against Denmark he set up De Boer's goal and scored from a Michael Reiziger pass. Against France he drifted in to finish unerringly from Sander Westerveld's long punt. One of six Barcelona players in the Dutch squad, Zenden's two years at Nou Camp have been up and down.

Restricted to eight starts in his first season by Rivaldo as he struggled for form, things have improved since he took on a more defensive role. Playing there in place of the Catalan Sergi has not endeared him to the fans. But at home he is guaranteed a hero's welcome.

fields.bodyText: Savo Milosevic (Yugoslavia) How things have changed. Formerly of Aston Villa and Row X, there was a time when Savo Milosevic was of more danger to the executive boxes than opposing defences. From blunderer to plunderer, the Yugoslavia striker has been a rejuvenated figure at Euro 2000. He headed his fourth goal against Spain on Wednesday and is now the competition's leading scorer. In certain parts of the west Midlands that may be more surprising than, say, Phil Neville being named defender of the tournament. But, as regular Savo-watchers will testify, his scoring exploits should not really be any surprise. This, after all, is a player who, with Real Zaragoza, has established himself among La Liga's 20-goals-a-season brethren. The man once known as Savo Miss-a-lot-evic has racked up 24 goals in 47 games for his country and now has set his sights on Stjepan Bobek's all-time national record of 37. "Everything has worked out as I hoped," he says. "I'm doing very well here but why should I be surprised? Just look at my scoring record and what I have done in Spain. I can always score goals, no matter what some people in England may think. "It is all about motivation. When I look around and see my team-mates giving everything it makes me play with all my heart. I will play until I fall down for my country. "I am the record scorer in the current team, so none of this is new to me. In fact, my object now is to become the record Yugoslavia scorer of all time. If I don't succeed I will feel like killing myself." All of which is a far cry from his slump-shouldered Villa days. Brian Little paid £3.5m to sign him from Partizan Belgrade in 1995 but in three turbulent seasons he managed only 31 goals. Matters came to a head when Milosevic's umpteenth six-yard miss in a match against Blackburn was the catalyst for him to be abused by his own fans. When he spat at them he was transfer-listed by Little's successor John Gregory and, within a couple of months, Villa had recouped their money from Zaragoza. Even so Milosevic still has an admirer in Little. "There was never any doubt in my mind that he would become a great goalscorer," Little says. "When he came to England he was only 21 and it was hard for him to settle. He was worried about the events back home where his family were in the middle of a war zone. Then the midfielder was restricted to occasional club appearances in place of Juan Veron. Tomorrow he will be the pivotal figure in his country's attempt to reach the semi-finals. If Kevin Keegan wants to teach England's players how to keep possession, he could do worse than make them watch this man. His late but rapid rise has come about purely because his talent has finally been allowed to shine. Some doubted whether he had the the strength of personality to lead a major club, never mind an international side. But the courage of Italy's coach Dino Zoff has been vindicated. They have an impressive record of buying cheap and selling big. Fiore has retained a professional approach despite his sudden rise to fame. Once the boyfriend of Miss Parma, he is becoming Mr Italy now. It doesn't matter. For with that goal the 19-year-old Ajax defender found instant fame. It has been a heady rise for the boy from Resita, who only three years ago was playing for that small-town team and whose inclusion in the Romania squad came as such a surprise that the official Uefa media guide could not manage a photo of him. But the young defender's confidence has remained unaffected by the altitude of his surroundings and the manner in which Chivu has filled the left-back position has impressed his veteran team-mates. His tenacity and bravery in defence allied to a poise on the ball and willingness to get forward mark him out as one of the best of Romania's new generation. The game against England was only Chivu's fifth cap. webTitle: Come in No10, your time is up

fields.headline: Come in No10, your time is up
fields.standfirst: The tournament has proved that in the international game today all good things no longer go through one man, writes Roy Collins
fields.trailText: The tournament has proved that in the international game today all good things no longer go through one man, writes Roy Collins.
fields.body:
If the French go home with the Henri Delaunay cup taped to their coach windscreen alongside their World Cup trophy, no one would be surprised to find the best player award also tucked away among Zinedine Zidane's luggage. But, deserving as he might be and unique as his gifts are, Zidane does not control the midfield strings in quite the style of France's old puppet master Michel Platini.

This is not a criticism of Zidane, merely a way of illustrating another significant shift in the ever changing fashions of international football in which, as we have seen in this tournament, teams no longer channel everything through a single playmaker - a quarter-back figure, so to speak, whose individual influence can stifle team initiative.

Though Zidane has the vision and technical skills to play the deadly pass, he is just as happy demonstrating his party pieces - a flick off the outside of the boot or a roll under the sole of his foot in the interests of a move's continuity rather than providing its decisive moment. And Emmanuel Petit, Patrick Vieira and Didier Deschamps have equal rights to play what Ron Atkinson describes as the Hollywood ball in a team ethic which is still one for all but no longer all for one.

This is the way of it at Euro 2000, where a long ball is as rare as a sober English fan and where England's players failed to learn the lesson that possession is now nine-tenths of the game. The style of the most successful sides here is short passes and big movement, providing moving targets that are harder for defenders to mark.

It is not quite the total football invented by the Dutch in the 70s where positions, as well as players, were interchangeable. But it is a variation on a theme, packing a side with players who are good on the ball and encouraging them all to get involved.

Portugal, perhaps the finest exponents of this style, thrashed the Germans with a wonderful demonstration by their reserves and scored their second goal against England after a move which involved 16 passes and covered 80 yards. That was the perfect example of the patience, control, skill and nerve of the best sides here, producing death by a thousand cuts.

Rui Costa and Luis Figo are both outstanding players for Portugal. But, if an opposing coach wanted to deploy a man marker, which of those two would he single out for special attention? And if both, who would keep an eye on Joao Pinto?

This is where England are so out of touch, still pining for the likes of Paul Gascoigne, Glenn Hoddle or, for older fans, Johnny Haynes - a junction box in midfield through which all traffic must pass. Their biggest problem was a lack of players comfortable on the ball, which is why their 4-4-2 system was so unbalanced compared to that of France and Spain, who have wonderful attacking and creative full-backs in Lilian Thuram and Michel Salgado.

Yugoslavia's Dragan Stoj-kovic and Romania's Gheorghe Hagi are the last of the old- fashioned playmakers here, players who both expect and demand the ball. But it was significant that Romania found their best form against England, when the absence of the suspended Hagi gave licence to the talented Adrian Mutu and Dorinel Munteanu to shape the game in a style more in keeping with the fashion in this tournament.

Spain had one foot in the Euro 2000 grave when they trailed Yugoslavia 3-2 deep into injury-time. But they still kept the other foot on the ball, working their way forward with short passes and intelligent running. Only at 3-3, with the clock all but run down, did they hump a long ball forward from which the winner came.

Charlie Hughes, the old FA technical director, would no doubt have pounced on that goal as vindication of all his hair-brained theories about the position of maximum opportunity and most goals coming from a small number of passes. No doubt he would also have tut-tutted as Spain, Portugal and Holland kept possession for a dozen or so passes while hardly advancing the same number of yards.

Of course, the long ball has its uses, both as a surprise tactic and as a sort of skeleton key to unlock the most impregnable of defences. But it is also a high-risk selection, increasing the odds of the opposition getting the ball and smuggling it away for hours on end.

In ideology football has taken a leaf from tennis where, these days, all the talk is of playing the high-percentage shot and reducing the risky one. That is why England, against opponents playing in such a way, averaged only 44% possession in their three matches.

It will be a lot higher for the Dutch who, with Dennis Bergkamp, Philip Cocu and Boudewijn Zenden in midfield, rely on subtlety and ball retention. But then they have played that way since the two Johans, Cruyff and Neeskens, were making the future orange.

Ironically, however, Holland's winning goal against France came from a punt out by the goalkeeper Sander Westerveld which reached the eventual scorer, Zenden, just outside the French penalty box. While Hughes would have claimed that to be proof of his theories, most of us would like to think of it as the exception that proves the rule.

fields.headline: Euro 2000 diary
fields.trailText: Dutch unity, the future for Larsson, name the coach and a Portugese view of England.
fields.body:
The new-found unity in the Dutch camp is clearly spiralling out of control. So eager are Frank Rijkaard's players to maintain team spirit that they are queuing up to be dropped so their team-mates can bask in all the glory. Take the goalkeeper Sander Westerveld: "I am a great goalkeeper, but we want to be the European champions and it's better for me and better for the team that Edwin van der Sar plays." Where's your ambition, man?

 Sweden's Henrik Larsson is coming to terms with life after Euro 2000, although the Celtic striker won't be returning to Scotland just yet. "I didn't sleep too well last night," he wrote on his official website. "I need to speak to Celtic and talk to them about what is happening." And the reason for his lack of enthusiasm? "They say Chris Sutton may be coming to the club. That's interesting ..."

 Name the coach: "I feel it is important to attack. The team showed through all their matches that they could be positive." Yes, that'll be Denmark's Bo Johansson whose team's record read no goals and no points. "Maybe I look a little stupid," he added. Quite possibly.

 At least someone found England's Euro 2000 campaign amusing. Portugal's Paulo Sousa almost wet himself. "They've got Paul Scholes and David Beckham, but the rest of them are clumsy, slow and easy to get past," he said. "I was even laughing on the bench when I saw their defenders heading back towards their own penalty area rather than trying to tackle Figo or Rui Costa."

 The Everton manager Walter Smith has warned Abel Xavier that fluorescent hair and yellow beards are definitely not "in" on Merseyside. "He wrote to me and said, 'Hey man, what have you done?'," said the Portuguese defender. Expect a more sober bouffant come August.

 The following were winners in Wednesday's Diary competition: David Clater, Dave Sutton, Ed Bassford, Damian Roche, John Denton, R Evans, Adam, Andrew and Luke Snell, F Razzaq, David Owen, Alix Mackay. The correct answer was (b) 20% and copies of "Victory - England v Germany", distributed by Visual Entertainment, are in the post. The video goes on general release today, priced £12.99.

webTitle: Lessons from my brush with badger

fields.headline: Lessons from my brush with badger
fields.trailText: is exactly the right one to ask some important questions about the future of the English game. Such as: is Badger Bonce still the right name for the geezer?
fields.body:
So it's all over for another year. Until the next Euro 2000, the game is up, the frolics finished, the fun, along with the face paint and the comedy strap-on pot bellies, pushed to the back of the cupboard. Yet for some reason some of them is still trying to carry on as if there's still summat worth playing for.

Yours truly has yet to work out why your continentals, your French, your Dutch, your Spaniards and that, still think there's any point staying on for now the party's over. Obviously it takes a while for your euro to drop Belgium-side.

I know it is most deffo not the instinct of the English media at moments of national sporting defeat to go on and on and on about it, shaking their heads, wringing their hands and the players necks. I know we don't like to drown ourselves in self-pity and post mortems, but prefer, as a nation, just to lean over, ruffle the lad Nev's hair and say "nay mind, son, better luck next time".

But personally, yours truly feels that this moment in time is exactly the right one to ask some important questions about the future of the English game. Such as: who'll get to wear the mighty magenta boots now Keowny's destined for the scrap heap? And Badger Bonce: is that still the right name for the geezer?

For me, close involvement with the England party this tournament has changed my whole attitude to that particular aspect of the game. These last few weeks, as he's stood on the sidelines doing that puffing out his chest business what looks like he's telling Incey to put on an Anna Kournikova sports bra, Badger's bonce has turned an unsullied tone of purest white.

Whiter than a schoolgirl's socks. Whiter, indeed, than a gram of Marco's finest procured in the gent's at Dell's just as the effects of seven bottles of Andalucian lager is beginning to take its toll on the Tackle pulling technique. Yet Polar Bear Bonce doesn't quite sound right. And Coke Head perhaps sends out the wrong signals. I'm working on it, and rest assured, will let you - the faithful Tackle public - know for deffo soon as I've had a word with Wattsy.

Right now, unfortunately, Watts is not available, seeing as how he is spending his five weeks hard-earned rest on a tropical island - an holiday what he bought with the little bonus he got from that betting syndicate in Singapore for providing mundane information in advance about the time and identity of the scorer of an own goal in that crucial relegation six-pointer at the Daihatsu in March. Mick Watts, 48 seconds, was his prediction and blow me down if he was only bleedin' right. He's always been lucky in a punt, Wattsy.

That said, I heard some toss-pot journalist on the radio going on and on this week about how footballers earning the amount our lads do should be able to pick out a player from their own side with the ball. To which, I says, just look at the case of Wattsy.

If we footballers is earning what we is supposed to be earning, how come an honest pro like Wattsy is obliged to turn to a little freelancing in order to provide his family with the essentials in life? Such as a tropical island with a stable of motor launches and hot and cold running hula girls. There is no short cuts in this world and if you pays peanuts you gets monkeys. Though to be honest, a truck load of gibbons couldn't of defended worse than England.

But hey, it is not in the Tackle nature to carp, to remind ex-Badger Bonce that he has been pointing out all season the answer to the left flank of the England side. Darren Tackle is not about to take this opportunity to whinge on and on about how the tournament might still be going on if a certain no-nonsense over-lapping full-back had been given his chance. Yours truly is too broad in the shoulder to stick his fingers in his ear, extend his tongue and yell in the direction of the so-called English management: "ner nerny ner ner, told you so".

Football is all about opinions. Ex-Badger has his opinions. And Tackle has his: specifically that the management should be beheaded as traitors and their entrails pegged out on the washing line for the birdies to pick at.

Perhaps now is not the time for mature reflection of that kind. Now is the time to get fore-square behind the lads as they climb aboard the ferry for the short, sad journey home. Then stick our collective boots up their backsides and kick the tossers in the sea so we can start again with a clean sheet. Which obviously, being England, wouldn't last for long.

As for Tackle, you may be wondering what the future holds for him. A career in management? A contract at Real Madrid? A week at the Priory? But that will be then, this is now. And right now I is just going to give Rodney a buzz to see if he can't get in touch with Wattsy's Singapore mob and check out if they'd be interested in buying a piece of inside information yours truly has managed to lay his hands on these past two weeks. It's this: England are pants.

fields.headline: Chill Factor
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A join-the-dots buddy action movie
fields.body:
Cuba Gooding Jr and Skeet Ulrich sleepwalk their way through Chill Factor, a join-the-dots buddy action movie directed by Hugh Johnson, a first-time director who has learned his craft at the Ridley Scott Associates commercials agency.

A government scientist has invented a bomb which is going to be snatched by a sinister ex-army terrorist played by our own Peter Firth, who has bulked out and had a Number One cut. The bomb will go off if it is not kept cold, and our heroes have to keep it in a refrigerated ice-cream truck which Cuba has nicked. Hence the title. Gooding's attempts at goofiness are deeply irritating.

fields.headline: Big Momma's House
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: The usual crude excursion, which strategically retreats into sentimentality
fields.body:
It isn't Martin Lawrence's worst comedy thriller, but Big Momma's House, directed by Raja (Never Been Kissed) Gosnell, is the usual crude excursion, which strategically retreats into sentimentality.

Staking out a suspect, FBI agent Malcolm (Lawrence) has to disguise himself as the fat grandmother of the suspect's beautiful girlfriend Sherry (Nia Long). It involves a gloatingly unpleasant, jeering view of old women's bodies which is intensified by his ickily protective feelings for Sherry and her young son.

fields.headline: Isn't She Great
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: This is a very likable film, with snappy dialogue, pacy direction and sweet performances
fields.body:
The lack of a question-mark in Isn't She Great is deliberate; this was the perpetual cry of in the 60s of Irv Mansfield, manager and husband of Jacqueline Susann, author of racy page-turners about pill-popping Hollywood whores of all sexes and professions. She virtually created the S'n'F genre we know today, and with a trouper's intuitive genius, laid down the blueprint for modern publishing's cult-of-personality hype machine.

Bette Midler is the obvious, perhaps the only, choice for the lead, because gutsy lovable Susann died of breast cancer, having had only 10 years to fulfil her dream of worldwide fame.

This is a very likable film, with snappy dialogue, pacy direction and sweet performances. You too will hiss as Truman Capote sneers at Miss Susann's dress sense, and cheer as Valley of the Dolls cruises past Graham Greene's The Comedians in the New York Times bestseller list.

fields.headline: Jaya Ganga
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Elegant and beautifully photographed... Singh's film is made with seriousness and a pleasing and unaffected grace
fields.body:
The Indian film-maker and writer Vijay Singh has scored a great success on the festival circuit with Jaya Ganga - and rightly so.

This elegant and beautifully photographed novella of a film concerns Nishant (Asil Ras), a young writer pursuing his own spiritual journey along the Ganges. At first dreamily infatuated with what he believes is the memory of a beautiful woman called Jaya, he falls in love with Zehra, the Jaya spirit made flesh, a poetess and courtesan who is indentured - in fact, enslaved - at a brothel. Nishant buys her freedom and they begin a languorous and erotic adventure. Singh's film is made with seriousness and a pleasing and unaffected grace.

fields.headline: Relative Values
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: The adaptation smudges the clarity and unity of the stage settings... On the screen everything looks too creaky
fields.body:
Eric Styles made a distinctive debut with his first film, Dreaming of Joseph Lees, a gloomy, Hardyesque tragedy. Now he has exhumed Noël Coward's Relative Values, a brittle comedy which is not of the Master's first rank. In attempting to dissolve its theatrical boundaries, the adaptation smudges the clarity and unity of the stage settings and in any case ends up becalmed in the various rooms of "Marshwood Hall".

There is much tinkling laughter and people in black tie saying lines like: "Everything is quite, quite ghastly!" Julie Andrews is a regal presence as the Countess of Marshwood - though her hair and deportment suggest modern California rather than pinched, 50s Britain. She resents her son's engagement to Miranda (Jeanne Tripplehorn), an American movie star being pursued by another Yank, Billy Baldwin.

It's the kind of accomplished cast that would pack them in at, say, London's Theatre Royal, Haymarket. But on the screen everything looks too creaky - including the reactionary view that Brits and Americans should know their respective stations in life. That said, there is a droll turn from Stephen Fry as the butler and an outstandingly funny, sympathetic performance from Sophie Thompson as Moxie the maid.

fields.headline: Not One Less
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: This film refuses the easy crescendos and crises of ordinary drama... You feel the unnerving, yet exhilarating sense of having a window on real life
fields.body:
Zhang Yimou's Not One Less is a world away from, say, the gorgeously rich, elaborately realised period drama of his Raise the Red Lantern. Premiered here at the London Film Festival in November, this is part social documentary, part wan pastoral comedy, performed by non-professionals and semi-professionals largely duplicating the roles they play in real life.

It is the story of a 13-year-old girl, Wei, who arrives in a remote village to be a substitute teacher and all-round care-giver to a large class of rowdy infants. She is hardly older or better educated than her charges and is tricked out of her agreed wage by a wily mayor, who promises her a bonus if she prevents any of the children dropping out of school - so when one leaves for the city to beg, Wei goes looking for him.

This film refuses the easy crescendos and crises of ordinary drama; it moves at a very slow walking pace, changing to a rising trot by the end. You feel the unnerving, yet exhilarating sense of having a window on real life, and the authentic story of a quietly unheroic heroism of someone young, frightened and poor.

fields.headline: Brothers
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Cliched... derivative, shallow material
fields.body: Martin Dunkerton's debut feature Brothers is an Ibiza Uncovered/Is Harry on the Boat?-type caper, with a hint of a coming-of-age drama about a group of friends who after that summer were never the same again, etc. It's cliched, with some naff Fatboy Slim on the soundtrack, ponderous emotional moments and sub-OU riffs about philosophers. Dunkerton now needs to show he can move on from this derivative, shallow material.

fields.headline: Bats
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: An old-fashioned B-movie... Reasonably entertaining hokum
fields.body:
Bats is an old-fashioned B-movie starring Lou Diamond Phillips about, well, a swarm of killer bats secretly developed by a creepy official agency as a form of biological warfare. Then the darned things get out of control and the wholesome Texan sky is dark with fluttering bats the size of poodles.

John Carpenter's Vampires managed this sort of thing with a bit more wit and style, but this is reasonably entertaining hokum.
