fields.headline: The Next Best Thing
fields.standfirst: Madonna's latest film could have been a Kramer Vs Kramer for the 21st century. But, says Peter Bradshaw, it lacks the light touch
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: What lets it down from the word go - what sinks this film with all hands - is the relentlessly heavy-handed feel to the whole enterprise
fields.body:
With her Irish setter hair, invisible goatee beard, Popeye arms and a trace of a decaf limey accent, Madonna is back with her stately new film vehicle, The Next Best Thing - which turns out to double, exasperatingly, as a feature-length promo-showcase for her cover version of American Pie.

Dismayingly queenly, and pervasively, subtly humourless and unrelaxed, Madonna plays Abbie, a yoga instructor in LA. Abbie's job is funkily to instruct her various classes, and there's even a scene in which, broodingly alone, she does a very complicated black-belt yoga manoeuvre involving lots of tricky supple things, although this is filmed in long shot. Abbie is smart, funny and has what her outgoing boyfriend crisply informs us is a "fantastic body". Yet she can't find a man and yearns for a baby.

As fortune would have it, she is best friends with Robert (Rupert Everett), a designer gardener, gay, recently jilted. They are lonely; a one-night-only sexual chemistry sparks between the two of them; Abbie gets pregnant. And so a thoroughly modern Millie, 21st-century solution suggests itself: they will set up house together; Robert will be a father to the child - but they can both date as if she was a single mom, and he her gay buddy, sharing house.

It's a seductively contemporary-sounding ménage, a witty fictional response to the Blairite/Clintonite quasi-liberal politics of upholding family values while at the same time trying to redefine the "family". It appears to challenge assumptions from all sides of the sexual politics spectrum; and as gay men might tire of the hedonistic stereotype, so straight men might feel envious of what appears to be gay men's unmediated access to female friendship. (Tina Brown's Talk magazine recently suggested that women desire emotionally intelligent men who are JGE - Just Gay Enough.)

It's not an entirely new idea, though: as recently as 1998, Nicholas Hytner's The Object of My Affection had a very similar high concept, and as for the idea of a gay man having intensely loving feelings for his children within a conventional marital household, there is the example of Oscar Wilde - which, oddly, is never invoked in this film.

But what lets it down from the word go - what sinks this film with all hands - is the relentlessly heavy-handed feel to the whole enterprise. John Schlesinger directs with granite gloves. Effectively, Rupert Everett is being asked to reprise and extend his grandstanding performance in My Best Friend's Wedding, complete with rapid-response cellphone advice, mercurial wit, playacting, singing in public, etc etc.

But where that performance had lightness and insouciant style, his screen presence here is freighted with brow-furrowing earnestness and moments in which Everett has to break down in tears and - inevitably - come to terms with his own father. Finally, Abbie and Robert's household falls apart on the question of who gets the child when a relationship of Abbie's gets serious, and Rupert finds himself in a very self-conscious new version of Kramer Vs Kramer, with Everett as a taller, handsomer and better dressed Dustin Hoffman.

The family courts in the state of California, are represented, I sense accurately, as pretty reactionary in the matter of gays and childcare: for a reversal of roles, it's interesting to consider Mike Newell's The Good Father from 1987, which had Anthony Hopkins as a man inciting his friend, played by Jim Broadbent, to contest his estranged wife's and her female lover's application for child custody. In the time of Kramer and The Good Father, gay politics and gender politics could be a bitter and acrimonious bone of contention between the principals themselves; here, a heavy consensus notionally reigns and that kind of high-octane opposition is off the agenda, leaving only a squishy, touchy-feely sense of sadness.

None of this need have been a problem, had it not been that Madonna never fully inhabits her role, never for one moment forgets her mission to attain seriousness and maturity in a new medium - yet clearly considers it expedient to keep in touch with her music fan base. (At one point she says allusively: "I've made up my mind, and I'm having this baby.")

Madonna gives an averagely competent account of herself, yet the magic ingredient of believable spontaneity and fun is missing from the first half of the film, and absent from the second half are the real anger and real pain that go with the end of all relationships.

fields.headline: Summer preview
fields.standfirst: Peter Bradshaw picks his top 10 up-and-coming movies
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw picks his top 10 up-and-coming movies
fields.body:
In some ways, the really big summer movie came out in the spring: Gladiator. But there's plenty to look forward to anyway:

1 M:i-2 That's Mission: Impossible 2 to you: Tom Cruise is back as pertly youthful special agent Ethan Hunt, up for all manner of stunts and scrapes, and falling in love with beautiful thief Thandie Newton. The extravaganza is directed by John Woo, who choreographs some sleek and sexy action sequences and gives Tom a tasty, Brucey little cut to the cheek.

2 High Fidelity Master craftsman Stephen Frears returns with a chipper version of Nick Hornby's 90s bestseller about Rob, the owner of a vinyl-only record shop who is dumped by his girlfriend. The dingy North London locale is transplanted to bright and breezy Chicago. The excellent John Cusack stars, as well as co-producing and co-writing.

3 Gone in 60 Seconds No-brainers don't come much no-brainier than this remake of a 70s car heist movie, produced by Jerry Bruckheimer: enjoyable Twoc-shlock. Nicolas Cage is a retired car thief who has to steal 50 automobiles in one night, or a sinister limey crimelord played by Christopher Eccleston will murder his brother (Giovanni Ribisi). There's a mostly mute cameo from Vinnie Jones, some uproarious stunts, and it's always good to see a battered old car floating through the air in slow motion, having been driven at improbable speed up a ramp.

4 O Brother, Where Art Thou? The Coen brothers are back, with a Depression-era screwball comedy in homage to Preston Sturges. Loosely (and I do mean loosely) structured on Homer's Odyssey, it is about the adventures of George Clooney as a fast-talking, wise-cracking convict who busts out of a prison chain gang with buddies John Turturro and Tim Blake Nelson, and ends up inadvertently forming America's most popular bluegrass band.

5 Dancer in the Dark Lars Von Trier's new film made a sensational splash at Cannes this year. It stars Björk as a factory worker who is going blind and takes refuge in an inner fantasy life of musicals. I am one of the unbelievers about this film, but it is distinctive. The opening sequence with Björk and Catherine Deneuve rehearsing an am-dram Sound of Music is in its way inspired. I predict this will be the summer's art-house talking-point.

6 The Yards This is a downbeat New York thriller about corrupt municipal politics and crime, directed by James "Little Odessa" Gray. James Caan gives a steely performance as the boss of a rolling stock firm who gives his ex-con nephew Mark Wahlberg a job working alongside the deeply unreliable Joaquin Phoenix.

fields.headline: Boost for Labour heartlands
fields.standfirst:
Hundreds of millions pumped into regions in move to narrow north-south divide
North-south divide: special report
fields.trailText: The government will use next month's spending review to pump hundreds of millions of pounds into England's regions in an effort to close the north-south divide and rally support in its traditional heartlands.
fields.body:
The government will use next month's spending review to pump hundreds of millions of pounds into England's regions in an effort to close the north-south divide and rally support in its traditional heartlands.

Senior ministers will announce a new blueprint for the regeneration of rundown areas at a summit meeting in Birmingham today attended by the eight chairmen of the year-old English regional development agencies.

In return for extra cash and greater flexibility, the RDAs will be told that they will be expected to hit tough, treasury-monitored targets for generating clusters of geographically concentrated firms, creating links between business and higher education and ensuring the provision of finance for new start-up firms.

The move, which follows pressure from the RDAs to be given greater freedom of action, reflects government concern at the marked variation in economic conditions across the UK, with regional disposable income ranging from £11,084 a head in London to £8,080 a head in the north-east. Four ministers - the chancellor, Gordon Brown, the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, the education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, and industry minister Richard Caborn will attend today's meeting.

They will present a paper drawn up jointly by Ed Balls, the treasury's chief economic adviser, and Joe Irvine, the special adviser to John Prescott at the department for the environment, transport and the regions, which offers extra money in return for progress in meeting government regeneration goals. The paper says that the government is trying to strike a balance between ensuring that its priorities are delivered while allowing RDAs "to be innovative, to tailor interventions to regional characteristics and to best meet the economic development needs of their regions, and to demonstrate their capabilities."

The paper says: "There needs to be a strong regional dimension to government policies to promote economic growth. They key to raising regional productivity is to enable regions more fully to exploit their comparative advantages and to address those market failures."

Ministers believe that economic disparities within regions are at least as great as those between regions, and that "securing rising productivity in all the English regions is key to delivering the government's objective of high and stable levels of growth and employment in the UK".

Government sources said that the extra cash allocated in the comprehensive spending review would be skewed towards those regions of greatest need, but stressed that the aim was to streamline the process of regional aid so that the RDAs could allocate funds more effectively. Although Mr Brown is a strong supporter of RDAs, he will tell the chairmen today that they will need to build up a track record in order to secure government funding over the medium term.

The chancellor is particularly concerned by the regional discrepancies in business start-ups and will emphasise that one of the government's targets will be to promote "enterprise for all" across England.

fields.headline: Racist probation service shocks inspectors
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The probation service is infected by racism to "an unacceptable degree", the Home Office minister, Paul Boateng, said yesterday in the face of an official report showing that its approach to race equality has largely stood still over the past decade.
fields.body:
The probation service is infected by racism to "an unacceptable degree", the Home Office minister, Paul Boateng, said yesterday in the face of an official report showing that its approach to race equality has largely stood still over the past decade.

The chief inspector of probation, Sir Graham Smith, said he was "very disappointed" that his investigation had discovered a service that was suffering from complacency, having for years paid lip-service to race equality.

The probation inspectors who carried out the report as part of the government's response to the Stephen Lawrence inquiry were shocked by what they found.

The report said that white probation officers were uncomfortable dealing with black offenders, because they were terrified of being accused of racism. The result was that they produced pre-sentence reports, crucial in determining the penalty imposed by the court, which were of a poorer quality for black defendants than for white.

Mr Boateng said this could explain why defendants from ethnic minorities were given harsher sentences on average than white defendants.

Mr Smith said the report's findings were particularly depressing after the probation service had played a trail-blazing role on race equality work in the late 1980s and early 1990s.

The report said that many black probation staff had no confidence in the policies, while among some white staff the fear of being called racist outweighed fear of being found incompetent. While probation did attract significant numbers of black staff, few were employed at chief officer or other management level.

Too many black probation officers were failing in their initial year in the job, and those that did stay on lost out on promotion. A disproportionate number also faced disciplinary proceedings.

Mr Boateng said the fact that white probation officers felt uncomfortable dealing with black offenders must have an effect on the quality of pre-sentence reports and so of sentencing by the courts. "We already know there is a disproportionate number of black offenders and this is an indication that race equality is not just a problem for the police but for the whole criminal justice system."

The National Association of Probation Officers called for action. "The probation service pioneered equal opportunities and it is still well ahead of other agencies, but Napo is deeply concerned about the number of black staff failing their probationary year," spokesman Harry Fletcher said.

Sir Graham Smith said the inspectorate would follow up the report with all probation services being asked to review their equal opportunities policies and provide a progress report in October.

The report found that little common understanding existed across the 54 different probation services about what constituted racist behaviour. More than half the staff who completed a questionnaire said they had experienced racist behaviour during their work, about half of it from offenders, but the other half from colleagues or others in the criminal justice system.

webTitle: Former Tory minister cleared of punching woman

fields.headline: Former Tory minister cleared of punching woman
fields.trailText: Former Tory minister Rod Richards was today cleared of causing grievous bodily harm to a young woman at the end of a case which his QC said was a "classic cautionary tale for a middle-aged man at a loose end in London."
fields.body:
Former Tory minister Rod Richards was today cleared of causing grievous bodily harm to a young woman at the end of a case which his QC said was a "classic cautionary tale for a middle-aged man at a loose end in London."

Eight women and four male jurors took just under five hours to clear the former minister of punching 23-year-old Cassandra Melvin in the face and breaking her arm. Mr Richards of Cardiff resigned as Tory leader in the Welsh Assembly after the allegations made last summer.

During the five-day trial it was claimed that Mr Richards had attacked the woman outside her sister's flat in London. He admitted to the jury trying to chat them up and being less than "frank" in police interviews when first asked of his intentions with the women that night.

The three had gone back to the flat following a meal in a nearby pizzeria. Baroness Ann Mallalieu QC, defending, said he was not the first man to enjoy the flattery of taking two good-looking young women out for dinner.

"This is the very stuff of middle-aged fantasies and played out night after night in bars and restaurants up and down the country. You (the jury) may disapprove of such actions but if such conduct was a criminal offence the prisons of this land would be full to overflowing."

The prosecution alleged that Mr Richards, who had a previous conviction for violence when he was a student, was thrown out of the flat after making sexually offensive remarks towards the women. He was then said to have punched Cassandra in the face before throwing her into a parked car, breaking her arm.

In Mr Richards' version of events Ms Melvin told him to leave the flat. "As she was pushing me out, the front door was pushed effectively on my back and I was in the position of being squeezed out the door. I pushed the door back to make enough space to get out of the door. As I tried to leave the property I felt a push from behind me," Mr Richards told the jury.

He then said he hurried away from the scene before the situation worsened and the first he learned that something was wrong was when he was rung by the police on his mobile phone while driving home to Cardiff informing him of a "serious incident".

David Davies, the Tory's chief whip in Cardiff, said he had no doubt that Mr Richards would be found not guilty. "I never had the slightest doubt about his innocence and I have maintained that for the last year. It is just not within his character to behave in that fashion," he said. The party whip was withdrawn from Mr Richards earlier this year after he failed to vote with the Conservatives on the Assembly budget.

Outside the court his solicitor read a statement thanking Mr Richards's legal team. "He would further like to thank his wife, children, family and friends for their unwavering support throughout what has been an emotionally draining and personally stressful time of his life," he said. Mr Richards refused to take any questions and his solicitor would not comment on the state of the former Tory minister's marriage

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: Day thirteen

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: Day thirteen
fields.standfirst: Four men, armed with £50, aim to be the last man standing after 23 days of daily football betting. It's You Bet Your Life, brought to you in association with BlueSq
fields.trailText: After the weekend, there'll just be three days of gambling left. So is it any wonder that the stakes are getting higher and the bets more risky? Of course, it's all part of the fun. Have you filled in your slips yet?
fields.body:
After the weekend, there'll just be three days of gambling left. So is it any wonder that the stakes are getting higher and the bets more risky? Of course, it's all part of the fun. Have you filled in your slips yet?

The current standings:

Sean Ingle £67.69
Scott Murray £66.67
Mike Hodgkinson £47.08
Paul MacInnes £12.50

Our weekend's selections follow...

Sean Ingle

Saturday
Double: Hagi-Bargy evens and Portugal to win 4/11 (£7.69)

Hagi-Bargy isn't some new hippy-dippy alternative treatment, but an enticing side-bet over whether Romania's spiritual leader will be booked against Italy. I say he will, judging by his record so far - two matches, two bookings - and his volcanic temperament. And I throw in a small joss-stick of value by backing Portugal to beat Turkey as well.

Sunday
Holland v Yugoslavia: Draw after 90 minutes 2/1 (£10)

I know Holland are at home. And I know they were pretty impressive against France's reserve team. But they're not that good. And they're certainly not the overwhelming favourites the bookies make them out to be against Yugoslavia (who can be backed at 9/2). The two teams played out a close game in World Cup 98, so don't be surprised if they are still level after 90 minutes on Sunday.

Scott Murray

Saturday
Double: Portugal to win after 90 minutes 11/8 and Italy to win after 90 minutes 11/8 (£15)

The truth will out this weekend as the big teams pull out all the stops when it really matters. Portugal should be too strong for Turkey, whose star player Hakan Sukur will either be carrying an injury or not playing at all. Romania will struggle against the resurgent Italians as well: they're a couple of key men down and their only impressive displays have been against two of the weakest teams in the tournament.

Sunday
France v Spain: France to win after 90 minutes evens (£20)

The erratic Spanish are almost bound to self-destruct when faced with French poise, so a result for the world champions inside the ninety doesn't seem too ridiculous to contemplate. I'd love to see this entertaining Spanish side survive, mind you, so there'll be some consolation for me should my twenty quid go down the pan. He says now.

Mike Hodgkinson

Saturday
Portugal v Turkey: Portugal to beat Turkey 3-0 after 90 minutes 11/1 (£10)

I'm putting my faith not so much in the Portuguese attack but the hilarious Turkish defense. Having proved themselves to be the worst team in the tournament, they are utterly inappropriate guests in the quarter finals and I expect Portugal to show them the door in unceremonious fashion. The Portuguese, after all, have the most lethal attack in the tournament and will punish the laughable defensive abilities of Abdullah and co. Three times, to be precise.

Sunday
Holland v Yugoslavia: Draw after 90 minutes 2/1 (£10)

These are perhaps the two most erratic sides in the tournament. Okay, Holland had a 100% record in their group but always looked susceptible to pressure in every game. Yugoslavia are just as capable of scoring goals as they are of conceding them and enter into every game hell for leather. They should be able to exploit the persistently fragile Dutch confidence and secure a draw by the end of 90 minutes.

Paul MacInnes

Saturday
Portugal v Turkey: Portugal to win 2-1 7/1 (£4)

I think (although why I should listen to myself any more on these matters I don't know) that Turkey will give Portugal a tough game in Amsterdam. They've improved with each match so far and have the support of a delirious nation behind them. The Portuguese seem similarly determined however, and have a lot more ability at their disposal. So, a goal for Turkey, but a win for the Portuguese. Either that or the complete opposite. Or something in-between maybe.

Sunday
Spain v France: First goalscored G Mendieta 11/1 (£8.50)

If everything goes to plan, plan Z that is, then this will be my final bet. I like Mendieta, I like him a lot. I would marry him if it is was legal, but instead I will stake my remaining cash on his ability to find space around the box and get a shot off.

I might try this gambling thing again. Ciao.

fields.headline: Flop, Flip and Flap
fields.trailText: BOARD GAMES
fields.body:
BOARD GAMES

Kelvin Koogan still hasn't worked out how to play the magnetic board game the FA gave him when he became England manager. He tried using it last week, but only managed to arrange the little discs that came with it into a smiley sun, a tree, and a rather vulgar little stick man he christened 'Mr Front Tail'. But as for using it to detail complex tactical manoeuvres, forget it. The man clearly needs some help.

"[Kelvin] needs help in that department and he would accept that himself," pondered kindly FA chairman Geoff Thompson, looking on. "We have got a very good technical director," he meditated, accidentally airing his thought processes to a representative of the press at the same time. Acting on impulse - you don't become chairman of the FA for nothing, you know - he summoned Howard Wilkinson, who rushed in clutching a bag of magnetic arrows and marker pens in his eager little hands.

Sadly for Howard, it looks as though he'll not be getting his hands on Koog's discs. "Any changes to [Koogan's] back-up team are ultimately his responsibility and his alone," FA chief executive Adam Crozier said today, which suggests that Koog was none-too-receptive to the idea of listening to any of Wilkinson's ideas (but why?!?) and may have 'had a word'.

"[Kelvin] has had, and will continue to have, full responsibility for selecting the England team, its tactics and its performance on the pitch," Crozier added. Which sounds like great news if you don't want dour Howard anywhere near the England first eleven. But not so good when you take time to study what we're left with.

A SATURDAY IN THE LIFE OF GRANNY FIVER

5am

Rise in time for the dawn chorus on the sheltered housing lawn. Bell Vicky in reception for a reviving cuppa.

5.01am

That's better. Twelve hours to go until the Portugal v Turkey quarter final. Sit and contemplate the match for a while.

4.30pm

Wake from my reverie to find Master Gary in my living room introducing the match. Charming, but what is that foreign johnny alongside him saying?

5pm

No Mr Big Ron to suggest that Portugal tend to take it Easy José at the back stick. Looking to benefit is Mr Hakan Suker. That crafty Turk general manager Can Cobanoglu - can he? But he was not just a Birmingham babe magnet, he told himself: he was also a tactical genius and man-manager. Oh yeah! Because 70 minutes into the FA Cup final, his plan to bore Chelsea into submission was working absolutely...

Flap, flap, flap, flap, flap! And then it all started to go horribly wrong. First Villa lost the FA Cup final. Damn right, John. At least David Ginola looks like he's heading to Villa Park. Manchester City have again been linked with a £4m move for Leeds striker Alan Smith.

Rangers will play FK Zalgiris Kaunas of Lithuania or NK Brotnjo of Bosnia in the second qualifying round of Big Cup. Celtic will play Luxembourg's AS Jeunesse Esch in the first round of Euro-Vase, while Hearts head north to take on Icelandic side IBV Vestmannaeyjar. Aberdeen are at home to Irish side Bohemians.

Ipswich have signed 25-year-old Dutch international midfield player Martijn Reuser from Vitesse Arnhem for £1m - with a further £250,000 to be paid if the club retain their Premiership status next season.

fields.headline: Pegasus Apparel Group
fields.trailText: Fashion is sooo incestuous. Where business acquisitions are concerned at least, confusion is rife. If you can get your head around the fact that Gucci owns YSL while it wants to buy Armani, Prada, not Jil Sander, owns Jil Sander, and LVMH owns just about everything, including a bit of Gucci, you may (or may not) be pleased to know that there is now another big name to remember: Pegasus Apparel Group.
fields.body:
Fashion is sooo incestuous. Where business acquisitions are concerned at least, confusion is rife. If you can get your head around the fact that Gucci owns YSL while it wants to buy Armani, Prada, not Jil Sander, owns Jil Sander, and LVMH owns just about everything, including a bit of Gucci, you may (or may not) be pleased to know that there is now another big name to remember: Pegasus Apparel Group.

Pegasus (for short) is a newly founded conglomerate with an $800m private equity fund behind it. With all that dough, the group, headed by Stephen Ruzow (big name fashion bod previously at the helm of Donna Karan), is aiming to acquire 10 fashion companies in the next two years. At the moment, they own the likes of Miguel Adrover (part of his autumn/ winter 2000 collection is pictured above), Daryl K and Pamela Dennis, and this week they added to the list American trendy Nanette Lepore. They also hope to snap up John Bartlett and Cynthia Rowley.

Pegasus are, in other words, shopping for companies like we shop for shoes. But whereas big names such as LVMH are after the Jimmy Choos of the fashion world, Pegasus is scouring Brick Lane shoe stalls for the next big thing. All their acquisitions so far are of trendy young things, designers who aren't in the big league yet but soon will be. (Miguel Adrover, for example, was anointed this year's Best New Designer by the US fashion council, CFDA.) Thus this is a name to watch out for. The future of fashion is in their hands.

fields.headline: Most wanted
fields.standfirst: ...Slingbies
fields.trailText: ...Slingbies
fields.body: A woman's hosiery drawer is a curious thing. Most men would have a difficult time believing that all the stockings, socks, sockettes and footsies bundled inside had any relevance to the female anatomy, or indeed to modern life. "What are those funny little nylon bits?" a boyfriend once asked as a pair of deodorised popsocks fell out of my bedroom drawer one morning. It's OK for them: a drawerful of thick ribbed socks and they're happy. Dressing the female foot is a harder thing altogether - especially when the weather gets hot. The more elegant the shoe, the more agony inflicted on the toes and heels - which is where all those funny little nylon bits come in. Spotted on a recent trip to John Lewis was something we never knew existed: Slingbies (priced £2.49 from Pretty Polly, stockist enquiries 01623 552500). Perfect for wearing under this season's elegant slingbacks, they represent bunion-free heaven. So don't laugh until you've tried them.

fields.headline: Most everywhere
fields.standfirst: ...scissor-cut T-shirts
fields.trailText: ...scissor-cut T-shirts
fields.body:
Customisation has reached epidemic proportions. Now that designer looks are in the high street before you can say "Prada Bowli ..." the smart money has realised that DIY is the only way to achieve true originality. After contenting ourselves with sticking studs on to tops, fixing diamantés on to jeans and adding bits of lace to our vests, enter, stage left, the new scissor phenomenon: instead of adding things to clothes, we are now attacking them with very sharp objects.

Silly as it may seem to those outside fashion parameters, it is now all the rage to wear T-shirts that are slashed at the neck, cut in tassels at the bottom, with little holes cut out all over. The appeal being that this is one trend that is completely free and can be created by anyone, regardless of artistic talent. "I saw them in Urban Outfitters for £30 and thought I could do it myself," says one London-based fashion ladette, who likes "adding an original touch to a plain top".

It's really very easy: simply take a T-shirt (with or without logo), snip, snip, snip, and it's instantly transformed from mundane to, er, extremely fashionable indeed. You can create any pattern you want - diamonds, hearts, even the girls-holding-hands you cut out of paperchains as a kid, if you're feeling ambitious. Fun for the moment but watch out: this trend will have expired by, oh, the end of next week.

fields.headline: Monkey business
fields.standfirst: His slogan is 'Paul Frank is your friend' and who wouldn't want to be the man's friend when his cartoon-based design company is bringing him fame and fortune?
fields.trailText: You might not know his name, but you will have already met Julius the monkey. You will have seen him clinging to skinny young chests in fashionable bars; grinning at you from wallets flashed in cool checkout queues; winking from Cameron Diaz's handbag, Drew Barrymore's vest top and Graham Coxon's guitar strap. On all kinds of accessories in fashion stores across the world (New York, Tokyo, Hoxton), Julius is the cheeky, chic-y monkey who can't believe he is making so many friends - or earning so much fortune and fame for his master.
fields.body:
You might not know his name, but you will have already met Julius the monkey. You will have seen him clinging to skinny young chests in fashionable bars; grinning at you from wallets flashed in cool checkout queues; winking from Cameron Diaz's handbag, Drew Barrymore's vest top and Graham Coxon's guitar strap. On all kinds of accessories in fashion stores across the world (New York, Tokyo, Hoxton), Julius is the cheeky, chic-y monkey who can't believe he is making so many friends - or earning so much fortune and fame for his master.

His master is Paul Frank, a 32-year-old Californian designer whose name and cheesy-breezy slogan - "Paul Frank is your friend" - appears on the labels of Julius merchandise. Frank's graphics are inspired by skatewear and American commercial art of the 50s and 60s, and Julius the monkey is the most popular of the characters that decorate Paul Frank accessories. The label's global success is a lesson in the huge sales potential to be had from combining a clever cartoon-vision with a knack for bags and T-shirts. Frank started off hand-stitching wallets in a garage in 1995; now Paul Frank Industries employs 30 people, earns over five million dollars per year and is redefining the rules of merchandise and media.

Frank dresses like a geek-trendy (dark denim, rugs as sideburns, Joe 90 specs) and speaks with a bizarre childlike naivety, as if he is a little terrified by his success. It's rather like talking to a character from a Belle and Sebastian song, albeit one that has relocated to Costa Mesa (near San Diego) and can afford "fancy cars". He had no formal design training, but took art classes after he left high school, teaching himself to draw by "sitting in a library forcing myself to draw Huckleberry Hound over and over again". His mom bought him a sewing machine when he was 25, because he had developed a taste for stitching extra stripes on to his Jack Purcell trainers, and his ex-girlfriend Daiquiri helped him to the next level. (They split because she thought his fame would drive them apart, but he still "really loves" her.) She and he would draw animals on their notes to each other and one day he drew her a monkey, based on a sock puppet his grandmother had once given him. The monkey became Julius.

In the mid-90s, Frank was working on a newsstand in his home town, occasionally knocking things up for friends on his sewing machine. He would take backpacks and purses apart to see how they were made, then make patterns for his own. One day, he showed his friend Ryan Heuser a bag and wallet he'd made to match one of Daiquiri's dresses. Ryan, a PR for Mossimo, saw sellability; he set himself and Frank up in business, then in 1997 brought in John Oswald, an investment broker, as a third partner. ("They protect me from business," Frank says. "I can't deal with that world. I'm like a kid.") Investment money meant Frank could quit the newsstand, go to trade fairs and employ freelance sales representatives. When the orders from Japan started coming in, they began to contract out patterns to manufacturers. They haven't looked back.

They took Paul Frank's name for the company partly because he wanted to do homeware (his heroes are mid-century modernist furniture designers such as Charles and Ray Eames, George Nelson and Arne Jacobsen) and he thought a simple name would transfer better than a streetwear brand name. More worthily, Frank maintains a direct personal involvement in his designs; he still draws all the patterns for the bags himself, starting with cardboard models he makes at home, and each piece is designed individually according to the character appearing on it.

He has developed a personal fan base with his eponymous position and author-like signings; he makes appearances at shops, autographing his clothes with a little monkey or giraffe and making mental notes about his audience. "I get to meet customers at signings," he says, saucer-eyed, "and it helps me know more about them. They always seem excited - I guess the monkey makes people get a nice feeling inside. It reminds us of when we were little."

Which it surely does, though there are multiple layers of nostalgia in Paul Frank's work. The referencing of clean, mid-century-modern commercial graphics, and his bags evoking 60s jet-set culture, link him to a contemporary kind of kitsch (Tiki revival, New York and LA lounge clubs, the art direction of Wallpaper, the pop artist Shag) that has held sway with a certain set of twenty- and thirtysomething Americans for the past two or three years. It is this combination of cute and clever that lies at the heart of his appeal.

As for the future, Paul Frank Industries have just opened their first stand-alone retail outlet, in Costa Mesa, and are planning more; there will be more furniture and eventually an entire lifestyle range. Frank is also painting pictures for a gallery exhibition and collaborating on some designs with Shag. The company has entered into a partnership with a new media group which will allow Frank to develop his characters into animated cartoons on 25 websites, as well as into children's books, collecting them under the umbrella title "Julius and Friends". Creatures such as Sir Randolph the gorilla, Clancy the giraffe, Worry Bear the polar bear and Skurvy the skull and crossbones will be given histories, personalities and voices in the first-ever example of entertainment content being developed from merchandise, rather than vice versa.

There are rumours that TV networks are interested, too. Any deals in this regard are sure to be watched closely by a) those interested in the overlapping of the fashion and entertainment industries and b) anyone who ever thought one of their idle doodles might look good on a T-shirt. In today's global fashion climate, you never know where that small garage enterprise might lead you.

Any deals in this regard are sure to be watched closely by a) those interested in the overlapping of the fashion and entertainment industries and b) anyone who ever thought one of their idle doodles might look good on a T-shirt. In today's global fashion climate, you never know where that small garage enterprise might lead you.

fields.headline: Here comes summer
fields.standfirst: Want to be a hit on the beach?  Laura Craik explains how
fields.trailText: Want to be a hit on the beach? Laura Craik explains how
fields.body:
Y'know that plain black one-piece lurking at the bottom of your lingerie drawer? Make sure it stays there. Do not under any circumstances let it see the light of day all summer - unless, that is, you want to be tragically out of fashion. This season, the same rules apply to swimwear as to the rest of the fashion landscape: minimalism is more out than Stephen Gately.

This is confusing, of course, because if anything benefits from being minimal, it's your swimwear. The whole point of swimwear is to ensure you get a tan - a nice, even one with as few strap marks as possible. So we'd best make one thing clear right now: the swimsuits pictured here are not for sunbathing in. They're for posing in. Fabrics more commonly featured on eveningwear now crop up shamelessly on beachwear: beading, embroidery, snakeskin prints and shiny metallics. Call it a continuation of this season's trend for maximalism, but summer's swimwear has been well and truly Lopez'd. Just like Jennifer, it knows that more is always more.

Wanna wear a diamanté necklace by the pool? Or a gold chain snaking round your belly? Go for it. Never mind if people stare - if you can't over-accessorise on holiday, when are you supposed to indulge yourself? Even if your holiday budget only stretches to a week in an eggbox in Benidorm, you must dress as though you're a guest on Donatella's yacht as it sails to the Maldives. Liz Hurley's best friend, if you like. Or even (why not?) Liz Hurley herself - minus the dummy. Some accessories are never a good idea.

A piece of advice: despite the current vogue for deep mahogany tans, only the daftest women are still seeking them on the beach. The truly stylish arrive at their destination already brown, from a bottle. True posers are too busy posing to lie frying for six hours. Besides, lobster-red is not a good look. It certainly doesn't work with diamanté.

webTitle: Met chief says cuts are making blue line thinner

fields.headline: Met chief says cuts are making blue line thinner
fields.standfirst: Crime: special report
fields.trailText: Sir John Stevens, the Metropolitan police commissioner, warned yesterday that he will not be able to police London "with confidence" if the number of officers in his force continues to fall.
fields.body:
Sir John Stevens, the Metropolitan police commissioner, warned yesterday that he will not be able to police London "with confidence" if the number of officers in his force continues to fall.

Sir John spoke of a "recruitment crisis" in London which he blamed on government cuts.

"We have reached a point where I am going to have to say publicly that unless we get some massive changes we do not have enough officers to police London with confidence," he told a lunch at the Westminter press gallery.

Home secretary Jack Straw will respond to Sir John's warning today by announcing that the government is to restore the housing allowance for Met officers which was withdrawn by the Tories in 1994.

But Sir John's intervention will damage the government which has spent the past year fending off Tory attacks on dwindling police numbers. Ann Widdecombe, the shadow home secretary, said Sir John's speech showed how the government had let down the police and the public.

Sir John said his force was failing to attract enough recruits because of low pay and poor conditions. He welcomed the restoration of the housing allowance but said this did not go far enough.

"Recruitment in the Metropolitan police is at its lowest number of officers for 20 years," he said. "We have 25,480 officers to police London - five years ago there were 28,200. I need to maintain at least 25,600 officers if I am to police London with confidence. Unless we sort out the pay issue, my classrooms at Hendon will remain empty and shifts all over London will be stretched to breaking point."

Sir John said that a recent £2.5m recruitment campaign to boost numbers had been a failure. Hundreds of officers were also trying to leave the Met - 68 officers have joined a queue to join a force in South Wales.

Many officers were determined to leave because of the Met's "poor image". Sir John said: "I wonder if at times the press is institutionally downbeat on what we achieve. We have some incredibly courageous and breathtakingly brave officers doing amazing things but we see little of it in the press."

Sir John qualified his stark warning over recruitment by talking of the progress made by the Met since the publication of the Macpherson report on the investigation of the murder of the black teenager, Stephen Lawrence. "I believe we have come a very long way into the way my force dealt with the murder of Stephen Lawrence," he said. "We cannot change history but we can learn from it and use the lessons learnt as a platform to take us forward."

Miss Widdecombe said that Labour had cut police numbers in London by 1,700 officers, leading to an upsurge in violent crime.

"Labour have created more victims of crime and fear of crime across our capital," she said. "Their arrogant failure to heed the concerns of people like John Stevens are a damning indictment of three years of New Labour and a hammer blow to morale."Fred Broughton, the chairman of the Police Federation, warned last month of a crisis of confidence over police numbers.

In a speech to the federation's annual conference, Mr Straw announced that he would accelerate plans for forces to recruit 5,000 more officers over the next two years. There would be £59m for new recruitment this year, allowing for an extra 3,000 officers nationally.

Mr Straw dismissed Tory attacks on the government over falling police numbers, saying that the decline started under the last government.

webTitle: Dutch driver remanded on Dover death charge

fields.headline: Dutch driver remanded on Dover death charge
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: A Dutch lorry driver, accused of the manslaughter of 58 Chinese immigrants, was today remanded in custody for seven days
fields.body:
A Dutch lorry driver was today remanded in custody for seven days when he appeared in court accused of the manslaughter of 58 Chinese immigrants found dead in the back of a sealed truck in Dover.

Perry Wacker, 32, of Rotterdam, is also charged with illegally bringing two people into Britain and illegally attempting to bring the other 58 into the country at the port in Kent on Sunday night.

Mr Wacker spoke only to confirm his name and acknowledge that he understood the charges against him at Folkestone magistrates court. He was remanded in custody to reappear on June 30.

The 58 bodies and two survivors were found in the back of a sealed refrigeration container at Dover just before midnight on Sunday night by Customs officers.

An inquest into the deaths is due to be opened in Dover this afternoon by south and east Kent coroner Richard Sturt. Post mortem examinations have shown that 58 people died of suffocation.

The two survivors are now being interviewed at length by specially trained police officers using interpreters at a safe-house in Kent under armed police guard.

A Kent police spokesman today said officers were also continuing to question a Chinese man and woman who were arrested in connection with the incident in Canterbury late on Tuesday night. Officers have until late on Saturday to continue questioning the man and woman from London.

Meanwhile Dutch police were continuing to question two men who were arrested on Tuesday in relation to smuggling.

One of them is Arie van der Spek, 24, who registered a freight company in Holland days before the lorry carrying the Chinese illegal immigrants came to Dover.

Kent police today said a group of Chinese immigrants detained by Belgian police in April, who's release was captured on film, were not the same group as those whose bodies were found in Dover on Sunday.

webTitle: Blowing hot and cold in Ulster

fields.headline: Blowing hot and cold in Ulster
fields.standfirst:
The decision by the loyalist paramilitary UFF to suspend its threat to end its ceasefire may seem absurd, but reflects increasing unease about the security situation in the province
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Friday, 3.30pm: The decision by the loyalist UFF to suspend its threat to end its ceasefire may seem absurd, but reflects increasing unease about the security situation in the province, writes former Northern Ireland correspondent Derek Brown.
fields.body:
The loyalist paramilitary group calling itself the Ulster Freedom Fighters (UFF) has withdrawn its threat to end its ceasefire. But in its latest typically bombastic statement, it has warned that attacks on Protestant homes in Belfast "cannot be tolerated".

The now-you-see-us, now-you-don't tactics of the UFF may seem absurd from outside the province, but they reflect increasing unease about the security situation as the loyalist marching season gets seriously under way.

The UFF threatened to call off its six-year-old ceasefire - it has been broken once already, in 1997-98 - following a series of ugly communal confrontations in west Belfast. Tension is high in the city, with an Orange Order parade due to take place close to Catholic homes tomorrow.

Another loyalist march is due to take place in Portadown, close to the staunchly Catholic Garvaghy Road, scene of many bloody communal clashes. There have been disturbances at both flashpoints within the last 24 hours.

Earlier this week, two Catholic men were wounded by an explosion at their home close to the main trouble spot in Belfast. Suspicion is hardening that the men, a father and son, were assembling a small bomb, and that they could be connected with one of the republican splinter groups, the so called Real IRA and the Continuity IRA, opposed to the fragile peace accord.

To raise the temperature even further, unionist politicians are once more rumbling with discontent about the failure of the main IRA faction to open their arms dumps for independent inspection.

Under the complex formula which allowed the resumption of power-sharing devolved government last month, the IRA is supposed to open its weapons dumps to international inspectors, who will then periodically check that the arms have been put "beyond use".

Unionist hardliners are angry that there have been no such inspections. Now the delay is likely to be lengthened by the incapacity of one of the two principal inspectors, former Finnish president Martti Ahtisaari, who is due to enter hospital for knee surgery before the end of June.

fields.headline: Let the regions decide
fields.standfirst: The government is right to highlight the disparities in wealth within individual regions of Britain, says northern editor Martin Wainwright
fields.trailText: The government is right to highlight the disparities in wealth within individual regions of Britain, says northern editor Martin Wainwright.
fields.body:
Joseph Wan, the head of posh people's shop Harvey Nichols, made an interesting decision this week which has an urgent bearing on today's regional summit in Birmingham hosted by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, and the chancellor, Gordon Brown.

Government leaders from Whitehall and the regions are concerned to avoid simplistic "north-south" thinking in their plans to pump millions of extra pounds into lagging parts of the country. Mr Wan is a perfect model for them.

He signed a contract for a new Harvey Nichols store in Manchester, only the fourth outside London, and - significantly - less than 40 miles from the thriving branch in Leeds.

How can this be, when Harvey Nicks has repeatedly turned down Birmingham, the home of today's summit, fearing that a Midlands store would "cannibalise" trade at the flagship branch in Knightsbridge, London, where plenty of wealthy Brummies have accounts?

Mr Wan sums up his reasons by saying: "people don't seem to want to cross the Pennines to shop". In other words, there is money aplenty along the M62 corridor; wads of it in Wilmslow and bucketfuls in Boroughbridge. Absolutely not the north of cobble-and-white myth - this is a part of Britain where the economy is going at full steam.

But within miles of such prosperity, there are truly alarming blackspots. Indeed, the corridor has a European Union objective 1 area dangling from either end: Merseyside and South Yorkshire, which fall into the lowest tranche of European performance and so qualify for maximum help.

The fact that there is only one other objective 1 area in Britain, Cornwall, also supports New Labour's concern that the phrase "north-south divide" does not get overused.

Simplistic doling out of money from the centre to the edges already has a deadly example in the UK - the Barnett formula, which the Treasury has used since 1978 to parcel out subsidy to Scotland and Wales.

Joel (now Lord) Barnett admitted at the time that this was a back-of-a-postcard job to tackle a crisis and has recently begged for this growing embarrassment to his name to be consigned to the bin.

Calculations made by a chief secretary to the Treasury 22 years ago have little or no relation with the index of need outside London in the year 2000. The only appeal of the formula is, alas, the very powerful political one of keeping Scottish and Welsh voters loyal.

Mr Prescott faces the same temptation in relation to the much-talked-about Labour heartlands, especially in the north. But the signs are that the Birmingham summit will resist such a Tammany Hall approach to allocating regional funds. The people who know best where the greatest need is are the regional leaders, especially the members of the eight regional development agencies, whose chairs are they key figures at the summit.

The guidance document for them, drawn up by a group including Mr Brown's right-hand man, Ed Balls of the Treasury (whose wife, Yvette Cooper MP, happens to represent the deprived constituency of Pontefract and Castleford), is reassuring about this.

Its approach of setting the business-dominated regional development agencies tough targets for job-creation and inward investment sits well with what seems to be a genuine willingness to put them in charge of funding distribution within each region.

London is often a useful backstop and court of appeal. But the people on the spot, and especially those with experience of wealth-creation and employment (from the trades union as well as management side), really do know the complicated pattern of prosperity and poverty best.

webTitle: Graham executed after failure of appeal

fields.headline: Graham executed after failure of appeal
fields.standfirst: Which state kills the most?
fields.trailText: Gary Graham was executed at shortly after 3am London time. He left a long, angry final statement in which he accused his jailors of brutality, and the American state  of genocide. He asked that his case be taken to international courts, and reportedly struggled to his last against his executioners.
fields.body:
Gary Graham was executed at shortly after 3am London time. He left a long, angry final statement in which he accused his jailors of brutality, and the American state of genocide. He asked that his case be taken to international courts, and reportedly struggled to his last against his executioners.

Graham, who had vowed to "fight like hell" on the trip to the death chamber, appeared to have put up a struggle. He was strapped to the gurney around his wrists and across his head - more restraints than are normally used in Texas executions.

He made a long, defiant final statement in which he reasserted his innocence and said he was being lynched. "I die fighting for what I believed in," Graham said. "The truth will come out."

The execution was witnessed by supporters that included the Rev. Jesse Jackson, the Rev. Al Sharpton and Amnesty International representative Bianca Jagger.

Bush said he supported the execution and pointed out that Graham's case had been reviewed by 33 state and federal judges.

"After considering all of the facts I am convinced justice is being done," Bush said after final appeals were denied. "May God bless the victim, the family of the victim, and may God bless Mr. Graham."

Outside the Huntsville prison, hundreds of Graham supporters gathered in stifling heat and humidity near the brick building where 222 executions have now been carried out since capital punishment resumed in Texas in 1982. The total is by far the highest in the nation.

When the Texas parole board, made up of 18 Bush appointees, refused to block the execution, that left the Republican governor with no options. The single 30-day reprieve a Texas governor may unilaterally give a condemned inmate was issued to Graham by Bush's predecessor in 1993.

The parole board, which has spared a prisoner only once during Bush's tenure, could have granted a 120-day reprieve, a commutation to a lesser sentence, or a conditional pardon.

"I can say, unequivocally, that the board's decision not to recommend clemency was reached after a complete and unbiased review of the petition and evidence submitted," board chairman Gerald Garrett said, hours before the execution.

The Supreme Court, a federal judge and state appeals court also turned down Graham's last-minute appeals, which delayed the execution for more than two hours.

webTitle: Deal could end Fiji hostage crisis

fields.headline: Deal could end Fiji hostage crisis
fields.standfirst: Coup in Fiji: special report
fields.trailText: 3pm update: Gunmen holding 31 political hostages in Fiji and the country's military rulers today struck a deal that could end the captives' 36-day ordeal soon, according to negotiators.
fields.body:
Gunmen holding 31 political hostages in Fiji and the country's military rulers today struck a deal that could end the captives' 36-day ordeal soon, according to negotiators.

Military commander commodore Frank Bainimarama and rebel leader George Speight planned to sign the accord on Saturday, following a breakthrough in negotiations after six days of talks, the spokesmen said.

Metuisela Mua, one of Mr Speight's advisers, said the hostages could be released any time after the signing, possibly within hours. Such a deal would end the standoff at parliament. But it also could leave Fiji open to widespread criticism and even economic sanctions by other countries. The accord is expected to scrap some of Fiji's democratic traditions, reduce the rights of its ethnic Indian minority and grant an amnesty to the coup plotters.

Minority Indians already are fleeing the country in large numbers and reports of the agreement to end the crisis are not expected to persuade them to stay. Mr Speight and an armed gang stormed parliament on May 19, taking prime minister Mahendra Chaudhry and other members of his government hostage.

Mr Speight claims to be acting on behalf of the indigenous majority, whose rights, he said, were trampled upon by Mr Chaudhry. But some observers say Mr Speight's motives are not ideological. Joe Gudace, a former senior official in Mr Chaudhry's government, said he believed Mr Speight was acting on behalf of Fijians who have lost their ability to make favourable business deals under Mr Chaudhry.

Sugar, the nation's cash crop, lies at the core of Fiji's troubles. Indian farmers built the industry by operating plantations on land that is communally owned by indigenous Fijians and leased at low rates set by English colonial law. Those leases are due to be renewed, and the refusal by Mr Chaudhry's government to accept demands for higher rents on the land enraged many Fijians. The relatively affluent ethnic Indian minority operates most of the business sector in Fiji.

Asked if an agreement had been reached, rebel spokesman Jo Nata said, "Yes." The final wording of the accord, however, was still being hammered out, and details were not released.

webTitle: Cherubs stripped for cash - but is it art?

fields.headline: Cherubs stripped for cash - but is it art?
fields.standfirst: Valuable masterpieces rubbished, drinkers slate art sale, soccer fans drive on by  and something ratty amid the white high heels
fields.trailText: Valuable masterpieces rubbished, drinkers slate art sale, soccer fans drive on by  and something ratty amid the white high heels
fields.body:
DIY chiphoard
Artistically not a great deal has happened in Bradford since David Hockney packed up his brushes and moved to America. At least not until this week, when a local man uncovered three rare and valuable paintings whilst stripping down the doors of his house.

Mohammed Mangoo, of Four Lane Ends, was in the process of renovating his home when he discovered the paintings, which had been painted onto the house's original wooden doors but subsequently covered over with chipboard. Unimpressed with the images of cherubs and young girls, Mr. Mangoo's initial reaction was to throw the doors out but his daughters Parveen and Narjif, pleaded with him to keep them.

Their caution proved justified when it turned out that the pictures were by renowned Victorian artist William Stephen Coleman. "His work is displayed in the Victoria and Albert Museum and the Glasgow Art Gallery," said art expert Andrew Stewart. "If the scenes on the doors can be removed without damaging them they could fetch up to £5000 each at auction."

The pictures are currently being verified by experts, whilst Mr. Mangoo is exploring behind every other piece of chipboard in his home. "Things like this seem to happen in Bradford all the time," said one local art enthusiast. "Only last week I bought a donut that turned out to be the spitting image of Mother Teresa."
The Bradford Telegraph and Argus

Artlovers pissed off
More art news from North Wales, where a pub landlord looks set to make a small fortune from the sale of a large slab of solid slate. The piece of slate in question, which weighs in at well over a hundredweight, sits inside the We Three Loggerheads pub in Llanferres, near Mold, and is significant because on it is a 200-year old painting by one of Wales most famous artists, Richard Wilson.

Titled We Three Loggerheads - hence the name of the pub - the painting was executed some time in the 1780s, inspired by a famous argument between the vicar of Llanferres and an unnamed local man. For two centuries it hung outside the pub, attracting a constant stream of admirers and art students, before eventually being brought inside to protect it from the elements.

Now landlord Paul Waters has decided to sell it, a move which could net him as much as £30,000. "Ideally I'd like to see it go to a museum rather than a private collector," he said. "That way more people can see and appreciate the work."

Not everyone, however, is happy about the proposed sale. "It's part of the pub's history and it should stay there," said one local drinker. "Getting pissed just won't be the same without it."
This is North Wales

Left on the sidelines
If possible it's best to avoid road accidents altogether. If you do have to have one, however, it seems advisable not to do it anywhere near Hereford. Such was the lesson learnt recently by social worker Wendy Newson who, having crashed her motorcycle on the A49, spent almost half an hour waving for help to passing traffic before anyone bothered to stop.

Ms. Newson, 33, of Pudleston, was thrown from her motorbike at the bottom of a steep hill after colliding with the kerb. Despite a broken ankle and severe bruising she managed to drag herself onto the grass verge beside the road from where she tried to flag down traffic.

Numerous cars were passing, and it would have been clear to them both from her posture and her damaged motorcycle that she was in severe pain. For reasons best known to themselves, however, none of them bothered to stop. "I just couldn't believe it," said the mangled motorcyclist. "That time could have meant life or death for me. People are just so ignorant."

A driver did eventually contact the emergency services and Ms Newson was duly rushed to Hereford General Hospital, where she has a full recovery. "I do feel bad," admitted one of the passing motorists, "But she has to see it from my point of view. If I'd stopped I would have missed the kick-off of the England-Romania match. It's painful, but sometimes you just have to prioritize."
The Hereford Times

Rat tales
A decade ago we had Essex Girls. Now, however, the county appears to have spawned an altogether less appealing creature: Essex rat. The new genus - Rattus Essexus - has been particularly in evidence in Brentwood, where infestations have rocketed by 24% in less than a year.

"We've had a record year for rats," admitted one council insider. "A few years ago we were getting a maximum of 500 infestations per year. In 1998, however, it had gone up to 800, and last year we had well over 1,000." The council's environmental health department has been at full stretch trying to deal with the situation, and householders are being urged to be more careful with their waste, and not to leave food lying around. It is by no means certain, however, that these measures will succeed in turning the tide.

"It's mainly down to the mild weather," said a council expert. "So long as that continues so will the growth in the rat population." But at least one local resident sounded relaxed about the invasion: "Personally I don't think they're too bad. At least they don't go around on Saturday night singing Three Lions and vomiting curry all over the town centre."
The Essex Evening Echo

Letter of the week
If the person who stole my Sony car radio cassette from my VW Polo on Station Road, Cottingham last Friday, in the process causing £400 worth of damage to the car, would like to contact me, I can give him the code without which the radio won't work. I'd hate to think he didn't get his money's worth.
R Baker, The Hull Daily Mail

fields.headline: When I Lived in Modern Times by Linda Grant
fields.standfirst:
(Granta £9.99) The surprise Orange prizewinner (whose author was accused of and denied plagiarising AJ Shermans Mandate Days: British Lives in Palestine 1914-48). Condensed in the style of the original
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Listen. Times were very hard if you were a poor, politically correct Jewish girl living in the east end of London during the Blitz and you were trying to eke out a living as a hairdresser.
fields.body:
Listen. Times were very hard if you were a poor, politically correct Jewish girl living in the east end of London during the Blitz and you were trying to eke out a living as a hairdresser. They were even harder if you never knew your Dad and your mother had just died. So, in 1946, I lied my way on to a boat sailing for Palestine. I joined a kibbutz on my arrival. I loved the long, exegetical discussions we all had about the history of kibbutz life but it was hard work having sex with some of the men.

I wanted to be a new Jew, not some Russian emigre from a collective farm, so I hitched a lift with Levi, or Johnny, as he sometimes called himself, a man with impeccable Jewish credentials, and headed off for Tel Aviv.

I moved into a block of flats and met some locals who gave me history lessons on the differences between the Oestjuden and the German experience. My neighbour, Mrs Kulp, conveniently happened to be a hairdresser and after testing me on the history of hairdressing, she hired me to work in her salon where my British clients mourned the passing of Empire and offered their historical perspective on Palestine.

Johnny reappeared after a spate of kidnappings and, after a long discussion on the history of the Jewish resistance, we had sex, and thereafter he pressed me for information on my clients. We still had time for fun, though, because we also discussed the historical significance of Jewish haircuts. Mrs Linz told me later that Johnny was an Irgun terrorist, but I didnt get time to confront him before a hotel was blown up and he went into hiding. He reappeared later, and after another historical dialogue on factionalism, he said the police were on to me and that I should also go into hiding.

Shortly afterwards, I discovered I was pregnant and that Johnny had been arrested. How I missed our history lessons.

The British eventually caught up with me and put me on a boat to France. I met my husband, Leo, in a cemetery there and six years later my son (with Johnny) died by swallowing a balloon. Johnny went on to become an air steward with El Al, but I didnt go back to Israel for many years. Tel Aviv had changed a lot.

And if you really are pressed: The digested read, digested...

File under non-fiction for a historical analysis of the creation of the State of Israel that manages to end before the British withdrawal from Palestine.

fields.headline: Beware the bin doctors
fields.standfirst: Labour won yesterday's Tottenham byelection but only a quarter of the electorate bothered to vote. Duncan Hames, who stood for the Liberal Democrats and came second, reflects on the result.
fields.trailText: Friday, 1.30pm: Labour won yesterday's Tottenham byelection but only a quarter of the electorate bothered to vote. Duncan Hames, who stood for the Liberal Democrats and came second, reflects on the result.
fields.body:
My congratulations to David Lammy, the new MP for Tottenham - but a word of warning too. He must not take the people of Tottenham for granted. The endorsement which they have given him is scarcely tinkling, let alone ringing. His vote fell by 15%, with a swing of 12% to the Liberal Democrats.

After weeks of pounding the streets, I can tell him why. There is enormous disappointment that a government which promised so much in 1997 has delivered so little. In an inner-city area with far too much poverty, pensioners are outraged by the miserly 75p increase which the government has given them while families are deeply disappointed by its failure to improve the quality of the borough's schools. Many other groups have little for which to thank the government, in particular the many sub-postmasters and mistresses who fear the loss of their businesses because of the changes in the way benefits are to be paid.

No wonder, therefore, that the theme of Labour's campaign was little more than a series of pictures of David Lammy. He was always "the Labour candidate", never "the New Labour candidate". Tony Blair's name was only mentioned once.

The new MP will also have to contend with the deep unpopularity of the Labour council, which now charges the highest council tax in London, but is notoriously bad at keeping the streets clean or emptying dustbins. On one occasion, when David Lammy was due to be filmed on a particular street by the BBC, the bin men put in a rare and unscheduled appearance just before to spruce the location up. Neither spin doctors nor bin doctors are a proper substitute for providing proper public services all year round for Tottenham's residents.

There has been much head scratching about the low turnout in the election. We all need to engage people more in the political process, but there were some very special factors in Tottenham to which people have not perhaps paid enough attention. Large numbers of residents do not have English as a first language. I canvassed many people using their daughter or son as an interpreter.

The biggest story of the night was, I believe, the failure of the Conservatives. Their slump to third place showed that people in Tottenham have long memories. Despite visits to the constituency by William Hague, Ann Widdecombe and Michael Portillo, they remember how they were neglected by successive Tory Governments and they do not believe the party has any more to offer them now.

Labour coasts to victory in Tottenham
Special Report

webTitle: Business start-up figures expose north-south divide

fields.headline: Business start-up figures expose north-south divide
fields.trailText: New businesses still prefer to set up in London and the south rather than elsewhere in Britain, according to official figures revealed today by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, and the chancellor, Gordon Brown.
fields.body:
New businesses still prefer to set up in London and the south rather than elsewhere in Britain, according to official figures revealed today by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, and the chancellor, Gordon Brown.

A "league table of enterprise" of new business start-ups per head of population showed that the seven top areas were all in the capital while the bottom five were in north-east England.

The statistics confirming the north-south divide were published by Mr Prescott and Mr Brown at a Birmingham meeting to boost the role of the regional development agencies created by the government in an effort to reduce regional inequalities in the UK.

Mr Prescott promised a strengthened role of regional development agencies to achieve a "more balanced growth" between the regions.

"We are putting new tools in the hands of the regions to create new types of development and build new and vibrant economies - putting back confidence and decision-making powers that are the springboard for future development," he said.

"I have long been committed to a stronger role for the English regions. Regional development agencies have been introduced as a first step and we are looking at new models of regional governance where there is strong popular demand for them."

Mr Brown said the government would be providing support programmes worth up to £2,000 to new businesses starting up in areas of high unemployment as part of next month's comprehensive spending review.

The table, which covers England, Scotland and Wales, shows far more firms registering for VAT in the south than the north.

The seven leading areas for business creation were all in London, headed by the City of London, with 2,893 start-ups per 10,000 residents and the City of Westminster, with 300 start-ups per 10,000 residents.

The bottom five areas were all in the north-east, with Wansbeck in Northumberland having 12 start-ups per 10,000 residents, followed by Redcar and Cleveland with 14 start-ups per 10,000 residents.

The average across the UK was 40, with an average in England of 42.

Publishing the table, the Treasury acknowledged: "There are significant differences in business start-up rates across the regions of the UK and within the regions."

But the Treasury stressed that its figures, while being the "most precise measure" available for new business creation, were far from perfect. They "may be disproportionately skewed due to special factors" such as the creation of business headquarters in London, it said.

Don Foster, Liberal Democrat spokesman for the environment, transport and the regions, said: "Blair cannot keep pretending the north-south divide does not exist when his own deputy and the chancellor are calling for action to level up the regions.

"Any additional funds for the regions are welcome but what matters most is greater flexibility to deal with different problems in different areas.

"Regional development agencies need to be more fleet of foot and less tied up by red tape. But the democratic deficit is the real issue. We need proper regional government responsible to local people not Whitehall."
