fields.headline: Sir Harry Melville
fields.standfirst: His early work on polymer chemistry boosted industry; later, his administrative flair showed the way in national scientific research
fields.trailText: Sir Harry Melville, who has died aged 92, was one of the backroom boys of British research, whose avoidance of the public limelight resulted in him becoming known, in the 1960s, as the "giant clam of science". His pioneering research into complex aspects of polymer chemistry underpinned the rapid and successful development of the plastics, synthetic rubber and man-made fibre industries.
fields.body:
Sir Harry Melville, who has died aged 92, was one of the backroom boys of British research, whose avoidance of the public limelight resulted in him becoming known, in the 1960s, as the "giant clam of science". His pioneering research into complex aspects of polymer chemistry underpinned the rapid and successful development of the plastics, synthetic rubber and man-made fibre industries.

Although Sir Harry, a quietly-spoken lowland Scot, would have avoided such a bold claim, the fact is that through practical products that have changed the material face, and the economics, of the world, the advances he initiated more than 50 years ago now touch all our lives. At first working alone, Melville defined, in a quantitative way, the unifying principles that provide a framework for the complex chemistry and bonding mechanisms involved in the formation of large polymer molecules. Paradoxically, when he began this work in the 1930s, initially at Edinburgh University and then at Cambridge, Melville was concerned with reaching a more complete understanding of the explosion limits of reactions between gases.

Although existing theories provided a general explanation of critical thresholds and instabilities in gas mixtures, there were few experiments - and virtually no measurements - to establish their correctness or, if shown to be right, fill them out into practical tools.

Assessed by the technology of the time, Melville's early achievements seem extraordinary. He found ways of measuring the rates of chemical reactions (the so-called velocity coefficients) during the critical stages of the highly unstable situations that immediately precede an explosion. He went on to develop even more sensitive methods that revealed the first details of what are known as "branching coefficients" in the steps of an explosive chain-reaction. In short, he proved, and then extended, existing theory.

Once he was as confident in the theory as he was with his own techniques, he set out to investigate the dynamics, explosive limits and principles that control the subtle range of reactions that result in polymerisation, and which, later, were important in the production of new and stable compounds with unusual properties.

The progress of this work, which, at the age of 28, had already earned Melville the Institute of Chemistry Meldola Medal, was in full flow at Cambridge when it was overtaken by the needs of the second world war. In 1939, Melville had been offered the chair of chemistry at the University of Aberdeen, a post he could not take up until 1945. Instead, armed with his decade of research, he became scientific adviser to the chief superintendent of chemical defence. In 1941, aged 33, he was elected a fellow of the Royal Society.

Unlike some involved in secret wartime posts, Melville rarely spoke - and never wrote - of his experiences. Many believe he was among the first scientists in Britain to realise that Nazi Germany was stockpiling the nerve gas Sarin. In 1943, he was appointed superintendent of the prestigious radar research station at Malvern, Worcestershire, which had been set up to accelerate and unify research and development in this crucial area.

After the war, at Aberdeen, Melville built up a flourishing new research school of physical chemistry, focusing on the new fields of polymer science. Nobody was surprised when, in 1948, he accepted the Mason chair of chemistry at Birmingham.

In the 1950s, the Birmingham school achieved a reputation as one of the world's few outstanding centres of polymer research, exploiting Melville's techniques of radio-isotope labelling to determine molecular lengths and cross-linked polymer structures. This work was of immense practical consequence to industry, and grew rapidly. Many were therefore astonished when, in 1956, while at the height of his creative powers, Melville ended his research career to become an administrator - as permanent secretary of the Department of Scientific and Ind- ustrial Research (DSIR).

In retrospect, the transition is not difficult to understand. Melville had never severed his connections with Whitehall and its backroom science. In the immediate post-war years, he had served on the government's Scientific Advisory Council, been scientific adviser to the Ministry of Aviation and a regional chief scientific adviser for civil defence. In any case, his great breadth and speed of technical grasp - and his gifts of touch and judgment as an administrator - put him in a unique position to define and interlink productive research areas.

At this time, the government was committed to rapid increases in national expenditure on civil science, and was working toward a new and more formalised grant assessment structure. That Melville was seen as the right man to take the helm was confirmed in 1965 when the old DSIR, traditionally steered by an informal network, was transformed into the Science Research Council (SRC) - with secretariats and an executive board.

Melville, who had played a key role during the discussions leading to the reorganisation, was appointed as the SRC's first chairman. The DSIR, swift and sure when mounting new projects, had become slow and weak in clearing out dead wood. Sir Harry hated waste of time or effort, and believed that the SRC would nurture the nation's increasingly complex research fabric rather better, yet be as lean and purposeful as the old DSIR.

He was acutely aware that critics believed that the new structure was top-heavy and vulnerable to government vacillations, likely to be as concerned with procedures and its own image as with the beneficial administration of civil science. Indeed, he found the transition was not without troubles, although within three years - acting in the spirit of his unusual second Christian name, Work (which is of Orkney origin) - he had shaped a structure which survived for two decades.

Melville, who received his knighthood in 1958, was a scientist's scientist, at his happiest when talking shop with his equals. Although sometimes described as colourless, he had a wry and mischievous sense of humour, was an entertaining after-dinner speaker and, in a remarkable series of Christmas lectures at the Royal Institution, London, demonstrated a natural light-hearted ability to communicate with children.

Edinburgh born and bred, he went from George Heriot's school to Edinburgh University as a Carnegie research scholar, and then, as an exhibitioner, to Cambridge, where he was a fellow of Trinity College from 1933-44. Although the record tells of his entertaining observations on the strange phenomena he observed at high table, Melville's major observations at this time were made in the remarkable Colloid Science Laboratory, run by Professor Rideal, which, well ahead of its time, covered the vast interdisciplinary areas between chemistry, physics and biology. In 1938, Melville became Rideal's assistant research director, focusing on polymers.

In 1967, with the SRC on its feet, Sir Harry became principal of Queen Mary College, London, retiring in 1976. During this period, he was a member of the parliamentary scientific committee and the nuclear safety committee, and served as president of the Chemical Society.

In 1942, Melville married Janet Porteous, with whom he had two daughters. Apart from chemistry and his family, he had only one lifelong passion, a compelling fascination for gadgets and new technological possibilities. These, and a huge specialised mind, made him one of the most modest, inventive and quietest giants of our time.

fields.headline: Glastonbury
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about this weekend's music festival on the net
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about this weekend's music festival on the net.
fields.body:
1. The festival season begins today as Glastonbury gets in the groove for its 30th anniversary celebrations. Or something like that.

2. It's the most famous and popular of all Europe's big music events - around 100,000 people attend each year.

3. But this year ticket sales are down. Recent festivals have been blighted by bad weather, and according to Avon and Somerset police, record numbers of tent thefts.

4. The festival started the day after Jimi Hendrix died on September 19 1970. Farmer Michael Eavis charged revellers £1 to drink his milk and watch Marc Bolan.

5. Since 1981 (when the festival turned a profit and stopped being a "fayre") Glastonbury has taken place every year but three. Some of Glastonbury's most committed supporters (including Sir Winston Churchill's granddaughter Arabella) are still involved in the running of the festival.

6. Acts lined up for this year's festival include Burt Bacharach, the Chemical Brothers and Bob Marley's former backing band the Wailers.

7. Glastonbury also comes with a host of mystical and spiritual associations: according to legend King Arthur found his final resting place here on the Isle of Avalon and the Tor stands on a powerful ley line.

8. Joseph of Arimathea may have brought Christianity to the British Isles at Glastonbury and hidden the holy grail used at Jesus's last supper in the town's Chalice Well.

9. So all in all, it's not a bad place to take a few mind-altering substances, head for the Pyramid stage, and unwind to the blissful sounds of Sunday night headliner, Mr David Bowie, whose only previous Glasto performance was in 1972. Recalling his show recently, Bowie said he had accompanied himself on "poorly played guitar and even worse Woolworth's electric organ".

10. If you can't make it, why not sit in front of your computer and watch one of the many webcasts instead?

webTitle: Bardot lured out of retirement by death camp epic

fields.headline: Bardot lured out of retirement by death camp epic
fields.trailText: After 27 years off-screen, Brigitte Bardot has been lured out of retirement to star in a new epic about the Nazi death camps
fields.body:
After 27 years off-screen, Brigitte Bardot has been lured out of retirement to star in a new epic about the Nazi death camps.

According to the Express newspaper, film-maker Frank Turkisch claims that Bardot has agreed to appear alongside a number of other stars in Once Upon a Time In Europe, a film about the male and female child prostitutes used as 'entertainment' for German officers running the second world war concentration camps.

Turkisch worked with Bardot in her 1959 film Babette Goes To War and approached the star at her St Tropez home. "She was really enthusiastic about the venture and all I need to do now is tie things up with her management" he said.

The 66-year-old former sex symbol, who was in the news recently accused of inciting racial hatred (see our report), wants to be filmed near to her home in St Tropez and has said she plans to donate the money for her role to her own charity foundation. It is not thought that Bardot's appearance will lead to a full-scale return to the screen.

There is a possibility that ex-president of the Soviet Union, Mikhail Gorbachev, and Czech president Vaclav Havel will have cameos in the film. Gorbachev has shown interest in the project but has not yet made a firm commitment to it. President Haval is said to be keen to write and deliver a eulogy at the end of the film about Jewish survivors, but his involvement is dependent on the speed of his recovery from a recent bout of severe bronchitis.

webTitle: MI6 destroyed notes on 'red letter' that doomed first Labour government

fields.headline: MI6 destroyed notes on 'red letter' that doomed first Labour government
fields.trailText: MI6 destroyed documents relating to the Zinoviev letter - one of the greatest political scandals of the 20th century - papers released yesterday at the public record office show.
fields.body:
MI6 destroyed documents relating to the Zinoviev letter - one of the greatest political scandals of the 20th century - papers released yesterday at the public record office show.

The letter, almost certainly forged, was leaked to the Daily Mail on the eve of the 1924 general election which led to the fall of the first Labour government under Ramsay Macdonald.

Purported to have been written by Grigori Zinoviev, president of the Comintern, the internal communist organisation, it called on British communists to mobilise "sympathetic forces" in the Labour party to support an Anglo-Soviet treaty (including a loan to the Bolshevik government) and to encourage "agitation-propaganda" in the armed forces.

A study by Gill Bennett, chief historian at the Foreign Office, last year pointed the finger at elements in the intelligence services.

She revealed that Stewart Menzies, a future head of MI6 whose allegiances, she said, "lay firmly in the Conservative camp", admitted sending a copy of the Zinoviev letter to the Mail.

A note to the Foreign Office released yesterday and dated April 1952 says there is "no harm whatsoever [that] some papers should be registered and some destroyed".

The letter is signed by C - or chief of MI6, as the agency's head is known. C at the time was Stewart Menzies.

A further document released yesterday discloses that a Foreign Office official noted later: "Perhaps some letters and papers have been destroyed in the past which ought to be preserved under the Public Records Act".

On October 25, 1924, four days before the election, the Mail splashed headlines across its front page claiming: Civil War Plot by Socialists' Masters: Moscow Orders To Our Reds; Great Plot Disclosed.

Labour lost by a landslide.

Ms Bennett said that the letter "probably was leaked from SIS (the Secret Intelligence Service, commonly known as MI6) by somebody to the Conservative party central office".

She said MI6 was at the centre of the scandal, though there was no evidence of a conspiracy in what she called "the institutional sense". The security and intelligence community at the time consisted of a "very, very incestuous circle, an elite network" who went to school together.

MI6 and Foreign Office files which have not been destroyed show the Zinoviev letter was widely circulated, including to senior army officers, to inflict maximum damage on the Labour government.

She said the letter - sent to MI6 from one of its agents in the Latvian capital, Riga - was written as a result of a campaign orchestrated by White Russians who had good contacts in London. The report said there was no hard evidence that MI6 agents in Riga were directly responsible - though they had close contacts with White Russians.

MI6 deceived the Foreign Office by asserting that it did know who the source was - a deception it used to claim the Zinoviev letter was genuine.

Ms Bennett said it was wrong to conclude the scandal brought down the Macdonald government which had already lost a confidence vote and Liberal support on which it depended was disappearing. However, she said it certainly damaged the Labour party's reputation.

webTitle: June 23: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: June 23: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: M Night Shyamalan approached for Indiana Jones 4, Scary Movie too much for director's parents, Salman Rushdie cast in Bridget Jones, Danny Glover gets taxi revenge, Jet Li signs for Green Hornet, and big names flock to Focus
fields.body:
 Steven Spielberg and Harrison Ford have approached Sixth Sense director M Night Shyamalan (pictured) to write the script for the forthcoming Indiana Jones 4 film. If Shyamalan agrees it is hoped he will begin writing in 2001 with a view to production beginning in 2002, according to Variety.

 The parents of director Keenen Ivory Wayans walked out in disgust during the premiere of his new film, Scary Movie. The film - a parody of horror movies - also stars his brothers Shawn and Marlon and contains some graphic sex scenes which seemed too much for the senior Wayans to take. Asked about it later by Fox News, Wayans Junior said: "My father's a Jehovah's Witness. He probably got out his Bible when he got home. We're going to hear about it."

 Salman Rushdie is to get a cameo in the new Bridget Jones film. The Satanic Verses author will play himself in a scene set at a literary party.

 Danny Glover, who once sharply criticised New York cab drivers for their reluctance to pick up black men, will be playing one himself in the forthcoming Showtime movie, 3am. The actor said he will draw on his own experience driving a cab in San Francisco for the Spike Lee-produced project, which also stars Jackie Brown star Pam Grier. Glover criticised New York cab drivers in November after he was passed by five times in a single day.

 After months of speculation, martial arts star Jet Li has agreed to appear in the big screen adaptation of the 1960s TV series, The Green Hornet. Li will play Kato, the role that Bruce Lee made his own in the original series. Li is expected to earn his biggest paycheck yet, receiving a $5.2m advance against 5% of the movie's gross profits.

 Laura Dern, William H Macy and David Paymer will star in the new indy film Focus, based on playwright Arthur Miller's novel of the same name. Published in 1945 and set during the last few months of the second world war, Focus is the story of a man (Macy) and his wife (Dern) who are mistakenly identified as Jews by their anti-semitic Brooklyn neighbours.

 Leslie Nielsen will star as Santa Claus in the forthcoming Santa Who?, a Wonderful World of Disney holiday picture due to start production next month. Nielsen will play a Santa stricken by amnesia after falling out of his sleigh two days before Christmas.

webTitle: Internet cinema plan to beat Oscar rules

fields.headline: Internet cinema plan to beat Oscar rules
fields.trailText: Website ifilm has joined forces with US cinema chain AMC in an attempt to manoeuvre round new rules announced last week by the Motion Picture Academy of America, barring any film that is first shown on the internet from being considered for an Oscar
fields.body:
Website ifilm has joined forces with US cinema chain AMC to launch a showcase, screening internet films in conventional movie theatres. The move follows rules announced last week by the Motion Picture Academy of America barring any film that is first shown on the internet from being considered for an Oscar (see our report).

Under the current rules of the Academy, a film must be shown for at least three days in a movie house to qualify for an Oscar nomination. This means that internet-based shorts like Mission: Imp (pictured) and Frying Private Fryan (which premiered on the ifilm network) are not eligible for Oscar consideration because they were premiered on the internet.

AMC and ifilm are planning to create monthly theatrical showcases so that internet films can debut in AMC Cinemas before they go online. The chief executive of ifilm, Kevin Wendle, said: "This is an ongoing effort to create more of an event for film-makers, a real theatrical showcase where they can invite the people that worked on the film, their families and anyone seeing this new content on the big screen."

The showcase is due to launch next month, and selected films will screen twice daily for three consecutive days at AMC cinemas.

webTitle: Cold turkey and Clive Tyldesley's saliva

fields.headline: Cold turkey and Clive Tyldesley's saliva
fields.trailText: I got into a bit of a panic yesterday. No football, not even a review of the tournament so far, which, given the fact that both BBC and ITV have been drip-feeding us with unadulterated 100 per cent pure football for the last two weeks, seemed a little heartless, not to mention a little irresponsible.
fields.body:
I got into a bit of a panic yesterday. No football, not even a review of the tournament so far, which, given the fact that both BBC and ITV have been drip-feeding us with unadulterated 100 per cent pure football for the last two weeks, seemed a little heartless, not to mention a little irresponsible.

Twenty live matches followed by cold turkey. It was tough but a pretty good EastEnders helped.

After the disappointment of England's performance, the prospects for the armchair viewer looked bleak. But happily, along came a match to remind us why we were looking forward to the tournament in the first place.

Spain's absurd win over Yugoslavia proved to be a cathartic experience. A passionate one-night stand after your loved one had walked out on you - again. Ultimately of course, it was a meaningless experience but no less enjoyable for that - a bit like football itself really.

Later that night we were treated to another enjoyable game when Holland faced France in a match many people saw as a dress rehearsal for the final. By many people, I mean ITV commentator Clive Tyldesley. For him this was no ordinary game. In fact one would have to go back to Anna Kournikova's last Wimbledon appearance to hear an English commentator salivate with such relish.

Tyldesley spent the entire game reminding the viewers how privileged they were to be watching an average Dutch side play a reserve French XI with absolutely nothing at stake. Useful for the blind viewers I suppose, but the rest of us, even those exposed to England on a regular basis, can still recognise a decent game when we see one. In fact many of us had seen one only three hours earlier.

It wasn't just the football that impressed Tyldesley; the supporters and especially those from Holland were compared favourably to their English counterparts. I'm not so sure.

In their favour the Dutch don't ransack foreign cities, abuse the locals and shame their country and generally-speaking, they get behind their team in a vocal and occasionally fervent fashion. On the downside though, they do wear a lot of orange and there's a suspicious absence of irony about their jollity.

Mmm, tough call that one.

webTitle: Labour coasts to victory in Tottenham

fields.headline: Labour coasts to victory in Tottenham
fields.standfirst:
The count
Elections 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Labour coasted to victory in the Tottenham byelection early today, but the party's success was marred by a low turn-out which will revive criticism that the government is failing to inspire its heartland supporters.
fields.body:
Labour coasted to victory in the Tottenham byelection early today, but the party's success was marred by a low turn-out which will revive criticism that the government is failing to inspire its heartland supporters.

David Lammy, a high-flying barrister, won the safe Labour seat with 8,785 votes, a majority of 5,646, on a 25.4% turnout.

His victory ensures that Tottenham, north London, one of Britain's most multicultural constituencies, will continue to be represented by a black MP after the death of Bernie Grant in March.

The Tories were beaten into third place by the Liberal Democrats, in a result which will ring alarm bells at central office. The Lib Dems' Duncan Hames won 3,139 votes, with the Tories' Jane Ellison trailing on 2,634 votes.

Mr Lammy, 27, described his victory, in which he secured 53.5% of the vote, as a "magical moment". He said: "It is a long way from where I grew up just five roads away. We struggled hard as a Labour family, raised by a single mother, on a small income."

Mr Lammy, who becomes Britain's youngest MP, admitted that as one of the few black MPs he would carry a "heavy burden" at Westminster. "Yes I expect to be symbol for something," he said.

In an attempt to silence critics, who will claim the low turnout shows that Labour's core supporters are mounting "armchair" protests by refusing to vote, Mr Lammy said his performance showed the government was on course. "The heartlands in Tottenham are safe in New Labour's hands."

Paul Boateng, the home office minister, said he was greatly encouraged that Mr Lammy had managed to secure more than 50% of the vote. He took delight in reminding the Tories that they lost a string of supposedly safe seats at the same stage in the last parliament.

Mr Boateng also dismissed the low turnout, saying that only 57% of the electorate turned out in Tottenham in the general election, way below the national average.

However, the poor turnout will strengthen the hands of the likes of the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, who urged Tony Blair at the weekend to do more to connect with the party's "own people".

Labour has performed poorly in recent byelections. It came within 556 votes of losing one of its safest seats at Hamilton South last year and at the Ceredigion byelection last February Labour slipped into fourth place.

Even Blairite loyalists at Millbank admit the government has taken a battering recently. Leading cabinet members are to be wheeled out to drum up core supporters by warning of the dangers of a return to Tory rule.

Mr Lammy, who became the first black Briton in 1996 to study at Harvard, impressed the Labour party machinery with his adept handling of the campaign and there is speculation he could be in line for a ministerial job soon after the general election.

However, some of Mr Grant's relatives said they would not be voting for Mr Lammy, who was seen as being too close to Millbank. The late MP's sister, Rosamund, issued a statement on Wednesday saying that "none of the Grant family will be voting for Lammy".

This contradicted an assurance from Mr Grant's widow, Sharon, who backed Mr Lammy after he beat her to the Labour nomination.

The count

David Lammy

Labour 8,785

Duncan Hames

Liberal Democrat 3,139

Jane Ellison

Conservative 2,634

Weyman Bennett

LSA 885

Peter Budge

Green 606

Labour majority 5,646 Turnout (%) 25.43

fields.headline: Horse Heaven
fields.trailText: On the second Sunday morning in November, the day after the Breeders' Cup at Hollywood Park (which he did not get to this year, because the trek to the West Coast seemed a long one from Westchester County and he didn't have a runner, had never had a runner, how could this possibly be his fault, hadn't he spent millions breeding, training, and running horses? Wasn't it time he had a runner in the Breeders' Cup or got out of the game altogether, one or the other?), Alexander P. Maybrick arose from his marriage bed at 6:00 a.m., put on his robe and slippers, and exited the master suite he shared with his wife, Rosalind.
fields.body:
Chapter one: JACK RUSSELL

On the second Sunday morning in November, the day after the Breeders' Cup at Hollywood Park (which he did not get to this year, because the trek to the West Coast seemed a long one from Westchester County and he didn't have a runner, had never had a runner, how could this possibly be his fault, hadn't he spent millions breeding, training, and running horses? Wasn't it time he had a runner in the Breeders' Cup or got out of the game altogether, one or the other?), Alexander P. Maybrick arose from his marriage bed at 6:00 a.m., put on his robe and slippers, and exited the master suite he shared with his wife, Rosalind. On the way to the kitchen, he passed the library, his office that adjoined the library, the weight room, the guest bathroom, the living room, and the dining room. In every room his wife had laid a Persian carpet of exceptional quality - his wife had an eye for quality in all things - and it seemed like every Persian carpet in every room every morning was adorned with tiny dark, dense turds deposited there by Eileen, the Jack Russell terrier. Eileen herself was nestled up in bed with his wife, apparently sleeping, since she didn't raise even her head when Mr. Maybrick arose, but Mr. Maybrick knew she was faking. No Jack Russell sleeps though movement of any kind except as a ruse.

Mr. Maybrick had discussed this issue with Rosalind on many levels. It was not as though he didn't know what a Jack Russell was all about when Rosalind brought the dog home. A Jack Russell was about making noise, killing small animals and dragging their carcasses into the house, attacking much larger dogs, refusing to be house-trained, and in all other ways living a primitive life. Rosalind had promised to start the puppy off properly, with a kennel and a trainer and a strict routine and a book about Jack Russells, and every other thing that worked with golden retrievers and great Danes and mastiffs, and dogs in general. But Eileen wasn't a dog, she was a beast, and the trainer had been able to do only one thing with her, which was stop her from barking. And thank God for that, because if the trainer had not stopped Eileen from barking Mr. Maybrick would have had to strangle her. Rosalind, who sent her underwear to the cleaners and had the windows washed every two weeks and kept the oven spotless enough to sterilize surgical instruments, tried to take the position that the turds were small and harmless, and that the carpets could handle them, but really she just thought the dog was cute, even after Eileen learned to jump from the floor to the kitchen counters, and then walked around on them with her primevally dirty feet, click click click, right in front of Mr. Maybrick, even after Eileen began to sleep under the covers, pushing her wiry, unsoft coat right into Mr. Maybrick's nose in the middle of the night. "Do you know where this dog has been?" Mr. Maybrick would say to Rosalind, and Rosalind would reply, "I don't want to think about that."

Mr. Maybrick was a wealthy and powerful man, and in the end, that was what stopped him. He knew that, in the larger scheme of things, he had been so successful, and, in many ways, so unpleasant about it all (he was a screamer and a bully, tough on everyone), that Eileen had come into his life as a corrective. She weighed one-twentieth of what he did. He could crush her between his two fists. He could also get rid of her, either by yelling at his wife or by sending her off to the SPCA on his own, but he dared not. There was some abyss of megalomania that Eileen guarded the edge of for Mr. Maybrick, and in the mornings, when he walked to the kitchen to get his coffee, he tried to remember that.

The first thing Mr. Maybrick did after he poured his coffee was to call his horse-trainer. When the trainer answered with his usual "Hey, there!," Mr. Maybrick said, "Dick!," and then Dick said, "Oh. Al." He always said it just like that, as if he were expecting something good to happen, and Mr. Maybrick had happened instead. Mr. Maybrick ignored this and sipped his coffee while Dick punched up his response. "Can I do something for you, Al?"

"Yeah. You can put that Laurita filly in the allowance race on Thursday."

"You've got a condition book, then."

"Oh, sure. I want to know what races are being run. You trainers keep everything so dark"

"Well, sure. Al, listen"

"Dick, Frank Henderson thinks it's the perfect race for her. A little step up in class, but not too much competi"

"I'll see."

"I want to do it. Henderson said"

"Mr. Henderson"

"Frank Henderson knows horses and racing, right? His filly won the Kentucky Oaks last year, right? He would have had that other horse in the sprint yesterday if it hadn't broken down. Listen to me, Dick. I shouldn't have to beg you." This was more or less a threat, and as he said it, not having actually intended to, Mr. Maybrick reflected upon how true it was. He was the owner. Dick Winterson was the trainer. The relationship was a simple one. Henderson was always telling him not to be intimidated by trainers.

"We'll see."

"You always say that. Look, I don't want to watch the Breeders' Cup on TV again next year. Henderson thinks this filly's got class."

"She does, but I want to go slow with her. We have to see how the filly"

Mr. Maybrick hung up. He didn't slam down the phone - he no longer did that - he simply hung up. If Dick had known him as long as Mr. Maybrick had known himself, he would haw: realized what a good thing it was, simply hanging up. And here was another thing he could use with his wife. He could say that if he didn't have to pass all those turds in the morning he could start off calmer and his capacity for accepting frustration would last a little longer. It was scientific. When they didn't have the dog, he had gotten practically to the fourth phone call without offending anyone. Now he got maybe to the second. He took another sip of his coffee, and called his broker, then his partner, then his general manager, then his other partner, then his secretary, then his broker again, then his AA sponsor (who was still in bed). This guy's name was Harold W., and he was a proctologist as well as an alcoholic. Mr. Maybrick had chosen him because he was a man of infinite patience and because he knew everything there was to know about prostate glands.

"I want a drink," said Mr. Maybrick. "There's turds all over the house. I bet you can understand that one."

"Good morning, Al. What's really up? You haven't had a drink in two years."

"But I'm always on the verge. It's a real struggle with me."

"Say your serenity prayer."

"God"

"God"

They said the serenity prayer together.

"Look," said Al, "I got this pain in my groin"

"No freebies. That's the rule. My partner will be happy to"

"It's like water trickling out of a hose. I can't"

"You need to be working on your fourth step."

"What's that one again?"

"Taking a fearless inventory of your character defects."

"Oh, yeah."

"Trying to get something for nothing is one of your character defects."

"I never pay retail."

"Then you need to work on your third step, Al."

"What's that one?"

"Turning your life over to your higher power."

Mr. Maybrick cleared his throat, as he always did when someone said those higher-power words. Those words always made an image of Ralph Peters come into his head, the guy who used to be head of the Mercantile Exchange in Chicago, and who foiled the Hunt brothers when they tried to corner the silver market back in '80. Peters was an Austrian guy. He had "higher power" written all over him, and he was the last guy Mr. Maybrick had ever feared. He would never turn his life over to Peters.

Harold went on, "Let's think a little more about the last day. What about rage? Have you been raging?"

"Well, sure. A guy in my posi"

"Should be filled with gratitude. Your position is a gratitude position. Thank you, God, for every frustration, every bad deal, every monetary loss, every balk and obstacle and resistance."

Harold often teased him in this way. Mr. Maybrick felt better for it, because it made him think Harold W. liked him after all, and it reminded him, too, of when his old man had been in a good mood. Joshing him.

"Every non-cooperator, every son of a bitch, every idiot who gets in my way, every slow driver, every"

"Okay."

"I've got to go to work."

"But IThere's wine in the liquor cabinet."

"Throw it out. I've got to go to work. The assholes are accumulating."

Mr. Maybrick laughed. Harold W. laughed, too. Harold W. wasn't a saint, by any means. He had been in AA for thirty-two years, at a meeting almost every day. Mr. Maybrick didn't know whether to respect that or have contempt for it, but he knew for a fact that Harold W. was a force to be reckoned with, and he thanked him politely, ragelessly, and hung up the phone.

Now Eileen trotted into the room. It was clear to Mr. Maybrick that the dog was intentionally ignoring him. She clicked over to her bowl and checked it, took a drink from the water dish, circumnavigated the cooking island, and then, casually, leapt onto the granite counter and trotted toward the sink. "Get down, Eileen," said Mr. Maybrick. It was as if he hadn't spoken. Eileen cocked her little tan head and peered into the garbage disposal, noting that the stopper was in place. Her little stump of a tail flicked a couple of times, and she seemed to squat down. She stretched her paw toward the stopper, but her legs were too short; she couldn't reach it. She surveyed the situation for a moment, then went behind the sink, picked up a pinecone that had been hidden there, and jumped down. Only now did she look at Mr. Maybrick. She dropped the pinecone at his slippered feet and backed up three steps, her snapping black gaze boring into his. "I don't want to do that, Eileen," he said. Her strategy was to take little steps backward and forward and then spin in a tight circle, gesturing at the pinecone with her nose. But she never made a sound.

"You're not a retriever, Eileen, you're a terrier. Go outside and kill something."

Indeed, Eileen was a terrier, and with terrier determination, she resolved that Mr. Maybrick would ultimately throw the pinecone. She continued dancing, every few seconds picking up the pinecone and dropping it again. She was getting cuter and cuter. That was her weapon. Mr. Maybrick considered her a very manipulative animal. He looked away from her and took another sip of his (third) cup of coffee. Now she barked once, and when he looked at her, she went up on her hind legs. She had thighs like a wrestler - she seemed to float. Mr. Maybrick had often thought that a horse as athletic as this worthless dog would get into the Kentucky Derby, then the Breeders' Cup, win him ten million dollars on the track, and earn him five million a year in the breeding shed for, say, twenty years. That was $110 million; it had happened to others. He had been racing and breeding horses for eleven years, and it had never happened to him. This was just the sort of thing that made you a little resentful, and rightfully so, whatever Harold W. had to say about gratitude. He closed his eyes when he felt himself sliding: that way, beginning to count up the millions he had spent running horses and thinking about deserving. With his eyes closed, Al could hear her drop the pinecone rhythmically on the tile, chock chock chock chock, the bass, her little toenails clicking a tune around it. Didn't he deserve a really big horse? Didn't he? And then, while his eyes were still closed, dog and pinecone arrived suddenly in his lap, a hard, dense little weight but live, electric. With the shock, he nearly dropped his coffee cup, and as it was, spilled on the counter. "God damn it!" he shouted. Eileen jumped down and trotted away. "Hey! Come here, Eileen," he said. "Eileen!" Eileen sheared off into the living room, and he realized that he had forgotten to let her out. Mr. Maybrick put his arms up on the table and laid his head upon them.

If Dick had known him as long as Mr. Maybrick had known himself, he would haw: realized what a good thing it was, simply hanging up. And here was another thing he could use with his wife. He could say that if he didn't have to pass all those turds in the morning he could start off calmer and his capacity for accepting frustration would last a little longer. It was scientific. When they didn't have the dog, he had gotten practically to the fourth phone call without offending anyone. Now he got maybe to the second. He took another sip of his coffee, and called his broker, then his partner, then his general manager, then his other partner, then his secretary, then his broker again, then his AA sponsor (who was still in bed). This guy's name was Harold W., and he was a proctologist as well as an alcoholic. Mr. Maybrick had chosen him because he was a man of infinite patience and because he knew everything there was to know about prostate glands. "I want a drink," said Mr. Maybrick. "There's turds all over the house. I bet you can understand that one." "Good morning, Al. What's really up? You haven't had a drink in two years." "But I'm always on the verge. It's a real struggle with me." "Say your serenity prayer." "God" "God" They said the serenity prayer together. "Look," said Al, "I got this pain in my groin" "No freebies. That's the rule. My partner will be happy to" "It's like water trickling out of a hose. I can't" "You need to be working on your fourth step." "What's that one again?" "Taking a fearless inventory of your character defects." "Oh, yeah." "Trying to get something for nothing is one of your character defects." "I never pay retail." "Then you need to work on your third step, Al." "What's that one?" "Turning your life over to your higher power." Mr. Maybrick cleared his throat, as he always did when someone said those higher-power words. Those words always made an image of Ralph Peters come into his head, the guy who used to be head of the Mercantile Exchange in Chicago, and who foiled the Hunt brothers when they tried to corner the silver market back in '80. Peters was an Austrian guy. He had "higher power" written all over him, and he was the last guy Mr. Maybrick had ever feared. He would never turn his life over to Peters. Harold went on, "Let's think a little more about the last day. What about rage? Have you been raging?" "Well, sure. A guy in my posi" "Should be filled with gratitude. Your position is a gratitude position. Thank you, God, for every frustration, every bad deal, every monetary loss, every balk and obstacle and resistance." Harold often teased him in this way. Mr. Maybrick felt better for it, because it made him think Harold W. liked him after all, and it reminded him, too, of when his old man had been in a good mood. Joshing him. "Every non-cooperator, every son of a bitch, every idiot who gets in my way, every slow driver, every" "Okay." "I've got to go to work." "But IThere's wine in the liquor cabinet." "Throw it out. I've got to go to work. The assholes are accumulating." Mr. Maybrick laughed. Harold W. laughed, too. Harold W. wasn't a saint, by any means. He had been in AA for thirty-two years, at a meeting almost every day. Mr. Maybrick didn't know whether to respect that or have contempt for it, but he knew for a fact that Harold W. was a force to be reckoned with, and he thanked him politely, ragelessly, and hung up the phone. Now Eileen trotted into the room. It was clear to Mr. Maybrick that the dog was intentionally ignoring him. She clicked over to her bowl and checked it, took a drink from the water dish, circumnavigated the cooking island, and then, casually, leapt onto the granite counter and trotted toward the sink. "Get down, Eileen," said Mr. Maybrick. It was as if he hadn't spoken. Eileen cocked her little tan head and peered into the garbage disposal, noting that the stopper was in place. Her little stump of a tail flicked a couple of times, and she seemed to squat down. She stretched her paw toward the stopper, but her legs were too short; she couldn't reach it. She surveyed the situation for a moment, then went behind the sink, picked up a pinecone that had been hidden there, and jumped down. Only now did she look at Mr. Maybrick. She dropped the pinecone at his slippered feet and backed up three steps, her snapping black gaze boring into his. "I don't want to do that, Eileen," he said. Her strategy was to take little steps backward and forward and then spin in a tight circle, gesturing at the pinecone with her nose. But she never made a sound. "You're not a retriever, Eileen, you're a terrier. Go outside and kill something." Indeed, Eileen was a terrier, and with terrier determination, she resolved that Mr. Maybrick would ultimately throw the pinecone. She continued dancing, every few seconds picking up the pinecone and dropping it again. She was getting cuter and cuter. That was her weapon. Mr. Maybrick considered her a very manipulative animal. He looked away from her and took another sip of his (third) cup of coffee. Now she barked once, and when he looked at her, she went up on her hind legs. She had thighs like a wrestler - she seemed to float. Mr. Maybrick had often thought that a horse as athletic as this worthless dog would get into the Kentucky Derby, then the Breeders' Cup, win him ten million dollars on the track, and earn him five million a year in the breeding shed for, say, twenty years. That was $110 million; it had happened to others. He had been racing and breeding horses for eleven years, and it had never happened to him. This was just the sort of thing that made you a little resentful, and rightfully so, whatever Harold W. had to say about gratitude. He closed his eyes when he felt himself sliding: that way, beginning to count up the millions he had spent running horses and thinking about deserving. With his eyes closed, Al could hear her drop the pinecone rhythmically on the tile, chock chock chock chock, the bass, her little toenails clicking a tune around it. Didn't he deserve a really big horse? Didn't he? And then, while his eyes were still closed, dog and pinecone arrived suddenly in his lap, a hard, dense little weight but live, electric. With the shock, he nearly dropped his coffee cup, and as it was, spilled on the counter. "God damn it!" he shouted. Eileen jumped down and trotted away. "Hey! Come here, Eileen," he said. "Eileen!" Eileen sheared off into the living room, and he realized that he had forgotten to let her out. Mr. Maybrick put his arms up on the table and laid his head upon them.

fields.headline: Lepo Sumera
fields.standfirst: Estonian composer active in an age of musical and political freedom
fields.trailText: While writers often lead political double lives, composers only very rarely hold public office. The great Polish composer-pianist Ignacy Paderewski is the most celebrated example, having once been his country's prime minister; more recently, the Greek composer Thanos Mikroutsikos has served in the Greek cabinet, while the Estonian Lepo Sumera, who has died of heart failure aged 50, was his country's minister of culture from 1988-92, during the momentous period of independence from the Soviet Union.
fields.body:
While writers often lead political double lives, composers only very rarely hold public office. The great Polish composer-pianist Ignacy Paderewski is the most celebrated example, having once been his country's prime minister; more recently, the Greek composer Thanos Mikroutsikos has served in the Greek cabinet, while the Estonian Lepo Sumera, who has died of heart failure aged 50, was his country's minister of culture from 1988-92, during the momentous period of independence from the Soviet Union.

Sumera's importance to Estonia extends much further than his tenure of a relatively peripheral political post. After Heino Eller (1887-1970), whose last pupil Sumera was, and Arvo Pärt, Sumera became one of the most internationally renowned composers from his country, his works being taken up by orchestras throughout North America and Europe (though less readily in Britain), and as far afield as Australia and Cuba.

The modern orchestra was, without doubt, his preferred medium for expression, and his six symphonies and three concertos, all written between 1981 and this year, form the backbone of his output. Only last month, his Sixth Symphony was premiered in a concert to mark his 50th birthday, as, indeed, was another new work, the Concerto Grosso, a week earlier.

It has been suggested that the intensity of his involvement in preparing both scores for performance may have undermined his frail medical condition; he had a history of cardiac problems, and had undergone an exploratory operation some years earlier.

Sumera's music passed through a variety of styles over the years, in the 1970s employing a free form of Schoenberg's 12-note method, as well as collage. Later, he evolved an idiom that, in common with the music of many of his compatriots, seems to embrace minimalism, but the roots for which lay not in any American model, such as Philip Glass or Steve Reich, but rather in the ancient runic songs of Estonia.

Sumera first came to notice in 1972 with In Memoriam, his orchestral tribute to Eller. This work proved prophetic in its atmospheric orchestration and invigorating blend of various musical styles, features of later works such as the Third Symphony (1988). The five movements of his Fourth Symphony, Serena Borealis (1992), separately cover a wide range of moods - from calm quietude to unbridled ferocity; the Fifth (1995), written in one, half-hour-long movement, synthesised the disparate elements of his works of the previous decade into one of his most impressive works.

That Sumera also had an acute ear for instrumental sonority can be heard plainly in his brooding and intense Piano Concerto (1989, revised in 1997) and Cello Concerto (1999), as well as in earlier works - such as Music For Chamber Orchestra (1977), with its enchanting flute solos, or the solo piano Piece From The Year 1981. His output also includes much chamber music, as well as cantatas, more than 50 film scores, and a multi-media opera, Olivia's Master Class (1997), in which paintings by one of the characters are displayed via video.

In the late 1980s, Sumera became increasingly interested in electro-acoustic music, eventually founding, in 1995, the Electronic Music Studio at the Estonian Academy of Music. In 1999, his electro-acoustic work, Heart Affairs, used sounds made by the human heart - transformed electronically during performance - as well as echocardiographic images, including those of his own heart. He is credited with being the first Estonian composer to use a computer systematically for composition.

Sumera first studied music with the composer and musicologist Veljo Tormis (whose choral music has also begun, in recent years, to have considerable international appeal), moving in 1968 to Eller's class at the then Tallinn Conservatory (now the Estonian Academy of Music). He completed his studies with Heino Jürisalu, graduating in 1973, by which time he was already working as recording director for Estonian radio, a post he relinquished in 1980 after starting a two-year postgraduate course at Moscow Conservatory.

Sumera began teaching composition at the Estonian Academy in 1978, and was appointed profesor in 1993. His most renowned former pupil is Erkki-Sven Tüür, who delivered the oration at his funeral. He also served as chairman of the Estonian Composers' Union from 1993.

In 1972, he married the pianist Kersti Einasto, who survives him, and with whom he had two daughters, Kadri-Ann and Eva-Maria, and a son, Tammo. Guy Rickards

Lepo Sumera, composer and teacher, born May 8 1950; died June 2 2000

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Strips of juicy rumour flame-grilled and served with a selection of dips. And fries, of course
fields.trailText: There's a continental flavour to today's rumours. But where are Crespo, Kluivert, Pires and (ahem) Riseth off to?
fields.body:
Lazio are interested in Argentinian striker Hernan Crespo - and are ready to offer Sergio Conceicao, Marcelo Salas, or Matias Almeyda in part-exchange for him, according to Planet Football. No way, say Parma - they want £60m cash.

Patrick Kluivert wants to leave Barcelona for Juventus. "Playing in Italy again with my friends Edgar Davids and Edwin van der Sar is a definite possibility," he said. "There are negotiations going on and the move is a possibility, so I don't see a problem with talking about it. But we need to tie up a deal quickly because if you wait too long in football you miss the train." The Dutch striker would cost the Italians £7.5m.

Robert Pires is still undecided about whether to move to Arsenal or Real Madrid. "Frankly, I hesitate," he says. "In front of me, there are two very beautiful proposals - Arsenal for four or five years and Real Madrid for five years. There is a slight financial advantage for the Spanish... Real is the club of my dreams"

Sunderland could launch a £1.5m bid for Celtic's Norwegian international midfielder Vidar Riseth. When asked about the deal, Reid refused to either confirm or deny the reports saying: "I have a number of players on my shopping list, but things just don't happen overnight."

fields.headline: Peter McWilliams
fields.standfirst: Campaigner for the medicinal use of marijuana
fields.trailText: An architect of the growing campaign to legalise marijuana for medical purposes in the United States, the author Peter McWilliams, has died, aged 50, from Aids and cancer. He was awaiting sentence for possession of the drug, having fallen foul of the authorities after growing marijuana for patients whose doctors had recommended its use.
fields.body:
An architect of the growing campaign to legalise marijuana for medical purposes in the United States, the author Peter McWilliams, has died, aged 50, from Aids and cancer. He was awaiting sentence for possession of the drug, having fallen foul of the authorities after growing marijuana for patients whose doctors had recommended its use.

An active member of the Californian Libertarian party, which campaigns against government involvement in private lives, McWilliams wrote the bestseller, Ain't Nobody's Business If You Do, a study of how consensual acts, such as smoking cannabis, have been criminalised, particularly in America. He also found very different markets for The Personal Computer Book and How To Survive The Loss Of A Love.

Along with a colleague, Todd McCormick, McWilliams was arrested in 1998 after police raided an estate in the Bel-Air area of Los Angeles, where they were supposedly growing 4,000 marijuana plants. McWilliams argued that he wanted to supply the increasing number of cooperatives that dispense the drug to patients suffering from Aids, cancer, glaucoma, anorexia and arthritis, and whose doctors have recommended its use to alleviate pain and stimulate the appetite.

The federal authorities accused McWilliams of being a dealer. He argued that he was entitled to grow the drug because California's voters had, in 1996, passed an initiative calling for the legal use of marijuana for medical purposes. After being told by the trial judge that this did not constitute a defence, both men pleaded guilty.

McWilliams was due to be sentenced in August, and his case had become a cause celebre among campaigners for changes in the drugs laws. He was on $250,000 bail on condition that he did not use marijuana. This, he said, left him feeling weak and nauseous, and he finally choked to death on his vomit. Mark Hinkle, leader of the Californian Libertarian party, said the court's decision that McWilliams should not have access to the drug was, in effect, a "death sentence". McWilliams had taken to using marijuana after being diagnosed with non-Hodgkin's lymphona in 1996. Having not used the drug for many years, he found it helped him deal with the side-effects of chemotherapy. His arrest led to a greater debate on the issue, and how the law was imposed. Doctors in California cannot prescribe marijuana, but they can "recommend" it, and in a number of cities - including San Francisco and Santa Cruz - arrangements are made for patients to obtain the drug legally.

McWilliams's trial was seen as a test case on how far the state authorities would go in enacting the electorate's wishes on an issue that brought them into conflict with the federal government.

McWilliams is survived by his mother, Mary, and his brother, Michael. Duncan Campbell

 Peter McWilliams, writer and campaigner, born 5 August 1949; died 14 June 2000.

• This article was amended on 1 November 2011. The original endnote said that Peter McWilliams died on 15 June 2000 and that the initiative calling for the legal use of marijuana for medical purposes was passed in 1966. This has been corrected.

fields.headline: No 10: Boudewijn Zenden
fields.trailText: Reputation: "The new Marc Overmars"
fields.body:
Reputation: "The new Marc Overmars"

Really? Well he's fast, Dutch and plays on the left-wing - and has the frustrating tendency to let the odd cross or two go wayward.

But Zenden hardly set the world alight in Barcelona's Champions League Campaign, did he? We agree - until Euro 2000 we had him down as a poor man's Overmars. But against Denmark and France he's scored, set up several chances and generally looked a mighty fine player.

So where did it all start? At the prodigious Ajax academy, I wager Not quite. It was PSV scouts who spotted young Boudewijn playing in the amateur leagues and it wasn't long before he made his debut as an 18 year-old in August 1994, replacing Peter Hoekstra for the last five minutes.

Hoekstra? Didn't he play at Rangers? He certainly did. Once Zenden arrived, PSV had two left wingers, so they had to let one go. Despite interest from Ajax for Zenden they sold Hoekstra (who later moved to Glasgow) instead. It proved to be the right decision. At PSV Zenden prospered, and in 1997/98 he won the Dutch player of the year award. But as for Hoekstra...

No, I don't know where he is now either. Anyway, back to Zenden. Yesterday you told us that Zlatko Zahovic likes juice and Tina Turner. So what's Zenden into? Judo? Spot on! Until he was 16, he played both judo and football and, under the guidance of his father Pierre, a television commentator, he was three times judo champion of his home province of Limburg.

You're having me on, aren't you? Would we? "Judo is a very complete for excercising all muscles," says Zenden. "As you are on your own, it is also character building. The one-on-one contests are great, but I prefer the team spirit among soccer players."

Any chance of him coming to England? Well, according to reports in the British press last weekend, George Graham and Gerard Houllier are both willing to meet Barcelona's £4m valuation.

And the reality? Oh come on! For a start Zenden signed for Barca for £4m, so he's got to be worth at least £6m now. And he hasn't exactly expressed a desire to leave either. "I think it's going to be difficult for everyone with a different coach and a different chairman," he admits. "But I'm working on the basis that I'll still be there next year."

Do say: "Zenden sets the oranje alight!"

Don't say: "I don't know what Boudewijn Zenden means, but it scores an impressive 38 points in Scrabble!"

fields.headline: Nun the wiser
fields.standfirst: In an extract from an exclusive Guardian Unlimited interview, Julie Andrews talks to Peter Bradshaw about her new film, Relative Values
fields.trailText: In an extract from an exclusive Guardian Unlimited interview, Julie Andrews talks to Peter Bradshaw about her new film, Relative Values
fields.body:
Peter Bradshaw: You play the Countess of Marshwood and you're very patrician, and also a little mischievous. Did you enjoy playing that role?

Julie Andrews: Yes I did, it was a lovely role, delicious; I'm so pleased they asked me.

PB: And lovely language: do you relish working with Noel Coward? Have you played much Noel Coward before?

JA: I've sung a lot of his songs in my career, and I did a movie called Star in which I did excerpts from a lot of the things he had written, but I haven't actually done a play in full. This is wonderful, and really it's an unknown play.

PB: What songs did you sing?

JA: I've sung so many: Mad About the Boy, 20th Century Blues, London Pride and a lot of the bitter sweet songs.

PB: Was that in cabaret?

JA: All throughout my career. In my own concert act - I even sing Don't Put Your Daughter on the Stage Mrs Worthington, in reference to myself!

PB: You have another big movie smash in London, semi-perpetually, and that's of course Sing-along-a-Sound of Music at the Prince of Wales cinema where people turn up for the chance to sing along to the lyric. It's a situationist happening now in London - it's a real phenomenon. And it's very popular, very greatly but not solely, with the gay community. I wondered what you thought of becoming a gay icon yourself?

JA: I don't think about it, truthfully. I'm thrilled if I am, I'm awfully pleased everyone is flocking to see it. It's all done in such good fun, this karaoke, and I believe the whole thing's going to America. I also think they're going to do something like Grease next.

PB: Have you been to see Sing-along-a-Sound of Music?

JA: No, but I'd love to be a fly on the wall. How do I go - as myself in disguise?

PB: Interesting question! I read somewhere that after the Queen you're the 2nd most dreamed-about person. You have this legendary status - more than celebrity status, a kind of mythic status.

JA: I think it's the size of those roles and the fact that they've been around for such a long time.

PB: Do they seem distant now?

JA: No, they don't. Actually it's because they are ever-present, they seem to keep coming around again and again, particularly Poppins and The Sound of Music, and also to some extent Victor Victoria. I'm just very glad to have been a part of those movies.

PB: What is it, do you think, about The Sound of Music that hooks into people's minds so emphatically?

JA: I think a quality of decency and goodness and innocence, perhaps. It's a rattling good story. You put religion and those beautiful mountains and children and that great music altogether and it's going to give you a lovely feeling. Also it's a brilliantly crafted movie; everything about it was done so professionally and well. It wasn't just slapped together, it was probably at that time the beginning of the end of an era of brilliantly crafted movies, and that's all come back again - for a while it was very out of fashion.

PB: I don't know if you've seen this year's Palme D'Or winner, Dancer in the Dark, which is partly based on The Sound of Music which has Catherine Deneuve and Björk rehearsing the Favourite Things sequence from The Sound of Music. It's a sensational, a very controversial film and I was wondering if you'd seen it?

JA: No I haven't, and you're the first person that's talked about it. I'd love to see it.

PB: Back to Coward [and Relative Values]. It's a very British movie and perhaps specifically a very English movie.

JA: I think that's it's charm. It's one of the those ensemble pieces that the British do so well.

PB: Talking about British movies, I was wondering what you thought about the new resurgence in British movie making - very different from Noel Coward.

JA: I'm thrilled. The British have always been great at making movies, but they're just so hard to get distributed and made and they cost so much.

PB: Do you have any favourites, have you seen Trainspotting?

JA: I love The Full Monty which is about to be a musical of course down on Broadway_ I'm very partial to some of the old British movies like The Lavender Hill Mob and I'm All Right Jack.

PB: Congratulations on your latest film. It's been a pleasure to meet you.

webTitle: Loyalist terror group 'suspends' threat to resume violence

fields.headline: Loyalist terror group 'suspends' threat to resume violence
fields.trailText: The loyalist Ulster Freedom Fighters today "suspended" the threat to end their ceasefire.
fields.body:
The loyalist Ulster Freedom Fighters today "suspended" the threat to end their ceasefire.

The paramilitary group, which earlier this week warned it would shoot anyone attacking Protestant homes in north and west Belfast, said talks should now begin between community leaders.

Tensions in the area are high before tomorrow's Orange Order march past nationalist homes in the city. But after appeals by politicians and the organisation's political wing, the Ulster Democratic party, the UFF said it wanted dialogue.

The full text of today's statement by the UFF, one of Northern Ireland's most ruthless terrorist groups, said: "In response to an appeal from the Ulster Democratic party and in recognition of the potential for dialogue at a community level, the UFF leadership suspends its decision of June 20 2000.

"We state clearly that attacks on Protestant homes cannot be tolerated, but affirms our desire to have this problem resolved peacefully. The onus is now on community leaders to engage seriously and find a resolution of the issue."

The UFF had threatened to call off its ceasefire from midnight on Tuesday.

John White, chairman of the UDP, said: "This is a positive statement. It gives us an opportunity to resolve this issue peacefully. We will now try to organise a series of meetings as soon as possible. At the same time, I would appeal to the UFF leadership to withdraw its threat completely."

Progressive Unionist party assembly member David Ervine said he hoped the UFF move would help defuse tensions between Catholics and Protestants living in Belfast's flashpoint areas.

The East Belfast MLA, whose party is linked to the other mainstream loyalist paramilitary group on ceasefire, the Ulster Volunteer Force, said: "Wisdom has prevailed. It seems other people who did not issue such threats have concentrated minds and moved them towards the only rational outcome other than what was suggested.

"Obviously we hope this will begin to defuse tensions in Belfast between communities on the ground, but that will still require an awful lot of hard work."

Sinn Fein assembly member Gerry Kelly said the suspension of the UFF's threat to break its ceasefire proved that it "should never have been made". The North Belfast MLA claimed: "Its withdrawal is a tacit acknowledgement by the UFF that they were wrong.

"Despite this apparent public withdrawal of the threat to kill Catholics, I would urge everyone to remain vigilant."

Mr Kelly claimed that loyalist groups - and the UFF in particular - in north and west Belfast were "intent on stirring up sectarian attacks on Catholic residents, particularly around planned Orange marches".

He expressed concern about plans for an Orange parade through the Springfield Road in the west of the city. A Sinn Fein delegation was due to meet the parades commission about today's march.

fields.headline: No 10: Boudewijn Zenden
fields.trailText: Reputation: "The new Marc Overmars"
fields.body:
Reputation: "The new Marc Overmars"

Really? Well he's fast, Dutch and plays on the left-wing - and has the frustrating tendency to let the odd cross or two go wayward.

But Zenden hardly set the world alight in Barcelona's Champions League Campaign, did he? We agree - until Euro 2000 we had him down as a poor man's Overmars. But against Denmark and France he's scored, set up several chances and generally looked a mighty fine player.

So where did it all start? At the prodigious Ajax academy, I wager Not quite. It was PSV scouts who spotted young Boudewijn playing in the amateur leagues and it wasn't long before he made his debut as an 18 year-old in August 1994, replacing Peter Hoekstra for the last five minutes.

Hoekstra? Didn't he play at Rangers? He certainly did. Once Zenden arrived, PSV had two left wingers, so they had to let one go. Despite interest from Ajax for Zenden they sold Hoekstra (who later moved to Glasgow) instead. It proved to be the right decision. At PSV Zenden prospered, and in 1997/98 he won the Dutch player of the year award. But as for Hoekstra...

No, I don't know where he is now either. Anyway, back to Zenden. Yesterday you told us that Zlatko Zahovic likes juice and Tina Turner. So what's Zenden into? Judo? Spot on! Until he was 16, he played both judo and football and, under the guidance of his father Pierre, a television commentator, he was three times judo champion of his home province of Limburg.

You're having me on, aren't you? Would we? "Judo is a very complete for excercising all muscles," says Zenden. "As you are on your own, it is also character building. The one-on-one contests are great, but I prefer the team spirit among soccer players."

Any chance of him coming to England? Well, according to reports in the British press last weekend, George Graham and Gerard Houllier are both willing to meet Barcelona's £4m valuation.

And the reality? Oh come on! For a start Zenden signed for Barca for £4m, so he's got to be worth at least £6m now. And he hasn't exactly expressed a desire to leave either. "I think it's going to be difficult for everyone with a different coach and a different chairman," he admits. "But I'm working on the basis that I'll still be there next year."

Do say: "Zenden sets the oranje alight!"

Don't say: "I don't know what Boudewijn Zenden means, but it scores an impressive 38 points in Scrabble!"

webTitle: British Oscars hopes for more glitz and dazzle in February slot

fields.headline: British Oscars hopes for more glitz and dazzle in February slot
fields.trailText: As we reported in April, it is looking increasingly likely that plans to move The British Academy of Film and Television Arts film awards ceremony to a slot several weeks before the Oscars are going ahead
fields.body:
As we reported in April, it is looking increasingly likely that plans to move The British Academy of Film and Television Arts film awards ceremony to a slot before the Oscars are going ahead.

The awards - the UK version of the Oscars - are currently held two weeks after the Academy Awards, but the event has attracted criticism for a scheduling that leaves it looking anticlimactic after the glitz and dazzle of Oscar night. The new schedule would put them in late February, ie a month before the Oscars.

Key film distributors - who would be among those most affected by the move - have come out in support of the change. Dreamworks, Pathe Distribution and Film Four are all backing the plan which would see the ceremony being held next year on 25 February.

DreamWorks' Peter Dunne said "more talent will come because the Baftas will be strategically more important." It is also hoped that a pre-Oscar slot could generate more press coverage for the event, which in turn would promote British and overseas cinema in the UK.

A move to 25 February could mean that the Baftas would replace The Golden Globes as an important Oscar indicator. FilmFour's Peter Buckingham agrees: "A number of British Academy members are also American Academy members... From the point of view of the public and the press [the Baftas] will be become an important staging point."

Unlike many other countries which tend to celebrate local titles, the awards have always been an international rather than a purely British showcase. This year, American Beauty picked up six statuettes, and high-profile stars such as Kevin Spacey and Dustin Hoffman were in attendance. There was much criticism however, of its amateurish presentation.

If the plan goes ahead, the revised deadline for screening films to Bafta members will be 17 December, while films will have to have played to a paying audience for seven consecutive days in the UK prior to 1 February and be on general release by 18 March.

webTitle: Cook queries wisdom of spy chief's book

fields.headline: Cook queries wisdom of spy chief's book
fields.trailText: Robin Cook last night made a surprise intervention in the Whitehall row over the decision by Dame Stella Rimington to publish her memoirs by calling on the former head of MI5 to think again.
fields.body:
Robin Cook last night made a surprise intervention in the Whitehall row over the decision by Dame Stella Rimington to publish her memoirs by calling on the former head of MI5 to think again.

His intervention, which came after a rare Commons debate on the security and intelligence services, contrasts with the implicit backing she received from Downing Street when her decision was leaked last month.

It is all the more surprising since the foreign secretary is responsible for MI6 and GCHQ but not for MI5 which is answerable to the home secretary, Jack Straw.

Whitehall officials believe the original leak - to the Sun newspaper - came from MI6 seizing the opportunity to embarrass its "sister service".

Mr Cook told MPs he understood Dame Stella had not yet submitted her draft to a publisher. "There is still time for her to reflect on whether it would be right for her to do so," he said.

Mr Cook said Dame Stella's text had been submitted for scrutiny by the security agencies and she had given her agreement that nothing would be published that would "undermine national security"

He added: "While there may be nothing that would be of direct compromise to national security, I detect that MPs ... would wish her to reflect on the example it would set and whether it would be wise to proceed in this way."

Tory MPs had earlier criticised her decision to write her memoirs.

The government, meanwhile, was pressed to set up a special tribunal to allow officers of the three security and intelligence agencies to air their grievances.

A number of Labour backbenchers also urged the government to establish a Commons select committee to monitor the agencies's work .

Pressure for a special tribunal came from Tom King, the former Conservative cabinet minister and chairman of the parliamentary intelligence and security committee which meets in private, whose members are appointed by the prime minister, and whose mandate is limited.

Dale Campbell-Savours, a Labour member of the committee, added his voice to the idea. He said security service employees needed a system through which to pursue grievances. He added that potential whistle-blowers should be allowed to go to their MP.

Richard Tomlinson, the renegade MI6 officer jailed for breaking the Official Secrets Act and now on the run in Italy, was prevented from taking his case to an industrial tribunal after he was sacked.

At the government's behest, he has been expelled from France, Switzerland, and Germany, after threatening to write a book. David Shayler, the former MI5 officer now living in Paris, has criticised the existing system whereby staff with grievances can go to a government-appointed staff counsellor.

Alan Beith, Liberal Democrat deputy leader who is also a member of the King committee, told MPs the greatest difficulty the body had was in obtaining information on advice given to ministers.

In a reference to the Melita Norwood spy saga - whose handling was attacked in a report by the committee last week - he said the central issue was "who knew what and when".

He added: "There really is no argument now that mistakes were made by the security service and by the home office, both over the failure to consult properly about non prosecution and about the handling and publication of the material."

Earlier, Mr Straw said MI5 had learned "a great deal" from the affair. The ISC report said ministers were kept in the dark about Mrs Norwood's role as a spy which was minor but was exaggerated afterthe publication of a book by the former KGB officer, Vasili Mitrokhin, last year.

Ann Widdecombe, the shadow home secretary said she found it "regrettable that confessed traitors such as Melita Norwood would never be prosecuted for betraying their country".
