webTitle: Oxford denies Blair degree in revenge for elitism row

fields.headline: Oxford denies Blair degree in revenge for elitism row
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is to be snubbed by Oxford University and denied an honorary degree as his alma mater exacts its revenge for the government's assault on Oxbridge elitism.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is to be snubbed by Oxford University and denied an honorary degree as his alma mater exacts its revenge for the government's assault on Oxbridge elitism.

Lord Jenkins of Hillhead, the chancellor of Oxford and a sometime Blair mentor, yesterday confirmed that the prime minister is to be shunned in the same way as Lady Thatcher, who was denied an honorary degree in the 1980s in protest at education cuts.

Asked in a magazine interview whether Mr Blair would receive the honorary degree that is normally handed out to Oxford graduates who go on to become prime minister, Lord Jenkins gave the curt reply: "No, not now."

Lord Jenkins launched a scathing attack on the chancellor, Gordon Brown, who denounced as "an absolute scandal" the decision by Magdalen College to deny a place to Laura Spence, the Tyneside sixth-former who has a comprehensive school background.

Declaring that he made it to Oxford from a "most awful school", Lord Jenkins said: "Gordon Brown had a singularly ill-chosen target. The examiners of Magdalen are a very progressive body of men. The phrases he used - the old school tie, the old boy network - it was absolutely farcical."

Lord Jenkins, who pointed out that Mr Brown's own alma mater, Edinburgh University, has more Etonians than Oxford, said governments should steer clear of trying to influence university admissions.

"There should be no question of governments, or agents of governments, deciding which individual should or should not be admitted to university," he said. "It would be intolerable that someone should be excluded on the grounds that they are from a privileged school."

Downing Street yesterday dismissed Lord Jenkins' intervention. The prime minister's spokesman said: "Tony Blair is rather more concerned to make sure that more young people have the opportunity to get real degrees rather than worrying about getting an honorary degree."

However, Lord Jenkins' attack on Mr Brown will be shared by some members of the prime minister's inner circle, who were dismayed by the chancellor's provocative intervention in the Laura Spence affair.

Mr Brown's harsh rhetoric was one of the factors that prompted the prime minister's "middle Britain" speech to the Women's Institute, which backfired so spectacularly.

Lord Jenkins attempted to row back on his remarks yesterday, letting it be known that he felt they had been taken out of context. He also released a statement saying that Oxford had "got into the habit" of offering honorary degrees only to heads of state. But he includes himself in such exalted company: during his Spectator interview, he pointed out that he was awarded an honorary degree in 1969.

In his interview the former SDP leader was at his sniffy best, saying that the prime minister possessed a "second- class mind". Asked whether he thought Mr Brown was brighter than Mr Blair, Lord Jenkins said: "Blair thinks he is. He says Gordon has a brilliant intellect."

Lord Jenkins also rounded on his pupil for failing to take a lead on the euro. "It is a fallacy to believe that you can pay out the rope and let the other side make all the running, and then believe that after the election you can suddenly convert the public," he said.
fields.bodyText: Tony Blair is to be snubbed by Oxford University and denied an honorary degree as his alma mater exacts its revenge for the government's assault on Oxbridge elitism. Lord Jenkins of Hillhead, the chancellor of Oxford and a sometime Blair mentor, yesterday confirmed that the prime minister is to be shunned in the same way as Lady Thatcher, who was denied an honorary degree in the 1980s in protest at education cuts. Asked in a magazine interview whether Mr Blair would receive the honorary degree that is normally handed out to Oxford graduates who go on to become prime minister, Lord Jenkins gave the curt reply: "No, not now." Lord Jenkins launched a scathing attack on the chancellor, Gordon Brown, who denounced as "an absolute scandal" the decision by Magdalen College to deny a place to Laura Spence, the Tyneside sixth-former who has a comprehensive school background. Declaring that he made it to Oxford from a "most awful school", Lord Jenkins said: "Gordon Brown had a singularly ill-chosen target. The examiners of Magdalen are a very progressive body of men. The phrases he used - the old school tie, the old boy network - it was absolutely farcical." Lord Jenkins, who pointed out that Mr Brown's own alma mater, Edinburgh University, has more Etonians than Oxford, said governments should steer clear of trying to influence university admissions. "There should be no question of governments, or agents of governments, deciding which individual should or should not be admitted to university," he said. "It would be intolerable that someone should be excluded on the grounds that they are from a privileged school." Downing Street yesterday dismissed Lord Jenkins' intervention. The prime minister's spokesman said: "Tony Blair is rather more concerned to make sure that more young people have the opportunity to get real degrees rather than worrying about getting an honorary degree." However, Lord Jenkins' attack on Mr Brown will be shared by some members of the prime minister's inner circle, who were dismayed by the chancellor's provocative intervention in the Laura Spence affair. Mr Brown's harsh rhetoric was one of the factors that prompted the prime minister's "middle Britain" speech to the Women's Institute, which backfired so spectacularly. Lord Jenkins attempted to row back on his remarks yesterday, letting it be known that he felt they had been taken out of context. He also released a statement saying that Oxford had "got into the habit" of offering honorary degrees only to heads of state. But he includes himself in such exalted company: during his Spectator interview, he pointed out that he was awarded an honorary degree in 1969. In his interview the former SDP leader was at his sniffy best, saying that the prime minister possessed a "second- class mind". Asked whether he thought Mr Brown was brighter than Mr Blair, Lord Jenkins said: "Blair thinks he is. He says Gordon has a brilliant intellect." webTitle: Thousands of teachers set to win £2,000 rise

fields.headline: Thousands of teachers set to win £2,000 rise
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Nearly 200,000 classroom teachers have applied for a £2,000 performance-related pay rise and most can be expected to receive it, the school standards minister, Estelle Morris, announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Nearly 200,000 classroom teachers have applied for a £2,000 performance-related pay rise and most can be expected to receive it, the school standards minister, Estelle Morris, announced yesterday.

The release of figures showing that 197,000 teachers, more than three-quarters of the 250,000 eligible, have put in for the award, coincided with a decision by the two largest teaching unions to take industrial action against extra administrative work.

The National Union of Teachers and the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers unveiled a rare joint campaign, amounting to an effective work to rule against non-teaching tasks. They accused the government of timing the pay announcement in an attempt to overshadow their decision, though this was denied.

The unions have instructed their members not to carry out a range of tasks including bulk photocopying, processing exam marks, chasing pupil absences, analysing attendance figures, administering cover, and ordering supplies.

Members were told to attend only one evening meeting a week, avoid meetings which lasted more than 60 minutes, and to boycott planning meetings before school inspections. Reports should be limited to one a year per pupil, and should be no longer than 400 words per pupil and 40 words per subject.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the NASUWT, described the "blitz on bureaucracy" as "action with a halo". A members' ballot had revealed 94.3% supported industrial action. Of about 120,000 eligible to vote, 47,190 had done so, with 45,175 in favour of action.

"The action is pupil friendly. No child will lose a single second of education. Indeed the action will enhance education by freeing teachers from burdens which hinder the effective performance of their duties," Mr de Gruchy said.

The unions said their action was based on the Department for Education and Employment's own directives on cutting red tape.

"Those recommendations have not been fully implemented: teachers are still being asked to carry out tasks which distract from their responsibilities to their pupils. The situation can no longer be tolerated," said the NUT general secretary, Doug McAvoy.

Ms Morris said more needed to be done to reduce bureaucracy in schools, but teachers had to accept some administrative work was inevitable.

She expected most of those who had applied for the pay award to be successful. Many of the 50,000 teachers who did not apply would do so next year, she believed.

The rise is for classroom teachers who do not have any formal management responsibility and have reached the top of their pay scale, currently £23,958.

The £2,000 award is in addition to the 3.3% across-the-board rise for teachers announced in the spring, and the government expects some classroom teachers soon to be earning more than £30,000.

For the first time teachers' pay was being based on their success in teaching in the classroom, Ms Morris said. "At the end of the day our aspirations for schools and parents' aspirations for their children will depend on the quality of teaching in our classrooms. We have put in place a system that will reward that."

The pay claims will be assessed by the applicant's head teacher and an outside body, Cambridge Education Associates.

fields.headline: Literacy loophole
fields.standfirst:
Children are still failing the third 'r'
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: School inspectors have warned the education secretary that his ambitious literacy target for 11-year-olds will be missed unless the writing skills of primary school pupils are improved.
fields.body:
School inspectors have warned the education secretary that his ambitious literacy target for 11-year-olds will be missed unless the writing skills of primary school pupils are improved. Were the "doom and gloom" merchants among the teaching unions and education academics right to oppose the government's literacy and numeracy hours? Far from it. Were ministers wrong to interfere in an area where professional independence had traditionally ruled? Not at all. Ministers were right to set ambitious targets for the year 2002 and sensible in the methods which they adopted to achieve them.

Progress has been phenomenal. A school system in which four years ago more than half of all 11-year-olds were failing to reach expected standards, is now well on its way to reaching the 75% goal for numeracy and making good progress towards the 80% literacy target. Last year there was a 10% rise in numeracy (to 69%), and a 10% rise in reading (now 81%) but only a 3% rise in writing, languishing at a lowly 54%. The new report from the inspectors warns ministers that not enough attention is being given to developing writing skills, not enough time to grammar and technical knowledge, too much time on ideas and too little on the writing process. One-quarter of 300 literacy lessons observed were unsatisfactory. It should not be surprising that pupils find learning to read (a decoding procedure) easier than learning to write (an encoding process). Until recently, most teachers came out of a training process which emphasised imagination and empathy and downplayed practical technical skills. But now daily literacy and numeracy hours are conducted in all 20,000 primary schools; the necessary curriculum is in place; where teachers have needed guidance, it's provided; schools which are succeeding with their own approach can continue to follow it; tests at seven and 11 are monitoring the progress that children are making. Much more competent - and confident - primary pupils are moving into the secondary system.

The political problem is David Blunkett's promise to resign if schools fail to achieve the literacy goal. He must not panic. There are still two years to go. The reading and maths scores have demonstrated the success which a highly focused campaign can achieve. Time now for a two-year blitz on writing - a third "r" equally as important as the other two.

webTitle: Up to nine Britons among 15 killed in Australian hostel blaze

fields.headline: Up to nine Britons among 15 killed in Australian hostel blaze
fields.trailText: Fifteen backpackers, including up to nine young Britons, died yesterday when a fire ripped through a busy Australian hostel.
fields.body:
Fifteen backpackers, including up to nine young Britons, died yesterday when a fire ripped through a busy Australian hostel.

Authorities were searching for a man who was seen outside the Palace Backpackers Hostel in Childers, 130 miles north of Brisbane, just before the fire began. The cause of the blaze was not known, but police have not ruled out the possibility of arson.

Survivors said the blaze spread rapidly through the 100-year-old building and some said they had heard no fire alarm.

About 20 Britons were among the survivors, the Foreign Office said. Some fled the building in their underwear as the fire raged on, shattering windows.

The authorities said that of the 90 people thought to have been inside, 15 had died. Three who had been unaccounted for were later traced.

No names of the dead and missing have been released, but local police said they came from the UK, Australia, Holland, Spain, Japan and South Korea. According to one unconfirmed report, the dead included five English people, two Welsh and two Irish.

One local hostel owner said that a backpacker kicked out of the hostel a week ago had threatened to seek revenge. Rob Haddow, manager of the nearby Federal Hotel, said: "He went berserk and the owners threw him out. He said 'I'm going to get them'  Then some of the backpackers said he was seen at the site last night."

A police spokeswoman said: "We are treating it as a crime scene, but we cannot comment at this stage on possible causes." She said the hostel had been declared structurally safe and officers had gone in to look for bodies.

She said it would take days to identify the bodies of those who had perished. "We may need dental records and DNA tests to identify the dead, who will all be brought back to Brisbane to a forensic centre."

Childers, a Queensland town of 1,500 people, relies on backpackers looking for pocket money to pick produce from nearby farms. As many as 500 backpackers a day descend on local farms during the season.

Survivors described the desperate scramble to escape the blaze. Keith O'Brien, thought to be from Wigan, said he had to kick down a door and squeeze though window bars. "The smoke was like you couldn't see in front of your face," he said.

"In the room the door was shut, so I ended up kicking the door in and climbed out a window. But there were bars on the window  so I shoved my friend through and she got pulled out, and then some of the firemen yanked me out."

Another survivor, an English backpacker identified only as Emma, said she realised there was a fire as soon as she woke up and she screamed at her room-mates to get out. She told Australian television: "We heard cracking around us, windows, one of the girls woke up ... I instantly knew it was a fire, and so I screamed at everybody to get out."

Emma said her room fronted on to the balcony of the historic timber building and she and her room-mates were able to escape onto the veranda and run across the roof to an adjoining shop.

Louise Brewster, 19, from Hertfordshire, said she feared that at least two of her friends had died in the fire. "I worked with them both yesterday, so it's such a shock," said Ms Brewster, who was camping near the hostel.

It took firefighters four hours to tackle the blaze and by daybreak charred pieces of wrought iron could be seen littering the street while a scorched potted palm tree remained on the hostel's second-floor balcony. Footprints could be seen on the metal roof of the shop next door to the hostel, the only escape route for some of those who fled the blaze from the second level.

Wooden bunk beds could be seen through the front door of the destroyed hostel as firefighters rolled up hoses. A giant crane worked overhead, picking pieces of burned wood in an effort to check the stability of the remaining walls.

Australian Prime Minister John Howard described the fire as "a terrible tragedy".

Local fire commissioner Jeff Wright said the building had had regular safety checks and was equipped with smoke detectors. But some survivors told police they had not heard any alarms going off.

An emergency number has been set up for anxious relatives: 0061 741 26 22 22.

webTitle: The goalkeeper's fear of being picked

fields.headline: The goalkeeper's fear of being picked
fields.trailText: Why the FA should leave it to Kevin and why Sander Westerveld wants out.
fields.body:
* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ADVERTISEMENT

Play football, see football, talk football, breathe football. The Euro is brought to you in association with www.breathe.com It's amazing what happens when you breathe.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EUROTALK

"Frankly, I hesitate. In front of me, there are two very beautiful proposals - Arsenal for four or five years and Real Madrid for five years" - France winger Robert Pires on his transfer dilemma.

"There is a slight financial advantage for the Spanish... Real is the club of my dreams" - Hmm, doesn't sound like much of a dilemma to us.

THE EURO-TORIAL

Yesterday FA Chairman Geoff Thompson crawled out of the Lancaster Gate woodwork and gave Kevin Keegan a subtle, but stinging, rebuke. Go and seek some coaching advice from Howard Wilkinson, he was told. And while you are at it, allow him a great say in deciding tactics too.

"We have got a very good Technical Director and a lot of good coaches and we have to integrate that into the full international set-up," said Thompson. "I think Kevin may need a little bit of help in that department, and he would accept that himself."

All this sounds mighty ominous. No wonder seasoned Keegan-watchers are wondering whether he'll jump ship - yet again - if England don't get a result against Germany in their first World Cup 2002 qualifying game.

But why are the FA are placing such trust in Wilkinson's tactical acumen? Those of us who remember his Sheffield Wednesday and Leeds days haven't forgotten his rigid 4-4-2 formations, or those long hopeful balls to Lee Chapman - tactics straight out of the Charles Hughes football manual.

We're told we shouldn't worry, because apparently Wilkinson's had a Road to Damascus conversion: embracing the continental style and an enterprising 4-1-2-3 formation which, according to the Express, "research shows is the most successful in international football".

How they've worked that out we don't know: Brazil certainly don't play it - and nor do any team in Euro 2000 as far as we can work out. And his record with it at the European U-21 Championship wasn't very good either: a team that qualified (under Peter Taylor) with 100 per cent record lost two of their three games. Remind you of anyone?

CLICHÉS? THEY'RE CRAZY, ZANY, BONKERS

Goalkeepers. They're mad, aren't they? Well no, actually, they're not. They're professional athletes who are employed to stop footballs going into nets using their hands and bodies.

For example, you could write that Sander Westerveld is a loon for trying to talk himself out of the Dutch starting eleven by saying this: "I think it's better for the team that van der Saar plays because I still think he is the best goalkeeper we have."

And you could feasibly pen a paragraph about what a nutter he is in the light of these comments: "I'm a very good goalkeeper, but van der Saar is one of the best in the world, and we want to become European champions, so it's better for the team and for me if he plays."

But if you did, we'd have to come round to your house and take steps to make you stop writing. Either by breaking all your fingers or scribbling on a big pad with your pen for ages and ages until we've used up all your ink. We're not sure which.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

A MESSAGE FROM BREATHE.COM

You'll get a wider view of Euro 2000 at www.breathe.com - click on the link on the left hand side. See how you score with fantasy share trading and you could win a 28" wide screen TV.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EURONEWS

Portugal defender Secretario is suffering from an injured right arm and will miss the quarter-final against Turkey. He will be replaced in defence by Abel Xavier, the only man at Euro 2000 whose hair appears to have been soaked in the juice from chewing tobacco.

Fernando Hierro is a doubt for Spain's quarter-final match against France. "He is still feeling inflammation in the adductor muscles in his right knee, which is why he is a doubt," explained the team doctor, as if the Euro understood what he was on about.

Scottish referee Hugh Dallas has been chosen by Uefa as one of the eight referees to stay on at the tournament after the group stages. Dallas will be the fourth official at the quarter-final between France and Spain and is expected to fling his cards around like a man possessed and award questionable penalties during one of the semi-finals.

The two Yugoslavia fans who tried to attack referee Gilles Veissiere in their country's match against Spain have been ordered to leave Belgium. Do you think they'll go to Holland?

EURORUMOUR with KAREL POBORSKY

Hello there, new Bradford boss Chris Hutchings here! Karel can't do the rumours at the moment - he's packing all his stuff up ready to go home - so he's asked me, Chris Hutchings, to step in and do the rumours. webTitle: Labour hold Tottenham on minimal turnout

fields.headline: Labour hold Tottenham on minimal turnout
fields.trailText: Labour held their seat in the Tottenham by-election with the election of Britain's youngest MP, David Lammy. The party's majority was reduced, although turnout was even lower than anticipated at 25.43%.
fields.body:
Labour held their seat in the Tottenham by-election with the election of Britain's youngest MP, David Lammy. The party's majority was reduced, although turnout was even lower than anticipated at 25.43%.

After a low-key campaign for the north London seat, Mr Lammy succeeds Bernie Grant, whose death caused the contest.

Mr Lammy took 53% of the vote, a 15% swing away from Labour, with Liberal Democrats reaping most of the benefit and snatching second position from Tories.

Liberal Democrat Leader Charles Kennedy hailed the performance of his candidate Duncan Hames and said the Lib Dems were "the only party able to claim success from the Tottenham result".

But Conservative chairman Michael Ancram insisted his party's Jane Ellison had suffered from Tory supporters staying at home and said the Labour vote had "plummeted to its lowest share for several years, due to widespread disillusionment with the Government."

Mr Lammy, who was born in the constituency, is a London Assembly Member and a barrister. At 27 he becomes the baby of the Commons - being just three weeks younger than Christopher Lesley, his party colleague from Shipley, Yorkshire.

He took the Tottenham seat with 8,785, over Mr Hames' 3,139 and Miss Ellison's 2,634, on a turnout of just 16,417 - 25.43%.

webTitle: Eight Britons feared dead in Australian backpacker hostel fire

fields.headline: Eight Britons feared dead in Australian backpacker hostel fire
fields.trailText: Up to eight British people were believed to have died in a fire at a backpackers hostel in southern Queensland, Australia, early today.
fields.body:
Up to eight British people were believed to have died in a fire at a backpackers hostel in southern Queensland, Australia, early today.

Fifteen people were killed in the blaze in the Palace Backpackers Hostel, a 100-year-old, two-storey, wooden building, in Childers, 130 miles north of Brisbane, according to the town's mayor Bill Trevor. A further three were unaccounted for.

"There were British people involved and the latest information we have from the police who have been interviewing survivors is that three or possibly four English people are unaccounted for, as well as two Welsh people and two Irish people.

"It's highly likely that they are among the dead," he said.

The backpackers, who mostly worked picking fruit on local farms, had become part of the town, and their deaths have devastated the small community.

"This has just torn the guts out of this community," said Mr Trevor. "They weren't just backpackers. They lived with us, worked with us and played with us. We're all finding it very difficult."

About 80 people were believed to have been staying in the building at the time of the fire, and Mr Trevor said that 62 had been rescued.

The cause of the fire was unknown but police were treating it as a crime scene. It took firefighters four hours to put out the blaze. Many of those at the hostel were working as fruit pickers in the area.

Keith O'Brien, one of dozens of international backpackers staying at the building and working in nearby farms, said he woke to the smashing of glass but was not immediately aware of the fire. "We're doing fruit picking and they usually wake you up in the morning if you oversleep, so at first we thought that's what it was.

You couldn't see your hand, the smoke was so thick. I ended up being dragged through a window."

Mr O'Brien added: "There were Australians, Kiwis, English, Scottish, Welsh, Koreans, Japanese - you name it, there was someone from that country in this hotel."

Another British backpacker, who did not give her name, said she was also alerted to the fire when she heard the sound of breaking glass. "I was lying awake and suddenly I heard the most tremendous sound of cracking glass.

"I screamed at the girls in my dorm, 'Wake up' because I thought somebody was trying to break the place up.

"We were really lucky. We didn't see the smoke of flames until we got out. Once we were out on the roof panic set in. The people who were still getting out started to scream."

Wayne Heidrich, the editor of the town's newspaper, Isis Town and Country, said terrified survivors were in shock when he arrived at the scene.

webTitle: Brown urged to alter euro tactics

fields.headline: Brown urged to alter euro tactics
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown is being challenged by cabinet pro-Europeans to make an assessment before the general election of Britain's readiness to join the euro in order to avoid looking shifty or dishonest during campaigning.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown is being challenged by cabinet pro-Europeans to make an assessment before the general election of Britain's readiness to join the euro in order to avoid looking shifty or dishonest during campaigning.

The chancellor is insisting that the issue can be kept out of the election campaign by delaying an assessment of his five tests until early in the next parliament.

The pressure for a fundamental shift in government tactics comes only days after Tony Blair ordered cabinet members to put on an elaborate show of unity over the euro at the EU summit in Portugal at the weekend. Pro-Europeans believe the government will simply not survive vigorous questioning and cam-paigning on the issue before the election if it continues to give no view on whether the British economy is near to being ready to join the euro.

The call for a shift in tactics is being supported by Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, and Robin Cook, the foreign secretary. It is also known that Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, believes the current policy will need adjustment before the election.

Those pressing for an assessment by the Treasury, or a body appointed by the Treasury, before the election believe its report would show that the British economic cycle is not yet aligned with the continent, but is close to being so. But such a report would give the government an intellectually coherent position.

The chancellor, intent on fighting the election on the government's successful economic record, believes he can keep a lid on the euro debate by saying he will not provide a running commentary on the tests and by pledging that they will be assessed early in the next parliament. The Treasury is adamant that there will be no change in policy, or tactics.

But the pro-European wing believes ministers will be left looking shifty and dishonest if they stonewall over the issue. They point out that other organisations such as the Organisation for European Cooperation and Development and the European Central Bank have recently said that the British economy is close to convergence.

They predict a torrent of similar assessments from other organisations in the run-up to the election and during the campaign. A position of no comment from the government will leave ministers facing accusations of a hidden agenda.

In the first sign that Michael Portillo intends to make the tests a key election issue, the shadow chancellor said yesterday: "Mr Brown's tests will simply not survive the scrutiny of an election. They will fall apart once ministers get into the TV studios. The tests in any case are almost completely subjective. Four of them are no more than matters of opinion. They were always intended to give the government a free hand to decide whatever it wanted, whenever it wanted. This remains a cabinet divided over tactics."

Further pressure on the government will come in the autumn when the Liberal Democrats adjust their policy and establish the criteria on which they believe Britain should make its judgment on joining. One of them is likely to be the exchange rate.

Mr Blair yesterday again insisted that the assessment will not be made until after the election. He said: "Whatever you have read, our policy has not changed and will not change.''

fields.headline: Union support for euro
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's favourite trade union leader will today claim the euro is a heartlands issue in an attempt to win support for the single currency among core Labour voters.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's favourite trade union leader will today claim the euro is a heartlands issue in an attempt to win support for the single currency among core Labour voters.

Sir Ken Jackson is to step up the offensive for the new currency among pro-Europeans on a platform with Patricia Hewitt, an industry minister, and Kenneth Clarke, the former Tory chancellor.

The Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union general secretary is believed to have Downing Street's tacit backing to broaden the euro's appeal.

At a seminar in Derby attended by a senior executive from the local Japanese-owned Toyota car plant, Sir Ken is to warn the high pound risks destroying thousands of manufacturing jobs and that Labour's traditional supporters have most to lose if the pound stays out of the new currency. "Heartlands will suffer most outside the euro - the midlands, the north will come off worst," Sir Ken intends to say.

"These are the regions most dependent on trade and inward investment. At least 15,000 jobs in this area [Derby] depend on being in Europe and it's our people who need these jobs most. The euro is not about the city, it's about the heartlands too. We have to explain to working people the risk of staying outside."

Opinion polls suggest a majority of skilled and manual workers hostile to the euro. Sir Ken last week accused chancellor Gordon Brown, architect of the "prepare and decide" policy, of trying to "duck the issue".

fields.headline: Showdown over Europe
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Germany's chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, has signalled his intention to accelerate European integration. Berlin wants talks to take place by 2004 to tackle the "big issues", including the difficult relationship between the European Union and the nation state.
fields.byline: John Hooper in Berlin   and Ian Black in Brussels
fields.body:
Germany's chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, has signalled his intention to accelerate European integration. Berlin wants talks to take place by 2004 to tackle the "big issues", including the difficult relationship between the European Union and the nation state.

His initiative will put Tony Blair, who is due in Berlin next week for a private meeting with the chancellor, under intense pressure at home and on the continent.

Germany's move points to a renewed drive to persuade the union's 15 members to transfer more sovereignty to the common EU pool. Berlin is proposing the most fundamental rewriting yet of the European community's founding charter, the 1958 Treaty of Rome.

Officials said that, as soon as the current round of reforms was completed, the chancellor wanted inter-governmental negotiations to begin to tackle "the big issues".

One source said the topics would include:

 A new EU constitution;

 A review of the treaties on which the EU is founded;

 Changes to the balance of power within the union; and

 Changes to the division of responsibilities between regional authorities, national governments and EU institutions.

Others said the talks would also have to reach a decision on creating an "inner core" of EU states, ready and willing to blaze a trail towards full political union.

This was at the crux of proposals aired last month in a controversial keynote speech by Germany's foreign minister, Joschka Fischer.

According to some sources, the new German agenda would include potentially explosive proposals for splitting the Rome treaty. Under this vision, two new treaties would be written.

One would enshrine the EU's broad aims and principles and could be altered only by unanimous consent. The other would cover more routine, but still crucial, issues including EU voting procedures, and could be amended by a simple majority in the union's council of ministers - thus ending the British veto.

The forum that would carry forward the changes sought by Berlin is an inter-governmental conference, which could last months or even years. Proponents want it to get under way as soon as a far more modest set of reforms - due to be approved at the union's Nice summit in December - are ratified by national parliaments. This is likely to take at least two years. Officials said the proposed conference could start as early as 2003.

"We want the Nice summit to create the conditions for EU expansion. But there should also be another big inter-governmental conference within a specific time limit which should deal with the big issues," one official said.

"It would be a logical step," said another, who cautioned that it would not be appropriate to table a formal proposal until after France's six-month term as holder of the the EU presidency ends in December.

Reducing the scope for using national vetoes, reducing the number of EU commissioners and altering the voting weights of member states are all meant to be resolved in the next six months. Euro-enthusiasts also want the next inter-governmental conference to deal with a charter of rights.

Mr Fischer argued last month that the looming enlargement of the union could paralyse decision-making if there were not a much clearer vision of where its institutions were heading.

Britain, France and almost all other EU members reacted coolly to his speech, insisting that the key integration issues from the 1998 Amsterdam treaty had to be tackled first and that further debate was both premature and divisive.

Germany's ambitions were clear during this week's summit at Santa Maria da Feira in Portugal, when Mr Schröder and France's president, Jacques Chirac, upbraided Mr Blair for opposing a "two-speed Europe" and said that a Britain outside the single currency was already in the slow lane.

In Brussels, the EU's commissioner for the inter-governmental conference, Michel Barnier of France, said Mr Schröder was trying to placate the powerful states that make up Germany; they want the division of powers between states and the EU to be addressed soon.

In London, the Conservative foreign affairs spokesman, Francis Maude, said the German idea "gives the lie to Labour's claims that the EU is going its way".

In Brussels, the EU's commissioner for the inter-governmental conference, Michel Barnier of France, said Mr Schröder was trying to placate the powerful states that make up Germany; they want the division of powers between states and the EU to be addressed soon. In London, the Conservative foreign affairs spokesman, Francis Maude, said the German idea "gives the lie to Labour's claims that the EU is going its way".

fields.headline: Texan loses clemency appeal
fields.standfirst:
Defiant Gary Graham struggles with jailers after 'death by fax' parole board ruling
Which state kills the most?
fields.trailText: The Texas convict Gary Graham appeared doomed to execution by lethal injection last night for a murder he insists he did not commit after the state's parole board turned down his appeal for clemency and dismissed his lawyers' claims that he never received a fair trial.
fields.body:
The Texas convict Gary Graham appeared doomed to execution by lethal injection last night for a murder he insists he did not commit after the state's parole board turned down his appeal for clemency and dismissed his lawyers' claims that he never received a fair trial.

The board voted by clear margins to turn down both a temporary reprieve and a commutation to life imprisonment. As the news spread a crowd of protesters outside the execution chamber began to chant: "murderers, murderers".

Aides to the Texas governor, George W Bush, said he had no legal option but to comply with the board's decision, as Graham had already received the sole stay of execution allowed under state law from Mr Bush's predecessor.

The Board of Pardons and Paroles, which is appointed by the governor, made its decision without meeting to discuss the case - as it always does. Each board member considered the evidence separately, and sent in their decision by fax. In Texas legal circles, it is called "death by fax".

"The members of the Texas Board of Pardons and Paroles are fully aware of the responsibilities we have in rendering our votes as part of the executive clemency review process," Gerald Garrett, the board chairman wrote.

"I can say unequivocally that the board's decision not to recommend clemency was reached after a complete unbiased review of the petition and the evidence submitted."

Graham's lawyers said they would file an urgent petition to halt the execution by lethal injection, scheduled for 6pm Texas time, to the US supreme court, which has already turned down an appeal to review the evidence.

As protesters gathered outside Huntsville prison where the execution was due to take place, Graham - who had warned he would "fight every step" of the way to the death chamber - struggled with guards sent to escort him the 46 miles from death row in a prison in Livingston. "As we went to cuff him at the wrist and put shackles to his ankles and waist, he resisted,'' Larry Fitzgerald, a spokesman for the Texas department of criminal justice, said. Several officers had to hold Graham down to put the shackles on. Once he arrived in Huntsville, he refused to order a last meal.

Graham was convicted of the murder of a man in a Houston supermarket car park in 1981 on the strength of the testimony of one witness who saw the killer for a few seconds. Graham, 17 at the time, had previously been arrested for a string of other crimes, including rape and armed robbery.

Several other witnesses who said Graham did not resemble the murderer were not called at the trial, where he was represented by a court-appointed defence lawyer, Ron Mock.

Mr Mock's colleagues later testified that he had appeared certain Graham was guilty and had argued against a full investigation. He also did not show the jury a police ballistics report proving that the fatal bullet could not have been fired from the gun Graham was carrying when arrested.

Three of the jurors signed an affidavit saying they would not have sentenced Graham to death if they had been aware of the evidence in his favour.

Graham's lawyers have since tried on more than 30 occasions to win a new hearing in which all the evidence could be presented.

The case has focused attention on Mr Bush's handling of executions over more than five years as Texas governor. Until yesterday, he had overseen the execution of 134 convicts, more than any US governor in modern history, and repeatedly insisted he was confident that an innocent man had not been to death on his watch.

However, an analysis of Texas capital cases has revealed a system in which the odds are stacked against defendants, particularly those unable to pay a good lawyer.

The state has no public defender's office so defence lawyers are assigned by local courts and are often inexperienced or incompetent. The funds allocated to them rarely allow for a proper independent investigation of the case.

An opinion poll published in the Dallas Morning News yesterday suggested that Texans, while supporting capital punishment, did not share Mr Bush's confidence in the system. In the poll, 57% said they thought that Texas sometimes put innocent people to death.

Nationwide, support for the death penalty has fallen to its lowest level since 1981, at 66%, with a majority supporting mandatory DNA tests when there is a chance they might clear a condemned convict.

Gary Graham's case has been instrumental in pushing capital punishment on to the election agenda. Mr Bush's Democratic opponent in the race for the White House, Vice-President Al Gore, also supports the death penalty, but has said he will consider a fundamental review of the judicial process by which people are sentenced to death.

It is Mr Bush's record as final arbiter of clemency that is now under the microscope. He has only ever granted one 30-day stay of execution and once commuted a death sentence to life imprisonment, on the advice of the Texas Board of Pardons and Paroles.

fields.headline: Driver charged  over 58 deaths
fields.standfirst:
Refugees in Britain: special report
The issue explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: A Dutch lorry driver was last night charged with the manslaughter of 58 Chinese illegal immigrants found dead in an airtight trailer in Dover earlier this week.
fields.byline: Paul Kelso and   Andrew Osborn in Brussels
fields.body:
A Dutch lorry driver was last night charged with the manslaughter of 58 Chinese illegal immigrants found dead in an airtight trailer in Dover earlier this week.

Perry Wacker, 32, of Rotterdam, was charged after spending 88 hours in custody following the discovery of the bodies by customs officers early on Monday morning.

Wacker was also charged with one count of facilitating the illegal entry into the UK of two people and one count of attempting to facilitate the illegal entry of 58 people. He will appear before magistrates in Folkestone this morning.

Two young men survived the journey from Holland to the UK in the sealed refrigeration unit of the lorry, and were yesterday moved from hospital to a safe house where they will remain under police guard for further questioning.

Postmortems completed yesterday confirmed that the 54 men and four women in the group died from respiratory failure brought about by asphyxiation.

Four other people have been arrested in connection with the incident. A Chinese man and a woman were arrested on Tuesday after surrendering to police, and are being detained at Canterbury. Dutch police continue to question two men, one of whom is Aries van der Spek, 24, in whose name the truck was registered.

Kent police are continuing to examine possible links between the deceased and a group of 59 illegal immigrants detained by Belgian authorities in April near Antwerp.

Belgian authorities confirmed yesterday that three men, two Chinese and a Malaysian, are still in custody.

Last night Jack Straw, the home secretary, responded to criticism of British border controls by the Belgian interior ministry.

webTitle: US Senate clears way for Bogota drugs-war aid

fields.headline: US Senate clears way for Bogota drugs-war aid
fields.trailText:
The US raised its involvement in the Colombian civil war yesterday when the Senate approved a $1bn military aid package to bolster Bogota's efforts against drug trafficking by insurgents.
Much of it will go towards creating two new combat battalions and providing a fleet of helicopters to take troops to the rebel-controlled southern regions which supply more than 80% of the cocaine on the US market.
fields.body:
The US raised its involvement in the Colombian civil war yesterday when the Senate approved a $1bn military aid package to bolster Bogota's efforts against drug trafficking by insurgents. Much of it will go towards creating two new combat battalions and providing a fleet of helicopters to take troops to the rebel-controlled southern regions which supply more than 80% of the cocaine on the US market.

Opponents of the bill argued that the Colombian army was implicated in widespread human rights abuses and warned that the increased aid would ensnare the US in an intractable civil conflict. Its supporters insist that human rights monitoring has been built in, as have guarantees that US personnel will be kept out of combat.

With the backing of Bill Clinton and both parties' leaders, it was passed easily.

"This is a huge, huge issue," the president said yesterday.

"The quicker we can reach agreement and show that the United States is committed to a democracy and to fighting the drug wars in Colombia and to strengthening the oldest democracy in Latin America, the better off we're going to be."

He said he hoped that agreement on US aid would encourage European aid to Colombia. The EU is considering a £1bn contribution to "Plan Colombia", aimed at supporting President Andres Pastrana's campaign to destroy the drug industry. Britain's share would be £150m. A decision is due at a conference in Madrid next month.

webTitle: King Juan Carlos takes delivery of his new royal yacht

fields.headline: King Juan Carlos takes delivery of his new royal yacht
fields.trailText: Spain's King Juan Carlos has had to wait almost 10 years for his new yacht but this summer he will finally be able to indulge his taste for speed on a floating pleasure palace.
fields.body:
Spain's King Juan Carlos has had to wait almost 10 years for his new yacht but this summer he will finally be able to indulge his taste for speed on a floating pleasure palace.

The Fortuna was formally handed over earlier this week to a state body that owns royal palaces and other chattels, in a low key ceremony in Majorca, where the Spanish royals take their August break.

The 41-metre (136ft) yacht was described as "a formula one prototype, incorporating state of the art technology and prestige accoutrements" by Javier Arce, head of the state-owned shipyard that built it. It includes seven cabins, a specially commissioned portrait of the king and royal monogrammed linen.

The 3bn peseta (£11m) bill will not be footed by the Spanish taxpayer. Instead Majorca businessmen, mainly in the tourist industry, a couple of banks and utilities clubbed together to buy it. It was, they felt, a way of acknowledging the prestige King Juan Carlos brings the Balearic islands by holidaying there. The regional government chipped in £1.7m.

The new yacht's unveiling - elegant lines, gleaming decks and tinted windows - was greeted without demur by the Spanish press, which printed photographs and factual articles but no opinion. That reflects, in part, the circumspection always shown towards the royal family. Spain is not a profoundly monarchist country but King Juan Carlos is credited with safeguarding the democratic process and any attack on him is seen as a threat to Spain's hard won stability. The king himself has also chosen with care the moment to accept his new toy. In 1991, when Spain was sinking into recession and a series of financial corruption scandals were emerging, he refused a replacement yacht which had already been ordered.

Since then he has had to struggle on with the original Fortuna, a present from King Fahd of Saudi Arabia in 1979. Smaller and slower, it turned into a security threat, leaving the royals stranded at sea more than once.

However, a low key debate rumbled on, in marked contrast to the furore over Britannia's possible replacement. Proponents argued that a yacht was a useful public relations tool. Foreign dignitaries like President and Mrs Clinton, who enjoyed a day at sea on Fortuna with their daughter Chelsea in 1997, could be profitably entertained.

Opponents, including members of the Communist party and Republicans, criticised the king for accepting a gift from "a lobby group of businessmen" that included a German magnate, in keeping with a large German presence on Majorca.

But with the country enjoying an economic boom, Spaniards seem willing to indulge their monarch. They like the royals to be middle class but glamorous and forgive King Juan Carlos his occasional playboy tendencies.

Last summer, their pride was dented when the billionaire Miller family, in-laws of the former King Constantine of Greece who is brother to the Spanish queen, floated around Majorca in their mega-yacht as did the Italian fashion designer Valentino who played host to top models. The king was reduced to racing on his catamaran.

There will be rich pickings too for Hola readers. Juan Carlos was once snapped sunbathing in the buff on the old Fortuna; Crown Prince Felipe was found frolicking in the waves with the only serious girlfriend he is known to have had. It's a fair bet that this year the paparazzi will be all at sea.

fields.headline: Show me the money
fields.trailText: Emmerdale | EastEnders | River Deep, Mountain High
fields.body:
British soaps are not about rich people. How the other half lives, like the dark of the moon, is hidden from us - except in Emmerdale (ITV), where poshness flourishes and there are still profiteroles for tea.

Last night Lady Tara (of the de Boomdeay family) returned to stately Oakwell Hall. The last time I saw Lady Tara she was about to elope with Biff, her chauffeur, but thought better of it, rebuffed Biff and married money instead. Very like Lady Clara Vere de Vere who, you may remember, encouraged a humble admirer, and then "Fixed a vacant stare/ And slew him with her noble birth".

When not toying with the affections of chauffeurs, Lady Tara enjoys grinding the faces of the poor, who are often called Zak or Seth. Her housewarming at stately Oakwell Hall, therefore, promised to be lively.

Initially Fat Mandy was not inclined to hold out the hand of friendship ("Tara wanted to put my family on the street. Give me one good reason why I shouldn't smack 'er in th' mouth?") In the event, Mandy scored a bloodless victory by wearing an astounding acreage of gold corset. You wrenched your fascinated gaze from her with a noise like Velcro. Lady Tara's little shrimp-pink number paled, appalled.

After mutinous rumblings about not being seen dead there, the rude peasantry turned up and lowered the tone in spades. Sean offered to batter one of the guests, but his wife kneed him in the groin first. Mandy threw champagne over another and Terry threatened to take him out and plant him with begonias. I assume this was a threat. Really, one trembled for the safety of the Ferrero Rocher.

Meanwhile, back in EastEnders (BBC1), Phil was finking. The difference between Phil finking and not finking is that, when he finks, he kicks cars and says "Aargh! Gar!" This is often a good time to leave town. Phil had just heard that Dan was a grass. He called in Marcus, the bent brief, to get Dan's signature by false pretences, and Gog and Magog from Rent-A-Thug to steal his shirts. Then, as parsley round the plate, he organised a late-night poker game in the Queen Vic between Dan and various offended parties. Heavy silences, fat cigars and eyeballs clashing together like Newton's cradle. One of those.

Throwing his house keys on the table, Phil bet his arse against Dan's boozer. Dan objected that his boozer was worth more than Phil's arse, which seems unarguable. Then Phil laid down a full arse and smiled one of his rare, worrying smiles. Look, I'm a bit lost here. The upshot was that Dan left, uttering threats of a vague but heartfelt nature, not realising that he was a very lucky man indeed. Most landlords of the Vic leave with lilies on the lid.

River Deep, Mountain High (BBC1) was described as the roughest, toughest game-show on TV. It is part of the BBC's painfully-named Get Your Kit On campaign, intended to get the nation up and doing. The prize was another strenuous sporting holiday. As poor Mrs Fulton said plaintively as she plunged into an icy torrent: "Can't we just buy a holiday?" The Lathams and the Fultons were left in the Lake District for two days with - a peculiarly sadistic touch - laptop computers to give them orders and criticise their progress. I cannot begin to list the torments to which these blameless people were subjected. Traversing and orienteering and abseiling and getting blisters. Your heart went out to the smallest Fulton, who moaned "I really don't want to do this" as they tried to push him off a cliff.

Hungry and weary, they were cruelly offered tasty food if they surrendered a few points. As a young child, I once sat on top of Helvellyn and watched my pork pie bound to the bottom, making, it seemed to me, increasingly joyful jumps and parabolas. I resolved then never to climb another mountain and always to buy square pies. Resolutions I have never regretted.

The Lathams, who would have been a finely oiled machine if they hadn't been a family, drew smoothly ahead. The Fultons got lost ("They are about to make a very basic map-reading error.") I will say this for Mr Fulton. He was the only one to mention the view.

webTitle: Barak's deal puts peace in jeopardy

fields.headline: Barak's deal puts peace in jeopardy
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East - special report
fields.trailText: Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, narrowly survived his coalition crisis yesterday, but is left with an unstable government that could sabotage his efforts to make peace with the Palestinians.
fields.body:
Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, narrowly survived his coalition crisis yesterday, but is left with an unstable government that could sabotage his efforts to make peace with the Palestinians.

Mr Barak's year-old government was rescued from 10 days of political chaos when four cabinet ministers from the ultra-orthodox Shas party withdrew their resignations, moments before the expiry of a 48-hour grace period yesterday afternoon.

Their return to the fold comes with a heavy trade-off: the departure from the government of cabinet ministers from the Meretz party, which has been the most enthusiastic supporters of peace with the Palestinians during the last seven years.

In the end, it came down to arithmetic. Shas, which combines Jewish fundamentalism with an ethnic pride movement for Jews of Middle Eastern origin, has 17 seats in the Israeli parliament. Meretz has 10. So Meretz, whose head-on clash with Shas over education policy started this crisis rolling 11 months ago, had to go.

They tendered their resignations on Wednesday night, saying they wanted Shas back in the coalition so that Mr Barak had a government to carry on with the peace process. They also promised to continue to back his peace efforts.

Meanwhile, in the western suburb of Jerusalem that is the stronghold of the Shas movement, they brought out the champagne yesterday to celebrate the departure of their enemies.

But secular Israelis are sickened by the machinations of recent days, which saw a desperate Mr Barak held to ransom by his largest coalition partner. The manoeuvring has greatly damaged his image as a leader capable of shepherding his people through the hard decisions ahead.

The decorated general capitulated to virtually all of Shas's demands: extra cash infusions for its religious schools, legalising its pirate radio network, and giving the party a greater say in a peace process Mr Barak once regarded as his personal preserve.

Yesterday, Mr Barak shouted down the hecklers at a meeting of the Labour party central committee to say he had little choice. "I know it pains some of our members, but I am convinced including Shas in the coalition is the right thing for the state of Israel."

However, Palestinians say the crisis - though it leaves Mr Barak's government still alive for the difficult weeks that lie ahead - could wreck the chances for peace.

"The end of the coalition crisis comes completely at the cost of the peace process and the Palestinians," said Ghassan Khatib of the Jerusalem Media and Communications Centre. "This is all bad news. We had little hope of an agreement this September, and now even that little hope is vanishing."

He added: "When Barak is choosing Shas instead of Meretz, then he is choosing peace with the rightwing of Israel at the cost of peace with the Palestinians. He will be less able to undertake a deal which can be acceptable to the Palestinian side."

Shas has been more open to the peace process than other religious parties, justifying a withdrawal from the occupied West Bank to its followers as preserving Jewish lives. However, many of its constituents - who were born in Arab countries - take a far more hawkish line, and Shas appears sensitive to the prospect of being the only religious party to sanction returning land to the Palestinians.

Yesterday the Shas chairman, Eli Yishai, gave notice to Mr Barak that the party's return to the fold was conditional, and it would not promise to back a peace deal.

"From our standpoint he understands that we will not be able to give automatic approval to the process. We want the peace to make progress, we want security for the country," he told Israel Radio. "We have not committed to the results of the process," he added later.

fields.headline: IRA arms checks 'by next week'
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The inspection of IRA arms dumps could go ahead as early as next week before one of the two international inspectors goes into hospital. Irish government sources have confirmed that at least one inspection is imminent.
fields.body:
The inspection of IRA arms dumps could go ahead as early as next week before one of the two international inspectors goes into hospital. Irish government sources have confirmed that at least one inspection is imminent.

The former Finnish president, Maarti Ahtisaari, is due to have a knee operation at the end of the month and there is pressure not to delay the start of inspections for a further month.

His office in Finland confirmed yesterday that both he and his press secretary were abroad.

Cyril Ramaphosa - a second inspector - was not in his office in Johannesburg yesterday. His office confirmed that he was out of the country but was unable to reveal where.

An Irish government source said yesterday: "We are in the time frame now. You wouldn't be far wrong to expect it around now."

Another Irish government source said: "Rumours are that it will go ahead before the marching season really begins next month. Leaving things to go through to July would lead to a huge dip in confidence."

A report in yesterday's Irish News quoted "reliable sources" that inspection of the dumps would take place before Mr Ahtisaari went into hospital.

Sinn Fein's chief negotiator, Martin McGuinness, said in Washington on Monday, when asked if opening up the dumps was linked to reforms in the RUC: "I have more confidence that the IRA will fulfil its commitments than I have in others."

If there are no moves to open up the dumps before the hospitalisation of Mr Athtisaari, it means that the IRA could be delaying opening up for at least another month - making it almost three months since their surprise statement on May 6. In that statement the IRA promised to allow the inspections to go ahead "within weeks".

Meanwhile the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, said that he was optimistic that the IRA would fulfil its commitments. Unionists remain sceptical and impatient for developments.

The greatest threat to the delivery of arms by the IRA is anger in republican and nationalist circles about reform of the RUC.

webTitle: Leak reveals drive to cut NHS waiting

fields.headline: Leak reveals drive to cut NHS waiting
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Ambitious targets for a drastic shrinking of hospital waiting times have been drawn up by government action teams preparing for the radical review of the NHS to be announced by Tony Blair next month.
fields.body:
Ambitious targets for a drastic shrinking of hospital waiting times have been drawn up by government action teams preparing for the radical review of the NHS to be announced by Tony Blair next month.

Confidential drafts of their recommendations, obtained by the Guardian, set out "milestones towards a vision of five years from now, where 90% of patients wait less than three months for non-urgent hospital care, and no one waits more than six months".

The action team advising Alan Milburn, the health secretary, on improving patients' access to treatment also proposes more that 30 targets for reduced waiting times at every stage of health care.

They include a maximum of:

Two weeks for suspected cancer patients to get an outpatient appointment;

Four hours for a patient arriving at an accident and emergency department to be admitted or discharged; and

One minute for responses to calls to the 999 emergency number or NHS Direct.

The drafts were presented to ministers last week by the six "modernisation action teams" covering reform of the health service in England.

Health department sources said the targets might be amended after computer modelling in Whitehall to assess costs and staffing implications. Ministers know the pace of change will be limited by the time it takes to recruit and train more doctors and nurses. They must also estimate how far cuts in waiting times will stimulate increased demand for treatment. But those in government also know that the NHS review will lack credibility if it does not contain specific and challenging targets.

Final versions of the teams' reports are due in the next two weeks. The national plan for the NHS is to be published towards the end of next month.

The draft modernisation report on speed of access for patients comes from a team that is chaired by Lord Hunt, the health minister, and includes Barry Jackson, the president of the Royal College of Surgeons, and Lord Newton, the former Tory social security secretary. Its analysis of current performance is withering.

"Patients are dissatisfied with the poor accessibility and inconvenience of NHS services. Provision of primary care services outside office hours is still limited, patchy and unrelated to patient needs [with] 20% of people in work put off going to their GP because of inconvenient surgery hours and 29% having to wait two or three days for a GP appointment."

A third of health authorities are reporting serious difficulty in finding dentists for their residents. There are significant pockets of poor GP provision, particularly in deprived areas. Out of hours access to pharmacies is patchy and information can be hard to find.

"During 1998-99, 1.6m patients waited longer than three months for a first outpatient appointment. A further 1.3m waited longer than three months for inpatient admission," the report says.

Average waiting times for knee and hip replacements, coronary artery bypass surgery, cataract extractions and tonsillectomies were well above the 50-day national norm. There were cases where the wait was up to 230 days.

Other problems included a lack of choice for patients about admission times, long waits for patients who were in pain, cancellation of operations on the due day, long waits in accident and emergency departments and patients staying too long in hospital because of lack of support services if they were to leave.

"The standards put forward by the group are ambitious and go way beyond anything that has been achieved by the NHS in the past," the draft says. "But we should be ambitious. With the resources now available we should aspire to, and in time exceed, standards elsewhere in Europe."

To get primary care for people within 24 hours, the team proposes extending the role of community pharmacists to treat symptoms and provide medicines for minor ailments.

There would be more prescribing by nurses. GPs would be expected to spend less time treating minor cases and on non-clinical duties such as signing sick notes.

GPs' surgeries would be expected to open during early mornings, late evenings and at weekends, with single-handed doctors encouraged to work together to extend their access times.

Other proposals include:

Email advice from consultants as an alternative to hospital referral;

Authority for nurses and other professionals to refer patients to hospital;

Flexible hospital working hours, allowing more non-emergency care outside 9am-5pm, Monday to Friday;

Separation of major and minor cases at accident and emergency departments, with nurses running minor injury clinics; and

The linking of hospital funding to how well targets are met, and a refusal to authorise health community plans until every organisation involved is using best practice.

The draft report also calls for higher national standards for ambulance response times.

By 2005, it wants 90% of priority emergencies to receive an ambulance within eight minutes. In urban areas it calls for 90% of less urgent cases to be handled within 14 minutes and in rural areas within 19 minutes.

webTitle: British woman stabbed to death on Costa del Sol

fields.headline: British woman stabbed to death on Costa del Sol
fields.trailText: A British businesswoman was yesterday found stabbed to death on a road near her home on the Costa del Sol in Spain.
fields.byline: Adela Gooch in Madrid and Linus Gregoriadis
fields.body:
A British businesswoman was yesterday found stabbed to death on a road near her home on the Costa del Sol in Spain.

Irene Mulvihill, 45, was discovered by police near the Calypso housing complex in the picturesque village of Mijas near Fuengirola where she lived with her husband and two daughters aged seven and 11.

She had been stabbed through the heart but also had knife wounds to her arms and hands, according to police who found her body after an anonymous tip-off. Her body is believed to have been found under trees.

The motive for the killing was not known last night but Spanish detectives do not believe that Mrs Mulvihill was mugged. A local government source said: "The wounds suggest that she had struggled to defend herself but she was wearing jewellry which hadn't been stolen." Mrs Mulvihull, from Manchester, is believed to have lived on the Costa del Sol, where she ran an estate agency, for 2 years.

The Foreign Office said last night it had been informed about the death by the Spanish authorities, and that British officials in Spain were being kept updated. Her family has been offered consular assistance.

A spokesman said that the magistrate presiding over the case had banned the Spanish authorities from giving out further details until a postmortem examination had been carried out.

He added: "A judge will consider how she died and then decide whether to launch a murder inquiry."

The Foreign Office said Spanish authorities were due to hold an autopsy this morning. The judge had banned any more information being given out until he had considered the cause of death.

webTitle: Amin hailed as splendid, but not very bright

fields.headline: Amin hailed as splendid, but not very bright
fields.trailText: Idi Amin, the former Ugandan military ruler who expelled all Asians and killed thousands of his own people in the 1970s, was described by a British official who knew him personally as a "splendid man by any standards", according to documents released yesterday at the public record office.
fields.body:
Idi Amin, the former Ugandan military ruler who expelled all Asians and killed thousands of his own people in the 1970s, was described by a British official who knew him personally as a "splendid man by any standards", according to documents released yesterday at the public record office.

The official, identified only as O G Griffith, praised Amin in a despatch sent in 1969 when the future Ugandan president was appointed commander of an army battalion with the rank of major.

Amin, he wrote, "is held in great esteem and affection by his British colleagues". He added: "He is tough and fearless and in the judgment of everybody... completely reliable". However, he was "not very bright and will probably find difficulty in dealing with the administrative side of command".

Amin, who served with British forces in Burma during the second world war, staged a military coup in 1971. He fled Kampala, Uganda's capital, in 1979 in the face of opposing Ugandan and Tanzanian forces and escaped to Libya. He is now living in Saudi Arabia.

fields.headline: More awards for Guardian journalists
fields.trailText: Last night Guardian writer Ignacio Gomez from Colombia was awarded the Amnesty International special award for journalism under threat. He has investigated human rights abuses in Colombia for many years and last month was forced to flee the country after he received death threats.
fields.body:
Last night Guardian writer Ignacio Gomez from Colombia was awarded the Amnesty International special award for journalism under threat. He has investigated human rights abuses in Colombia for many years and last month was forced to flee the country after he received death threats.

This is the sixth award made to Guardian journalists this week.

Weekend received three in the Magazine Design Awards. It took gold awards for the best designed newspaper magazine and for the best use of typography, and silver in the best front cover category. The judges said Weekend, which is designed by Mark Porter and Maggie Murphy, was: "Brilliant. This is what a newspaper supplement should be."

Earlier Polly Toynbee was voted the Industrial Society's National Newspaper Journalist of the Year and on Wednesday night the Guardian won the Windrush achievement award for the second year running. The award is for effectively reflecting a multicultural Britain.

webTitle: Inquest ordered on mother of twins

fields.headline: Inquest ordered on mother of twins
fields.standfirst: High court told failures at private hospital led to woman's death shortly after giving birth by caesarean section
fields.trailText: The husband of a 31-year-old woman who died shortly after giving birth to twins by caesarean section in one of London's most eminent private hospitals, yesterday won a high court battle for a coroner's inquest into her death.
fields.body:
The husband of a 31-year-old woman who died shortly after giving birth to twins by caesarean section in one of London's most eminent private hospitals, yesterday won a high court battle for a coroner's inquest into her death.

Peter Touche wants the inquest, he said, to find out "what happened, what didn't happen that should have happened and what caused her death" at the Portland hospital in February last year.

The case will raise serious questions about the way private hospitals are regulated and is likely to fuel concern over plans by the health secretary, Alan Milburn, to send more NHS patients for private treatment. Mr Touche accuses the hospital, where the Duchess of York, actress Caroline Quentin and Spice girl Victoria Beckham gave birth, of standards of care that are unacceptable in the NHS.

Laura Touche, a US citizen, graduate of Princeton University and Harvard law school, and direct descendent of president Thomas Jefferson, chose the Portland hospital for her first confinement because she wanted monthly scans, which are not available on the NHS, and a particular obstetrician for her care.

She had a healthy, uncomplicated pregnancy followed by an elective caesarean. At 10.24pm and 10.25pm on February 6, she gave birth to two boys, Alexander and Charles. If she had been in an NHS hospital, it is alleged, Mrs Touche would have been taken to a recovery room after her surgery and monitored every 15 minutes in the first hour, followed by every 30 minutes in the next two hours. None of that happened.

"Laura's vital observations, crucially her blood pressure, were not monitored at all until two and a half hours after the operation and then only after she complained of a very severe headache," her husband, from Chelsea, west London, said yesterday.

Her blood pressure was high and eventually she was given drugs to bring it down. At 4am, her speech became slurred and she was vomiting constantly. At 5.30am she started suffering fits. A brain haemorrhage was confirmed and she was transferred to the NHS-run national hospital for neurology and neurosurgery, where she died nine days later.

The Portland has since told her family there is no protocol concerning the monitoring and care of a woman who has just had a caesarean section, as there is in the NHS.

In the high court judgment yesterday, Lord Justice Kennedy quoted a letter from the Touche family's solicitors, Alexander Harris, to the inner north London coroner which asked for an inquest to be held. "We have expert advice to the fact that every NHS hospital in the country has a protocol in place for the care of patients in the post-operative phase," it said.

A consultant anaesthetist with an interest in obstetrics, David Bogod, who investigated Mrs Touche's care, said the failure to monitor her blood pressure when she was receiving pain relief after an operation was astonishing, "and described the level of neglect as 'starkly apparent'," said Lord Justice Kennedy.

There was a further report from Dr Williams, who runs the high risk obstetrics services at the NHS Chelsea and Westminster hospital. "Like everyone else, including the coroner, he is critical of the lack of post-operative observation," says the judgment.

Dr Williams considered that Mrs Touche's raised blood pressure was responsible for her brain haemorrhage. His report "does seem to provide clear grounds for suspecting that the post-operative failure to monitor and treat was an effective cause of death".

The court ruled that the coroner must hold an inquest, even though the death was not violent, sudden or of an unknown cause.

Mr Touche, an accountant who is the grandson of the founder of the Deloitte Touche empire, said: "One of the reasons I'm going through this is not just because of my anger, but because this could happen again. Mistakes will happen everywhere but this wasn't a mistake - it was a total omission. There is no system of care there."

His twin sons, he said, "are doing very well and are very happy bundles of energy. They are a wonderful source of joy." He was fortunate that he was able to take time off from his work to look after them, although he had the help of a nanny five days a week.

How to tell them about their mother was on his mind. "I want to ensure that Laura's memory is very much alive, that they grow up getting to know their mother and all her faults and the great things about her."

To those who now consider private health care, "I would say listen to this story and all the other stories they can find out about. Find out what should be happening and make sure it is happening."
