A brain haemorrhage was confirmed and she was transferred to the NHS-run national hospital for neurology and neurosurgery, where she died nine days later. The Portland has since told her family there is no protocol concerning the monitoring and care of a woman who has just had a caesarean section, as there is in the NHS. In the high court judgment yesterday, Lord Justice Kennedy quoted a letter from the Touche family's solicitors, Alexander Harris, to the inner north London coroner which asked for an inquest to be held. "We have expert advice to the fact that every NHS hospital in the country has a protocol in place for the care of patients in the post-operative phase," it said. A consultant anaesthetist with an interest in obstetrics, David Bogod, who investigated Mrs Touche's care, said the failure to monitor her blood pressure when she was receiving pain relief after an operation was astonishing, "and described the level of neglect as 'starkly apparent'," said Lord Justice Kennedy. There was a further report from Dr Williams, who runs the high risk obstetrics services at the NHS Chelsea and Westminster hospital. "Like everyone else, including the coroner, he is critical of the lack of post-operative observation," says the judgment. Dr Williams considered that Mrs Touche's raised blood pressure was responsible for her brain haemorrhage. His report "does seem to provide clear grounds for suspecting that the post-operative failure to monitor and treat was an effective cause of death". The court ruled that the coroner must hold an inquest, even though the death was not violent, sudden or of an unknown cause. Mr Touche, an accountant who is the grandson of the founder of the Deloitte Touche empire, said: "One of the reasons I'm going through this is not just because of my anger, but because this could happen again. Mistakes will happen everywhere but this wasn't a mistake - it was a total omission. There is no system of care there." His twin sons, he said, "are doing very well and are very happy bundles of energy. They are a wonderful source of joy." He was fortunate that he was able to take time off from his work to look after them, although he had the help of a nanny five days a week. How to tell them about their mother was on his mind. "I want to ensure that Laura's memory is very much alive, that they grow up getting to know their mother and all her faults and the great things about her." To those who now consider private health care, "I would say listen to this story and all the other stories they can find out about. Find out what should be happening and make sure it is happening."

webTitle: Four fudges and a fiddle, starring Huge Grant

fields.headline: Four fudges and a fiddle, starring Huge Grant
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Treasury questions, and there waiting on the order paper was No 12, asking the chancellor what discussions he had had with certain fellow ministers about replacing the pound with the euro.
fields.body:
Treasury questions, and there waiting on the order paper was No 12, asking the chancellor what discussions he had had with certain fellow ministers about replacing the pound with the euro.

It was tabled by Julian Lewis, the swivel-eyed rightwing Tory for New Forest East, and it was of course a landmine. Helpfully, the form of the question meant that it was surrounded by winking neon signs marked: "Warning! Landmine!"

Gordon Brown had no intention of answering if he could help it. The topic is far too sore for the government. He and his fellow ministers set about their own small filibuster. Ian Pearson had wild praise for the new tax rules for charitable donations. They would promote, he said, "a new age of giving".

Mr Brown went on for ages about that. He too saw "a new age of giving" about to begin. So overcome was he by his own generosity of spirit that he talked for almost five minutes about it.

Michael Portillo helped by accusing him of taking away more from charities than they got back. It was all spinning, and as John Prescott had pointed out a few days before, wasn't it the case that spinning was lying?

That was the perfect excuse. Mr Brown quoted chunks of the shadow chancellor's own speeches back at him. This took a very long time. So did Dennis Skinner's rant against rich men who give money to the Tories.

Things were getting on nice and slowly. Nearly a third of the way through, and we had only reached question 2.

David Taylor tried to slow things down even further with a spot of sycophancy, but fell off his own greasy pole. Anxious to praise the chancellor for his remarks about elitism, he wondered why "the levers of power in this country as so often exercised by those who went to public schools".

The name of Mr T Blair (Fettes and Oxford) sprang to mind, and Tories gloatingly cheered. But New Labour is a broad church: Mr Pearson will be shot, but only after the prime minister has personally served his last meal.

The topic of unemployment in the north-east occupied another interminable period, and so did tax relief for people on benefit. Then, at halftime, we reached question 7, on third world debt.

It was perhaps when Mr Brown began a thoughtful disquisition of the pupil-teacher ratio in Uganda that the Speaker realised what was going on. Steve Webb had tabled an impenetrable question (about "the number of married women who were paying national insurance at the reduced rate for married women in circumstances where they would have paid less national insurance had they paid the full rate of national insurance contributions") and received an even more impenetrable answer.

At that point she suddenly stopped taking supplementaries and the session began to gallop along with manic speed. With minutes left, question 12 suddenly arrived. We excitedly awaited the chancellor's reply.

But we did not get it. For in his place rose Melanie Johnson, the economic secretary, and most junior member of the treasury team. Not the organ grinder; not even his monkey; but someone the monkey had met down the pub.

Tories were incredulous. Ms Johnson blathered about the five tests for the euro (Mr Portillo correctly said that four of these are entirely subjective - "four fudges and a fiddle") and failed to answer anything remotely resembling the question.

Mr Brown sat laughing his head off, suffused with pleasure at his own cleverness. But as he left the chamber he was pursued by bellowing Tories, shouting "Frit!, frit!", Margaret Thatcher's famous dialect word for "cowardly".

webTitle: 'Robocop' hits back as zero tolerance policing damned

fields.headline: 'Robocop' hits back as zero tolerance policing damned
fields.standfirst: Insults traded after report attacks 'woeful' methods of suspended officer
fields.trailText: Superintendent Ray "Robocop" Mallon's attempt to win his job back was ambushed by the leak of an independent report yesterday that damned his "zero tolerance" policy and condemned his management of informers as "woeful and chaotic".
fields.body:
Superintendent Ray "Robocop" Mallon's attempt to win his job back was ambushed by the leak of an independent report yesterday that damned his "zero tolerance" policy and condemned his management of informers as "woeful and chaotic".

The disclosure of the Treasury barristers' secret advice to the crown prosecution service, which added that Middlesbrough detectives had bent and ignored the laws on criminal evidence, upstaged a highly emotional press conference called by Mr Mallon to denounce his continuing suspension after being cleared of criminal behaviour.

Salt was rubbed into the wound by the acting head of the police complaints authority, Molly Meacher, who broke with civil service precedent to urge people on Mr Mallon's former patch to read the revelations in yesterday's Daily Express.

Furious

Smarting from a furious attack on the PCA by Mr Mallon, who called the authority "biased and disgraceful" in its investigation of his regime, she was backed by his own MP, Frank Cook, Labour MP for Stockton North, who said he was disquieted and concerned at the allegations.

But Mr Mallon found an unexpected ally in his own Cleveland police force, which originally suspended him and is now legally required to keep him off work, on a £47,000-a-year salary, until internal disciplinary proceedings are over.

Barry Shaw, the force's chief constable, who had earlier taken a battering at Mr Mallon's press conference, said: "Det Supt Mallon knows better than most people the procedures that have to be followed before a suspended officer can return to duty. But we totally disassociate ourselves with unwarranted criticism made of him by other agencies and statutory bodies."

Mr Mallon's lawyers and the Labour MP for Middlesbrough South and East Cleveland, Ashok Kumar, said the PCA intervention was out of order and described the leaked report as "scandalous and full of inaccuracies". The superintendent's solicitor, Mick Hymenson, said he would register a complaint with the PCA and demanded an inquiry into how a legally privileged document intended for a very small circle had been made public.

Mr Mallon emphasised that the report - by Treasury counsel, who give advice to the state on a highly confidential basis - rejected the prosecution of him and seven other suspended detectives because of the "poor quality" of evidence laid out in the 31-month inquiry, Operation Lancet.

He said: "I have a confidential report of my own, dated August 1996, which lays bare the indiscipline and lack of management in Middlesbrough CID. That is exactly what I was brought in to address.

"It was so bad that when William Bratten, the New York police commissioner, came to Cleveland, he was banned from entering Middlesbrough because he might have bumped into a police officer and got the wrong impression. If Middlesbrough CID at that time had been a business, it would have gone bankrupt years earlier." Mr Mallon also dismissed the Treasury counsel's attack on his supposed zero tolerance policing, which the confidential report described as a failure that "brought in few if any rewards".

Stung by the barristers' claim that "officers who court publicity to the extent which Mallon did will invariably have an agenda of their own", he said: "It is always legal institutions and criminologists who don't like zero tolerance, but they know nothing about operational policing. I dismiss this out of hand."

Accused

Mr Mallon, 45, who left a Stockton Roman Catholic comprehensive school at 16 without O-levels, demanded immediate reinstatement by Cleveland police.

He said the CPS decision not to bring criminal charges vindicated his unwavering view that Lancet had been a "total waste of time and money".

And he accused the PCA of bias and "looking into my expenses, my dealings with the press and even my private life to try to make me a patsy and a scapegoat".

He added: "For a two-and-a-half year period I have been smeared left, right and centre by the police complaints authority. They wanted my scalp because I was a high-profile police officer and I think a number of people had their noses put out of joint in relation to what I had to say about policing issues. I truly believe that the PCA has been way outside the rules for two-and-a-half years."

Mrs Meacher, ex-wife of Michael Meacher, the environment secretary, described the claim as outrageous and said the PCA was wholly objective.

Mr Shaw said Operation Lancet had been dealt with in a "scrupulously fair way" and that it was galling to suffer innuendos and half-truths when the full facts could not be revealed until disciplinary proceedings were complete.

"Don't judge us now. Judge us when the inquiry is completed," he said. "We are doing this for the right reasons."

Mr Mallon enjoys strong support on Teesside, largely because of successful drives against crime in Hartlepool from 1994-96 and in Middlesbrough before his suspension in December 1997. He was held up as a model by leading politicians and was courted by Tony Blair, Jack Straw and Michael Howard in the run-up to the 1997 general election, when all three visited his base in Middlesbrough. Polls on Teesside supported his reinstatement during Operation Lancet and more than 30,000 people signed a petition backing him.

His policy of harassing known criminals with spot checks - 11,000 in Middlesbrough in the first half of 1997 compared with 600 in the whole of 1994 - relieved much of the fear of crime in the town.

He said yesterday: "I have a genuine passion for my job and I just want to get back to serving the community and protecting the public."

'Chaotic and contaminated by indiscipline'

What Molly Meacher wants Middlesbrough to know - key points from the Treasury counsel review of Operation Lancet evidence:

On the state of Middlesbrough CID Superior officers must carry responsibility for the indiscipline which disgraced Middlesbrough CID. There appears to have been a complete lack of supervision. The pressure and desire to obtain information were so great that detectives offered inducements to arrested suspects. These were either an amnesty from charges or an offer to drop an arrest warrant. There is a depressing pattern of suspects  not being charged when they should have been. The department was at the very least contaminated by indiscipline and a complete indifference to the letter, let alone the spirit, of the Police and Criminal Evidence Act 1984.

On zero tolerance We trust that never again will a dramatic and innovative method of policing be introduced without proper supervision, research and scrutiny. He [Mallon] must bear heavy responsibility for the woeful and chaotic manner in which the informant system was administered and supervised. Zero tolerance had little if anything to do with the widely held belief that it concentrated on the prosecution of all offences, no matter how trivial. [It] brought few if any rewards in the number of crimes detected, the amount of stolen property recovered or the number of suspects prosecuted.

And finally  Senior police officers who court publicity to the extent which Mallon did will invariably have an agenda of their own and that agenda may not necessarily be in the best interests of the force.

fields.headline: The seamless future arrives
fields.standfirst: The future of Microsoft: special report
fields.trailText: Computer scientists and science fiction writers have long imagined a futuristic world where the world's computers work seamlessly in the background to deliver whatever information people want to whatever device they have to hand, whether it be a personal computer, a mobile phone or Dick Tracy's wrist-watch communicator.
fields.body:
Computer scientists and science fiction writers have long imagined a futuristic world where the world's computers work seamlessly in the background to deliver whatever information people want to whatever device they have to hand, whether it be a personal computer, a mobile phone or Dick Tracy's wrist-watch communicator.

But until Bill Gates, revelling in his new title of Chief Software Architect, outlined Microsoft.NET in Seattle yesterday, nobody has ever seriously proposed building it.

The Department of Justice is still operating as though the world had not changed since 1995, when the web browser was just a small Microsoft Windows application. In the world of 2005-2025, as Gates showed, the browser will be part of everything, to the extent that users may never see it - but also may never leave it. The browser is integrated not just into Windows but into everything.

Under the new Windows.NET scheme, splitting Microsoft in two becomes equally pointless. Windows running on a PC may have been the platform for the last generation of computer programs, but the internet will be the platform for the next generation.

This is one reason why Microsoft, while not abandoning the PC, has spent so much time and effort over the past four years investing in its WebTV system, which has about a million users, in smart phones (where it has a deal with Samsung), in palm-top and handheld and "tablet computers" (where it has been working with Compaq, among others), and in Windows for Smart Cards.

In his speech, Gates characterised three eras of personal computing. First there was the world of the IBM PC with its green text screen, starting in 1981. Then came Windows 3 in 1990 with its idiot-proof icons and a mouse-cursor era (building on the pioneering work done by Acorn, Apple, Amiga, Atari et al). About to start is net-based computing, which represents an even more dramatic change.

What is most remarkable about Microsoft.NET is that Gates says it is built on open industry standards. In particular, the whole scheme is based on XML (Extensible Markup Language) - not owned by Gates - and used by everybody.

It may well be true, of course, that something like Microsoft.NET would have been developed anyway in spite of Gates.

Still, if Gates really is moving Microsoft's focus from the PC-Windows platform to an internet platform, he has in one day done more to bring competition to the computer industry than the US Justice Department has managed in its entire history. Who can resist the irony in that?

webTitle: Nurse in inquiry over child deaths

fields.headline: Nurse in inquiry over child deaths
fields.standfirst: Police investigating 18 cases
fields.trailText: The nurse at the centre of an inquiry into the deaths of up to 18 children in Essex is "totally and utterly devastated" that she is under investigation by the police, a close relative told the Guardian yesterday.
fields.body:
The nurse at the centre of an inquiry into the deaths of up to 18 children in Essex is "totally and utterly devastated" that she is under investigation by the police, a close relative told the Guardian yesterday.

The woman, who is in her 40s, denies any wrongdoing and has told detectives that she will cooperate fully with their inquiry, which is understood to be concentrating on a number of terminally ill children whom she helped to care for between 1995-99.

Officers are looking at whether there is any evidence that the children were given overdoses of the painkiller morphine, but the authorities admit that an eight-month trawl through the nurse's records has so far uncovered nothing.

"I can tell you that she will fully cooperate, 100% all the way, every day if the police want her to," the relative said.

"We have been in contact with the police. They do not want to meet with her or talk to her or interview her."

The nurse specialised in the care of terminally ill children. Most of her work involved home visits but she also saw patients in hospital.

The woman, who cannot be named for legal reasons, went into hiding yesterday after revelations in the Sun newspaper that police had begun an investigation, sparked by an audit of her work which was carried out by South Essex mental health and community care services NHS trust.

According to sources at the trust, a review of the nurse's work began when she was suspended in September last year because of concern over entirely unrelated matters.

During the audit, the trust became concerned about the treatment of a particular child. Police were asked to look into the child's death but dropped the inquiry in December, saying there was no evidence to support the worries.

But a much broader examination of the nurse's work began soon afterwards, led by Det Supt Ian McNeill. His squad has reviewed thousands of pages of case notes and has brought in medical experts to evaluate the treatment given to her patients Neither the nurse nor the parents of children involved were told of the inquiry until Wednesday night, just before the story was published. Teams of police family liaison officers and counsellors from the trust worked until 5am yesterday to notify parents.

"It must have come as a terrible shock to them," said a police source. "We did not want to upset people unnecessarily by telling them what was going on before we were ready. Many of these families have suffered great sadness and trauma in their lives and we did not want to talk to them about matters that might turn out to be unfounded."

The source added: "To arrest someone you need reasonable cause. We haven't even asked to speak to this woman yet. You can draw your own conclusions from that."

The nurse was told of the inquiry at 11.30pm on Wednesday. She left home to stay with her parents and is due to go on a pre-planned holiday today.

A relative who arrived outside to the nurse's home yesterday said: "The investigation is full of ifs and maybes. There are no substantive facts."

The regulatory body for nursing, the UKCC, sent a letter to the nurse yesterday notifying her of a hearing in a fortnight which is likely to suspend her from the profession throughout the country for the duration of the inquiry. At the moment, she is suspended only from working for South Essex mental health and community care services NHS trust.

The trust last night won an injunction in the high court in London preventing the naming of the nurse, who lives alone.

The police are not treating the case as a murder inquiry and have no plans at present to exhume the bodies of any of the children.

 A hotline for parents has been set up on 0800 169 1619

His squad has reviewed thousands of pages of case notes and has brought in medical experts to evaluate the treatment given to her patients Neither the nurse nor the parents of children involved were told of the inquiry until Wednesday night, just before the story was published. Teams of police family liaison officers and counsellors from the trust worked until 5am yesterday to notify parents. "It must have come as a terrible shock to them," said a police source. "We did not want to upset people unnecessarily by telling them what was going on before we were ready. Many of these families have suffered great sadness and trauma in their lives and we did not want to talk to them about matters that might turn out to be unfounded." The source added: "To arrest someone you need reasonable cause. We haven't even asked to speak to this woman yet. You can draw your own conclusions from that." The nurse was told of the inquiry at 11.30pm on Wednesday. She left home to stay with her parents and is due to go on a pre-planned holiday today. A relative who arrived outside to the nurse's home yesterday said: "The investigation is full of ifs and maybes. There are no substantive facts." The regulatory body for nursing, the UKCC, sent a letter to the nurse yesterday notifying her of a hearing in a fortnight which is likely to suspend her from the profession throughout the country for the duration of the inquiry. At the moment, she is suspended only from working for South Essex mental health and community care services NHS trust. The trust last night won an injunction in the high court in London preventing the naming of the nurse, who lives alone. The police are not treating the case as a murder inquiry and have no plans at present to exhume the bodies of any of the children.  A hotline for parents has been set up on 0800 169 1619

webTitle: Court battle looms as TV regulator gets tough over News at Ten

fields.headline: Court battle looms as TV regulator gets tough over News at Ten
fields.trailText: The row over ITV's decision to scrap News at Ten appeared certain to end up in court last night after regulators told the broadcaster to bring forward its 11pm news bulletin to an earlier time slot.
fields.body:
The row over ITV's decision to scrap News at Ten appeared certain to end up in court last night after regulators told the broadcaster to bring forward its 11pm news bulletin to an earlier time slot.

The independent television commission, in an unprecedented move, rejected ITV's final proposals to improve ratings for its news bulletins, which have fallen by 1m since News at Ten was axed last year.

The broadcaster is convinced the ITC has no power to "regulate for ratings" and to tell it when to schedule the news. If the commission decides to formalise its demand, ITV could force a judicial review.

ITV chiefs were in talks last night over their next move, but they are resolved to take the matter to court if necessary.

Yesterday's decision comes a month after the commission gave ITV extra time to arrest the fall in ratings for its news bulletins, which began when News at Ten was scrapped last spring. MPs, including Tony Blair, have demanded that the 10pm bulletin be restored.

ITV told the regulator yesterday it would invest £21m in quality programmes during the run-up to the 11pm Nightly News, which gets better ratings when preceding shows are popular. It also promised to bring back News at Ten at elections. The ITC said it would accept the plan, on condition that ITV agreed to reschedule the Nightly News if audiences did not improve.

But ITV rejected that condition as unworkable, saying it would not take account of future changes, such as any decision by the BBC to move its 9pm news to 10pm.

Sir Robin Biggam, the ITC chairman, said: "At the time the changes were agreed, ITV stated that they believed the news audience would hold or increase. In fact audiences fell by 13.9% and there has been no evidence of improvement."

ITV insists that ratings were not made a condition of the commission's decision to allow the scrapping of News at Ten. The ITC says it is confident of its legal position. The regulator admitted yesterday that it had no power to insist on a particular time at which ITV should schedule its news, but it is understood that it would agree to the Nightly News being aired at 10.30pm when, research showed, 30% more viewers were available.

An ITC spokesman said: "If ITV chooses not to come forward with a proposal for a bulletin earlier in the evening...we have statutory powers that enable us to order ITV to bring forward the news. This is about public service broadcasting."

Gerald Kaufman, chairman of the Commons culture select committee, said he was pleased with the ITC ruling.

"It is now for ITV to take note of the very strong feeling across the country and bring back News at Ten," he said.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Summertime, a lack of economic or corporate news and the distraction of Royal Ascot saw leading shares close towards lows for the day.
fields.body:
Summertime, a lack of economic or corporate news and the distraction of Royal Ascot saw leading shares close towards lows for the day.

Only rumours in the US that Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan had been involved in a car crash just days before the meeting of the interest rate-setting body, the FOMC, woke traders from their lethargy. After the market closed the Fed denied anything untoward had happened.

As Ladies' Day at Royal Ascot soaked up the attention the FTSE 100 slipped 64 points lower to close at 6,413.8, well below an early peak of 6,530.7. Volume of 1.536bn shares changing hands in 91,088 transactions was solid yet uninspiring.

Early - and dull - figures from the CBI on monthly trends showing UK export demands are further below normal levels than they have been for a year knocked back the blue-chip stocks.

Nevertheless, some things never change. The relentless rise of FTSE 100 newcomer Bookham Technology continued as the illiquid stock added a further 115p to £38.40p.

Misys benefited from a Deustche Bank buy note to close up 28p at 582p, while Logica gained 34p to £16.65p after its WAP alternative global launch. Only Sage Group suffered a miserable day among the IT plays, topping the FTSE 100 fallers by dropping 38p to 552p on rumours that it could follow US firm Great Plains with a negative trading statement.

Halifax shrugged off a broker downgrade from Goldman Sachs to close up 19.5p at 587.5p, largely due to news of its acquisition of Bank One's UK credit card business.

But BT lost 40p at 900p on a reduction in price target by ABN Amro from £16.80p to £14.70p. EMI added 53.5p to 658.5p amid consolidation hopes after the Vivendi-Seagram merger. Diageo lost 11p at 587p after announcing Burger King chief executive Dennis Malamatinas's resignation and the partial flotation of its fast food chain subsidiary on the NYSE.

Allied Zurich was among the worst performers, falling 35p to 762p as house broker Cazenove cut its recommendation to "reduce'' from "buy'' and slashed its price target by 15% to 850p.

Among the smaller stocks, games maker Eidos edged 20p lower to 496p as talk of firm bid developments faded.

Cosmetics chain Body Shop benefited from a 6% increase in sales in the first quarter to close up 2p at 128.5p. Beleaguered shareholders in troubled computer group Gresham had something to smile about - the shares have lost 60% of their value since the start of the year but climbed 22% to 36p.

fields.headline: Autonomy looks homeward bound
fields.trailText: Private investors may finally be about to be offered a relatively painless route through which to buy shares in Autonomy, one of the British technology sector's success stories.
fields.body:
Private investors may finally be about to be offered a relatively painless route through which to buy shares in Autonomy, one of the British technology sector's success stories.

The Cambridge-based intelligent software maker said yesterday that it is considering a stock market listing in London, as a way of making its shares more attractive to UK investors.

It also announced a three-for-one stock split, effective from August 1, to provide more liquidity.

Autonomy is presently listed on the Easdaq and Nasdaq markets and if it moved to London its market value of around $4bn (£2.7bn) would put the company within sight of the benchmark FTSE 100 index. It would doubtless attract much interest from institutions and individual shareholders alike - this is, after all, a blue chip technology company operating in a global market - but those looking to buy in at this stage might find the days of spectacular returns are over.

Autonomy listed on Easdaq, the Brussels-based speciality technology market, in July 1998.

The London authorities were reluctant to entertain the prospect of a tiny loss-making technology business using one of its exchanges to raise new funds. Very few analysts were prepared to cover the stock.

Shares began trading at $4 and bounced around between $2 and $6 until autumn of last year when technology stocks swung into favour. Between August and Christmas the shares rocketed six fold to around $60. Then in March they touched a record high of $218, valuing the four-year-old firm at $8bn and making the founder, Dr Mike Lynch, Britain's first internet billionaire. The subsequent correction in valuations has knocked the shares back and last night they closed down $1 at $116.

Of Autonomy's European investors, the majority are based in Britain. But as marketing director Dominic Johnson says: "A lot of the more general funds, which tend to overlook the Easdaq or Nasdaq, don't tend to get access to Autonomy."

Private punters in Britain rarely buy Easdaq listed shares at all.

In the past few months, the London Stock Exchange has worked hard to encourage more tech firms to list in Britain. The Techmark index has already raised London's profile. But there is a feeling that many of the moves have been half-hearted.

If Autonomy does "come home" it will be good news for the London market and British investors. The appetite for hi-tech shares has changed and it is easy to talk with hindsight. But the company should never have had to leave in the first place.

webTitle: Andy Capp rules north-east and it's not OK, says study

fields.headline: Andy Capp rules north-east and it's not OK, says study
fields.standfirst: North-south divide: special report
fields.trailText: Andy Capp is alive, well and running his native north-east, according to a critical report on councils and quangos in the English region closest to setting up its own assembly.
fields.body:
Andy Capp is alive, well and running his native north-east, according to a critical report on councils and quangos in the English region closest to setting up its own assembly.

Every institution running schools, health and other services is dominated by middle-aged men, who are wholly unrepresentative of the north-east's population profile, the analysis by two local universities concludes.

The study, Who Runs the North-east Now?, is expected to trigger a series of similar studies of power holders in other English regions, as the debate over English devolution grows. All are expected to show a similar shortfall of women in key positions and an almost total absence of young people.

"Democracy is at a low ebb in the north-east," said Fred Robinson of Durham University, which worked with the University of Northumbria to track down every member of police authorities, arts funders and housing associations, as well as larger bodies such as local councils and NHS trusts.

The report attacks a lukewarm attitude to transparency in many quangos, with one publicly funded further education college taking a fortnight and four phone calls to agree to provide a list of the members of its governing body.

The report also criticises the very low numbers of ethnic minority or disabled members on quangos.

fields.headline: BT talking £5bn for Openworld
fields.standfirst:
Float 'probable' for high speed net division
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Anne Hyland of BT said yesterday it was considering a flotation of Openworld, its broadband internet division, that could raise £5bn. The move would be the next stage of the business restructuring that was begun in the spring.
fields.body:
Anne Hyland of BT said yesterday it was considering a flotation of Openworld, its broadband internet division, that could raise £5bn. The move would be the next stage of the business restructuring that was begun in the spring.

No timing was given for a spin-off of Openworld, best known in the UK for the high-speed digital internet services launched in April.

The flotation would be in addition to the planned partial listing of Yell, BT's directory and e-commerce business, which includes Yellow Pages. Analysts have estimated that the stock market value of Yell will range from £3bn to £6bn.

Openworld has 2.5m customers in the UK, Italy, Spain and Ireland. It also has a further 1.1m indirect customers through alliances with WH Smith and Barclays. Its digital services provide internet connection at speeds 10 to 20 times faster than conventional analogue lines.

Marc Deschamps, Openworld's chief operating officer, said a float of his division was "probable".

Two months ago BT announced a restructuring of the group into six main divisions after pressure from institutional shareholders who were dissatisfied by the company's poor share price performance.

The desire to split Openworld from its parent is being fuelled by its need to make acquisitions.

The division has recognised that content is going to be crucial in winning and keeping internet customers, analysts said. It already has agreements with about 75 suppliers of news, sport, video clips and applications.

Jim McCafferty, head of European telecommunications at SG Global Equities said the flotation plans came as no surprise, and suggested "we would be talking numbers of about £5bn" which would give the business an equity base to make acquisitions.

Openworld also includes BT's stake in Open, the interactive television joint venture with BSkyB, and Genie, the mobile phone internet portal.

Shares in BT fell 40p to 900p yesterday; telecom shares generally were down.

 BT launched its latest mobile phone network for business customers yesterday. The network uses technology -known as general packet radio service - which allows high-speed "always on" mobile internet connections.

webTitle: Little love lost as parties put faith on agenda

fields.headline: Little love lost as parties put faith on agenda
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: In a church hall near Westminster, a biblical quotation picked out in gold lettering reads: "My little children, let us not love in word, neither in tongue, but in deed and in truth."  Yesterday, beneath the words of St John, there was little love lost between a Labour minister and a rightwing US Christian guru advising the Conservative party as both sought to set out a role for churches and faith groups in tackling some of Britain's most persistant social problems.
fields.body:
In a church hall near Westminster, a biblical quotation picked out in gold lettering reads: "My little children, let us not love in word, neither in tongue, but in deed and in truth." Yesterday, beneath the words of St John, there was little love lost between a Labour minister and a rightwing US Christian guru advising the Conservative party as both sought to set out a role for churches and faith groups in tackling some of Britain's most persistant social problems.

A religion and welfare conference addressed by a bearded Texan professor and Treasury minister Stephen Timms might not be expected to create waves amid the Westminster bustle. But, with William Hague importing elements of US Republicanism's so-called "compassionate conservatism" in an overt pitch for a British spiritual vote, the combustible mix of faith and politics is back on the agenda.

The Tory leader has made much of his meeting this week with Marvin Olasky, an advocate of "Bible-based free market economics" and adviser to the Republican presidential candidate, George W Bush, on welfare and faith-based programmes. Government's cannot, by definition, be compassionate, the professor argues, since compassion requires the giver to have a sense of personal involvement with the receiver, and an impetus that they improve their lot rather than become dependent.

Labour, in turn, has derided the partnership, pointing to Prof Olasky's suggestions that the state should hand responsbility for welfare provision to church and community organisations, and that feminism and working women are to blame for "great sexual irresponsibility" and the "marginalisation" of children.

Mr Timms yesterday condemned the professor's views as "repugnant".

Behind the exchanging of insults lies a combination of political manoeuvering and a genuine debate over the role of faith groups in delivering welfare support to Britain's poorest communities.

Tony Blair's government, primarily through programmes driven by its cross departmental social exclusion unit, is increasingly involving churches and other faith-based community groups in efforts to regenerate deprived areas, picking up on what Mr Timms called a "new faith-based social activism".

Representatives of the five largest faith communities in England sit on the inner cities religious council, a forum set up by the Conservatives in 1992 and based within the Department of Environment Transport and the Regions to feed "faith perspectives" into regeneration policy.

The key difference between such moves and the ideas of Prof Olasky, according to ministers, is that Labour favours partnership with faith-based organisations but dismisses the idea that such links could replace the role of government.

Yesterday, Frank Field, Labour MP, welfare expert and churchgoer, underlined the difficulties of importing US theories when he challenged Prof Olasky's proposition that, given £100 to spend on doing good, the vast majority would send it to a charity or local organisation rather than the government. The British welfare state, he said, was "a product of Christian and Jewish belief" and, though reform was needed, was valued by many as a symbol of "shared endeavour".

Mr Hague, conscious of the risks of borrowing too overtly from the Olasky principles, insists he does not want to see the creation in Britain of an American-style religious right. But, influenced by its recent listening to churches consultation, his party has quietly begun to promote a greater role in welfare for charities and the voluntary sector. Compassionate Communities, a consultation paper from the Conservative Christian Fellowship, argues: "There is increasing recognition that government does not have adequate answers to some of this country's deepest problems." Despite the government's partnership "rhetoric", the paper said, "charitable vision is suffocated by the overwhelming embrace of the bear-like state".

The question for Mr Hague and his new shadow cabinet sub-committee on faith-based welfare is how far his party can reconcile such conclusions and still insist it will protect the existing social safety net.

Labour strategists believe that, as he seeks to carve out a distinctive electoral manifesto, the Tory leader will incline more towards the Olasky vision of a diminished state than the traditional British model.

There are signs that Mr Hague may opt to steer his party towards a US-style position which would see policy influences translated into a direct political appeal to the religious vote.

The Conservative Christian Fellowship, which Mr Hague relocated within Tory central office, has links with the US religious right, including meetings with the powerful lobby group, the Christian Coalition.

Mr Hague, an irregular churchgoer but self-proclaimed Christian, has this year made high profile efforts to appeal directly to evangelical Christians, addressing an 8,000-strong audience at the evangelical spring harvest festival and promising to support anti-poverty projects denied government funds because they are religiously-based.

This spring, he appealed in a Roman Catholic journal for support on the basis of policies to promote marriage and the family, while he has subsequently spoken of his opposition to abortion.

The Tories are making overt pitches for the religious vote, according to Jonathan Bartley, general secretary of the cross-party Movement for Christian Democracy. But, he added, the Christian Socialist Movement, which Tony Blair joined in 1991, has also been angered at the "thin veneer" of ethical socialism rather than "authentic Christian thought" informing government agendas.

Both main parties are talking up links with faith groups out of pragmatism, he argues, with the rhetorical arms race over asylum policy betraying a lack of true Christian values. Churches and faith groups must press to ensure parties take on board a new agenda highlighting international development and social justice.

Even if the faith groups do not seek to influence government, they can be sure political parties are working out how best to use them - and the votes of their believers.

Charitable deeds

Faith groups which have impressed ministers:

 Jubilee 2000 - mainly church-led campaign to write off third world debt. It helped to persuade Gordon Brown to cancel debts to Britain from the world's poorest countries

 Pecan project in Peckham, south London. The Peckham Evangelical Churches Action Network played a big role in the government new deal programme in Southwark; now involved in the employment action zone, helping to cut unemployment.

 Bethany Trust in Edinburgh. Housed in an old chapel building, the charity works with homeless people, accommodating more than 120. Workers meet homeless people on the streets, offering food, shelter and support.

 Victory Outreach in London, Manchester and Dublin. A church-based project, whose staff go on streets to help drug users and prostitutes. Clients must sign up to programme focused on prayer, Bible study and church attendance.

Yesterday, Frank Field, Labour MP, welfare expert and churchgoer, underlined the difficulties of importing US theories when he challenged Prof Olasky's proposition that, given £100 to spend on doing good, the vast majority would send it to a charity or local organisation rather than the government. The British welfare state, he said, was "a product of Christian and Jewish belief" and, though reform was needed, was valued by many as a symbol of "shared endeavour". Mr Hague, conscious of the risks of borrowing too overtly from the Olasky principles, insists he does not want to see the creation in Britain of an American-style religious right. But, influenced by its recent listening to churches consultation, his party has quietly begun to promote a greater role in welfare for charities and the voluntary sector. Compassionate Communities, a consultation paper from the Conservative Christian Fellowship, argues: "There is increasing recognition that government does not have adequate answers to some of this country's deepest problems." Despite the government's partnership "rhetoric", the paper said, "charitable vision is suffocated by the overwhelming embrace of the bear-like state". The question for Mr Hague and his new shadow cabinet sub-committee on faith-based welfare is how far his party can reconcile such conclusions and still insist it will protect the existing social safety net. Labour strategists believe that, as he seeks to carve out a distinctive electoral manifesto, the Tory leader will incline more towards the Olasky vision of a diminished state than the traditional British model. There are signs that Mr Hague may opt to steer his party towards a US-style position which would see policy influences translated into a direct political appeal to the religious vote. The Conservative Christian Fellowship, which Mr Hague relocated within Tory central office, has links with the US religious right, including meetings with the powerful lobby group, the Christian Coalition. Mr Hague, an irregular churchgoer but self-proclaimed Christian, has this year made high profile efforts to appeal directly to evangelical Christians, addressing an 8,000-strong audience at the evangelical spring harvest festival and promising to support anti-poverty projects denied government funds because they are religiously-based. This spring, he appealed in a Roman Catholic journal for support on the basis of policies to promote marriage and the family, while he has subsequently spoken of his opposition to abortion. The Tories are making overt pitches for the religious vote, according to Jonathan Bartley, general secretary of the cross-party Movement for Christian Democracy. But, he added, the Christian Socialist Movement, which Tony Blair joined in 1991, has also been angered at the "thin veneer" of ethical socialism rather than "authentic Christian thought" informing government agendas. Both main parties are talking up links with faith groups out of pragmatism, he argues, with the rhetorical arms race over asylum policy betraying a lack of true Christian values. Churches and faith groups must press to ensure parties take on board a new agenda highlighting international development and social justice. Even if the faith groups do not seek to influence government, they can be sure political parties are working out how best to use them - and the votes of their believers. Charitable deeds Faith groups which have impressed ministers:  Jubilee 2000 - mainly church-led campaign to write off third world debt. It helped to persuade Gordon Brown to cancel debts to Britain from the world's poorest countries  Pecan project in Peckham, south London. The Peckham Evangelical Churches Action Network played a big role in the government new deal programme in Southwark; now involved in the employment action zone, helping to cut unemployment.  Bethany Trust in Edinburgh. Housed in an old chapel building, the charity works with homeless people, accommodating more than 120. Workers meet homeless people on the streets, offering food, shelter and support.  Victory Outreach in London, Manchester and Dublin. A church-based project, whose staff go on streets to help drug users and prostitutes. Clients must sign up to programme focused on prayer, Bible study and church attendance.

fields.headline: Carphone goes into venture capital
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Carphone Warehouse, the mobile phone retailer gearing up for a stock market flotation, is planning a $120m (£79.2m) venture capital fund to invest in wireless net businesses.
fields.body:
Carphone Warehouse, the mobile phone retailer gearing up for a stock market flotation, is planning a $120m (£79.2m) venture capital fund to invest in wireless net businesses.

The timing of the fund, details of which emerged on a new financial website, Sharecast.com, could give shares in the company added lustre by drawing more direct links to the market for mobile internet services. Carphone Warehouse is putting up $40m while three other, unnamed investors are making up the remainder.

Carphone Warehouse, which has 800 stores across Europe, is expected to be valued at between £1.6bn and £2bn on joining the market.

In the run-up to flotation the company has also announced the launch of a mobile internet portal named Mviva, which is 15% owned by America Online. The new investment fund is in addition to an existing $50m which has now been almost fully deployed.

Investments from the first fund include Clear Money, an electronic billing group, Homepro, a home improvement website, Picofun, a Swedish games portal and 3G.com, a cellular chip firm.

Both funds are being managed by Nigel Spray, a former investment banker at CSFB.

Carphone's other businesses include Value Telecom, which repackages One2One airtime under its own brand name.

The float, which will value founder Charles Dunstone's holding at up to £1bn, has been eagerly anticipated; the company has chosen to float now because of the opportunity offered by the wireless internet market. It aims to float 20% of the business with a potential of 25% if oversubscribed. The prospectus is due for publication later this month with pricing, allocation and shares trading due in July.

The five year-long deliberations of the directors have manifested themsleves in a cautious approach to the market, with plans to offer preference to retail investors who agreed to not to sell their shares for three months in order to calm the share price in the weeks following the float.

fields.headline: Just2Clicks in buying drive
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Just2Clicks, the business to business trading platform provider, said yesterday that it was considering acquisitions and spin-offs to boost its flagging share price.
fields.body:
Just2Clicks, the business to business trading platform provider, said yesterday that it was considering acquisitions and spin-offs to boost its flagging share price.

Chief executive Karl Watkins said it remained interested in acquiring Global Internet Billing, which it almost bought for £350m in April.

"If they agreed a £200m all-share offer we'd do a deal tomorrow," he said. It is understood that GIB shareholders would look for a higher offer.

A separate listing for e-procurement unit Tradezone, bought for £6m in March, was being considered. "When you consider our entire market capitalisation is about £100m, and a US company almost identical to Tradezone was valued at $1.7bn less than a month ago, then there must be better ways of realising the value in it," he said.

Just2Clicks operates at the "mucky" end of net commerce including a system for the power, cement, pulp and paper and cargo sectors.

In the nine weeks to March 31, Just2Clicks recorded revenues of £340,000 and a £1.94m loss. But, Mr Watkins said, the figures were distorted by exceptional costs of £134,000 and amortisation of £1.65m.

"Our cash burn is very low. As of the end of May we had £48.5m in the bank so we only spent £1.5m since we raised £50 at the float in February."

Mr Watkins admitted disappointment that the share price has more than halved from the post-flotation high of 240p in February. Last night the shares were unchanged at 103p.

fields.headline: Labour's women
fields.standfirst: MPs aim for the female voter
fields.trailText: The chancellor, Gordon Brown, is being lobbied by female Labour MPs for cash in next month's spending review for a cradle-to-grave series of women-friendly policies.
fields.body:
The chancellor, Gordon Brown, is being lobbied by female Labour MPs for cash in next month's spending review for a cradle-to-grave series of women-friendly policies.

The submission, which includes a demand for cash to allow parental leave to be paid, would allow Labour to enter the general election proclaiming itself the party directly addressing women's concerns, the MPs believe.

Recent focus group evidence has indicated a growing "dissatisfaction gap" with the government, with women significantly more troubled by lack of delivery in key services such as health and education than men. The women's minister, Lady Jay, will use a speech to Labour women's conference in Southport tomorrow to dismiss suggestions that a gender gap is reopening among British voters, but MPs hope the co-ordinated call for policies to benefit women and children will help woo back wavering female supporters.

The list of proposals, drawn up by the parliamentary Labour party women's group, covers a range of reforms from maternity rights through to improved pension arrangements for women.

It is aimed at persuading Mr Brown in advance of the so-called Spending Review 2000, due next month, which sets out cash allocations for each government department for a three year period from April 2001.

Lorna Fitzsimons, chairwoman of the women's group and MP for Rochdale, said: "The review is one of the most important landmarks in affecting policies which will affect everyone from the youngest children to the oldest grans." The review needed to reflect social changes, including the increased role for many working people in caring for elderly relatives, she said.

Payment for parental leave tops the list of women MPs' demands, reflecting the belief that supporters of the move are now pushing at an open door with ministers.

Research carried out for the women's group by Bolton West MP Ruth Kelly earlier this year has shown that, without payment to compensate for salary foregone, take-up of a new entitlement to up to 13 weeks' leave to care for children will be negligible, particularly among men. Trade secretary Stephen Byers has already indicated he is minded to back proposals made by Ms Kelly for a flat rate payment of around £150 a week.

The group, which has already held a meeting with the Treasury chief secretary, Andrew Smith, over its submission, also hopes that it will secure support for a right for women to return to work part time after maternity leave. A government review of maternity pay and leave, chaired by Mr Byers, is considering the plan, which aims to tackle a situation where many women are forced to return to work relatively swiftly after giving birth and then give up their jobs.

fields.trailText: The Royal Aeronautical Society has asked us to make it clear that Air Chief Marshal Sir William Wratten and Air Marshal Sir John Day resigned from the society in 1998 following a disagreement concerning the coverage of the Chinook in Aerospace International, a magazine published by the society, and not as a result of the report referred to in the article, A fault in the system, page 21, June 20, which was not commissioned or endorsed by the society. Our article also referred to a memo drafted by Sir William as air officer commander-in-chief - sent four days after the crash on the Mull of Kintyre on June 2 1994 - complaining about a decision by the ministry of defence airworthiness assessors to stop Chinooks flying. Sir William points out that at the time he was on a tour of duty in Saudi Arabia. He says he did not have anything to do with Chinooks before September of that year.

fields.headline: Bitter rivals in beer wars
fields.trailText: Peter Martin's complaint about the takeover of Bass by Interbrew (Letters, June 19) completely misses the point that it is not governments that bring about changes but individuals with the foresight and skill to organise.
fields.body:
Peter Martin's complaint about the takeover of Bass by Interbrew (Letters, June 19) completely misses the point that it is not governments that bring about changes but individuals with the foresight and skill to organise.

His survey shows that 99% of people do not like theme pubs. Why don't they get off their bums and join the Campaign for Real Ale? It beats bleating any day.

Martin might also like to know that small brewers here in East Anglia have set up a system of exchange with brewers in the south of England. No cask ever travels empty in either direction. All these small brewers are actually expanding production at the expense of the big brewers.

These small brewers would have to wait until the next millennium for the government to assist them.
Mike Harvey
Treasurer, Colchester and North East Essex Camra

 Peter Martin's disparaging remarks on the quality of European drinks and drinking places require some comment.

Interbrew's two most widely available imported beers in the UK (Stella Artois is brewed here under licence) are Hoegaarden (5.5% alcohol) and Leffe (6%), both stronger and more distinctive than the unpleasant watery liquids served as "real ales" in the average pub.

As well as welcoming availability of more continental brands, I hope that metric measures will follow shortly. With 250ml and 500ml glasses it will be possible to enjoy a drink without having its contents spilled everywhere.

This small move to European drinking habits will go a long way to making our pubs more pleasant places by removing the smell of stale spilt beer.
Michael J Cope
Dorking, Surrey

fields.headline: Exhibition celebrates royal banquets
fields.standfirst: The date was May 28, 1698, and dinner was served
fields.trailText: There were platters of roast pheasant, quail, snipe and grouse, two giant crabs, a male and a female lobster, a dish of sheep's trotters in cream, an elaboratedly decorated tongue served whole, a platter of hares roasted with their heads on, served with their bellies slit open to display the innards, mince pies, two huge wild boar pies covered in patterned pastry decorated with real gold leaf, a dish of pickled crayfish, salmon pies surrounded by scallops in pastry, venison pies, and pyramids of marzipan and candied fruits.
fields.body:
There were platters of roast pheasant, quail, snipe and grouse, two giant crabs, a male and a female lobster, a dish of sheep's trotters in cream, an elaboratedly decorated tongue served whole, a platter of hares roasted with their heads on, served with their bellies slit open to display the innards, mince pies, two huge wild boar pies covered in patterned pastry decorated with real gold leaf, a dish of pickled crayfish, salmon pies surrounded by scallops in pastry, venison pies, and pyramids of marzipan and candied fruits.

That was only the second course. The first course had already been eaten. But it was still quite a lot for two people, King William and Queen Mary, to get through.

Eat, Drink and be Merry, an exhibition opening at Kenwood House on Monday and lasting until September 24, recreates four centuries of the highest table dining.

Most meals are period examples recreated from contemporary sources, but William and Mary's dinner was a real meal, documented by the chef, Patrick Land, who managed to keep his head and his kitchen through the reigns of Charles II, James II, William and Mary and Queen Anne. "This was high baroque ritual food," food historian Ivan Day said. "It was a garter feast for John Hollis, Duke of Newcastle.

"He had slaughtered a lot of men in Ireland during the Glorious Revolution, and he was rewarded with not only the dukedom but a garter."

fields.headline: Capital loss
fields.body:
It is not just the north-east which loses as a result of the Barnett formula (Northern slights, June 22). London is coming under increasing strain as more resources are taken from it to boost the regions. In London, costs are higher and the intensity of need is far greater. Half of inner London's children are entitled to free school meals and unemployment in inner London is twice the national average. In the past seven years London has lost £451m as a result of formula changes to revenue grant distribution systems. This has been redistributed to other local authorities. If the Barnett formula remains unchanged and the redistribution of resources away from London continues, the capital will not be able to provide the same quality of services as the rest of the country.

Cllr Sir Robin Wales
Chairman, Association of London Government

fields.headline: Women's problems
fields.trailText: "Labour has always (at least since 1918) had a problem with older women and vice versa" (Leader, June 19).
fields.body:
"Labour has always (at least since 1918) had a problem with older women and vice versa" (Leader, June 19). Keir Hardie apart, the same problem was apparent earlier in the Labour movement.

Around 1900, women were not permitted to join a Manchester branch of the Independent Labour Party, the New Labour of the day. As they could not become ILP members, Emmeline, Christabel and Sylvia Pankhurst were unable to use the branch's Pankhurst Hall for a women's meeting. According to Sylvia, this was "the last straw which caused Mrs Pankhurst to decide on the formation of a new organisation of women".

Under the circumstances, she felt women had no other choice but to act independently. The Women's Social and Political Union was formed soon afterwards on October 10 1903.
Penny McKenna
London

 You report (Down with Girls!, G2, June 21) that the Sunday Times is serialising even before its publication a new American book blaming feminists for boys' under- achievement at school. Polly Toynbee feels the need to deploy (ironically?) simplistic stereotypes of "feminist orthodoxy" and "ignorant" women voters as a means of establishing her credentials to make a wholly convincing critique of Labour's failure to deliver women friendly policies (Comment, June 21).

Both illustrate the kind of political climate which makes it possible for Labour to marginalise women politicians, dilute European directives on part-time workers and parental leave, renege on its promises to deliver adequate, affordable, quality childcare. Is all of this the fault of feminism? Surely to believe so requires a "standing-on-the- head posture", not so habitual to feminists, as Polly Toynbee would have us believe, but to shadow-boxing media and politicians evading gender equity and social justice.
Dr Barbara Einhorn
University of Sussex

 I wish I could claim to be surprised at New Labour's political correctness enforcers' latest spiffing idea (TV plan to monitor images of ultra-thin women, June 22).Has Tessa Jowell considered the plight of those who wear spectacles or who are bald or both? May I assure her that men forced to wear spectacles from childhood and who, in their advancing years, find themselves with more scalp than hair, have also been "stripped of their self-confidence and stopped from achieving their full potential". I look forward to reading of a similar initiative in respect of these unfortunates.
Peter Dickinson
London dickinson@hanwell7.freeserve.co.uk

fields.headline: Don't blame the war
fields.trailText: Tony Parsons' experience of the aftermath of war is different from mine (Letters, June 21). My father served at Dunkirk and at the invasion of France and I had an uncle who was in a Japanese prisoner of war camp.
fields.body:
Tony Parsons' experience of the aftermath of war is different from mine (Letters, June 21). My father served at Dunkirk and at the invasion of France and I had an uncle who was in a Japanese prisoner of war camp. They hardly ever spoke of their experiences to me and most of my contemporaries found their fathers equally taciturn. For me and my friends there was no "shadow of the second world war" - the Battle of Britain was as remote as the Battle of Hastings.

What Tony Parsons is talking about is not some sense of common experience communicated through the generations but a concoction created by politicians, aided and abetted by the entertainment industry, who saw an opportunity to appropriate the heroic dimensions of the second world war for electoral purposes. Xenophobia and racism may be one of the outcomes of this, but it is not the fault of the war itself - and certainly not of those who fought.
Richard Henderson
Bristol

 When England played Germany in 1966 there was never the slightest suggestion that English fans would view the occasion as anything other than a football match. The fact that there had recently been a war in which the two nations had been on opposing sides, was not a major factor. Yet it is now.

The British government and media seem hellbent on perpetuating the notion that a fear and hatred of foreigners is somehow natural and to be expected. Recent asylum legislation, the media's reporting of issues relating to asylum seekers and the upsurge in reported racist crimes bear witness to the increasing trend in which foreigners are portrayed as scroungers, liars and generally inferior beings.

Carping on about the war, as Mr Parsons does, can only serve to perpetuate the kind of rivalry that we all seek to condemn when it is acted out by English fans - because it gives them a valid excuse for their behaviour.
Daniel Guedalla
London

 Margaret Hodge's call to place a voluntary ceiling on overseas footballers (Malaise at the heart of football, June 22) is another variant of the little-Englander response to our shortcomings. It has been a pleasure to watch the creative skills and talents of those overseas players and managers who have graced the English game. We should be grateful that they stay despite the deep-seated hostility to everything non-English.
Chris Miller
Bristol christopher.miller@virgin.net

 I'm sure many "hooligans" will sleep sounder knowing that TR Reid didn't see them, but became a "hooligan sympathiser" anyway (Hooligans? I didn't see any, June 22). I saw hundreds of English who were drunk, obnoxious, and rude. The Belgian police should be commended on their efforts and TR Reid should get a plot summary before trying to tell the tale.
Harlan Levey
Brussels

 May I suggest a lottery-funded replica Romanian village where potential future English footballers are kept, depending entirely on food parcels from the public and an occasional rock concert for their benefit.
J Prajapati
London jlamb@easynet.co.uk

 Time to return to that other favourite media pastime, slagging off the cricketers. It is summer after all.
Dennis Ruston
Newbold Coleorton, Leics

webTitle: A peace-loving peasant army, or ruthless killers?

fields.headline: A peace-loving peasant army, or ruthless killers?
fields.trailText: I spent much of the 70s filming for television in Latin America and witnessed first hand the mayhem that the US-supported dictatorships wreaked on the countries of that continent. Those regimes killed tens of thousands, tortured and traumatised many more and destroyed communities, all in the name of the fight against communism.
fields.body:
I spent much of the 70s filming for television in Latin America and witnessed first hand the mayhem that the US-supported dictatorships wreaked on the countries of that continent. Those regimes killed tens of thousands, tortured and traumatised many more and destroyed communities, all in the name of the fight against communism.

The articles by Duncan Campbell and Isabel Hilton on Colombia and the guerrilla struggle there are a vital reminder of what is at stake (Heart of Darkness, June 19; Colombians do not need help like this, June 21). The US is using its war on drugs as a fig leaf for its war against a peasant army that craves peace and an end to the rampages of the death squads.

The CIA in the Reagan years, under the direction of Oliver North, used Costa Rica as a transit camp for drug shipments to the US. The proceeds went to fund its clandestine war against the Sandinistas.

Its then protege, General Manuel Noriega of Panama, was one of its middle men. Without a ready US market for drugs, there would be no production in Latin America, but in a world of so-called free markets, these poor people are simply showing the capitalist enterprise and initiative so lauded by their big brother in the north.

The European Union must unequivocally reject any support for US machinations in Colombia if an ethical foreign policy is to have any meaning at all.

John Green
London


The prospect of the US launching a new Vietnam campaign in Colombia is enough to make almost anyone start to sympathise for the other side.

However, Duncan Campbell would do well to remember that just because the Farc's sworn enemies are in many cases as unpleasant as they are - an army tarnished by human rights abuses, paramilitary groups whose murderous excesses surpass even the guerrillas', a corrupt (albeit elected) government - this does not make them revolutionary heroes.

When they are not watching US television and holding touchingly earnest discussions of current affairs round the campfire, the guerrillas are ruthless killers and extortionists. They are succeeding in making normal economic life impossible and are helping to drive anyone with an education out of the country.

They are relics of the Soviet era and represent virtually no one but themselves, cynically drawing upon a tradition of rural revolt against central government to drum up recruits for their outmoded ideological struggle.

And if they are so interested in education and welfare, why have they repeatedly destroyed schools, clinics and infrastructure built by the government to improve rural conditions? Sadly, their entry into the drug trade means they are likely to be able to fund their war for another few decades, raising the prospect of Colombia becoming the Angola of the Americas.

Charles Linton
London

fields.headline: Hague's third way
fields.standfirst:
Socially tender, economically tough
Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Whatever else you think of him, William Hague has certainly solved his visibility problem. Thanks to a series of headline-grabbing statements on asylum seekers and vigilante farmers, and a run of self-inflicted Labour wounds, the likeliest response to the Tory leader is no longer "William who?".
fields.body:
Whatever else you think of him, William Hague has certainly solved his visibility problem. Thanks to a series of headline-grabbing statements on asylum seekers and vigilante farmers, and a run of self-inflicted Labour wounds, the likeliest response to the Tory leader is no longer "William who?". Now he's having enough of an impact to make several Labour backbenchers begin to panic - suddenly wondering if their seats and the party's majority is safe.

Mr Hague has made his mark not with his first-rate Commons debating skills: he's had those since he was a teenager. Rather he has shown a shameless talent for opportunism. If there's a bandwagon passing, he'll jump on it. His latest leap came yesterday when he offered to "help" the government should it move to crack down on football hooligans. Earlier he made a more interesting play - for the religious vote. He called for "a more generous acknowledgement" of the role of the church and other faith-based organisations in our national life. He spoke of the role religious communities can play in teaching children, helping the poor or rescuing the drug-addicted.

He may well have hit a rich vein. No society can leave the entire work of compassion and care to government; charities and the voluntary sector will always be essential extra players. As the sociologists would put it, their work is not just effective in itself - it also builds up our reserves of "social capital". Since religious communities have always been in the forefront of such activity, there is nothing controversial in paying homage to their work.

The problem is in the rest of Mr Hague's message. By meeting on Wednesday with Marvin Olasky, the ultra-rightwing Christian evangelical from Texas, the Conservative leader signalled a flirtation with the harsher face of religiously-informed politics. Mr Olasky is close to Republican presidential candidate George W Bush. He also blames poverty on the poor and describes women as fit for public office only when there are no men available.

Mr Olasky's politics are reactionary and ugly: by sitting on his knee, Mr Hague has cast a shadow over his praise for religion - and made it little more than another move by the Tory leader toward the intolerant right.

For a pattern is emerging here. William Hague is staking out rightwing positions on social and cultural questions: asylum, crime and now religion. Meanwhile, he is trying to head leftward on economics - promising to match Labour's increased spending on hospitals and schools and, as we reported yesterday, going easy on the Thatcherism: hence the recent silence on private health care. Mr Hague is crafting his very own third way: Labourite on the bread-and-butter issues of spending, Tebbitite on the inflammatory, phone-in issues of society and culture.

Will it work? The logic might be appealing: this way, the Tories hope to keep Middle England and regain the Basildon Man they lost in 1997. But there are problems. First, the Tories lack all credibility as the party of public services. They may promise to match Labour's money, but voters will not forget the Thatcher-Major record that quickly. Second, their Tebbitite brew on the culture could alienate as many voters as it recruits. Witness the loss last month of Romsey, the Tories' 50th safest seat. Hagueite talk on asylum seems to have turned off people there. The hope must be that elections in Britain are still won on the centre ground - and that the Conservatives are getting further and further away from it.

fields.headline: Hooray for literacy
fields.trailText: David Blunkett says he will resign if  "80% of primary school pupils fail to reach the expected standard in literacy" (School teachers resign, June 22). So if 21% succeed and only 79% fail, he should be all right.
fields.body:
David Blunkett says he will resign if "80% of primary school pupils fail to reach the expected standard in literacy" (School teachers resign, June 22). So if 21% succeed and only 79% fail, he should be all right.

Glasgow

 It's a big pity that New Labour is having trouble raising funds (Cash crisis threat to Labour, June 22). Why doesn't it ask its usual targets like pensioners, the disabled and single mothers to dig a little deeper into their pockets?

Ann Fine
London

fields.headline: Bring back News at Ten
fields.standfirst: ITV is wrong to oppose its watchdog
fields.trailText: ITV is wrong to oppose the Independent Television Commission's ruling that its 11pm news bulletin should be brought forward to an earlier time. Since ITV abandoned its flagship News at Ten programme last year in favour of the 11pm slot, ratings have fallen by a million.
fields.body:
ITV is wrong to oppose the Independent Television Commission's ruling that its 11pm news bulletin should be brought forward to an earlier time. Since ITV abandoned its flagship News at Ten programme last year in favour of the 11pm slot, ratings have fallen by a million. That means a million fewer people are watching and absorbing serious news and, as a result, the nation as a whole is worse informed. This is incompatible with the ITV's public service remit and at odds with the ideals of the information age. More than that, it was a commercial nonsense to abandon the title "News at Ten" which had become, and still is, a very powerful brand - something the Nightly News will never become.

News at Ten was also a big success in its own right before the misguided decision to axe it. It attracted 5.6m viewers, an audience most newspapers would die for, and in the months before the decision its viewing figures had increased by 8% while those of the BBC's Nine O'Clock News had fallen. It is such a good slot for news - judged that is by the biorhythms of the nation rather than the returns from commercials - that the BBC admitted this week that it was thinking of moving the Nine O'Clock News to 10pm.

ITV, understandably from its own commercial point of view, wants to run its own show. But it is not an ordinary commercial company. It has public service obligations which are part of its raison d'etre. If it wants to be free then it could switch its activities to one of the hundreds of digital channels now becoming available. But it won't because it likes being one of a select handful of terrestrial broadcasters. What it must not be allowed to do is to cherry pick its public service obligations. A large swathe of public opinion from the prime minister downwards wants to see News at Ten back in its natural slot. ITV should drop its threat to fight its corner in the courts and, for once, make news itself - by admitting it has got this one wrong.
