webTitle: New York subway may be the route for London

fields.headline: New York subway may be the route for London
fields.standfirst:
Experts tell Livingstone to look to US for answers to capital's ailing tube

Livingstone's London: special report
fields.trailText: Stark and seedy, New York's subway stations are unwelcoming. On a hot day passengers risk passing out on the platforms; in winter keeping out the cold is the problem.
fields.body:
Stark and seedy, New York's subway stations are unwelcoming. On a hot day passengers risk passing out on the platforms; in winter keeping out the cold is the problem.

Fortunately the wait for a train is short. The plastic seats were not designed with comfort in mind, but air-conditioned carriages are a welcome relief for 4.5m New Yorkers who ride the subway each day.

Abysmal performance, filthy trains and crime deterred passengers from using the subways 20 years ago. Now the city claims that the greater proportion of its residents make use of it. It is such a turnaround that London's new mayor, Ken Livingstone, who takes the reins of power next week, has been encouraged by experts to make it a role model for London's ailing tube.

The Transport for London group will report directly to Mr Livingstone. The government wants to fund improvements to the tube through the much-delayed public-private partnership - uniting private money with government subsidy - although has admitted it will only introduce the scheme if it is in the "public interest".

The infrastructure, essentially the tracks and signalling, are already out for tender but Mr Livingstone is a proponent of raising funds through bonds - essentially loans - to fund improvements.

In New York, the overhaul was funded, in part, by raising billions of dollars through the issue of bonds, of which $15bn is still outstanding and in the process of being refinanced. To Robert Gerard, the former Morgan Stanley investment banker who advised the subway in the 1970s, it was this ability to raise money through such loans that "contributed to a virtual 100% increase in passenger traffic.

Another important factor was the creation of a regional transportation authority to unite subways, buses and commuter railways under the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Now an academic in London, Mr Gerard believes the ability to raise the money through bonds was made possible by the fact that the MTA also had control of the seven bridges and two tunnels which connect Manhattan with the other suburbs in New York.

All the links charge a $3.50 toll on motorists - to cover the upkeep of the bridges, leaving a stream of money which can be used for other purposes. "This is a direct analogy to the [planned] congestion charge for driving into central London," he said.

The MTA also receives money from taxes levied on New York residents, whose phone bills, for instance, contain a line detailing the tax paid on long-distance calls. Other contributions include tax New Yorkers pay when they move house and on petrol. "Various elements of those tax streams are dedicated to some of the bonds we float. They provide revenue streams for our bonds," said Christopher Boylan deputy executive director of the MTA.

At federal level the system receives approximately $700m each year, purely for capital purposes, and a $105m contribution towards running costs from New York city funds. Mr Boylan, however, said he is "proud" to be able to claim that the $1.50 flat fare on the subway covers 65 to 75% of the average ride. "We used to rely on taxes much more heavily." Commuters with experience of both tube and the subway feel that the New York version is more reliable and less of a cattle truck.

Most New York residents seem prepared to use it, day or night. "I feel as safe at 4am as I do in commuting time," said a woman investment banker. London commuters cannot contemplate such early-hours rides as the tubes stop running around 12.30 am.

Mr Boylan produced statistics that show that "felonies" have fallen dramatically, even in the last six years. In the months of January to May, 3,400 crimes were reported in 1994. This year, the figure was closer to 1,600. He is at pains to explain that the MTA does not run an operating profit - as the tube does, reporting around £250m a year.

And while the arguments rumble on in London about how to fund improvements, New York is already able to claim progress. In contrast to other parts of the US where 85% of commuters travel to work each day by car, in New York four out of five use public transport, subway, bus or commuter rail. More commuters in New York travel on buses and trains in the city than all the rest of the country's subways and railways combined. In London, even finding the statistic for use of public transport involves much searching between public departments.

More commuters in New York travel on buses and trains in the city than all the rest of the country's subways and railways combined. In London, even finding the statistic for use of public transport involves much searching between public departments.

fields.headline: Rich nations block aid accord
fields.standfirst:
Short rails at Japan, France and Denmark
Labour's ethical foreign policy: special report
fields.trailText: Japan, France and Denmark have scuppered an international agreement to loosen the strings attached to Third World aid donations by rich industrialised nations, prompting the government to accuse them of putting narrow financial interests ahead of effective development policies.
fields.body:
Japan, France and Denmark have scuppered an international agreement to loosen the strings attached to Third World aid donations by rich industrialised nations, prompting the government to accuse them of putting narrow financial interests ahead of effective development policies.

After a two-day emergency meeting in Paris, members of the development assistance committee of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development failed to reach an agreement on untying aid to the world's poorest 48 countries despite the support of 18 of the 21 members represented.

The accord would have committed OECD members to abolishing by the end of next year long-standing requirements that much of the aid they provide be spent on goods and services purchased from suppliers in their own countries.

Clare Short, the secretary of state for international development, said: "We deeply regret that members of the DAC [development assistance committee] have failed to reach a consensus on proposals for untying financial aid. We have done our best to seek consensus, for example by accepting that other categories of aid would not be covered at least at the outset.

"It's highly regrettable that narrow considerations of self interest have prevented an agreement which would have made it much easier for developing countries to access aid on a harmonised basis free from commercial distortions. This demonstrates very clearly the ulterior motives behind aid which prevent it being spent on poverty reducation."

Ms Short will now press for the practice of tied aid, attacked by the World Bank and development charities as wasteful, selfish and anti-competitive, to be put on the main agenda at next month's Group of Eight summit in Okinawa, embarrassing the Japanese hosts who are planning to discuss how globalisation can be made to work for the poor.

Japan's reservations stem from fears that its technical consultancy companies will lose out if they are forced to compete for aid contracts in an open market, undermining domestic political support for aid spending, while both France and Denmark are also concerned about the potential loss of business at a time when so much of their aid is tied.

Jeff Chinnock of Action Aid said: "It is an utter disgrace that rich countries, who claim that they are trying to tackle extreme poverty, cannot take even the smallest step towards reducing the commercial abuse of their aid programmes. It is breathtaking hypocrisy."

webTitle: Russia and Israel head money laundering list

fields.headline: Russia and Israel head money laundering list
fields.trailText: Russia, Israel and a string of Caribbean and Pacific Islands head a list of global money laundering hotspots released yesterday, which were accused of recycling billions of dollars each year in receipts from organised crime.
fields.body:
Russia, Israel and a string of Caribbean and Pacific Islands head a list of global money laundering hotspots released yesterday, which were accused of recycling billions of dollars each year in receipts from organised crime.

The body coordinating international efforts to combat money laundering, the Paris-based Financial Action Task Force (FATF) named 15 countries in its first public disclosure of countries refusing to cooperate with the crackdown. Most are offshore financial centres also targeted by international watchdogs for loose banking regulation and harmful tax practices.

The list includes six Caribbean countries: the Bahamas, the Cayman Islands, St Vincent and the Grenadines, St Kitts and Nevis, Dominica and Panama; and five Pacific islands: the Cook Islands, Nauru, Niue, the Philippines, and the Marshall Islands.

Crooks, allegedly, have targeted the smaller, idyllic islands with vigour. Nauru, a tiny South Pacific island of just 10,000 people, is believed to have become one of the Russian mafia's top money laundering centres.

It has 400 offshore banks, according to the FATF, and the Russian Central Bank estimates Russian operatives moved an estimated $70bn through the country in 1998 -700 times its annual income. FATF said Russia faced a "unique challenge" in combating money laundering during its transition to a market economy.

Aside from Russia, the only European country named by the FATF is Leichtenstein. In the middle East, it named Lebanon as well as Israel.

The Cayman islands, the only British territory on the blacklist, reacted with disappointment to FATF's decision, which came after a decision earlier this week by the OECD to take it off a separate list of tax havens. Although FATF stopped short of advocating an outright ban on dealing with banks from the blacklisted countries, it called on financial institutions to pay special attention to such deals.

Gil Galvao, president of the FATF, said the group would hold talks with those countries on the list to help them improve legislation and monitoring aimed at reducing money laundering, but the report says that if they remain uncooperative it will consider counter-measures.

Some 16 countries, including Guernsey and Jersey were taken off the list after cooperating with FATF during its investigation. Around $600bn ($400bn) from drug cartels, mafia barons and other criminal or shady sources is believed to be recycled through banks and other investment institutions each year.

The simple guide to setting up your own bank

1 You need a fax machine, a phone, a laptop computer and an internet account, plus at least $200,000 in the bank. Start by searching the internet for one of the companies which purchase bank charters from the Nauruan government and sell them on to international customers.

2 Get a letter from the police stating you have no criminal record and a letter from your bank endorsing you as a good customer. The letter should be addressed to the Minister for Island Development and Industry, Republic of Nauru. You will also need financial statements showing that you have a net worth of at least $200,000 (£136,000).

3 Write out a cheque for $35,000 - the price for the company to register the bank. You can also pay them an annual fee to manage your records, but as the bank won't have any physical presence in Nauru, apart from a post office box, administering it will scarcely be onerous.

4 After a background check to confirm your acceptability to the licensing authorities in Nauru, the licence is granted, resident agent's agreements negotiated and all banking forms and documents are printed. Within four to six weeks, your bank will be up and running and you can start setting up accounts for it in London or the capital of your choosing. You never actually have to visit Nauru to make deposits or withdrawals - the bank exists only on your computer.

webTitle: Ford unions call strike vote at Dagenham

fields.headline: Ford unions call strike vote at Dagenham
fields.trailText: Union leaders yesterday called for a strike ballot at Ford's Dagenham plant after the company rejected pleas to rescind its plans to end car assembly with the loss of 1,900 jobs. The call came after Ford executives rejected the union's alternative to ending Fiesta production in early 2002 - assembling Volvo and Mazda models at the plant. But unions cancelled plans for a ballot of Ford's entire UK workforce.
fields.body:
Union leaders yesterday called for a strike ballot at Ford's Dagenham plant after the company rejected pleas to rescind its plans to end car assembly with the loss of 1,900 jobs. The call came after Ford executives rejected the union's alternative to ending Fiesta production in early 2002 - assembling Volvo and Mazda models at the plant. But unions cancelled plans for a ballot of Ford's entire UK workforce.

The vote will now be limited to 4,500 working in Dagenham's body, paint and assembly areas. It will take place after next month's annual shutdown and departure of 1,500 employees who have already taken voluntary redundancy.

Although car assembly at Dagenham will end after some 80 years, Ford will invest £400m and create 500 jobs at the site, turning Dagenham into its key European centre for diesel engine production.

Workers in the engine plant will not take part in the vote, but even so, the strike ballot represents the biggest test of Ford's resolve to staunch its losses - £119m in Britain last year - and take out chronic over-capacity in Europe.

Tony Woodley of the TGWU said after the talks: "We are extremely disappointed that Ford is not prepared to honour agreements and treat Britain and British workers as fairly and even-handedly as other Ford workers in Europe.''

The unions claim that Ford's decision to end assembly at Dagenham threatens a further 13,220 jobs in Britain's components industry, already reeling from other manufacturers' decisions to source overseas to offset sterling's strength.

Duncan Simpson of the AEEU said: "We want to sit down and discuss other options, including building Volvos and Mazdas. We are not prepared to throw in the towel.''

Talks are scheduled to resume with Jac Nasser, the Ford president, and Nick Scheele, Ford of Europe chairman, on July 19 but Ford says it is not prepared to consider alternative plans.

webTitle: Mugabe era is over, says opposition

fields.headline: Mugabe era is over, says opposition
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabwe democracy movement predicts election triumph, but broad-based coalition may soon suffer splits

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Robert Mugabe will be out of power within a month and Zimbabwe will have Morgan Tsvangirai, the leader of the Movement for Democratic Change, as its new president, according to Eddie Cross, the prospective finance minister in the new government.
fields.byline: Jonathan Steele and Andrew Meldrum in Harare
fields.body:
Robert Mugabe will be out of power within a month and Zimbabwe will have Morgan Tsvangirai, the leader of the Movement for Democratic Change, as its new president, according to Eddie Cross, the prospective finance minister in the new government.

With voters going to the polls tomorrow and Sunday in the most hotly contested parliamentary election since independence, senior MDC leaders have started making the most optimistic predictions.

"We expect to get over 76 seats which will be a majority in the 150-seat parliament. We will demand Mugabe's resignation and are confident the army will support us," Mr Cross, a leading industrialist, told the Guardian yesterday.

The economy was in "meltdown", he claimed, and in desperation the government had printed Z$30bn (£500m) worth of banknotes since January. Once Mr Mugabe stepped aside, there would need be no more than a week for nominations followed by a three-week election campaign and a new president would be in power before August.

One of the new government's first acts to revive the economy would be to devalue the Zimbabwe dollar by about 40%, in line with demands from commercial farmers.

He predicted that South Africa would play a pivotal role in removing Mr Mugabe. Zimbabwe relies heavily on South African electricity and has racked up an unpaid energy bill of millions of pounds.

Mr Cross acknowledged that Mr Mugabe, whose term runs until 2002, had the right under the constitution to appoint a minority government and rule by decree if he lost control of parliament. "But it would be tantamount to a coup and I don't think South Africa will accept it. They can cut his electricity and oil at any time."

Mr Mugabe has the right to appoint 30 members to the parliament, and only 120 constituencies are being contested this weekend. If the MDC were to win more than 60 seats but less than 76, "Mugabe might try to hang on to power, but we would block his budget," Mr Cross warned.

Mr Tsvangirai was less ebullient about the imminence of Mr Mugabe's departure, but he was confident the MDC ought to win more than half the contested seats. "Any result that does not give the MDC a majority will have been seriously rigged," Mr Tsvangirai said.

The candidates' agents as well as independent monitors from local civic groups will be able to stay with the ballot boxes at night on the two polling days to ensure there is no tampering, the government-appointed chairman of the election directorate, Dr Mariyawanda Nzuwa, said yesterday. However, the MDC has expressed concern about the security of the boxes when they are later taken to the counting centre. The Legal Resources Foundation yesterday made an urgent application to the supreme court to overturn a ruling that election monitors cannot accompany the boxes.

fields.headline: Dateline group clinches £50m titles sale
fields.trailText: Columbus Group, the publisher and Dateline lonely hearts group, is expected finally to complete the sale of its magazines division to Highbury House today for £50m in shares. Dateline will be floated as a separate entity.
fields.body:
Columbus Group, the publisher and Dateline lonely hearts group, is expected finally to complete the sale of its magazines division to Highbury House today for £50m in shares. Dateline will be floated as a separate entity.

It is also likely to announce the resignation of deputy chairman Nigel Wray, who has been embroiled in a shares sale controversy.

The deal has been delayed by a DTI inquiry into competitions run by one of its subsidiaries. Mr Wray has been at the centre of the controversy after it emerged that he sold half his 5% stake in Columbus around the time the DTI contacted the company and shortly before it issued a profits warning. He has strenuously denied knowing anything about the DTI's inquiry or the profit warning when he sold the shares.

The competitions inquiry related to complaints from customers who said they had not received prizes or refunds.

Last week Columbus said the issue had been resolved and that it had heard nothing from the DTI since last October.

Columbus publishes a range of finance and home entertainment magazines. Internet entrepreneur Chris Matthews is likely to sell his dating service Club Sirius to Dateline and run the combined group.

Highbury House's previous largest acquisition was a £39.3m deal to buy Nexus Media in February.

webTitle: Historic movement has deep contradictions lurking within

fields.headline: Historic movement has deep contradictions lurking within
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Whoever wins Zimbabwe's election this weekend, the Movement for Democratic Change has already made history with its challenge to President Robert Mugabe and his Zanu-PF party.  It has formed a more broad-based coalition than anything previously seen in southern Africa, dwarfing even Nelson Mandela's achievement in bringing unlikely partners into the same fold.
fields.body:
Whoever wins Zimbabwe's election this weekend, the Movement for Democratic Change has already made history with its challenge to President Robert Mugabe and his Zanu-PF party. It has formed a more broad-based coalition than anything previously seen in southern Africa, dwarfing even Nelson Mandela's achievement in bringing unlikely partners into the same fold.

Among whites, it includes men who fought with Rhodesia's special forces against the black liberation armies, as well as white civil rights activists and liberal church groups such as the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace which were persecuted by Ian Smith, the last white prime minister of Rhodesia.

On the African side, among the Shona, Zimbabwe's largest tribe, the MDC boasts middle-aged supporters who were once firmly in Mr Mugabe's camp, such as its president, Morgan Tsvangirai, who was a political commissar for Zanu-PF, and others who backed the African parties which collaborated with Mr Smith. But it also has a huge following from the "born free generation", young people who post-date the liberation struggle and want jobs rather than land.

While Mr Mugabe only managed to win support from the minority Ndebele by forcing their political party to submerge itself in Zanu-PF in 1987 after years of harassment and violence, the MDC has straddled the ethnic divide from the start. Its T-shirts carry a slogan in both the Shona and Ndebele languages, its leadership is mixed, and crowds at rallies chant in both languages. Although this rainbow of ethnic identities and political histories is breathtaking enough, the MDC's economic profile is even more striking.

A political party which arose out of a trade union movement with a proud if short history of surprisingly successful strikes in opposition to the open market policies of the International Monetary Fund is challenging for power on the basis of a conservative economic agenda which has the IMF's whole-hearted approval.

Cynics might say the MDC has repeated the British Labour party's 100-year trajectory in barely 100 days, but the astonishing growth in its numbers, along with the shift in its dominant ideology, make Tony Blair's concept of a big tent look like a wigwam. The MDC's candidate in Highfield, Harare's main African township, is Munheredzo Gwisai, a Trotskyist law lecturer; its shadow finance minister is Eddie Cross, a leading businessman and former chairman of the industrial employers' association.

Somewhere in between, though nowadays closer to the right than the left, is Mr Tsvangirai, its president. A former miners' union official who was the secretary general of the Zimbabwe Congress of Trade Unions for more than ten years, he calls the MDC's manifesto social democratic, and says: "I still hate the World Bank and the IMF, but you don't have to love your doctor."

One clue to the change is that the MDC is a fusion of two currents. The trade unions were the first groups to challenge Mr Mugabe in the late 1980s, initially on industrial issues. Later, in an alliance with students and civic groups, they fought Zanu-PF's plans to create a one-party state

When Mr Mugabe gave in to IMF pressure for an economic structural adjustment programme (Esap) in 1991, the unions led the resistance, with Mr Tsvangirai at the forefront. "Esap cut spending on social services, reduced wages of government employees from teachers to nurses and caused deindustrialisation, with jobs lost to imports when tariffs were reduced", said Brian Raftopoulos of the Institute of Development Studies.

As the Esap programme started to bite, along with a foreign currency crisis exacerbated by several seasons of drought, "more people became alienated not just by Esap but by corruption in Zanu-PF and the lack of open governance. Along with the economic critique came a constitutional one", he said.

When the new breed of civic groups and non-governmental organisations decided to form a national constitutional assembly (NCA) in 1998 to press for public accountability, open democracy, and a new constitution to replace the one inherited from Britain, Mr Tsvangirai left his trade union work and became its chairman. "By then," according to Munheredzo Gwisai, "he had become detached from the union rank and file.

The NCA was mainly a young black middle-class professional outfit." Last September the assembly's activists founded the MDC. When Mr Mugabe co-opted the idea for a new constitution and produced his own draft version and the promise of a referendum, the MDC had no hesitation in rejecting it. The February referendum campaign gave the new party a nationwide focus for mobilisation. When the MDC won, Zimbabwe found itself for the first time with a serious national alternative to Zanu-PF.

The MDC is not a western conservative party. In African conditions and in a country where around 62% of the population lives below the poverty line it could not be. Its programme contains scores of detailed schemes for poverty reduction, low-cost housing, a return to free health services and job creation. But it contains contradictions as deep as the extraordinary profile of its support base is wide, and they are more likely to tilt the party to the right.

"The MDC manifesto attempts to meet the needs of a market economy with a welfare programme based on the MDC's specific constituencies," said Mr Raftopoulos. "But I see a disturbing drift towards an uncritical approach to capital."

The February referendum campaign gave the new party a nationwide focus for mobilisation. When the MDC won, Zimbabwe found itself for the first time with a serious national alternative to Zanu-PF. The MDC is not a western conservative party. In African conditions and in a country where around 62% of the population lives below the poverty line it could not be. Its programme contains scores of detailed schemes for poverty reduction, low-cost housing, a return to free health services and job creation. But it contains contradictions as deep as the extraordinary profile of its support base is wide, and they are more likely to tilt the party to the right. "The MDC manifesto attempts to meet the needs of a market economy with a welfare programme based on the MDC's specific constituencies," said Mr Raftopoulos. "But I see a disturbing drift towards an uncritical approach to capital."

webTitle: Church attacks new French anti-cult law

fields.headline: Church attacks new French anti-cult law
fields.trailText: The French parliament yesterday adopted Europe's toughest anti-sect legislation yet, creating a controversial new crime of "mental manipulation" punishable by a maximum fine of £50,000 and five years imprisonment.
fields.body:
The French parliament yesterday adopted Europe's toughest anti-sect legislation yet, creating a controversial new crime of "mental manipulation" punishable by a maximum fine of £50,000 and five years imprisonment.

The move was applauded by Alain Vivien, head of a government committee that has identified 173 dangerous quasi-religious groups in France, but was denounced by both the Church of Scientology and the Unification Church as fascist, anti-democratic and in breach of basic human rights laws.

Current French law, described as "inadequate to deal with increasingly sophisticated and manipulative groups" by Catherine Picard, one of the MPs who proposed the bill, allows sect activities to be caught by prosecutions for traditional crimes such as incitement to murder, sexual assault, fraud and the abuse of a vulnerable individuals.

The new law allows judges to order the dissolution of any sect whose members are convicted of a criminal offence. It also bans sects from advertising, and prohibits them from opening missions or touting for new members near schools, hospitals or retirement homes.

But the law's key weapon is the new crime of mental manipulation, defined as "exercising, within a group whose activities are aimed at creating or exploiting psychological dependence, heavy and repeated pressure on a person, or using techniques likely to alter his judgment, so as to induce him to behave in a way prejudicial to his interests".

A justice ministry spokeswoman said the legal definition had been prepared carefully to ensure that it could not be applied to legitimate churches. But some Catholic leaders have expressed reservations about the law, saying that may lead to "over-zealousness and judicial excess", as well as discrimination against genuine religions.

"This is a steep and slippery slope for democracy," said Danièle Gounord, a spokeswoman for the Scientologists, which is not recognised as a religion in France. "In western Europe, the only regime so far to pass a law on mental manipulation was the fascist government of Mussolini, in an attempt to get rid of the communists."

fields.headline: Tyson parries press over 'bust-up'
fields.standfirst: Boxing: special report
fields.trailText: Mike Tyson loves Frank Warren but sometimes he does not like himself very much. And he enjoys hurting people. Really likes it a lot. But no, sir, he did not try to throw Frank Warren out of a window. Why not? Because there's a long line ahead of him.
fields.body:
Mike Tyson loves Frank Warren but sometimes he does not like himself very much. And he enjoys hurting people. Really likes it a lot. But no, sir, he did not try to throw Frank Warren out of a window. Why not? Because there's a long line ahead of him.

Two days before he enters the ring at Hampden Park, Mike Tyson spent yesterday parrying questions on his behaviour outside of it.

At an often farcical press conference in his Glasgow hotel, the heavyweight boxer was pressed on newspaper allegations that he had assaulted Mr Warren, the fight promoter, over an unpaid jewellery bill.

It emerged yesterday that lawyers for the jewellers, Graff Diamonds, had started high court proceedings over the bill for $630,000 (£429,000). Graff says Tyson has had the jewellery since January, when he bought it on his last visit to Britain, but it has not received a penny. A statement from Anthony Kerman, of Kerman & Co solicitors, said: "Tyson is saying Warren promised to pay for the jewellery, while Warren is denying this and saying Tyson is liable." A number of newspaper reports, meanwhile, have alleged that Tyson attacked Mr Warren in London after learning of the court action.

Asked yesterday if he had assaulted Mr Warren, Tyson replied: "I love Frank Warren."

"So you didn't try to throw him out of a window?" asked a journalist. "No, sir," said Tyson.

"Why not?"asked another reporter, to gales of laughter.

"Because there's a long line ahead of him," said Tyson.

Mr Warren was not present at yesterday's media event. His spokesman, Bernie Dillon, said his company, Sports Network, was preparing writs against a number of publications for "false and libellous" statements.

"Mr Warren is at home right now, dealing with several legal matters," he said. "We delayed the press conference so he might attend but he missed the flight."

Earlier, a broadcast journalist said he was forcibly removed from the press conference after asking for Tyson's reaction to the outrage among Scottish politicians and women's organisations at his arrival in the country. "I love them all, and so does God," said Tyson. The question was almost drowned out by abuse from boxing supporters in the room.

Appearing often distracted, Tyson picked at a logo on his baseball cap and made what appeared to be an obscene gesture when his opponent on Saturday, Lou Savarese, greeted members of the US press corps.

Asked how he felt about the public's opinion of him, Tyson replied: "I never cared about the public. I enjoy doing what I do. I enjoy hurting people. I really like it a lot." It did not matter that he was not more popular. "I sometimes don't like myself, so I can understand them not liking me."

Tyson was happy with his reception in Scotland. "It does not matter if I don't understand the dialect. I understand their heart and their heart is for me." Earlier, he had emerged from a nearby gym, donned a kilt and danced on his Mercedes car. Glasgow, however, has appeared to be underwhelmed by the Tyson bandwagon. Since his arrival in the city on Wednesday night only a few fans have turned up at the Hilton hotel to see him.

"I have been surprised there's not more people here," said Andrew Diamond, 16, from Finnieston, who had been waiting four hours for a glimpse of the boxer. "I thought there would have been crowds here, like there was in London."

Another onlooker, Billy McGregor, 38, a taxi driver, was greeted by Tyson as he left the hotel. "He's a lot smaller than I thought he would be," Mr McGregor said.

Women's groups confirmed yesterday they will stage a protest at the fight. Sandy Brindley, of the Glasgow rape crisis centre, which was unsuccessful in a legal attempt to have Tyson blocked from entering Britain, said: "We had decided not to do anything but we were contacted by so many people wanting to show their concern that we are going ahead."

The centre has been inundated with offers of financial and other support after it emerged that Mr Warren planned to try to recoup the costs of the court case initiated by the centre. The question of costs will be decided at a court hearing next month.

webTitle: Japan's PM linked with crime boss

fields.headline: Japan's PM linked with crime boss
fields.trailText: The Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, was accused of being "married to the mob" yesterday as the political temperature picked up ahead of Sunday's general election.
fields.body:
The Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, was accused of being "married to the mob" yesterday as the political temperature picked up ahead of Sunday's general election.

Mr Mori, whose verbal gaffes have made him one of the most unpopular prime ministers in the country's history, suffered the latest blow to his image when he admitted attending a wedding reception for the son of a former gangland boss.

The scandal came only a day after Mr Mori provoked derision by suggesting that those who had not made up their mind on how to vote by Sunday morning should stay in bed all day.

It provided fresh fuel to the opposition, which is trailing a long way behind the ruling Liberal Democratic party and its coalition allies in pre-election polls.

The mob allegations were made in the Shukan Bunshun weekly magazine, which said Mr Mori had taken a prominent role as a nakodo" (intermediary between the bride and groom) at the ceremony in 1996.

An unnamed guest told the magazine that Mr Mori had given a speech in which he boasted of "personal ties with the father of the groom", a 59-year-old property developer who once led a crime syndicate in Fukuoka in southern Japan.

The prime minister acknowledged being present at the event, but he said he was unaware of the background of the former gangster and had no connections with him.

"The fact that the report came out during an election campaign suggests certain motives," Mr Mori said in a counterattack against the magazine.

This is not the first time that Mr Mori has been linked to the yakuza.. Last month, Shukan Bunshun revealed that he had given a speech at a wedding in 1995 that was attended by Yuko Inagawa, head of one of Japan's biggest crime syndicates. Mr Mori said he had not checked the guest-list in advance.

According to the Asahi newspaper, Mr Mori also received a donation of more than 1m yen (£6,000) from a construction firm with close ties to the mob.

Accusations of gangster connections are nothing new for the conservative LDP. Former prime ministers have used the yakuza to intimidate opponents and four years ago there was an outcry when the LDP used public funds to bail out mortgage firms, many of which were run by crime syndicates.

Mr Mori's ratings have been under 20% since he described Japan as a "divine nation with the emperor at its core" - a phrase reminiscent of the country's pre-war militarism.

The impact of the scandal on the election in uncertain.

The LDP - which has deliberately avoided showing its unpopular leader on TV campaign commercials - holds a strong lead and is expected to extend its almost unbroken 45-year grip on power.

The only likelihood of an upset is if the huge number of undecided voters - about half of the electorate - use the ballot to express their disapproval of the prime minister.

fields.headline: Hague hasn't a prayer
fields.standfirst:
Politicians' attempts to corral the religious are ridiculous: state and church belong well apart


Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Politicians at prayer make an unedifying spectacle. This week the Tories have been staking their claim to be the only way, truth and light for the pious. William Hague yesterday met Professor Marvin Olasky, George W Bush's curious spiritual guru who advocates that churches, not the state, should provide welfare.
fields.body:
Politicians at prayer make an unedifying spectacle. This week the Tories have been staking their claim to be the only way, truth and light for the pious. William Hague yesterday met Professor Marvin Olasky, George W Bush's curious spiritual guru who advocates that churches, not the state, should provide welfare. Olasky is an old time, American, rightwing, bible-belt fruitcake, who thinks women unsuited to office, called Jews members of the Church of Zeus, is anti-abortion and blames the personalities of the poor for their plight. Treasury minister and churchgoer Stephen Timms spoke at the same "Religion and Welfare" conference as Olasky yesterday, attempting to neutralise the message and claim back religion for the left.

Politicians only have to see a defined group to feel impelled to try to annex it for their own political purposes. Tony Blair tried it on with the WI but they wouldn't be corralled. Now Hague is trying to lasso the religious - and risks getting the same response from most of them. In an article in the Times this week, he praised Olasky and his works, oozed with unction about "values" and "a still, small voice that speaks quietly" against bad things. He deplored the "disregard for the faith dimension in national life and failure to promote the family". It was a carefully crafted appeal. Just as he annexes anti-asylum seeker sentiment by raising the question without quite saying anything blatantly racist, so he tries the same trick with the religious. He doesn't, of course, say that he will be abandoning the welfare state to rely instead on religious charities: as a former social security minister he knows quite well it's all rubbish. (Under Mrs Thatcher, despite her exhortation to charities to take the welfare burden from the state, donations to charity fell sharply in her selfish there-is-no-such-thing-as-society years.) But he says just enough to try to plant his flag among what he thinks is the core religious vote. All this is preposterous stuff. Yet again the Tories make the serious mistake of looking to America for ideology and especially welfare ideas, where there are none to be had of relevance to our European traditions. Michael Portillo also made a speech this week extolling the American social way versus the European social model, laying out that choice. How these younger Tories yearn to be republicans, apeing and mouthing the delicious ideas of the US far right, but how badly they miss the British mood when they try it on. When it comes to religion, the two countries could hardly have more divergent cultures. The majority of Americans call themselves born-again Christians, obliging politicians to parade a lachrymose piety whether they believe it or not. US religion is a rainbow display of mania and weirdness that engulfs that semi-rational society: a majority say they have a personal guardian angel.

How unlike us, one of the least religious nations in the world. However William Hague may imagine there is a similar breed here after addressing a festival of 50,000 British evangelicals recently, many of them reactionary, creationist enthusiasts who do draw inspiration from American primitivism. At the same time he hinted about his "concern" over abortion in a Roman Catholic journal - just enough to position himself as more anti-abortion than Labour. Is there any cause he will not stoop to?

Hague strategists talk of diverting the election away from the economy towards "values": religion looks a short-cut brand. But do they have any idea what kind of religious beast they are chasing? First of all it's a rare breed. Church attendance is only 7.5% of the population, fallen 22% over the last decade. Like most nominal Christians, only a minority of Muslims are practicing. The unconvincing sight of politicians on their knees, or worse in the pulpit, may alienate many more voters than it pleases. Alongside Blair and Straw a surprising number of Labour ministers are churchgoers, but they don't flaunt it, either out of decorum or because they know it doesn't sell. As Hague pitched for the religious vote this week, how wrong he got it.

Times have changed profoundly. The Church of England is no longer the Conservative party at prayer, quite the contrary. William Hague should have examined the latest Mori figures. This is what they show: only 26% of the C of E members vote Tory, while 48% are Labour. The Catholics are even more leftwing: only 17% vote Tory while 48% vote Labour. Of the Muslims, 22% are Conservative, and 33% Labour. Reactionary religious leaders do not represent their flocks. Unlike in the US, most British practising Christians are the gentle, left-leaning souls who created the highly successful Jubilee 2000 third world debt campaign. They damned Thatcher on poverty with their devastating "Faith in the City" report and denied her a triumphalist service for the Falklands war. William Hague is wildly wrong to think he can suborn Christians who run welfare programmes, drug projects or homeless schemes. Those working with the poorest are least likely to embrace some hare-brained Tory wheeze to shift the welfare state on to charity. These believers might also give Labour a blasting for not doing enough to help the poor (but none the less vote for them). They rightly see their role as standing apart from politics, not as an arm of it. Stephen Timms was right when he pointed to the chapel past of the labour movement and its methodist roots.

But any party staking a claim to religion risks ridicule. Politicians may foolishly hope some spiritual gloss rubs off on them - but religion often bites back. Tories can expect sharp retorts from socially concerned Christians - but Labour should keep well away too. Think of Cardinal Winning's assaults on Blair, or the homophobic bishops in the Synod. Consider Rabbi Jonathan Sacks's awful reactionary homilies. What of the preachings of the more virulent mullahs? Getting too close to any of these, the risks outweigh the electoral rewards. Out there in the real world there are many more women who care about abortion, divorce and contraception, more gays outraged by the primitive words of Leviticus, more non-believers and free-thinkers than there will ever again be religious followers.

Labour's courtship of religion suggests that its own values, ideals and principles are somehow too weak or ill-defined to stand alone. Are they so short of secular morality that they need hired help? Now they talk of bringing in yet more religions to join the 25 bishops already crowding the Lords benches. They talk of handing over many more schools to religions to run, when already a third of all state schools are religious - wildly out of kilter with this unbelieving nation. (Popular for back-door selection and better resources, not for God.) Keep church and state apart: parties flirting with faiths look weak on their own morality while religions quickly turn sinister when they gain secular political power.

webTitle: Beijing warns Albright against 'son of star wars'

fields.headline: Beijing warns Albright against 'son of star wars'
fields.trailText: The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, faced tough talking yesterday in Beijing as Chinese experts warned that American plans for a national missile defence shield would compromise their security. China welcomed her with the sharp message that it would be forced to increase its nuclear arsenal if the US went ahead with its plan.
fields.body:
The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, faced tough talking yesterday in Beijing as Chinese experts warned that American plans for a national missile defence shield would compromise their security. China welcomed her with the sharp message that it would be forced to increase its nuclear arsenal if the US went ahead with its plan.

Ms Albright pressed her hosts to respond favourably to peace overtures by Taiwan's new president, Chen Shui-bian, and she raised US concerns about human rights abuses in China. Beijing's foreign minister, Tang Jiaxuan, retorted that the US should stop selling arms to Taiwan, exclude it from any defence arrangement and avoid encouraging pro-independence tendencies there.

As the most senior US official to visit Beijing since last year's US bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade, Ms Albright also hoped to give a boost to relations between China and the US. Mr Tang said cautiously that "bilateral relations have shown a certain improvement, especially after the setback last year."

The Chinese argument against Washington's national missile defence programme (NMD) has been strengthened by the success of last week's summit between the leaders of North and South Korea. This has been widely interpreted as reducing the threat of a "rogue" North Korean missile, which the US uses to justify its "son of star wars" project.

Beijing strategists have already argued that the US project will "compromise China's strategic capability".

A report to be issued by the Oxford Research Group, based on a recent conference with Chinese military experts in Beijing, warns that Chinese opposition to the NMD should not be under-estimated.

In a paper written for the conference, Major-General Pan Zhengqiang said that the missile programme would force China and Russia "to take measures to uphold the credibility of their respective strategic deterrents". It would poison relations between the three major nuclear powers and prompt "a new round of the arms race".

Chinese senior officials believe that since Beijing has helped to bring about détente on the Korean peninsula, the US should think again about the effects of the programme on its relations with China.

The image of North Korea as a "rogue state" which might launch a suicidal nuclear attack on the US has been frequently invoked by Washington. The term was used only last week by the defence secretary, William Cohen, on Russian television. But in a sign of embarrassment this week, the US state department announced that it will instead refer in the future to North Korea and other former "rogues", including Iran and Iraq, as "states of concern". China's foreign ministry spokesman, Zhu Bangzao, said last night that Beijing's opposition to NMD was "consistent and clear". It was equally opposed to the theatre missile defence package being considered by Japan, in which Taiwan has expressed an interest.

"China has consistently held that the US pretext for developing [these] systems does not have a leg to stand on," he said.

Another Chinese strategist quoted in the Oxford Research Group report, Dr Yan Xuetong, said the NMD would "invigorate the US-Japan alliance and make Japan more likely to become involved in potential military conflicts in the Taiwan Straits."

webTitle: We don't need immigrants to pay for our pensions

fields.headline: We don't need immigrants to pay for our pensions
fields.standfirst:
The crisis of the elderly is a myth made up by insurance companies

Refugees in Britain: special report
Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: It is typical of the confused debate over immigration, and the connected and equally muddled debate over the ageing crisis, that the Dover tragedy is being used by some to demand a tightening of immigration controls and by others to advocate their loosening.
fields.body:
It is typical of the confused debate over immigration, and the connected and equally muddled debate over the ageing crisis, that the Dover tragedy is being used by some to demand a tightening of immigration controls and by others to advocate their loosening. There is much obfuscation over these demographic issues, which seem in part to be matters of technical calculation, but which in fact raise the deepest questions about the nature of our societies, about who we think people are, and about how to set the balance between the collective and the private.

The confusion is made worse by the fact that, according to the level at which the debate is pitched, the political right and the political left shift their positions. The linking of the arguments over the "growing burden" of the aged and those over immigration leads many to the conclusion that immigration is desirable because it will redress the discrepancy between a large older generation that has to be cared for and a shrunken younger generation that will have to do the caring. Those on the right endorse the first half of the argument but not the second, at least for public consumption. Those on the left, by contrast, ought to repudiate the overdone panic over an ageing population, driven as it is by privatisers and anti-welfare interests, but do not often do so. But the left - at least when it is out of office - does go on to endorse the desirability of immigration on such grounds because that fits with a tradition that puts value on freedom of movement and embraces multi-culturalism.

Much evidence suggests that the two linked propositions - that industrialised societies face a crisis of ageing, and that a large flow of youthful immigrants would help us cope with that crisis, and would also be beneficial in other ways - are far from proven. "What kinds of national interests are being served by large-scale immigration ?" two academics concerned with social policy asked in a recent Washington Post article. In an America which has taken in huge numbers over the past two decades that is surely a legitimate question. The article notes the extraordinary re-migration from congested California - more have left that state since 1990 than the entire population of Wyoming - as an example of the kind of pressure on resources and space that ought to be taken into account, but often is not, when setting national immigration policies. In Australia, scholars such as Tim Flannery, impeccably liberal on racial and cultural questions, nevertheless feel that substantial immigration ought to end, because numbers are already near the limits which an ecologically constricted country can sustain.

In Paris this week a conference set up by an American thinktank will discuss the crisis of the elderly on the basis of a report suggesting that it is even more "severe" than previously thought, and that immigration is high among the solutions to be contemplated. Such arguments rest on flimsy foundations. Old age is a concept, not a scientific category. The conventions of what it is and when it begins change all the time. A simple redefinition of old age, putting its onset further on in life, would dissolve the statistics of the ageing crisis instantly. It might also make clear that the real problem is not old age but a labour market dominated by employers who want younger and more easily manipulated workers, unhindered by the baggage of family, occasional illness, and frequent obstinacy which older men and women inevitably carry with them. The difficulties older people face do not begin with retirement age but at some point much earlier in their lives when they become less desirable to employers. Similarly, the business of providing them with support is not confined to pensions, but begins when they start to falter in the labour market.

As Phil Mullan points out in his illuminating recent book, the crisis of the elderly was defined largely by people pursuing an anti-welfare programme. It was elaborated "within the context of the ideological and financial case for cutting back the welfare state." The crisis became a pretext for advocating cuts in public spending of every kind - on the old themselves, because they are costing too much, and on other welfare costs, since the old are supposedly soaking up too much of available resources.

If you check the sponsors of any meeting on the pensions crisis, you are likely to find the names of insurance companies and private health providers - precisely the organisations likely to benefit from a narrowing of state provision. Such a narrowing opens up what some see as the best kind of market, the kind which is driven by the anxieties of individuals stripped of the protections they used to enjoy. Mullan suggests that the worst aspect of this approach is the way it stokes inter- generational conflict, dividing us into a tribe of the young and a tribe of the old - to which one might add a third "tribe" of immigrants. Difficulties which arise from the overall direction of society as set by powerful actors, especially business, can then be dumped on a single social group.

It is important to underline that the same movement in the labour market which makes even the best employers favour a younger and less secure domestic workforce also operates to create a demand for immigrant labour, including that of illegal immigrants. At least some low-grade work, of the kind that locals are supposed to refuse to do and migrants be happy to perform, used to be done in the course of training, as part of the drudgery necessary before rising to a more comfortable level. But, with the decline in training and the reduction of intermediate management levels, drudgery is now a niche in the labour market rather than a phase in working life.

There is thus a strong case for saying that the debate over ageing and immigration as conducted at present is something of a fraud, distracting from what should really be at the centre of attention, which is the way the economic organisation of society is more and more out of kilter with its supposed principles. This is not to say that there are no genuine problems arising from demographic change, but the exaggeration of those problems by those with a vendetta against the welfare state has been harmful. Nor is it to say that the industrialised countries should necessarily set their face against further substantial immigration. But it is to argue that the economic case for such immigration is thin and that there are significant ecological and other arguments - varying according to the country or continent concerned - against it. Leaving aside the distinct question of asylum, it might well be decided that in the interests of openness and diversity and stimulus, such immigration is nevertheless worthwhile. But that decision ought to be taken on its merits and not on the basis of a spurious picture of our societies and their needs.

Phil Mullan's The Imaginary Time Bomb is published by I B Tauris

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: •Last week the Diary carried a letter of olde worlde charm from Lord Kimball, Tory peer and fox killer, to Baroness Jay, deploring a fall-off in good manners among civil servants - especially in writing thank-you letters after official lunches. Shocking stuff. Instead of binning it (not very polite, admittedly) the leader of the Lords passed it to her private secretary. "Baroness Jay has asked me to contact all private secretaries," writes Russell   Hamblin-Boone, "reminding us all of the need to be courteous at all times." Reading not very far between the lines, one can sense H-B struggling to keep a straight face: "Baroness Jay simply wants to be able to tell Lord Kimball that we all endeavour to be polite," he writes. "I hope you will accept this reminder in that spirit." In other words: Kimball's a nutter and we're just indulging him, so you can safely ignore this.
fields.body:
Last week the Diary carried a letter of olde worlde charm from Lord Kimball, Tory peer and fox killer, to Baroness Jay, deploring a fall-off in good manners among civil servants - especially in writing thank-you letters after official lunches. Shocking stuff. Instead of binning it (not very polite, admittedly) the leader of the Lords passed it to her private secretary. "Baroness Jay has asked me to contact all private secretaries," writes Russell Hamblin-Boone, "reminding us all of the need to be courteous at all times." Reading not very far between the lines, one can sense H-B struggling to keep a straight face: "Baroness Jay simply wants to be able to tell Lord Kimball that we all endeavour to be polite," he writes. "I hope you will accept this reminder in that spirit." In other words: Kimball's a nutter and we're just indulging him, so you can safely ignore this.

But his lordship can rest assured there is a surfeit of good manners in the House of Commons. Earlier this month the Diary reported that my colleague Lucy Ward was stopped from having a quick sit-down on a bench in the members' lobby of the Commons by an officious guard, oblivious to Lucy being seven months pregnant. (What if I fainted? asked Lucy. I'd have you carried out, replied the doorkeeper.) And lo, a week later, a lovely letter of apology arrives from the Serjeant at Arms that would even meet the high standards of Lord Kimball. "Please be assured I take a very serious view of your complaint," wrote the Serjeant. And yes - they will now let pregnant women have a seat if needed.

And now a concerned message to Michael Pilgrim, executive editor of the Sunday Express newspaper. I'm sorry to report that some prat has stolen company letterhead from your office and is using it to send pompous messages in your name. "I write to protest at the Guardian's breaking of the embargo on William photos," reads the one we've received, which goes on to whinge that the Guardian printed a particular pic of Prince William, "thus depriving us and other Sunday papers of our photo" (one can almost hear the sound of a tiny foot being stamped). "I trust a full public apology will be issued immediately." Trust no one, Michael, that's my advice.

It's a long time - not nearly long enough for some, perhaps - since we've heard from our old friend Taki. But rest assured that nothing much has changed, since he still has his special form of literary Tourette syndrome. In his latest Spectator column the ostensible subject is football hooligans, but that of course soon leads on to his all-time favourite subject, "Guardian scum": "Rusbridger, Young and their ilk are as responsible for the subhuman behaviour in Belgium as the beer-bellied pigs." That's quite true, and Hugo and Alan are handing over their passports in an effort to save England's bid for the 2006 World Cup.

Some cracking entries for the Merge Matics competition (where Diary readers combine two famous works into one). But it's hard to see anyone out-doing Right Ho, Lady Chatterley, by DH Lawrence and PG Wodehouse, where Jeeves and Mellors swap employers: "His eyes stared at Aunt Agatha like some wild beast that longed for his prey. 'What does tha want from me woman?' Mellors growled as he prowled around her like the animal he was. 'Well I'd be frightfully grateful if you could just prune back the roses,' replied Agatha. 'That's not what tha needs lass, tha needs a good fuck.' 'I say, steady on old chap,' interjected Bertie from the depths of the shrubbery. 'Oofy Wegg-Prosser is tootling down for tiffin and the roses really do need some attention'." (Thanks to Susan Hornby.)

As if the Chinese weren't enough of a threat across the straits of Formosa: "Taiwan mobilises army to battle banana glut," according to Reuters.

fields.headline: Telly visions
fields.standfirst: Telecommunications and media mergers are moving more swiftly than politics. New broadcasting legislation is needed sooner rather than later
fields.trailText: When the 1996 Broadcasting Act was promulgated there were still eight large cable companies in Britain. Two exist today. The BBC had two free-to-air channels instead of five (although the three extra barely affect viewing habits). There was no Channel 5 (ditto). Digital television was still something for the futurologists - BSkyB is now talking about having 5m digital subscribers by next year. And the internet was then strictly for geeks.
fields.body:
When the 1996 Broadcasting Act was promulgated there were still eight large cable companies in Britain. Two exist today. The BBC had two free-to-air channels instead of five (although the three extra barely affect viewing habits). There was no Channel 5 (ditto). Digital television was still something for the futurologists - BSkyB is now talking about having 5m digital subscribers by next year. And the internet was then strictly for geeks.

The need for new broadcasting legislation has been apparent for some time and in the autumn a communications white paper is due, with a view to new law being passed during the next parliament.

The term of art here is "convergence". This is exemplified by America Online, the internet service provider, buying the venerable media company Time Warner. It is the blurring of distinctions between telecommunications and media industries that makes the need for new regulation all the more pressing. The phenomenon was in evidence again this week when Vivendi, the French telecoms and media company, bought Seagram, which owns the Universal music and film businesses. When content and distribution platforms are owned by the same company, who should be watching over what they do? Tellingly, the white paper is being put together by both the Department of Culture, Media and Sport and the Department of Trade and Industry.

In telecommunications change has been as rapid. When mobile phone operator Orange floated on the London stock market in 1996 the share price fell below the offer and stayed there for some time. Last month France Telecom was prepared to pay £27bn for the still loss-making company because of its potential for internet-related wireless services including video streaming. Most of Europe's markets were not open to competition in 1996 and BT was not facing an onslaught from the likes of France Telecom in its own backyard. Meanwhile, the broadcasting ban on BT's networks will be lifted next year enabling the company to set itself up in competition with BSkyB. BT has already begun video-on-demand trials over its networks with a company called Yes Television.

The range of those with an interest in the white paper is large. They include, as well as BT, the actors' union Equity. The new act will need to consider competition and culture. In a market where there are hundreds of channels to choose from, do we need tight regulation on terrestrial companies' output? Critics of the BBC argue that the corporation is dumbing down to hang on to viewers in the face of competition instead of finding its character more easily defined among the detritus.

The debate still raging about ITV's News at Ten is a prime example of how difficult regulation has become. ITV has argued, perhaps reasonably, that its prime-time schedule was hamstrung by the need for a 10pm news slot. Without it, ITV's prime time share improved after years of decline. Why, in an age where the number of 24-hour news channels is growing and the internet offers information whenever the consumer wants, should there be News at Ten?

At the same time, should the BBC be allowed to use the licence fee to support a 24-hour news channel in a market where there are already commercial operators? BSkyB certainly thinks not after its own Sky News was bumped off a number of cable networks because the BBC offered its channel free.

ITV demands to be allowed to merge into a single company and to end its licence payment to the government, which amounts to some £400m a year. For BSkyB, the grievance is open access to cable platforms just as anyone can transmit over the satellite broadcaster's platform. For Channel 4, the issue is entrenching its public service broadcaster status and warding off privatisation.

The strict rules governing how much market share any single company is allowed to have - in television that is currently 15% of audience and 25% of advertising - will need to be considered. Also up for debate are cross-media ownership rules which prevent the owner of a national newspaper from owning, for example, an ITV licence. What else has kept Rupert Murdoch's hands off terrestrial television? The owner of a local radio station is presently not allowed to own a local newspaper in the same region. But such rules - designed to encourage diversity of voice - are likely to be relaxed. Ministers will need to find a balance between protecting plurality and diversity while at the same time creating world-beating companies. French champion Vivendi is now worth some £62bn compared to Granada Media at £7bn.

Clues to how the new legislation is shaping can be found in last year's paper, Regulating Communications: The Way Ahead, which advocated a lighter regulatory touch based on broad principles. It is a line already being put forward by the Independent Television Commission (ITC) which regulates commercial television, though not alone as the box shows. Its recent statement on regional programming proposed clearing away specific rules on what should be shown and when.

The growing feeling is that a single regulator for broadcasting and telecoms will emerge - a name has even been coined for the new body, Ofcom. The move would be similar to the merger of the electricity and gas watchdogs as the lines blurred between the two industries. It is hardly surprising then that there should be so much sabre rattling going on, particularly from the ITC, to make it clear how invaluable certain parts of the regulatory framework are. The ITC last week appointed Patricia Hodgson from the BBC as its new chief executive, a canny move. Mrs Hodgson negotiated the latest increase in the BBC's licence fee and has strong contacts in government; she is in a powerful position to lobby for the primacy of the ITC in any new system.

The phenomenon was in evidence again this week when Vivendi, the French telecoms and media company, bought Seagram, which owns the Universal music and film businesses. When content and distribution platforms are owned by the same company, who should be watching over what they do? Tellingly, the white paper is being put together by both the Department of Culture, Media and Sport and the Department of Trade and Industry. In telecommunications change has been as rapid. When mobile phone operator Orange floated on the London stock market in 1996 the share price fell below the offer and stayed there for some time. Last month France Telecom was prepared to pay £27bn for the still loss-making company because of its potential for internet-related wireless services including video streaming. Most of Europe's markets were not open to competition in 1996 and BT was not facing an onslaught from the likes of France Telecom in its own backyard. Meanwhile, the broadcasting ban on BT's networks will be lifted next year enabling the company to set itself up in competition with BSkyB. BT has already begun video-on-demand trials over its networks with a company called Yes Television. The range of those with an interest in the white paper is large. They include, as well as BT, the actors' union Equity. The new act will need to consider competition and culture. In a market where there are hundreds of channels to choose from, do we need tight regulation on terrestrial companies' output? Critics of the BBC argue that the corporation is dumbing down to hang on to viewers in the face of competition instead of finding its character more easily defined among the detritus. The debate still raging about ITV's News at Ten is a prime example of how difficult regulation has become. ITV has argued, perhaps reasonably, that its prime-time schedule was hamstrung by the need for a 10pm news slot. Without it, ITV's prime time share improved after years of decline. Why, in an age where the number of 24-hour news channels is growing and the internet offers information whenever the consumer wants, should there be News at Ten? At the same time, should the BBC be allowed to use the licence fee to support a 24-hour news channel in a market where there are already commercial operators? BSkyB certainly thinks not after its own Sky News was bumped off a number of cable networks because the BBC offered its channel free. ITV demands to be allowed to merge into a single company and to end its licence payment to the government, which amounts to some £400m a year. For BSkyB, the grievance is open access to cable platforms just as anyone can transmit over the satellite broadcaster's platform. For Channel 4, the issue is entrenching its public service broadcaster status and warding off privatisation. The strict rules governing how much market share any single company is allowed to have - in television that is currently 15% of audience and 25% of advertising - will need to be considered. Also up for debate are cross-media ownership rules which prevent the owner of a national newspaper from owning, for example, an ITV licence. What else has kept Rupert Murdoch's hands off terrestrial television? The owner of a local radio station is presently not allowed to own a local newspaper in the same region. But such rules - designed to encourage diversity of voice - are likely to be relaxed. Ministers will need to find a balance between protecting plurality and diversity while at the same time creating world-beating companies. French champion Vivendi is now worth some £62bn compared to Granada Media at £7bn. Clues to how the new legislation is shaping can be found in last year's paper, Regulating Communications: The Way Ahead, which advocated a lighter regulatory touch based on broad principles. It is a line already being put forward by the Independent Television Commission (ITC) which regulates commercial television, though not alone as the box shows. Its recent statement on regional programming proposed clearing away specific rules on what should be shown and when. The growing feeling is that a single regulator for broadcasting and telecoms will emerge - a name has even been coined for the new body, Ofcom. The move would be similar to the merger of the electricity and gas watchdogs as the lines blurred between the two industries. It is hardly surprising then that there should be so much sabre rattling going on, particularly from the ITC, to make it clear how invaluable certain parts of the regulatory framework are. The ITC last week appointed Patricia Hodgson from the BBC as its new chief executive, a canny move. Mrs Hodgson negotiated the latest increase in the BBC's licence fee and has strong contacts in government; she is in a powerful position to lobby for the primacy of the ITC in any new system. david.teather@theguardian.com

fields.headline: NHS action plan targets smoking
fields.standfirst:
Making nicotine patches more readily available is one recommendation in effort to improve health levels in the community
Smoking: special report
fields.trailText: The government's NHS review is considering selling cheap nicotine patches through supermarkets and newsagents as part of a drive to prevent avoidable illness in poor areas.
fields.body:
The government's NHS review is considering selling cheap nicotine patches through supermarkets and newsagents as part of a drive to prevent avoidable illness in poor areas.

Among the ideas floated in draft reports from six modernisation action teams set up by Alan Milburn, the health secretary, is a plan to give priority to reclassifying nicotine replacement therapy "as general sales and not just a pharmacy only product".

A team on prevention of illness, chaired by Liam Donaldson, the chief medical officer, said the high prevalence of smoking in working class families was one of the main causes of health inequalities that shortened the lives of the poor. The high price and poor availability of nicotine replacement therapy acted as a barrier to poorer people kicking the habit.

The report recommended that bupropion, an anti-smoking treatment due to be launched commercially next week, should be made available on NHS prescription. And ministers should consider offering free therapy on the NHS to help poor smokers to quit.

The team called for every area to draw up targets for cutting smoking, increasing consumption of fruit and vegetables, encouraging physical activity and reducing obesity.

Parts of the report may be amended before the final draft to ministers next month. There was amusement in Whitehall last night about its proposal for "a national network of health walks", providing GPs with maps where patients might like to take gentle exercise.

But the team is expected to stick to its core recommendations for much more active intervention to reduce health inequality.

The prevention team recommended greater attention by the NHS to the wider interests of the community. Its procurement and employment policies should be made to benefit disadvantaged areas.

NHS staff should help to improve diet and nutrition among pregnant women and children.

It should help set up a network of women able to offer "peer support" to encourage breast feeding. The NHS should support local food co-operatives in disadvantaged areas and organise "fruit and vegetable schemes" to promote healthy eating in schools.

The report warned: "The supply of good quality food and vegetables in many disadvantaged areas is poor, and the price is too high."

Proposals for consideration in the longer term should include a GP contract with better incentives for doctors to work in disadvantaged communities. NHS regional offices could be merged with government offices of the regions to allow promotion of public health to be co-ordinated across all services.

The work of the prevention team was criticised last night by Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the NHS confederation.

"The NHS should focus on what it can do to prevent ill health. For example, we can make sure that people who have a heart attack take aspirin. Yet we know there is a significant minority of GPs who don't prescribe it."

 Recommendations of the other MAT teams included:

Patient Empowerment:

Smart cards allowing patients to access their personal health records were proposed as part of a set of recommendations to make more health information available. The NHS would have a full health care record of every individual, accessible to health professionals in GP surgeries, hospitals, ambulances and other medical facilities.

Patients could either carry this information on their own smart cards or access central records via adapters on phones or TV.

More general information about illness and possible treatments should be provided at touch-screen kiosks in public places. One option would be to adapt national lottery terminals which have spare capacity outside the peak times on Wednesdays and Saturdays.

Other ideas included access to cut-down versions of health websites via Wap phones, interactive digital TV and email question and answer facilities on NHS Direct.

Performance and productivity:

Ministers were advised to impose controls on private practice "to prevent exploitation of the arrangements by a small section of the profession, and to ensure that NHS work comes first". This might include "restricting access to opportunities within the NHS for individuals carrying out unacceptable levels of private practice."

The diagnosis

The problems

 Provision of primary care services outside office hours is limited, patchy and unrelated to patient needs. 20% of people in work put off going to their GP because of inconvenient hours, 29% have to wait 2-3 days for appointment.

 One third of health authorities report serious difficulty in finding dentists.

 Significant pockets of poor primary care infrastructure remain, largely in deprived areas.

 Out of hours access to pharmacies is patchy and information can be hard to find.

 During 1998/99 1.6m patients waited longer than 3 months for a first outpatient appointment while 1.3m waited longer than 3 months for inpatient admission.

 Conditions such as knee and hip replacements, coronary artery bypasses, and cataract extraction have average waiting times of up to 230 days.

 Every year over 1m patients fail to turn up for their outpatient appointment.

 Every year 60,000 operations are cancelled by the hospital on the day they are due to take place.

 Patients can wait for hours in A&E, simply to be seen. Many patients well enough to leave hospital are forced to stay because support services are not available.

Barriers to change

 Services based on historical patterns and institutions - they are not planned to meet the needs of patients.

Rigid boundary between primary and secondary care.

 Lack of slack in the system. As a result, surges in demand for emergency care affect non-emergencies.

 No one takes overall responsibility for patients' care.

 Professional hierarchies create rigid boundaries.

 Staff feel overwhelmed by new initiatives.

 Insufficient importance given to leadership.
