webTitle: New checks will rule out 'dodgy doctors'

fields.headline: New checks will rule out 'dodgy doctors'
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The spectre of "dodgy" doctors like gynaecologist Rodney Ledward should become a thing of the past as a new system of appraisals and checks on every doctor's fitness to practise begins to bite, the president of the General Medical Council said yesterday.
fields.body:
The spectre of "dodgy" doctors like gynaecologist Rodney Ledward should become a thing of the past as a new system of appraisals and checks on every doctor's fitness to practise begins to bite, the president of the General Medical Council said yesterday.

Sir Donald Irvine was speaking at the launch of the GMC's revalidation document - the five-yearly review to which every doctor will be subject to ensure he is up to scratch . The GMC hopes the system, together with reforms to speed up the way it works and end secrecy, will defuse accusations of failing to act fast enough and defending doctors against patients' complaints.

Sir Donald insisted yesterday that the onus was not just on the GMC to ensure doctors were not performing badly. Employers - the hospital trust or health authority - must now be in the spotlight too. "The GMC does not, cannot, and should not manage the detail of doctors in their everyday work. That is and always has been the responsibility of employers," he said.

The government is requiring all hospitals and GP surgeries to oversee the work of medical staff in a way they never used to do. Under proposals by the chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, all doctors will have to undergo appraisal by their peers every year.

"If these local arrangements work properly, very few problem doctors should ever get as far as the GMC," he said.

The health minister, John Denham, meanwhile made clear that he intends to renegotiate hospital consultants' contracts by offering financial incentives to do more work inside the NHS.

Mr Denham predicted that he would have renegotiated the contract by the autumn. He wanted consultants to be given a statutory requirement to undergo an annual appraisal, and a rewards system that favoured those who showed loyalty to the NHS.

webTitle: Torso murders case goes to appeal court

fields.headline: Torso murders case goes to appeal court
fields.standfirst: Miscarriage of justice to be investigated over 1974 gangland killings
fields.trailText: One of Britain's longest running and most controversial alleged miscarriage of justice cases is to be referred to the court of appeal, it was revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
One of Britain's longest running and most controversial alleged miscarriage of justice cases is to be referred to the court of appeal, it was revealed yesterday.

The cases of two men convicted for the "torso murders" in 1974 were recommended for review by the criminal cases review commission, which has spent three years examining the convictions for the double murder in north London.

Reg Dudley, 75, and Robert Maynard, 61, who have always protested their innocence, were convicted in 1977 of the gangland executions of Billy Moseley and Micky Cornwall, and both were sentenced to life imprisonment. Dudley's daughter, Kathleen Bailey, was convicted of conspiracy to cause grievous bodily harm to Cornwall, and was given a two year suspended sentence. Her conviction is also to be referred to the appeal court. The killings were dubbed the "torso murders" after parts of Moseley's body were found in the Thames. Cornwall's body was found in a shallow grave in Hertfordshire.

Since the quashing of the convictions in the Guildford Four, Birmingham Six and Bridgewater Three cases, the double murder has become one of Britain's longest running and most controversial cases.

At their trial, the judge, Mr Justice Swanwick, recommended that Dudley and Maynard should serve a minimum of 15 years, but Maynard is still in prison and Dudley served 21 years before being given parole in August 1997.

The key prosecution witness against Dudley and Maynard was Tony Wild, a small-time criminal who later confessed to the Guardian that he made up his evidence because he wanted a lighter sentence on a robbery charge. He was jailed for five years when his fellow robbers received 18-year sentences after he agreed to give evidence against Maynard and Dudley.

He claimed he had heard them confess to the crimes while he was in the same wing of Brixton prison in south London. Dudley and Maynard, who both had long criminal records, claimed at their 136 day trial that they would never have confessed to a stranger in prison.

But after he was released from prison, Wild, by then a born-again Christian, contacted the Guardian to say he had made up his evidence and that the men had never confessed to him at all.

Yesterday Ms Bailey said her father was "over the moon" at the commission's decision. While an appeal does not automatically lead to the quashing of a conviction, the vast majority of cases referred back by the commission have led to convictions being overturned.

The case against Maynard and Dudley, both from Islington, north London, was that they had killed Moseley either because he was having an affair with another criminal's wife or because he had accused Dudley of being an informer. It was suggested that Cornwall, a bank robber, was killed because he sought to avenge the death of his friend.

There were no witnesses to the crimes or any forensic evidence and the case rested chiefly on remarks which detectives claimed had been made to them, which Dudley and Maynard denied, and Wild's claims that Dudley said he had taken Moseley's head to Brighton to show it to a friend. Two fellow prisoners also gave evidence.

A campaign to clear the men was launched after their conviction but a 1979 appeal was unsuccessful despite new evidence. Wild's confession and two TV documentaries failed to bring further appeals. New evidence slowly emerged indicating the innocence of the men but Wild has so far declined to give evidence for an appeal unless he is given immunity from a perjury charge.

Andrea Storey, spokeswoman for Dudley's and Maynard's solicitors, said: "We trust that the matter can now proceed to a just conclusion for our clients."

webTitle: The latest wonder of the world

fields.headline: The latest wonder of the world
fields.standfirst: The new Library of  Alexandria is ready to reopen, there's just one problem - no money for books
fields.trailText: In the days when 500,000 papyrus scrolls could store the entire sum of human knowledge, the Egyptian city of Alexandria - at the crossroads of Europe, Asia and Africa - was a natural site for the world's greatest library.
fields.body:
In the days when 500,000 papyrus scrolls could store the entire sum of human knowledge, the Egyptian city of Alexandria - at the crossroads of Europe, Asia and Africa - was a natural site for the world's greatest library.

It was here, under the Ptolemies, that man first calculated the circumference of the earth and discovered the power of steam, only to abandon it because energy from slaves was so much cheaper. But when the Great Library was destroyed, 1,400 or more years ago, hundreds of works of philosophy, science and literature were lost, knowledge which it took the world centuries to rediscover.

But later this year the Library of Alexandria will open for business once again - this time in a spectacular £120m building, with the world's most advanced cataloguing system, computerised book transport, CD-roms, microfilms, internet connections and a fire prevention system to ensure it doesn't suffer the same fate as its predecessor.

The new library's roof is a tilted disc, 160m in diameter, dipping below ground level and said to symbolise the rising sun. Its circular granite-clad wall is carved with letters from almost every known alphabet. The vast reading room, with 2,000 seats, rises through seven terraces. There's just a small matter of something to fill the shelves.

Though it is billed as "a unique research institution, a haven for scholars worldwide", the library has scarcely any money for books. Despite having the capacity to store 8m volumes, there will only be 400,000 when it opens. It's a familiar problem - and one that the ancient Egyptians solved ingeniously: according to legend, they raided passing ships and forced them to hand over any scrolls on board for copying.

The modern Egyptians do the same, more politely. They ask visiting businessmen and dignitaries if they happen to have any spare books. Scholars and librarians shudder at the prospect. "We have trenchantly argued that this is the wrong approach," says David Wardrop, secretary of the UK Friends of the Alexandria Library. "But the Egyptians say there's room for 8m books, so why worry."

Short of trying to collect every book in existence, as the ancient library did, experts say that Alexandria's best hope of becoming a world-class library is to develop an acquisition strategy with areas of speciality. Two reports have proposed just such a strategy: a twin focus on the history of the Mediterranean and science and technology. Acquisitions that fit the strategy include copies of Spain's Escorial collection of Arab scholarship of the 10th-14th centuries and of Turkey's Ottoman empire documents.

In Britain, the Friends of the library are raising funds to purchase a microfiche copy of all the Arabic manuscripts in the British Library - some 45,000 images. Meanwhile, back in Alexandria they are busy cataloguing such diverse titles as a life of Princess Diana, the Guinness Book of Records, and numerous outdated yearbooks.

"They've got to be more selective in what they accept in gifts," Dr Maurice Line, a librarian and former chairman of the UK Friends, says. The Egyptians' dilemma is how to allocate government resources between Alexandria and other, grossly under-funded libraries around the country, which will complain if Alexandria is given preferential treatment.

Another question on which no one will yet commit themselves is whether any books will be banned. In Egypt, writing and publishing can be hazardous occupations. One writer is currently on trial for promoting atheism and last month there were riots in Cairo over the reprinting of 1,000 copies of a 1983 novel, Banquet for Seaweed, which allegedly defamed Islam. While experts argue that the new library should be primarily for research, it could end up trying to be all things to all people.

Ordinary Alexandrians would like to drop in and borrow books, while the university - just across the road and deprived of a new library of its own - has also staked a claim. There's even talk of a special section for children. Building links with the local community is fine, Dr Line says - the French national library tried to do the same - but it only works if the research facilities are properly funded.

These are the sort of issues that normally would be resolved by the chief librarian. But, with only a few months to go before the opening, and with the world's cast-off books arrive to be catalogued, there is no sign of one.

Up to now, the entire project has been run by Dr Mohsen Zahran, an architect, with plenty of input from Suzanne Mubarak, the wife of the Egyptian president. Recruiting a top-calibre librarian would mean paying an international salary (£80,000 or more) which the Egyptians claim they cannot afford without risking a strike by librarians in the rest of the country. This may be a ploy to persuade foreign donors to stump up the money, but privately sources say that the Egyptians don't want a librarian running the show and that they already have a political figure in mind for the top job.

One of the new library's earliest benefactors was Saddam Hussein of Iraq, who donated $21m to help start the project shortly before invading Kuwait. He recently declared his intention to write a novel about youth, and will no doubt provide a copy for the library when it is published.

Who burned the books?

The main suspects in the destruction of the library are:

Julius Caesar: In 48BC he set fire to ships in the harbour and, according to Plutarch, burned 40,000 scrolls.
Queen Zenobia of Palmyra: In 270AD she captured Alexandria. Much of the city was destroyed during a counter-attack by the Roman Emperor Aurelian.
Christians: In 391AD they went on the rampage in Alexandria, destroying "pagan" writings.
The first Caliph of Egypt: According to legend, he is said to have ordered books to be burned to heat the public baths in the 7th century AD.

Short of trying to collect every book in existence, as the ancient library did, experts say that Alexandria's best hope of becoming a world-class library is to develop an acquisition strategy with areas of speciality. Two reports have proposed just such a strategy: a twin focus on the history of the Mediterranean and science and technology. Acquisitions that fit the strategy include copies of Spain's Escorial collection of Arab scholarship of the 10th-14th centuries and of Turkey's Ottoman empire documents. In Britain, the Friends of the library are raising funds to purchase a microfiche copy of all the Arabic manuscripts in the British Library - some 45,000 images. Meanwhile, back in Alexandria they are busy cataloguing such diverse titles as a life of Princess Diana, the Guinness Book of Records, and numerous outdated yearbooks. "They've got to be more selective in what they accept in gifts," Dr Maurice Line, a librarian and former chairman of the UK Friends, says. The Egyptians' dilemma is how to allocate government resources between Alexandria and other, grossly under-funded libraries around the country, which will complain if Alexandria is given preferential treatment. Another question on which no one will yet commit themselves is whether any books will be banned. In Egypt, writing and publishing can be hazardous occupations. One writer is currently on trial for promoting atheism and last month there were riots in Cairo over the reprinting of 1,000 copies of a 1983 novel, Banquet for Seaweed, which allegedly defamed Islam. While experts argue that the new library should be primarily for research, it could end up trying to be all things to all people. Ordinary Alexandrians would like to drop in and borrow books, while the university - just across the road and deprived of a new library of its own - has also staked a claim. There's even talk of a special section for children. Building links with the local community is fine, Dr Line says - the French national library tried to do the same - but it only works if the research facilities are properly funded. These are the sort of issues that normally would be resolved by the chief librarian. But, with only a few months to go before the opening, and with the world's cast-off books arrive to be catalogued, there is no sign of one. Up to now, the entire project has been run by Dr Mohsen Zahran, an architect, with plenty of input from Suzanne Mubarak, the wife of the Egyptian president. Recruiting a top-calibre librarian would mean paying an international salary (£80,000 or more) which the Egyptians claim they cannot afford without risking a strike by librarians in the rest of the country. This may be a ploy to persuade foreign donors to stump up the money, but privately sources say that the Egyptians don't want a librarian running the show and that they already have a political figure in mind for the top job. One of the new library's earliest benefactors was Saddam Hussein of Iraq, who donated $21m to help start the project shortly before invading Kuwait. He recently declared his intention to write a novel about youth, and will no doubt provide a copy for the library when it is published. Who burned the books? The main suspects in the destruction of the library are: Julius Caesar: In 48BC he set fire to ships in the harbour and, according to Plutarch, burned 40,000 scrolls. Queen Zenobia of Palmyra: In 270AD she captured Alexandria. Much of the city was destroyed during a counter-attack by the Roman Emperor Aurelian. Christians: In 391AD they went on the rampage in Alexandria, destroying "pagan" writings. The first Caliph of Egypt: According to legend, he is said to have ordered books to be burned to heat the public baths in the 7th century AD.

fields.headline: Staying on
fields.standfirst:
Peter Godwin 's 1997 best-selling book told the story of a white boy growing up in rural Rhodesia. Now, on the eve of Zimbabwe's elections, he has returned to meet the handful of defiant white families who remain in his home town
Zimbabwe: special report
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Peter Godwin 's 1997 best-selling book told the story of a white boy growing up in rural Rhodesia. Now, on the eve of Zimbabwe's elections, he has returned to meet the handful of defiant white families who remain in his home town
fields.body:
Heaven is empty and the Frog and Fern is closed. The war vets are on the warpath and Chimanimani's lodges are desolate. It is election time in Zimbabwe and I have come home. Although it's been years since I lived here, Chimanimani (which used to be called Melsetter, after the Orkney town) remains stuck in my mind as that central reference point from which all other places radiate. It lies in an isolated valley along the eastern border with Mozambique, nestled in the crook of a winding range of glittering granite mountains from which the village now takes its name. In recent times it has become even more remote; cyclone Eline swept away its bridges earlier this year, leaving it cut off by road for more than a month. As my car strains up the hillside from the Biriwiri valley, the road is reduced to one lane, the other has been washed down into the valley below.

The shadows of war are long here. In 1964, on this road etched into the cliff-side, the first attack of the Chimurenga, the liberation war, was carried out by a band of guerrillas called the Crocodile Gang. The victim was our next-door neighbour, Piet Oberholzer. My mother was the attending doctor. By independence in 1980, one of every four white farmers had been killed by guerrillas. And now, 20 years later, Chimanimani is under siege once more by remnants of those same guerrillas. But the power struggle has changed dramatically since then. Now Robert Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF party is fighting for its political life against an upsurgent opposition, the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), a party that didn't even exist a year ago.

I wander over to the Msasa cafe where I find its owner, John Barlow, in the back carving an African drum from a log of blue mahogany. "This was supposed to be the best year of my life," says Barlow sadly, as we sit in his newly renovated, empty, cafe, sipping fresh local coffee by the fire and discussing evacuation routes, the subject du jour around many Zimbabwean dinner tables this week.

Most white Zimbabweans, and indeed many middle-class black people, have what they call "gap bags" packed and ready, in case the election results trigger a spasm of violence. My sister and her friends have a complicated plan that involves various rendezvous along the route from Harare, then crossing the Zambezi into Zambia. (The Zanu-PF candidate in my sister's garden suburb of northern Harare is Comrade Stalin Mau Mau - a deliberately unsettling nom de guerre that jumps out at you from posters on every lamppost there.) They have food supplies and visas and have registered their cars with the police so they can drive across the border. Some here have acted pre-emptively, going "on holiday" for the next couple of weeks, deaf to the entreaties of the opposition MDC that everyone with a vote should stay and use it.

President Mugabe appears convinced that his present travails are all the fault of the whites, and his racial rhetoric has become white hot. Never mind that there are only 70,000 whites left here (in a population of over 12m) many of whom have been in deep political hibernation. Or that only four of the MDC's 120 candidates are white. The veterans' leader Chenjerai "Hitler" Hunzvi has said - in fact he keeps saying it - that if Zanu-PF loses the election, he and his men will go back to war. Add these two ingredients together: a threat of war and conveniently colour-coded culprits, and the evacuation plans don't seem quite so nutty.

Evacuating from Chimanimani however, is particularly tricky. With its back to the soaring mountains, there are only two roads in, and one of them has been blocked by cyclone Eline. If the other one is controlled by war vets, how to get out? The whites here have already evacuated once, last month, when several truckloads of vets became incensed at a rumour that Hunzvi's house in Harare had been torched (it was just another of a spate of wild rumours) and decided to take out their ire on the local whites. There aren't very many of them left, only about 20 families. Warned first by their domestic workers and black colleagues, and then by the local police chief (who has since been demoted and transferred for his troubles), the whites formed a convoy and drove up to Skyline junction, and out of the valley, to lie low till it cooled down.

John Barlow was about the only white to stay that time, but even he is taking evacuation seriously now. He has decided that if it comes down to it, the only way out for him might be to grab his kids and do a Sound of Music - climb up over the mountains and into Mozambique. The very idea of going to Mozambique for sanctuary strikes me as absurd: it is officially one of the poorest countries in the world after being ravaged by 30 years of civil war.

Having stripped and beaten the black school teachers in front of their pupils, and threatened the black managers at some of the saw mills, the vets in Chimanimani are particularly interested in one white man, Roy Bennet, the owner of Charleswood. This 7,000-acre farm is arguably the prettiest farm in the country, tucked up against the national park. It is latticed with irrigation canals, which feed the red earth and the neat rows of coffee bushes that sprout from it. The local Ndau people call Bennet, Pachedu . It means "one of us". A pitch-perfect Shona speaker, he was approached by a delegation of local councillors and kraal (village) heads who were sick of absentee MPs and stagnant development, and asked to stand as their candidate. After flirting with Zanu-PF, he's now standing for the MDC, a white man standing in a rural constituency where over 99.9% of the electorate is black. He shows me a file fat with letters from black supporters. Some address him as Father Chimanimani, others thank him for helping to repair bridges after the cyclone.

Bennet's rival, the Zanu-PF candidate, is Munacho Mutezo, an engineering graduate from Birmingham and Glasgow universities. His father was detained by the old Rhodesian authorities, Bennet tells me, for being involved with the Crocodile Gang. Now the battle lines are drawn once more. But this time the homeboy is a white man who spends most of his time here. Mutezo on the other hand, is based five hours away in Harare.

Judging by his reception from the locals, Bennet is probably a shoo-in - if he can just stay alive until the polls open tomorrow. He has had a steady stream of death threats. His farm is guarded by dozens of youths armed with clubs and iron bars, and he has informers in the village and the black township who warn him of approaching danger.

Bennet has only just moved back on to his farm after war vets invaded it. They seized his wife, Heather, who was pregnant at the time, put a machete to her throat and made her chant Zanu-PF slogans. They beat up several of the workers and then they occupied the farmhouse and trashed it over several weeks, stealing many of its contents and smearing shit on the walls. They cut the paws off the lion skin rug, to use them for muti - a type of traditional medicine. Heather miscarried. But Bennet negotiated a return and the vets eventually left, feeling vulnerable to a hostile workforce that had had a gut-full of being bullied.

"These white farmers who appease - I've got no time for them. Appeasement has never worked, just look at history," says Bennet, a great bear of a man, who played polo-cross for the national side and often goes barefoot in public. "What's so heartening about these elections is that there's a good percentage of Zimbabwean whites who've said, 'sod it, let's get involved,' and we've suffered together with the blacks, and feared together with them. We've made a stand and shown that we're prepared to sacrifice ourselves for this country. And isn't that what a patriot is, after all? It's the first time I've felt really Zimbabwean."

As we sit talking under the tall thatch by the fire, the radio crackles into life with a message of trouble - a truck of war vets has been spotted coming this way. All Roy's hunting rifles are in police custody, but one of his mechanics peels down a horse blanket on the sofa to reveal a shotgun and a bandolier of cartridges.

"Our guys," as Bennet calls his MDC guards, are gathering in strategic points to repulse the attack. "I'm sick of running now," he says. "If they're gonna come, they must come and let's get this over with."

But tonight is not to be the night and I eventually fall asleep to the gurgling of the river and the call of the nightjars. I wake up once to the sound of murmuring outside the window and peep out to see the MDC guards huddled round a fire there, with blankets draped over their shoulders, hands clasped around enamel mugs of coffee. These are brave men, many are kids still, who are taking on the full wrath of the state for their vision of better Zimbabwe, and they are in just as much danger as Bennet.

Later, I accompany Bennet to the police station where he has been summoned for a meeting with the vets. They tell him that they intend to reoccupy his farm, but they are prepared to do it peacefully, cooperatively. "That's what you said last time," spits Bennet, raising his voice and reeling off a litany of the crimes they committed when they first visited Charleswood. The room is thick with tension and several of the vets look as though they would shoot him this second, if they were armed.

We discover en route from Bennet's election agent, James Mukwaya, that the rally Bennet is supposed to address this morning in the Ngorima communal lands has been cancelled. Gangs from Zanu-PF have been there overnight, moving from house to house, warning people that if they attend they will be killed. But Bennet is not down hearted. They're all on our side anyway, he says, so why risk their lives with public rallies, we know how they'll vote when the time comes.

Along the foothills from Charleswood, the Steyns aren't quite so optimistic about the future. They are having a bad week and to make it worse, a bush fire has just crossed the mountain from Mozambique and is threatening to burn down their farm. In the old farmhouse with its Cape Constantia gables, Louis Steyn seems lost in a kind of numbed reverie. He sits in his plum-coloured draylon chair, sucking heavily on his pipe, while Daleen, his wife, keeps up a cheerful chatter.

Louis Steyn's grandfather came here in 1893, leading the Steyn trek up from the Orange Free State in South Africa. There have been Steyns farming these lush hillsides ever since, but it looks like Louis could be the last. His farm has been designated by the government for compulsory takeover, though he vows: "We'll fight it to the bloody end." A delegation of ministry envoys arrived by car last week, having driven all the way from Harare to deliver the designation letter by hand.

"I offered them a sandwich and a cup of tea," says Daleen, "but they were in a hurry because they had lots more designation orders to deliver to white farmers."

The Steyns have also been "occupied" by war veterans for some months now. When the vets first arrived, Daleen told them: "We worship the same God you and I, let's pray together to him for justice." And so they did, the vets and the Steyns, they got down on their knees on the lawn outside the farmhouse and prayed together, and then the vets went off and pegged their land.

Between occupation and designation it does look pretty bleak for the Steyns. Not that they haven't been through tough times before. For nearly a decade during the war they had to commute to the farm from the village because it was too dangerous to stay overnight.

"Then we got ambushed in our car," remembers Daleen. "They shot at us and fired at us with a rocket launcher. There was so much smoke it was dark and we saw tracer bullets flying all over the place, it was like a starry night." The car took 11 hits, but Louis managed to coax it to the next bend in the road. "I drove out of there on the rims of the tyres spinning on the road," adds Louis.

Their Rhodesian ridgeback canters after my car as the Steyn's wave goodbye, having asked me to give their apologies to Lord and Lady Plunket who are holding a tea party this afternoon. The Plunkets own a modest timber est ate and have been migratory residents here ever since I can remember. Lady Plunket has laid on quite a spread - the table is laden with plates of buttered gingerbread and delicate triangles of crustless sandwiches. Pretty much the whole white community is here. They fit comfortably on to the Plunket's veranda. Though it has brought much oppro brium down upon them, most of the whites here support Roy Bennet's stand. "He's my hero," says Lady Plunket, clasping her hands to her heart.

As the first fingers of the night mist creep down the mountain gorges, and pine-scented smoke from the hearth fire fills the air, we fall inevitably to discussing the election; the chances of a fair ballot, or of the government accepting a defeat; the possibility of a coup. There is talk too of an Idi Amin option where, just as the Ugandan dictator expelled all Asians, a furious Mugabe decides to purge the country of whites and gorge on their property. From the look and the sound of him these days, this is what he'd most like to do.

I leave early the next morning, after a tour of the Plunket's gardens, viewing their lichen-blotched Shona soapstone sculptures. The sun is just breaking through the granite ramparts of the mountain, dissolving the mist as I drive up and out of the valley to Skyline junction. But there is no skyline, just fat grey clouds sitting heavily on the hill, and rain. Work gangs in olive-green plastic ponchos dig on in the downpour, trying to keep the road open. As I drop down the other side, the rain stops and the clouds lift and the baobabs begin. I come up behind a slow-moving old Land Rover filled with young black men singing exuberantly. They wave me the open-palmed sign of the MDC and throw some fliers up into the air. For a brief moment one sticks to my windscreen and I see the grinning visage of Roy Bennet and the headline "Chinja Maitiro - Change your ways. Vote MDC", and then it blows off into the bush.

 Peter Godwin is the author of Mukiwa - A White Boy in Africa, published by Picador.

webTitle: My partner works too hard - should I leave before his health goes?

fields.headline: My partner works too hard - should I leave before his health goes?
fields.trailText: My partner is an academic. He works very hard, often in excess of 60 hours a week. Anything less is seen as a lack of commitment, so career and work have, over the years, taken precedence over home and family.

My partner is an academic. He works very hard, often in excess of 60 hours a week. Anything less is seen as a lack of commitment, so career and work have, over the years, taken precedence over home and family. Recently the stress has taken its toll - he is often unwell and always tired. He finds little time to exercise and is significantly overweight. Our relationship, although amicable, features little companionship and very few shared interests, as I have pursued my own interests and developed my own circle of friends. Our sex life is sparse. As our children grow up, I am growing increasingly uneasy about what the future holds. I fear being tied to nursing a chronically sick partner, as my mother was. A future with a soulmate, with shared interests to enjoy together, seems unattainable. We have, over the years, really grown up in to two different people. Once the children are independent, should I consider setting up on my own and making a new life? I do not expect that my situation is unique. What choices did other readers make and what were the results?

 Say goodbye and live again

Until recently I too had a partner who spent long hours at work, leaving home early and coming back late - resulting in no energy, emotional or otherwise, for either myself or my eight-year-old daughter. Like yours, our sex life was virtually non-existent, leaving me feeling frustrated and undesirable. My ex-partner was also frequently ill, which again took its toll.

If you are prepared to carry on until the children are independent, you may be depriving yourself of a full life. After I ended my relationship, life was hard as a single parent, but the benefits have proved considerable: new friends, wonderful support networks, casual but enjoyable relationships with men, increased self-esteem, and an overall improvement in the quality of my life.

In my experience, some men often use "the pressure of work" as an excuse to be inadequate and non-participative in other areas. You deserve more.
Jayne Francis
Birmingham

 You have to work at it

You are obviously feeling dissatisfied with your relationship and you are quite correct when you say that your situation is not unique. You and your partner have grown apart. However, if you want "a future with a soulmate, with shared interests to enjoy together" you have to work at it.

Don't just turn your back on this man and all you have shared. How can you consider abandoning him because he is now "significantly overweight...often unwell and always tired"? What about commitment? From what you write, it appears that your partner is a decent hard-working man who has committed himself to you and the children for many years.

Talk to him. Tell him of your feelings. Let him know that you feel excluded by his career. Give him the chance to change. Build the rest of your lives together. Are you fit and healthy? If so, how? Encourage your partner to share your keep fit activities. Take up a new activity together. Now your children are approaching independence, this is a wonderful time for a couple to share a new stage of their lives. Don't give up!
Sheila K Madhvani
London

 Clean him out financially

What are you waiting for? Do you want to leave it until it's too late - when the bastard is too ill for you to leave? And when you do leave him, make sure you clean him out financially, because whatever he promises to do for you and the children will never happen. The sooner you get on with your life the better. I did.
Janet Ward
Queensland, Australia

Next week:

My father left home when I was 11 and since then my happiness has been governed by my mother's emotional state. I would often come home from school to find her in tears or drunk. She once called me home from a visit to my father and I found her hysterical and possibly suicidal. As an adult I have witnessed her further crises, including years of binge drinking, a divorce, spells of agoraphobia, being unable to cope with her job and, for the past 15 years, the problems she has had looking after her own mother.

But lately things have greatly improved for her - my grandmother is living happily in sheltered accommodation and mum has moved into a more easily manageable bungalow. She rang recently, though, and told me she has become agoraphobic again. Then my grandmother phoned in tears saying: "I think your mother is heading for a breakdown." She said she didn't want me to think it was her own fault because of the years of stress caused by looking after her. I am now 11 weeks pregnant having had a near miscarriage earlier on (my mother is aware). I feel I have to be selfish and distance myself from these two demanding women. To be brutal, I just want them to stop bothering me. How can I achieve this without causing them too much distress? They both occasionally talk in veiled tones about suicide. Should I stop worrying and just let them get on with it?

fields.headline: Northern comfort
fields.standfirst: It's been called Scotland's answer to The Fast Show. And it went down a storm north of the border. But will Chewin' The Fat manage to cross the cultural divide when it makes its English debut tonight?
fields.trailText: The room is filled with smoke. A woman sits on an armchair, smoking furiously. Beside her are black bin bags filled with cigarette coupons. "Alex," she croaks, lifting a small electronic voicebox to her throat. "We've got enough coupons to get a 35ft cabin cruiser yacht."
fields.body:
The room is filled with smoke. A woman sits on an armchair, smoking furiously. Beside her are black bin bags filled with cigarette coupons. "Alex," she croaks, lifting a small electronic voicebox to her throat. "We've got enough coupons to get a 35ft cabin cruiser yacht."

The husband emerges from behind a beaded curtain and puts his own little machine to his neck. "Whit would we dae wi a cabin cruiser?" he retorts. "We've got a private jet lying oot there daein nuthin'."

This is the Kensitarse family, a pair of nicotine addicts who have had tracheotomies as a result of throat cancer but still refuse to quit. As the postman delivers gifts they have garnered from collecting cigarette coupons, they shout at him "shut the door, you're letting the smoke oot". The postman has had a tracheotomy as well. Sick, dark but very, very funny. The couple are two of a number of characters in a new Scottish comedy called Chewin' The Fat, a sketch show which has had the whole of Scotland in stitches. Described by some as a Scottish Fast Show, the series received a special mention at the Golden Rose of Montreux Television Festival.

The show has characters such as Ronald Villiers, the ham actor who can't act and tests the patience of directors and cast alike; Betty, the sex-mad, knicker-flashing granny who talks ceaselessly about getting "plundered" and loving "the boaby" [Scottish slang for penis] and Rab McGlinchey, a shell-suited, fag-smoking, beer-slugging guy who interprets the televisions news for neds.

Much of the humour is pub-based, wicked, even twisted, but in Scotland the viewing public loves it. The catchphrase "gonnae no dae that", taken from one of the show's skits, is now uttered in playgrounds, building sites and offices across the land.

Scotland has a rich vaudeville and music-hall tradition. And it has always had a reputation for loving its comedy, but being hard on its comics. The place is filled with people who think they are funnier than the comedians. But there have been a good number of successes: Billy Connolly, Jerry Sadowitz, Craig Ferguson, Gregor Fisher, Elaine C Smith, Robbie Coltrane and Arnold Brown to name but a few. And in terms of television series, the last decade saw Scotland give national television Naked Video and Rab C Nesbitt. But somewhere in the 90s, good television comedy ground to a halt, and attempts to bring Scottish humour to a wider audience flopped - shows like City Lights, which were huge in Scotland, bombed in England. How will this latest export fare?

Stuart Cosgrove, head of Channel 4's Nations and Regions unit, agrees. He says: "Chewin' The Fat is the biggest cult comedy to come out of Scotland for years. Scottish comedy has a mixed pedigree and is a notoriously bad traveller. But Chewin' The Fat has a bizarre array of characters that are as strange and likeable as any of the characters in The Fast Show or Smack The Pony.

"In the last few years Scottish comedy has seriously underperformed - the worst has been parochial and poor quality. Chewin' The Fat soars above the rest and deserves to be a network hit."

Chewin' The Fat is the creation of its two main stars, Ford Kiernan, 36, and Greg Hemphill, 29. The show contains a lot of rude, on-the-edge humour - what the pair call the "lowest common denominator" jokes. When they sit down to write their sketches there are no taboo subjects: this is evident in the Pearl Necklace sketches which feature the crew of a Captain Pugwash-style fishing boat spouting dirty double entendres.

Ship's mate: "Captain, we are losing speed in the storm." Captain: "Oh tarnation. Hoist the scrote net." Mate: "Ah cannae. It's caught on a crusty bum cleft. If we hoist it we risk straining the boaby shaft and ripping the panty mesh..." And so it goes on.

The Comedy Unit, which produced the programme, believes that its well-observed humour will make it easier to cross boundaries. And while many of the sketches are thick with Scottish slang and have local idiosyncrasies, they will not be cut out to tailor for a mainstream, English audience.

Kiernan says: "Humour's humour, regardless of how you cut it. If it's funny you leave it in. You have programmes like Goodness Gracious Me and Father Ted now, and Chewin' The Fat is no more parochial than them. I don't think we should slow things down. We will just suck it and see."

Comic actress Elaine C Smith, who starred in Naked Video and was Mary Doll in Rab C Nesbitt, says that what punters in the south liked about her shows was their Scottishness. She believes that writers and actors should keep it that way. "One of the problems is if you water it down for a network audience then it loses what is intrinsically funny about it. I think as Scots we worry too much about whether the English will understand us. When we took Nesbitt on tour we found that maybe things that work in Glasgow are not the things that get a laugh in Basingstoke, but then other things get laughs."

The Scottish stand-up comedian, Bruce Morton, sums it up: "There may be some who don't understand it. But as the comic parrot said about these people: 'Try harder'."

 Chewin' The Fat, tonight, 10.50pm, BBC1

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Pulp | Maria Callas: Life & Art | Lock, Stock And Two Smoking Barrels | Get Shorty
fields.body:
Pulp

(Mike Hodges, 1972)

8pm, FilmFour

Hodges made this as something of an antidote to the brutality of his seminal, newly re-released gangster film, Get Carter. Michael Caine, who played Carter, is his star again, playing a pulp fiction writer who finds life mirroring his art when the subject of the memoirs he's ghosting - a show-stopping cameo from Mickey Rooney - suddenly dies. His amateur detective work leads him into Mafia business in this well-written comedy thriller, relaxing the tension and playing it for laughs.

Maria Callas: Life & Art

9.05pm, Performance

In this intriguing documentary, Callas comes across as a sad victim of her own phenomenal success. An ambitious singer, she made a chameleonic transformation from pudgy diva to svelte clothes horse, only to be succeeded in the affections of the love of her life, Onassis, by Jackie Kennedy. She gradually became a recluse, dying in her Paris flat in 1977, at only 53.

Lock, Stock And Two Smoking Barrels

(Guy Ritchie, 1998)

10pm, Sky Premier

This tale of four East End lads losing out to local villain 'Atchet 'Arry (PH Moriarty) in a fixed card game, and their attempts to drum up the half-million they owe him, has prompted umpteen Brit gangster movies aiming to cash in on its success. There are big pluses - Vinnie Jones's well tasty enforcer, Lenny McClean's gruesome Barry the Baptist, a stonking soundtrack and some rich gags. But for a lesson in how it should be done, see The Long Good Friday or Get Carter.

Get Shorty

(Barry Sonnenfeld, 1995)

10pm, FilmFour

Light, sly picture of wheeler-dealing Hollywood, taken from Elmore Leonard's novel about crook Chili Palmer, whose life of crime is ideal experience for a career in film production. Some chuckling star turns: Gene Hackman's fiscally-challenged B-movie director; Rene Russo's over-the-hill starlet; Danny DeVito's egotistical actor; and Travolta is in his element as smart hood Chili.

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.body:
Animation is great on-screen, but can it work off-screen? That's the question being asked in the US as news reaches us from there of two new TV series, premiering this summer not on television but on the net.

The first, from The Drew Carey Show's executive producer Bruce Helford, has already gone live. The Oblongs is based on an underground San Francisco comic book about a family living near a toxic dump.

It is expected to move onto Warners' broadcast network, the WB, in January next year.

Continuing the theme (two animated shows on the net - it's a trend), every kid's favourite broadcaster Nickelodeon is launching a show online as well.

Dora, The Explorer (what else?) is set to launch early next month on Nickjr.com, the web site spun off from Nickelodeon's own spin-off - Nick Junior for teeny people.

Featuring a girl who lives inside a computer, it seems perfect for the world of the net. It will only graduate to TV in mid-August, airing on Nickelodeon TV in the US.

What's not clear is whether either Warners or the might of Viacom (which owns Nickelodeon) will bring either to the UK. But demanding viewers now have the ideal way of lobbying broadcasters to get what they want on air. Simply check out the online version of the show (your computer's video-streaming ability allowing) and lobby your local TV channel to suggest they buy the show forthwith.

Perhaps it's this degree of people power which makes producers wary of debuting programmes on the net. Helford has expressed reservations about the whole plan. Talking to US newspaper USA Today, he said: "I would never premiere any of my other shows on the internet. But the flash animation for The Oblongs looks great online." Let's hope we can see it over here.

 Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast magazine

fields.headline: He's bad (and that's kinda good)
fields.trailText: He's bad (and that's kinda good)
fields.body:
Typical. You take off on holiday for a month and when you come back, nothing's the same.

They've even changed the money on you. My first financial transaction on landing Stateside involved my surrendering $10 and getting back a fistful of what to my eye looked like quarters, worth 25 cents.

"You're fucking kidding," I said with the hair-trigger temper that is jetlag's most troublesome symptom. "I gave you a 10-spot. Gimme my money, asshole."

The man behind the cash register was a model of Jeevesian emollience: "Uh, these are the all-new dollar coins, sir. If you'll permit me to open the register I can also show you the new five-dollar bill. It's awful nice-looking."

I apologised profusely, in shamed and anguished terms, and walked into a glass door on my way out. I'd left all my purchases on the counter and had to return rather sheepishly for them an hour later.

Just as I got used to the fact that all American money was the same size and colour - and it only took me a couple of decades - all of a sudden the Fed goes all Bank of England on me. And whenever I return to England these days I have to get used to the money being all different.

I had a similar encounter in London thanks to what I thought were the inadequate distinctions between a tenner and a twenty-quid note.

In the following days, as the 'lag loosened its satanic grip on me, I encountered the rejigged, toy-money fives and squinted sceptically at the "all-new" dollar coin. It's the same size and weight as a quarter-dollar, but gold, not silver, and bears on its obverse the raised legend "E Pluribus Unum" - "From Many, One" - which prompted from me a sarcastic guffaw, given the hideously balkanised state of the American Republic these days (forget the melting-pot theory of America: today it's a compartmentalised salad bar in a rundown Sizzler steak-and-lobster joint).

And if they're going to change the money, why not change it a lot ? This new shit still features the same boring founding farts as the old: Hamilton, Ben Franklin, pot-farmer George. Why can't they put some decent people on the money, like Sly Stone or Jayne Mansfield or Warren Oates? Will Alan Greenspan never learn?

Turning from money to movies, as sadly we must, there's little that, on a cursory examination of the box-office charts, could possibly be termed "all-new". In fact it was so "all-old" that I wondered for a moment if George Pal hadn't had his wicked way with me and time-zapped me back to the early 70s.

Shaft and Gone in 60 Seconds at numbers one and two? And a Mission: Impossible film at number four? I looked out of my window for planet-sized Afros and aircraft-carrier lapels. Nothing. What gives?

Turns out it's all remakes, rip-offs, retreads and sequels this week. Lurking down at numbers 11 and 12 we've even got Fantasia 2000 and Jesus' Son (I hope the poster shrieks, "With All-New Testament!"), which is at least a better title than Son of Kong.

Mission: Impossible 2, to take one example, is the sequel to a big-screen remake of a TV series that was itself heavily indebted to the Bond movies and Our Man Flint. On top of that, it's also a redux version of Hitchcock's Notorious and even cops a few moves from John Woo's own Once a Thief. Although I rather like it, I lost count of how many degrees of separation from originality that involves.

Likewise the crowd-pleasing Gladiator, still hanging in there at number eight after seven weeks of boffo receipts. You can carve this movie up into the elements it nicks from old sword-and-sandal epics: the Imperial household familiar to us from Anthony Mann's sublime Fall of the Roman Empire, married to the up-from-slavery narrative trajectory of Kubrick's Spartacus - even down to Djimon Hounsou in the Woody Strode role - and force-mated with Leni Riefenstahl's cinema gargantua aesthetic. Been here before.

And Shanghai Noon is a retread of the 48 Hours comedy formula that Walter Hill refined from Stanley Kramer's po-faced The Defiant Ones, and which has been replicated ad nauseam et infinitum ever since in movies ranging (and not widely) from Lethal Weapon and Chill Factor all the way to Rush Hour. All that's changed is that the template has been relocated Way Out West. Oh sorry, I forgot about Red Sun, the 1970 Eastern Western starring Charles Bronson and Toshiro Mifune. Nothing new here either, then.

Need we mention Big Momma's House, whose star, Martin Lawrence, is a retread of his patron/mentor Eddie Murphy (himself a Richard Pryor xerox, minus the genius)? He's here doing an expanded version of Murphy's Grandma turn in The Nutty Professor - another remake, with a sequel of its own in the offing.

The former may be a step up from Gumball Rally and The Cannonball Run 2, but the title is its own best review. The director of the original was, if memory serves, killed in a car crash while filming its sequel, which has a certain symmetry to it. See it by all means - then rent Vanishing Point.

Jackson was the one thing worth watching in Deep Blue Sea, apart from Saffron Burrows being torn to pieces, and The Negotiator would have been nothing without him.

fields.bodyText: Typical. You take off on holiday for a month and when you come back, nothing's the same. They've even changed the money on you. My first financial transaction on landing Stateside involved my surrendering $10 and getting back a fistful of what to my eye looked like quarters, worth 25 cents. "You're fucking kidding," I said with the hair-trigger temper that is jetlag's most troublesome symptom. "I gave you a 10-spot. Gimme my money, asshole." The man behind the cash register was a model of Jeevesian emollience: "Uh, these are the all-new dollar coins, sir. If you'll permit me to open the register I can also show you the new five-dollar bill. It's awful nice-looking." I apologised profusely, in shamed and anguished terms, and walked into a glass door on my way out. I'd left all my purchases on the counter and had to return rather sheepishly for them an hour later. Just as I got used to the fact that all American money was the same size and colour - and it only took me a couple of decades - all of a sudden the Fed goes all Bank of England on me. And whenever I return to England these days I have to get used to the money being all different. I had a similar encounter in London thanks to what I thought were the inadequate distinctions between a tenner and a twenty-quid note. Been here before. fields.headline: Video roundup
fields.standfirst: Complicity | Anna and the King | Rockers
fields.trailText: Complicity | Anna and the King | Rockers
fields.body:
Complicity
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Entertainment in Video Cert 18
***

A typically unflinching tale of sex, drugs and journalism from Iain Banks, whose gripping and sometimes disgusting novel is brought properly to life by veteran director Gavin Millar, best known for TV treats like Cream in My Coffee. Banks's oeuvre would probably have been deemed unfilmable before Trainspotting put heather and whimsy-free Scotland on the screen and, appropriately, Trainspotter Jonny Lee Miller gets the lead role as the lefty firebrand reporter thrown off the crime desk for his over-political reporting style.

Even when he is given the safe job of a puff piece on a local brewery, Miller finds that it's being taken over by the Japanese and as a series of rightwing villains start popping their clogs in imaginatively gruesome Banksian ways, our hero becomes chief suspect. Dark and murky deeds are a given with Banks and they get ever more twisted as police chief Brian Cox tries to untangle them and Miller looks ever more guilty.

This is like The 39 Steps rewritten from an anarchist-Marxist point of view: "It's worse than conspiracy. It's complicity." Banks fans will be pleased to see that the book's sex scenes (ice cubes and restraints) emerge intact along with his demented plotting. Complicity shares with Ratcatcher the phrase "ya wee pairvairt" and some Lottery assistance. The Scots seem to be using their windfall far more wisely than the English.

Anna and the King
Rental
Fox Pathe Cert 12
***

Jodie Foster takes the starchy schoolmarm role in this oft-filmed tale while, following Rex Harrison and Yul Brynner, Chow-Yun Fat is more ethnically appropriate casting as the King of Siam who finds himself engaged in a lengthy (very lengthy in this case) battle of wills with the woman engaged to teach English to his brood of 58 kids.

Foster makes the role implicitly pre-feminist - this being the 1860s - and Chow makes a far less imperious and camp monarch than Brynner. Director Andy Tennant aims for a relatively realistic version and this is as much history lesson as romance with Chow's kingdom threatened by the Burmese, a duplicitous empire - ours of course - and treachery from within.

Foster proves she can be at least as convincingly English as Gwyneth Paltrow in this 50s-style epic that is a bit heavy on the sweeping strings and teary-eyed heroism at times. It's an east-west Jane Eyre with a hint of Brief Encounter and feels like it could have been made 20 years before such recent Hollywood easterns as Kundun. There's none of that film's visual flair on show here either, despite some sumptuous backgrounds - it was filmed in Malaysia.

Rockers
Retail (£12.99) and DVD (£17.99)
Wienerworld Cert 15
***

Rudimentary film-making in many ways but still cherishable as one of those films that dumps you in another place and another culture and lets you find your way around. This is 70s Jamaica and for anyone hankering for another trip around Kingston after The Harder They Come, this is the one.

Like that classic, this has English with subtitles, momumental amounts of dope, dreadlocks and I&I-speak and lovely music made in primitive conditions amid grinding music-biz exploitation. Junior Murvin's wonderful Police and Thieves is a standout and Burning Spear and the Heptones resonate as a number of reggae boyz make cameo appearances.

It's often wincingly funny with a wonderful use of English ("Feel more upful,"someone is advised) and features some of the world's most relaxed arguments. Choice of hats, waistcoats and walking style are all clearly competitive sports in this neck of the woods where "lickle mishaps" tend to occur. There's a passable, vaguely Robin Hoodish plot too. For honkies, it makes you nostalgic for when Brixton was ruled by Rasta rather than Nike. Righteous.

fields.headline: Visions in the dark
fields.standfirst: Sixty years after The Maltese Falcon, why are we still obsessed by film noir? Because these movies depict our voluptuous nightmares, argues Tom Dewe Mathews
fields.trailText: Sixty years after The Maltese Falcon, why are we still obsessed by film noir? Because these movies depict our voluptuous nightmares, argues Tom Dewe Mathews
fields.body:
Film noir is one of those movie terms that drive people crazy. For aficionados, the films are as difficult to shut up about as they are to define. Is noir a genre? A mood? A style? Or just some moody lighting and a sax riff? Why is The Maltese Falcon noir, but not Bonnie and Clyde? Why The Last Seduction but not The Usual Suspects? Why Raging Bull but never, ever Rocky? Or do you simply have to shrug and say, "It's like art, you'll know it when you see it"?

Certainly, Raymond Chandler did. The essential qualities have never been better described than by that noir archetype of the disillusioned outsider, Philip Marlowe, when he looks down on LA in The Little Sister: "Now we've got big money, the sharp shooters, the percentage workers, the fast dollar boys, the hoodlums out of New York and Chicago. We've got the flashy restaurants and nightclubs they run, and the hotels and apartment houses they own, and the grifters and con men and female bandits that live in them. The riffraff of a big hard-boiled city with no more personality than a paper cup."

But that was then - the time of chain-smoking loners in the rain-slicked streets of film noir's heyday in the 40s and early 50s. What is noir now? And, more to the point, why does it never die? The answer is paranoia. The fear - especially during the Reagan/Thatcher years of the late 80s - that the world was, in fact, not on an extended 50s rerun of "be happy" innocence, that Reagan's "City on the Hill" was at best a mirage, at worst a tip or, as the downbeat noir novelist Jim Thompson suggested in the 50s, "Things are not what they seem." Because, like its grumpy, grizzled grandfather, today's film noir is paranoid, nihilistic, maybe even sadistic.

The world it inhabits looks out of kilter and dangerous; there are shadows everywhere, and garish swatches of brightness - usually coming out of gun barrels. Yet the actors aren't just framed in darkness, they're shrouded in it - or sliced by the stabbing shadows of venetian blinds.

But noir isn't just a style, an art director's plundering of pre-war French and German movies. It's wisecracking and know-it-all but with something romantic in it too. In all the best noir movies, there's a yearning for something more. Film noir - and, for that matter, neo-noir - tells us that by refusing the illusion of solace and sentimentality, by looking into the shadows, we may find something more solid and trustworthy than anything our pipe dreams can offer us. Because films noirs are visions in the dark. They are our voluptous nightmares.

Classic Noir

The Maltese Falcon (1941): The first and and some say the finest noir, John Huston's debut movie gave Humphrey Bogart his most exciting role. Even after a dozen viewings, Bogart's Sam Spade shocks us with his sudden outburts of greed and rage, with his shifts between self-interest and moral rectitude and back again. That is the film's strength and the reason why it defined film noir - good and evil are handcuffed together in all its characters.

Murder, My Sweet (1945): Based on Raymond Chandler's Farewell, My Lovely, this film's use of shadows, mirrors and disorienting fogs - not to mention venetian blinds - gave noir its visual style. Curiously, Chandler thought that its star, the ex-crooner Dick Powell, rather than Bogart, came closest to his conception of Philip Marlowe.

Double Indemnity (1944): The result of an uneasy alliance between three of noir's greatest names, Double Indemnity was taken from a James M Cain novel, directed by Billy Wilder and adapted by Wilder and Raymond Chandler. And it's got everything: style, sex and murder. There are no happy endings in noir, but who wouldn't kill for Barbara Stanwyck's femme fatale?

The Big Heat (1953): The director, Fritz Lang, is the link between film noir and its visual roots in German expressionism, but it's the sadism in The Big Heat that poleaxes you - from a hero imbued with obsession and loneliness to the heavy played by Lee Marvin rearing back from his scarred moll after he's thrown scalding coffee in her face.

Touch of Evil (1958): In a famous essay, director Paul Schrader says this movie is "film noir's epitaph". But what a way to bow out. By then noir had been whitewashed and transplanted to TV shows like Dragnet but this lurid, flamboyantly exhibitionist thriller from Orson Welles is as palpably nasty as the murky waters of the canal featured in its deadly climax.

Neo-noir

Chinatown (1974): In Robert Towne's original script, Evelyn (played by Faye Dunaway) shoots her father and is saved from jail by JJ Gittes (Jack Nicholson). But director Roman Polanski insisted that the forces of darkness were unbeatable. No one makes any difference, and Gittes' meddling probably only makes matters worse. Polanski, as Towne said, "saw the darkness at the end of the tunnel".

Night Moves (1975): Noir in the 70s was about deflating myths and puncturing film genres, and one of the most effective deflators was Arthur Penn. Here, the shamus (Gene Hackman) has a fatal flaw. He needs to know the facts, the answers. But Hackman can't save anyone, much less himself. His increasing frustration is the film's message: to search for the truth is futile.

Body Heat (1981): This is a film noir about a man who's seen too many films noirs, a dim Florida attorney who, in time-honoured noir tradition, gets trapped by a beautiful, mysterious woman into murdering her husband. Though the film clings almost too closely to the femme fatale's coat-tails, Lawrence Kasdan's steamy, sex-driven camera takes you back to the slinky, good old, bad old days.

Devil in a Blue Dress (1995): An underrated urban drama with a difference, a neo-noir about outsiders - African-Americans, non-fatal femmes and, most of all, its hero, Easy Rawlins, straddling the "color line" in late-40s LA. "Nervous?" asks the heroine. "Here I was in the middle of the night," says Easy, "in a white neighborhood with a white woman in my car. Naw, I wasn't nervous. I was stupid."

LA Confidential (1997): A high-low conspiracy writ large, Curtis Hanson's movie lacked the ruthless bite of James Ellroy's original novel. More a nostalgic homage than a searing rejuvenation of noir, but the film recognised how deep the tradition of police corruption runs in LA, and that made it as outrageous as today's headlines.

From page to screen

Out of the Past (1947): It was the little-known British pulp writer Frank Fenton who put some structural backbone into this adaptation of Daniel Mainwaring's flabby novel, Build My Gallows High. He rounded out the characters, made them believable and, after the comment "She can't be all bad - no one is", provided Robert Mitchum's punchline: "She comes the closest."

Kiss Me Deadly (1955): Robert Aldrich's film simultaneously exploits and ridicules Mickey Spillane's high-octane novel. Spillane's hero, Mike Hammer, still engages in his trademark roughhousing, but Aldrich lifts the earthbound Hammer into the ethereal with his final scene: Spillane's conventional black bag containing money from a drug deal becomes a Pandora's box - the bomb that defined the mid-50s blows up into a nuclear noir.

Point Blank (1967): The film that launched neo-noir is based on one of a series of novels written by Donald Westlake under the pen-name Richard Stark. The pulp writer said: "This is a rare instance of where the auteur theory works; John Boorman took a mediocre script and turned it into a terrific movie."

The Grifters (1990): In the late 80s, not a month seemed to go by without a screen adaptation of one of Jim Thompson's novels. But this sun-streaked, bleached noir was the only one worthy of the "dime-store Dostoyevsky". So how was the pulp-meister's work adapted and updated? "It was easy," says Donald Westlake. "I took their hats off."

Get Carter (1971): It was the way Mike Hodges brought Ted Lewis's novel Jack's Return Home to the screen that earned this film its cult status. Newcastle replaces nowhere specific in the book, Carter is toughened up - he no longer bites his nails - and, in spite of pressure from MGM, who wanted a sequel, and in contrast to the book, Carter dies - thus ensuring his immortality.

The bottom line

Fred MacMurray saying goodbye after meeting Barbara Stanwyck's sinuous siren in Double Indemnity: "Will you be here? Same chair, same perfume, same anklet?" "I wonder if I know what you mean." "I wonder if you wonder."

Bogart's Sam Spade to Mary Astor's femme fatale in The Maltese Falcon: "I won't play the sap for you. If I send you over, I'll be sorry as hell. I'll have some rotten nights - but that'll pass."

The private eye, Bradford Galt, at bay in The Dark Corner: "I'm backed up in a dark corner and I don't know who's hitting me."

Kathie, the devious dame in Out of the Past, appealing to Robert Mitchum: "I don't want to die." "Neither do I, baby - but if I have to, I'm going to die last."

A dying Richard Widmark to Cornell Wilde after he's been shot by Ida Lupino's torch singer in Road House: "I told you she was different."

John Garfield's Mob lawyer in Force of Evil: "I didn't have enough strength to resist corruption but I had enough strength to fight for a piece of it."

Marlene Dietrich greeting an oversized, padded-up, false-nosed Orson Welles in Touch of Evil: "You're a mess, honey. You've been eating too much candy."

A young Charles Bronson to his boss, after levelling his gun at an interfering woman in Crime Wave: "You want I should clip a curl off the cutie?"

Easy Rawlins in Devil in a Blue Dress: "When somebody tells me ain't nothing to worry about, I usually look down to see if my fly is open."

Roman Polanski's hood, poking a switchblade up Jack Nicholson's nostril in Chinatown: "You know what happens to nosy fellows? They lose their noses."

Kathleen Turner's femme fatale, Matty Walker, to Racine, the patsy in Body Heat: "You're not too smart, are you?" "No." "I like that in a man."

 Crime Scene 2000 runs at London's NFT from July 14-16. Details and booking: 020 7928 3232.

Though the film clings almost too closely to the femme fatale's coat-tails, Lawrence Kasdan's steamy, sex-driven camera takes you back to the slinky, good old, bad old days. Devil in a Blue Dress (1995): An underrated urban drama with a difference, a neo-noir about outsiders - African-Americans, non-fatal femmes and, most of all, its hero, Easy Rawlins, straddling the "color line" in late-40s LA. "Nervous?" asks the heroine. "Here I was in the middle of the night," says Easy, "in a white neighborhood with a white woman in my car. Naw, I wasn't nervous. I was stupid." LA Confidential (1997): A high-low conspiracy writ large, Curtis Hanson's movie lacked the ruthless bite of James Ellroy's original novel. More a nostalgic homage than a searing rejuvenation of noir, but the film recognised how deep the tradition of police corruption runs in LA, and that made it as outrageous as today's headlines. From page to screen Out of the Past (1947): It was the little-known British pulp writer Frank Fenton who put some structural backbone into this adaptation of Daniel Mainwaring's flabby novel, Build My Gallows High. He rounded out the characters, made them believable and, after the comment "She can't be all bad - no one is", provided Robert Mitchum's punchline: "She comes the closest." Kiss Me Deadly (1955): Robert Aldrich's film simultaneously exploits and ridicules Mickey Spillane's high-octane novel. Spillane's hero, Mike Hammer, still engages in his trademark roughhousing, but Aldrich lifts the earthbound Hammer into the ethereal with his final scene: Spillane's conventional black bag containing money from a drug deal becomes a Pandora's box - the bomb that defined the mid-50s blows up into a nuclear noir. Point Blank (1967): The film that launched neo-noir is based on one of a series of novels written by Donald Westlake under the pen-name Richard Stark. The pulp writer said: "This is a rare instance of where the auteur theory works; John Boorman took a mediocre script and turned it into a terrific movie." The Grifters (1990): In the late 80s, not a month seemed to go by without a screen adaptation of one of Jim Thompson's novels. But this sun-streaked, bleached noir was the only one worthy of the "dime-store Dostoyevsky". So how was the pulp-meister's work adapted and updated? "It was easy," says Donald Westlake. "I took their hats off." Get Carter (1971): It was the way Mike Hodges brought Ted Lewis's novel Jack's Return Home to the screen that earned this film its cult status. Newcastle replaces nowhere specific in the book, Carter is toughened up - he no longer bites his nails - and, in spite of pressure from MGM, who wanted a sequel, and in contrast to the book, Carter dies - thus ensuring his immortality. The bottom line Fred MacMurray saying goodbye after meeting Barbara Stanwyck's sinuous siren in Double Indemnity: "Will you be here? Same chair, same perfume, same anklet?" "I wonder if I know what you mean." "I wonder if you wonder." Bogart's Sam Spade to Mary Astor's femme fatale in The Maltese Falcon: "I won't play the sap for you. If I send you over, I'll be sorry as hell. I'll have some rotten nights - but that'll pass." The private eye, Bradford Galt, at bay in The Dark Corner: "I'm backed up in a dark corner and I don't know who's hitting me." Kathie, the devious dame in Out of the Past, appealing to Robert Mitchum: "I don't want to die." "Neither do I, baby - but if I have to, I'm going to die last." A dying Richard Widmark to Cornell Wilde after he's been shot by Ida Lupino's torch singer in Road House: "I told you she was different." John Garfield's Mob lawyer in Force of Evil: "I didn't have enough strength to resist corruption but I had enough strength to fight for a piece of it." Marlene Dietrich greeting an oversized, padded-up, false-nosed Orson Welles in Touch of Evil: "You're a mess, honey. You've been eating too much candy." A young Charles Bronson to his boss, after levelling his gun at an interfering woman in Crime Wave: "You want I should clip a curl off the cutie?" Easy Rawlins in Devil in a Blue Dress: "When somebody tells me ain't nothing to worry about, I usually look down to see if my fly is open." Roman Polanski's hood, poking a switchblade up Jack Nicholson's nostril in Chinatown: "You know what happens to nosy fellows? They lose their noses." Kathleen Turner's femme fatale, Matty Walker, to Racine, the patsy in Body Heat: "You're not too smart, are you?" "No." "I like that in a man."  Crime Scene 2000 runs at London's NFT from July 14-16. Details and booking: 020 7928 3232.
